In the name of God, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. Your pardon, O God. Praise be to God, who created human minds diverse, and made souls revolve around the point of contentment in their opinions, and adorned their deeds for them until they imagined they were among the current proverbs (al-amthal al-sa'irah). I praise Him for His blessings that clarified what was ambiguous and confused, and revealed the fire of guidance that could only be kindled by the fingers of taste, and trained the steed of criticism which, when it aims for a goal, does not turn its rein nor hold back. I bear witness that there is no god but God alone, with no partner, a testimony cooed by the dove of the tongue from certainty upon its arak tree, saving its speaker from falling into the snares and traps of polytheism, and serving as a treasure for him when his stillness follows his movement. I bear witness that Muhammad is our master and His servant, whom God protected from error in speech and action, and by whom He guarded the pasture of eloquence—were it not for him, the grazing land would have mixed with the neglected—and gave him concise speech such that the eye of wish did not aspire to it, nor did the hand of hope covet it. May God’s blessings be upon him and his family and companions, whom the black snakes feared and the lions dreaded; their actions were homogeneous, for there was none among them but who would roam and be generous, govern and lead. Their characters were innocent of defects, so there was no arrogant, haughty, or envious one among them—a prayer revealed by the lip of dawn smiling in the dark lips of the night, and veiled by the light of the full moon at the wedding of perfection. 

After this: The book 'Al-Mathal Al-Sa'ir' (The Current Proverb) by Al-Sahib Diya' al-Din ibn Athir al-Jazari—may God treat him with His kindness and forgive him for what the breezes of arrogance shook from the branch of his sympathy—is among the books whose leaves have fluttered in fame, and the pen strove in its service on its head as a servant strives on his leg. It became famous among the people of composition (Insha) as night is famous for concealment and day for revelation; nay, like the fame of the Banu Udhra in love for the burning of their entrails. The people of literature in the horizons became fond of it like the generous are fond of spending; nay, like the spies are fond of lovers. However, its author, may God have mercy on him, although he combined knowledge and action within it, and rhymed between the heavy and the ramal meters, and imagined that the full moon of his merit was complete and perfect, and imagined that the neck of composition after him was unadorned and his art obscure—he has removed his rare good deeds by the succession of his hasty bad deeds. He wasted those unique flowers in the wastelands of claims wherein the traveler finds no pleasure. The blackness of his night lingered over people after his crescent moon, and they rejected the sites of his dew because of the scum of his flood. Yes, for: 'The onyx is not worthy that a glance be repeated / upon it, nor that necks be turned towards it.' This is because he exhausted that expanse in self-admiration and flattery, and prolonged the belittling and disdain of his peers. He thought that God had forbidden eloquence to anyone coming after him, and that those before him were either a sheikh senile in his old age or a child playing in his cradle. He dragged the robe of pride and arrogance stitched with the needle of praise, and exaggerated in that like Abu Zubayd al-Ta'i's description of the lion. He described himself as Imru' al-Qais never described his horses, and praised it as Abu Nuwas never praised the dregs of his cup. He repeated this until souls were nauseated by that scum, and increased until anxiety mourned the garment of patience for what he lamented.

The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Beware of three things: Greed, for it expelled Adam from Paradise; Pride, for it brought Iblis down from his rank; and Envy, for it called the son of Adam to kill his brother.' And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Envy consumes good deeds as fire consumes wood.' It is said: It is the first sin by which God was disobeyed in heaven and earth. And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said, narrating from God Almighty: 'Pride is My cloak, so whoever disputes with Me regarding it, I will enter him into the Fire.' Ja'far bin Muhammad said: 'God knew that sin is better for the believer than vanity (ujb); were it not for that, no believer would be tested with a sin.' Some wise men said: 'The affliction for which a person is not rewarded is vanity, and the blessing for which one is not envied is humility.' And it was said: 'Nothing hides virtues more than haughtiness and vanity.'

This is in addition to the many slips in the book, choices that are neither successful nor sound, the support of falsehood, the adornment of the idle, the preferring of what is weak and flimsy, and the weakening of what is established and concluded. 'Disadvantages, if divided among beautiful women / they would not have been dowered except with divorce.' I used to stand upon its ruins when reviewing it calling out, and stumble upon its tails when reading it often, and sigh at the isolation of those pearls in the string of jet, and find the blackness of its nights long while the morning of its beauties neither shone nor dawned. I heard what Izz al-Din ibn Abi al-Hadid, may God have mercy on him, wrote about the book by way of critique, and that those grievances cried out to him for refuge. But when I stood upon 'Al-Falak Al-Da'ir' (The Revolving Sphere - Ibn Abi al-Hadid's critique), I found he had neglected much, taking a little and leaving the significant. So I loved after that to pick up what he left behind, and track its anomalies and rarities.

'And I must perform my prayer after / it has passed, if I did not perform it in its time.' Although coming after Ibn Abi al-Hadid, I am like one who came after the sweeping of a flood, and became a gatherer of wood at night after the fruit-picker of the day. For this man has works that indicate his mastery and knowledge, the correctness of his aims when extending his reach, and his hydration from the arts and his undertaking and burden-bearing of them. Among them are two commentaries on 'Al-Muhassal' and 'Al-Mahsoul' by Imam Fakhr al-Din, and a third commentary on 'Al-Arba'in' by Fakhr al-Din. He versified 'Fasih Tha'lab' excellently in a day and a night, and this 'Al-Falak Al-Da'ir' he attached in thirteen days alongside the duties of his Diwan (office). His brother Muwaffaq al-Din ibn Abi al-Hadid wrote to him when he wrote 'Al-Falak Al-Da'ir': 'The Current Proverb (Al-Mathal Al-Sa'ir), O my master / You have composed for it The Revolving Sphere (Al-Falak Al-Da'ir) / But this is a revolving sphere / In which you have become the current proverb.' He also wrote a commentary on 'Nahj al-Balagha' in sixteen volumes—and suffice it to say regarding one who addresses 'Nahj al-Balagha' and explains it, covering what relates to it from every science: principles (usul), jurisprudence (fiqh), Arabic language, history, biography of men, and other things. Whoever stands upon this explanation knows that few can enter that citadel with him or graze with him in such a pasture. It is enough that he critiqued Imam Fakhr al-Din and raised objections against him. I found verses by him beginning: 'By your right, if you entered me into the Fire I would say to / those in it, I was among those who loved Him / I spent my life in the intricacies of His sciences / and my desire was nothing but His satisfaction and nearness / Grant me a sinner whose ignorance ruined his forbearance / and whose sin destroyed him before creation / Does not the law of generosity require His pardon? / Is it proper that His passion and love be forgotten? / Did He not refute the deviation of Ibn al-Khatib and his doubt / and his falsification in religion when its matter became grave? / Did he not intend the truth in what he said? / Did not his books support Monotheism (Tawhid) and Justice (Adl)?'

So I said, responding to him in his meter and rhyme: 'We knew from this statement that you take / the view of Mu'tazilism, a matter grave in religion / You claim that God will not be seen in the Gathering / and that is a belief whose outcome will destroy you / You deny God's attributes, though they are eternal / and His books have affirmed them about your God / You believe the Quran is created and originated / and that is a disease whose cure is difficult among people / You affirm for the weak servant a will / by which that which his Lord did not decree comes to be / And things from these scandals are many / so which of you is the caller of misguidance and his party? / And who is the one who has become close to guidance / and protected the true religion with his defense? / Fakhr al-Din is not harmed by a statement you composed / containing excessive ugliness as you insult him / He was possessor of a light leading to guidance / when the meteors of his doubts rose in the darkness / If you gave the right of yourself its due / you would have extinguished an ember you kindle with impossibility / You are not among his peers on the day of battle / nor do you ever have a resemblance to the Imam.'

I copied from the handwriting of Hafiz al-Yaghmuri, who said: Imam Rukn al-Din Abu al-Qasim recited to me verses of his own regarding Izz al-Din ibn Abi al-Hadid when he wrote 'Al-Falak Al-Da'ir' against 'Al-Mathal Al-Sa'ir': 'He brought something cold and heavy / and did not inherit that from afar / He is, as you have known, a thing / the most famous of which was in iron (Hadid).' He also wrote a book refuting Ibn Abi al-Hadid and named it: 'Nashr al-Mathal al-Sa'ir wa Tayy al-Falak al-Da'ir' (Unfolding the Current Proverb and Folding the Revolving Sphere). I say: This Rukn al-Din Abu al-Qasim is Mahmud ibn al-Hussein ibn Imam Arshad al-Din, originally from Isfahan, born in Sinjar. He was a Hanafi who knew the school of thought, the two principles (usul), disagreement (khilaf), and literature. He read under Saif al-Amidi and Diya' al-Din ibn al-Athir. He abandoned the rag of the jurists and dressed in the attire of soldiers. He died in Damascus on the 6th of Ramadan, 650 AH, and was buried at the foot of Mount Qasioun. He was born in 592 AH. Regarding his transition to the military, he said verses including: 'Look, O brother of reason, at a profession / from which we fled to the clamor of war / If it were not the most unlucky thing in creation / we would not have been satisfied with swift death instead of it.' I was, at a time when I wrote about 'Al-Muhassal' by Imam Fakhr al-Din al-Razi, composed verses appropriate to mention here, which are: 'The science of Usul is victorious through Fakhr al-Din / by him we attack with wonder and miracle.'

'By him, the bright Sunnah became clear / established for the resident and the passerby / He has researches, how many doubts have they burned / with their meteors, so who is the critic of Al-Razi!' Our Sheikh, the Imam and Hafiz Athir al-Din Abu Hayyan Muhammad ibn Yusuf recited to me from his own words in the Egyptian lands in the year 728 AH, saying: Our Sheikh, the genealogist and Hafiz of the East and West, Sharaf al-Din Abu Muhammad Abd al-Mu'min ibn Khalaf ibn Abi al-Hasan al-Dimyati recited to us on Wednesday, the 15th of Jumada al-Akhira, 680 AH in Cairo, while I read to him, saying: The Sheikh, the Scholar, the Sahib Izz al-Din Abu Hamid Abd al-Hamid ibn Hibat Allah ibn Muhammad ibn Muhammad ibn Hussein ibn Abi al-Hadid the Mu'tazilite recited to us in Baghdad—his birth was in Al-Mada'in at the beginning of Dhu al-Hijjah 586 AH—of his own poetry: 'Were it not for three things, I would not fear my demise / they are not as the young man of Al-Abd (Tarafa) said / That I support Tawhid and Justice in / every place, exerting my effort / And that I converse with God, enjoying / a solitude sweeter than honey / And that I walk through time with pride against / every mean person, turning my cheek in disdain / For that reason, I desire neither a young girl / nor wine, nor one of youthful bosom.' Ibn Abi al-Hadid's saying here: 'Were it not for three...' is a reference to the saying of Tarafa bin al-Abd: 'Were it not for three things which are the pleasure of a youth / by your grandfather, I would not care when my visitors rose / Among them is my outstripping the scolding women with a drink / of dark wine which, when mixed with water, foams / And my charging, when the distressed calls out, leaning / like the wolf of the thicket, whom I alerted, coming to water / And shortening the cloudy day, and the cloudy day is delightful / with a buxom woman under the pole-supported tent.'

From the poetry of Ibn Abi al-Hadid is a poem ending in 'B' (Ba'iyya) among his praises for Ali bin Abi Talib, may God be pleased with him: 'Verily, the path of glory is clearly marked / though it has many paths and is dreaded / It is the refined honey gathered by a man / who sought it, while the tips of spears are the queen bees / Taste death if you wish for highness, and feed on destruction / for the attainment of wishes is earned by death / Wade through death, you will be safe from the plan of humiliation, for / the blaze of the matter reveals itself while the matter is ignited / Did the news not inform about the conquest of Khaybar / for in it are wonders for the one of intellect who responds / And the victory of Ali in highness is its victory through him / for each is added and attributed to the other / Fortresses guarding the gap where they displayed themselves / and not every mountable beast is ridden / Necklaces of stars are hung upon them / and showers of clouds fall below them.' From it: 'And a reckless army, waving the rein, he scatters it / so neither dragging of a train nor breastplate availed it / For the matter has distractors regarding it and changes / just as there was a turning away regarding it for calamities.' From it: 'A day of swords in the darkness of a dusty night / so there is a bright white and a pitch black / Joshua mourns over them with the wailing of Qarun / and Jacob sheds the tears of Joseph over them / In it are thunderbolts from the roaring of men / and downpours from the pouring of surging blood.' From it: 'His sword and spear eject death / and his scabbard and the spear-shafts kindle fire.'

And among his praises for Ali bin Abi Talib, may God be pleased with him, is a poem beginning: 'The toothpick talks about her saliva / fragrantly, so did the Arak tree see you? / And for her glance, the coward acts feminine, but if she gazes / with a look, she is the lethal lion / Nets of hearts, and I did not think before her / that hearts are hunted by traps.' From it: 'O she whose polished face is the water of his youth / what is death were it not for your lethal glance? / Or did the story of her standing in the forenoon reach you / while our hearts were pierced by the tips of separation? / Nothing is sharper than the separation of loved ones or / the sword of the Wasi (Successor - Ali), both are shedders of blood.'

These two poems are long; I abbreviated what I abbreviated from them, and limited myself to what I limited myself to, seeking to indicate his merit, and the sharpness of his spearhead and blade. But his abundant materials led him to withdraw (to Mu'tazilism) and become a Shi'a, and he neglected the side of the Sunnah and wasted it. He has prose in which he excelled with some of his quality, but it was not like his poetry which raised his hill and consolidated his mountain. He cited some of it in 'Al-Falak Al-Da'ir', but the prose of Ibn al-Athir is more grounded than his in the view of those with insight; had he deleted it, it would have been better than affirming it, and more protective for him against the testing of his arrow and the pressing of his spear. So with what feathers can one coming after this speaker rise? And what sword can cut like his cutting when it is notched? The Mu'tazila are knights of research, and among those for whom determination for debate is abundant and motives and incentives obey it. But: 'A young man may attain glory while his clothing / is worn out and the pocket of his shirt is patched.' The first left for the last more than what he brought, and minds varied in criticizing the wild cows of beauty and its buxom maidens, and the cloud of intellect followed when it cleared with the downpour of its clouds. 'The mother of generosity did not become barren after Hatim / she has a newborn every day among creation.'

I have collected what I stumbled upon of Ibn al-Athir's slips in these papers, and pitched this tent over them and extended these curtains. I listed them in order, and drove them according to that arrangement. I named it 'Nasrat al-Thaa'ir 'ala al-Mathal al-Sa'ir' (Aid/Victory of the Avenger against the Current Proverb). I chose this name for it as a sign and a signal, because the 'Thaa'ir' (Avenger) in language is the one who does not spare anything until he takes his revenge. And if I discuss with him a research he presented, or compete with him in a good thing he spoiled, I hardly leave that place empty of the beauties of the masters of this art whom he criticized, and whose stations of blame he frequented and visited. Especially Al-Qadi Al-Fadil, may God Almighty have mercy on him. For he opposed him in some of what he composed, and criticized what he adorned and embellished. 'Suha said to the sun: You are hidden / And the darkness said: O morning, your color is changing.' The sword is famous without a baldric, and the morning is witnessed without evidence. And where are the intents of Al-Fadil and the distance of his aim, and his snatching of meanings with the subtlety of his intent and the hidden nature of his path? Far from it, for between them is the difference between the humiliation of the foot and the glory of the parting of the hair. The subtlety of that is not hidden from the taste of the skilled writer, and the beauty of his meanings inwardly is double his words outwardly. How excellent is Ibn Sana' al-Mulk when he says, although most of his Diwan is about him: 'The perfect ones bore witness of merit to Al-Fadil / or the newborn almost bore witness / Time promised to be generous to creation / but with his like, it does not be generous.' And Ibn Qalaqis when he says also about him among verses: 'He intoxicated us with a statement that lasted until / we wondered how he warned us against wine / Meanings that eloquent ones sit back from / and their thoughts hear them standing / Orphans that give charity in his highness / the saying of one who called him the Father of Orphans.' As for Ibn al-Sa'ati, he praised him frequently. Of that: 'There is none who compares a creature to his likeness / except like one who compared the lowlands to the peaks / If he advances in highness boasting / Simak (Arcturus) knows his place and steps back.' People addressed Ibn al-Athir because he was a contradictor of Al-Fadil, and he was shot by their tongues and pens with the slashing of debate swords and the shooting of struggle arrows. 'So do not panic at a sunnah (way) you walked / for the first to accept a sunnah is the one who walks it.' This is not the place to praise Al-Qadi Al-Fadil, and you will stand upon it, and the whiffs of his perfume will guide you when you reach him. From here, I strip the forearm of critique, and sharpen the arrows that I think are penetrating the target. And upon God is the intent of the path; He is my sufficiency and the best disposer of affairs.

**Starting with the Hamdala (Praise of God)**
Ibn al-Athir, may God forgive him, said: 'We ask God to make us reach of praise what He is worthy of, and to teach us of expression (Bayan) that which the merit of speech and its virtue fall short of, and the wisdom of address and its decision.'

I say: The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Every speech that does not begin with the praise of God (Hamd) is cut off (ajdham).' If he had said: 'Al-Hamdu lillah' (Praise be to God), it would have been better. Perhaps Al-Zamakhshari was criticized for this at the beginning of 'Al-Mufassal' for saying: 'Allah I praise' (Allaha Ahmad), and Al-Hariri for saying: 'O God, we praise You' (Allahumma inna nahmaduk), because they did not open their speech with 'Al-Hamd'. It is most appropriate to adopt what came from God Almighty, for there is no station for the servant more noble than prayer because it is worship. Even the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'The closest a servant is to his Lord is when he is prostrating.' Al-Fatiha, which is the Mother of the Book and the pillar in prayer, opened with 'In the name of God, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful, Praise be to God, Lord of the Worlds.' Sahl bin Harun said: 'It is a right upon every person with a statement to begin it with the praise of God before opening it, just as grace began before entitlement.' Ibn al-Athir, may God Almighty have mercy on him, used that in the signing of his books, saying: 'Every speech that does not begin with the praise of God is cut off.' Ibn Abi al-Hadid raised an objection against Ibn al-Athir regarding this rhymed prose (saj') which is sufficient, so let that be taken from 'Al-Falak Al-Da'ir'.

As for the second rhyme, I do not know the meaning of his saying 'that which the merit of speech falls short of.' What is it that He teaches him such that the merit of speech falls short of it? If he meant by that the subtlety of meanings which are the souls of words, then when has speech fallen short of a meaning that the soul did not bring forth completely? And if he meant by that the things that are upon the structures of words regarding beauty and splendor, that is other than 'Bayan' (expression/clarification), because Bayan is the clarification of meanings and their display and manifestation. That which you intended of beauty and subtlety which exist in some speech, that is other than Bayan. It is like charm (malaha) for which no meaning is understood nor expressed. As it was said: 'A thing by which creation is tempted, other than what / is called beauty, and I do not know what it is.' And it is said: 'With the beloved is something else other than his beauty which intercedes for him to hearts.' Do you not see that some forms, whose individual limbs are the ultimate in beauty, do not have that meaning which belongs to others? Likewise, it was said about the antidote (tiryaq), that after composition God pours upon it a property that was not in the power of its parts in the state of singularity. The collective form has a meaning other than the state that belongs to its individuals. There is no doubt that the speech of the eloquent in the state of composition has properties for which that beauty found in it cannot be expressed. Therefore, jurists gave a fatwa regarding one who changes the order of Al-Fatiha, and flips some verses to the place of others, that his prayer is not valid, because he invalidates the miracle of the Great Quran, which is its context on this strange pattern, and its composition on this wondrous system. Here is a research between the Ash'ari and the Mu'tazili which I skipped seeking brevity. If Ibn al-Athir asked for this special property, then this special property is not called 'Bayan'. And if the matter is so, it is proven that the meaning of this rhyme is not understood. Ibn Abi al-Hadid discussed with him his saying 'speech' (Nutq) and what he intended by it, so let it be taken from his book.

He said: 'And upon his family and companions, among whom are those who preceded and hastened, and among whom are those who persevered and were patient, and among whom are those who sheltered and supported.' I say: If he had said: 'And among whom are those who emigrated (hajar) and supported (nasar)', it would have been better from two aspects: First, he would achieve balance and inlaying (tarsi') between 'hajar' (emigrated) and 'sabar' (was patient/persevered) [Note: likely referring to rhyming with 'nasar']. Second, it would cover the Muhajirun and Ansar from the Companions, may God be pleased with them, for they are prioritized over the Ansar, and in his saying there is no mention of the Muhajirun, for among the Ansar are those who preceded others to faith. If it is said: His saying 'sabar' (was patient) and 'sabara' (persevered) have the same meaning, I say: Follow the wording of the Quran in His Almighty's saying: 'O you who have believed, be patient and persevere (sabiru wa sabiru).' For patience (sabr) is other than perseverance (musabara), because musabara is a mutual action, which is meeting the action of the other with the like. It is as if that is an increase over the patience that a human can bear.

**Al-Hariri's inability to compose what was asked of him in the Diwan**
He said: He mentioned Al-Hariri of the Maqamat, may God Almighty have mercy on him, and that such a book issued from him, but when he was asked to write in the Diwan (official correspondence office), he was silenced. He cited the famous story. Then he said: 'This is something to wonder at, and I was asked about this so I said: No wonder, because the Maqamat all revolve around a story that exits to a conclusion, but correspondence (mukatabat) is a sea with no shore, because meanings in it renew with the renewal of the accidents of days, and they are renewing by the number of breaths. Do you not see that if an eloquent writer writes about a vast state whose sultan has a famous sword and mentioned endeavor, and stays on that for a short period not reaching ten years, he records from correspondence what exceeds ten parts, each part of which is larger than the Maqamat in volume, then if sifted, half of it comes out pure.'

I say: As for people's wonder at the incident of Al-Hariri, it is a place of wonder at first glance. Because for someone from whom issued such a book which has no peer in its field—and in literature it is: 'The sun of its forenoon, the crescent of its night / the pearls of its necklaces, the chrysolite of its jewelry'—to then pause at a letter requested from him, that is strange. But if a human thinks, and knows that composition (Insha) is a matter of openings (futuh) upon a human, it would not be strange. For God Almighty may open with that at a time and not another. Sheikh Muhyiddin ibn Arabi counted poetry and good writing among the 'openings' (futuh), and people remain so, sometimes it opens for them and sometimes it does not open. Al-Hariri at that time was not opened upon. Furthermore, Al-Hariri at the time of making the Maqamat was in his house, alone with himself, molding, breaking, demolishing, and building; if a station repelled him he turned to another, and if a meaning held back from him he left it and pulled what was smoother in leadership than it. It was mentioned that the drafts of the Maqamat were a camel's load. That is a matter different from his sitting in the Diwan and his first arrival, while he is among a group of masters of the art, and a meaning is proposed to him from which he has no escape, nor room in its narrowness, nor salvation from its slip, and he had not prepared for it; inevitably he was silenced, paused, and plucked his beard. 'A man is not blamed for the cowardice of his day / if his bravery was known yesterday.' Perhaps Ibn al-Athir forgave him in what he cited of his words in 'Al-Mathal' and 'Al-Washy Al-Marqum' and 'Al-Ma'ani Al-Mubtada'a' and other attributions of the Maqamat. For he narrated about himself in 'Al-Mathal Al-Sa'ir' that he used to recite the Great Quran, and if a noble verse passed him and he glimpsed a meaning in it suitable to be in such-and-such, he built a book or a chapter upon it and established it. Or as he said. And most of what he established is but oppositions by which he opposed the books of Al-Qadi Al-Fadil and Abu Ishaq al-Sabi, and this is of the nature of making Maqamat while he is in his house reviewing what he makes, reflecting, erasing, and establishing. 'They imagined play to be war, and stabbing in the / battle to be other than stabbing in the hippodrome.'

As for his saying: That the writer produces in the period he mentioned ten parts, each part larger in volume than the Maqamat, and if sifted and revised they would be five, this is partisanship and a claim upon which no proof stands, or ignorance reaching the limit. What correspondence of a writer whose era preceded and until now has had a single volume collected for him like the Maqamat, circulated by people, drinking its cups, quoting its verses and rhymes, repeating it from its beginning to its end, searching for its defects, and digging for its evils, yet finding no flaw in it, nor locating a point of attack? Rather, it clarifies upon smelting, and improves upon usage. 'The passing of nights increases it in newness / and the aging of days in beauty of youth.' Although Ibn al-Khashab replied to it regarding slight words, and Al-Mas'udi answered him about them, Ibn al-Khashab was correct in the little of the little, and obstinate in much of the little. Similarly, Ibn Barri placed slight notes upon it. Suffice it for you a book that became famous, became a proverb, became one of the supports (athafi) in the science of literature, its words and meanings became proof, and copies were transferred by the number of its letters. 'It traveled the path of the sun in every place / and blew the blowing of the wind in land and sea.' I have not seen nor heard of anyone who took a part of correspondence, read it to a sheikh, memorized it, sought narration by it, and attached comments of language, parsing, and meanings to it. People have written extensive commentaries on the Maqamat, like Al-Mas'udi who has two commentaries on them, Al-Mutarriz, Ibn al-Anbari, Abu al-Baqa, and others. I have even seen some claim they are symbols in alchemy, and it is told that the Franks read them to their kings in their language, illustrate them, and narrate their stories to one another. This is only because this book, one of its manifestations is those funny stories and incidents which, if a human starts to stand upon them, his soul aspires to what they end in, and yearns to know the end of that story. This is in addition to the wisdom and proverbs contained therein which resemble the book Kalila wa Dimna, and the types of literature and its various arts and diverse styles. Sheikh Fath al-Din Muhammad ibn Sayyid al-Nas told me on the authority of his father Abu Amr on the authority of his father Abu Bakr, saying: We said to Ibn Amira, the writer of Andalusia: Why do you not make something like the Maqamat? He said: As for the words, I am not overcome regarding them, but those lies which he tells, I do not know how to put the like of them.

I heard Judge Shihab al-Din Mahmud, may God Almighty have mercy on him, while this book was being read to him, narrating that Al-Qadi Al-Fadil, may God Almighty have mercy on him, wanted to oppose them (the Maqamat), and he composed thirteen maqamat opposing each chapter with its like until he came to Al-Hariri's saying in the fourteenth Maqamah: 'Know, O refuge of the hopeful and support of the widows, that I am from the elites of the tribes, and the noble ladies. My family and my husband ceased not to occupy the chest (front), and march in the heart (center), and mount the back (beasts), and bestow the hand (generosity). But when time destroyed the upper arms (helpers), and bereaved the bodies of the limbs, and the back of the belly was overturned, the onlooker turned away, the eyebrow was harsh, the eye went (blind/lost), the palm was lost (poverty), the fire-stick failed to spark, the right hand weakened, and the elbows were separated, and there remained for us neither a central incisor nor a canine. Since the green life turned dusty, and the yellow beloved (gold) turned away, my white day turned black, and my black hair turned white, until the blue enemy pitied me, so welcome to the red death.' Al-Fadil said: From where does a human bring a chapter to oppose this? Then he cut what he had done of the Maqamat and it did not appear. Or as he said. Suffice it for you that someone like Al-Qadi Al-Fadil says such a thing about him, and confesses inability to him. As for me, whenever I read this chapter and mention it, I find a euphoria like the euphoria of wine, and a joy—no joy of the night traveler at the appearance of the morning. In what correspondence do you find the peer of this chapter which has this lightness and grace, and rhymes did not disturb it? The Maqamat have been wronged by whoever placed them in the category of correspondence; correspondence is a part of them. Rather, it is a book of knowledge in its field, and the rhetoric of the man is known from his mentioning of a thing in most of his Maqamat with praise and blame. This is rhetoric: that you describe a thing then blame it, or blame it then praise it, as he did in the Maqamah of the Dinar, and the one in which he differentiated between the writing of composition and calculation, and the one in which he mentioned the virgin and the matron, marriage and celibacy, and other things. His eloquence is known from his taking current proverbs and joining them to a rhyme better than them. Like his saying: 'You gave the bow to its shaper and settled the house with its builder.' And his saying: 'She escaped, a shell from a chick, and became innocent as the wolf was innocent of the blood of Jacob's son.' And his saying: 'Was our promise lost like the promise of Urqub, or did a need remain in the soul of Jacob?' And: 'When his ray indicated his sun, and his address betrayed the secret of his scroll.' And: 'So I remained more confused than a lizard and more stunned than a lover.' And: 'Thinner than a pen and drier than a stone.' And: 'If there was a strap in my stick and a rain in my cloud.' And: 'I folded it on its fold, and protected its mouth from its cold.' And: 'You are the two Farqad stars of a sky and like two fire-sticks in a container.' And his saying: 'So that it be known that his wind met a tornado and his stream encountered a torrent.' And: 'A desire with no welcome and a drink that has no sweetness left for me.' And: 'Ability is the visit of a phantom, and opportunity is a summer cloud.' And: 'Farther than returning yesterday that has passed, and the dead that is gone.' And: 'How long is your rope and how terrible is your trick.' And: 'It was a day longer than the shadow of a spear, and hotter than the tear of a bereft mother.' And: 'So he began to sting and shout, and behave impudently and not feel shy.' And: 'Where is the crawling place of your youth (boyhood), and from where is the blowing place of your east wind?' And: 'I found so I envied, and found noble so I bound.' And: 'Not gone from your wealth is what admonished you, nor committed a crime against you he who awakened you.' And: 'You hovered over a tearful well, and exposed yourself to an empty cell.' And: 'Not every black woman is a date, nor every red one wine.' And: 'Like one who seeks the eggs of the Anuq bird, and seeks flight from she-camels.' And: 'Do you teach your mother copulation and your wet nurse breastfeeding?' And: 'When we saw their fire was a glow-worm, and their news was like the mirage of wastelands.' And: 'I am more obedient than your shoes, and more agreeable than your nourishment.' There is much of this type in it which I skipped for fear of elongation. 'I did not reach the limit in broadcasting his beauties / except that what I leave is more than what I said.'

**The Culture of the Writer**
He said: If God installs in a human a nature capable of this, he requires eight types of tools, then he listed them.

I say: The writer needs to memorize the Dear Book (Quran) and persist in reciting it, so that it circulates on his tongue, runs in his thought, represented before the eyes of his memory so he may spend from its abundance. And [he needs] knowledge of language and grammar and persistence in parsing (I'rab) night and day, until that becomes a good faculty for him. And morphology, meanings (Ma'ani), expression (Bayan), embellishment (Badi'), prosody, rhyme, and royal rulings as he mentioned in his book. And some exegesis (Tafsir), and some Hadiths like the book 'Al-Shihab' or 'Al-Najm' by Al-Aqlishi, and the traditions transmitted from the Companions, may God be pleased with them, and what passed between the Rightly Guided Caliphs and their governors, and what passed between Ali and Muawiyah, may God be pleased with them both, of dialogues. And the signatures (tawaqi') of Caliphs, Viziers, and Writers, and Arab proverbs. And memorizing a good portion of Arab poetry, the Mukhadramin, the Moderns (Muwalladin), and the stallions of the latecomers. And memorizing well 'Al-Hamasa' and selections of 'Al-Mufaddaliyat', and some poems of 'Muntaha al-Talab' collected by Ibn Maimun. And what is possible of history, biography of men, and calculation. And reviewing the mother books of literature, such as 'Al-Aghani', 'Al-Iqd', 'Al-Bayan wa al-Tabyin', 'Al-Dhakhira', 'Zahr al-Adab', 'Amali al-Qali', 'Al-Kamil' by Al-Mubarrad, and 'Tadhkirat Ibn Hamdun'. And memorizing a good portion of the Maqamat and the Nubatian Sermons (Khutab al-Nubatiyya), and some poetry of Al-Mutanabbi, Abu Tammam, Al-Buhturi, 'Saqt al-Zand' and others. I have selected from the poetry of these four poets in a small volume. And standing upon the correspondence of writers and observing what they intended in every art: of congratulations, condolences, conquests, testaments, their traditions, signatures, commands, and prohibitions therein, and the openings of their supplications in all the branching paths of writing, and the method of beginnings and replies in gifts, intercessions, descriptions, letters of brethren, and what follows this course. This is a door whose shutter is not closed, and consensus is not tied upon its limitation. In summary, the writer needs everything; were it not that verifying every art is not binding on him, I would have said he is the one who knows existence as it is. But far from it. Yes, people vary in that and they are on levels: some have climbed the degrees, and some have not risen from the depths, and what is between that. Participation is necessary whenever possible, even if it is knowledge of the terminology of every art owner. If he completes his materials or approaches completion, then knowing the terminology of the Diwan in correspondence regarding titles, attributes, and what follows this course. For knowing this with practice, he conceptualizes and knows it in less than a week, and it is something whose rule is not established, because it differs with the difference of every time and its people. This is of no account, for it is the easiest thing he knows.

**Does violating grammar harm the meaning?**
He said, mentioning grammar: If we look at its types and divisions, we find most of it is not needed for understanding meanings. Do you not see that if you ordered a man to stand and said: 'Qawm' (Stand!) confirming the Waw and not making it jussive (omitting the middle vowel), nothing of the understanding of that would be disturbed. Similarly, the conditional and all adjuncts follow this course, like the circumstantial accusative (Hal), specification (Tamyiz), and exception. He cited things of these types.

I say: Only common people, those not clothed in knowledge, and those who have not smelled the scent of science would bring up such a thing. Does he not know that if a letter issues from a correspondent who does not make his imperative verbs jussive, nor his conditions and their answers, and does not put his subject in the nominative and his adjuncts in the accusative, nor observes any of his grammar rules which are apparent, nor maintains anything of parsing (I'rab) at all, it would be a laughingstock for the simple-minded, let alone the wise? In that case, scholars and ignoramuses would be equal. Umar, may God be pleased with him, wrote to Abu Musa al-Ash'ari: 'After this, understand the Sunnah and learn Arabic.' Abdullah bin Umar, may God be pleased with them both, used to beat his child for solecism (Lah'n). Abdul Malik said: 'Solecism in speech is uglier than the marks of smallpox on the face.' Abu al-Aswad al-Du'ali saw sacks of merchants written upon them 'Li-Abu Fulan' (For Abu So-and-so - grammatical error). He said: 'Glory be to God, they commit solecism and profit.' It is said: 'Whoever loves to find pride in himself, let him learn Arabic.' Does he not know that some have deduced that Grammar is a communal obligation (Fard Kifaya), if not said to be an individual obligation, and some went so far as to say God does not accept supplication if it is not parsed correctly? Sheikh Taqi al-Din ibn al-Salah said: 'I fear for the one who engages in Hadith and does not know Grammar, that he enters into his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: Whoever lies about me intentionally, let him take his seat in the Fire.' Then he excepted things from that which are not known except by parsing. So I say: One cannot reach the knowledge of the obscure except after knowing the clear, and whoever does not know the evident will not know the intricate, to move in understanding from the lower to the higher.

Al-Khalil bin Ahmad, may God have mercy on him, said: 'No one reaches from Grammar what he needs except by learning what he does not need.' Abu Amr said: 'If what is needed cannot be reached except by what is not needed, then what is not needed has become needed.' Every science is of this status; it contains the clear and the obscure. In Jurisprudence (Fiqh), its obscure issues in menstruation, dry ablution (Tayammum), inheritance shares, and what is in algebra and comparison, and circular reasoning issues in divorce and other things. And as in Logic, its obscurities in syllogisms, mixed modalities, and fallacies and other things. And as in Theology (Kalam) regarding confirming the indivisible atom (Jawhar Fard), and that an accident ('arad) does not remain for two moments, and that the non-existent is not a thing. A human does not reach the knowledge of these intricate issues except after premises he understands from the clear issues. I have not seen anyone bring up such a thing except the common people, or one who is ignorant of this art.

**Does Solecism (Lah'n) detract from the beauty of speech?**
He said, after citing some poetry of Abu Nuwas, Abu Tammam, and Abu al-Tayyib and their solecisms: 'Solecism was not a detractor from the beauty of speech.'
I say: Nothing remains after this but for him to say: 'Observance of parsing (I'rab) is a cause necessitating the ugliness of speech.' Does he not see that he did not hear their saying: 'Grammar in speech is like salt in food.' Some have gone to say that 'I'rab' (parsing/making clear) was named I'rab because the Arabs in His Almighty's saying: 'Uruban atraba' (loving, equal in age) are those who endear themselves to their husbands, so it is as if the one who parses his speech endears himself to his addressee. I say: The meaning of his endearing is that he mentions signs indicating his meanings. For if he wants to express wonder, he says: 'Ma ahsana Zaydan' (How beautiful Zayd is!), and if he left parsing and said: 'Ma ahsan Zayd' silencing the Nun and Dal, understanding would be confused for the addressee and he would remain in bewilderment: Is he asking, wondering, or informing? When he put the Nun in the accusative (fatha) and the Dal [of Ahsan], it was known he is wondering. If he said: 'Ma ahsanu Zaydin' raising the Nun (damma) and genitizing the Dal (kasra), it was known he is asking. And if he said 'Ma ahsana Zaydu' putting Nun in accusative and raising Dal, it was known he is informing by negating charity from him. When the speaker relieves the one he addresses from thought and bewilderment by parsing, he has endeared himself to him. And it has been said... 'There is no worth for the solecist even if his crown reached the clouds of the sky.' As for me, I do not deny that the subtlety of composition and ease of speech is another matter beyond Grammar. This is known, but the dispute is in his arbitrariness and obstinacy.

**Regarding the color of the Cow in the Verse: 'Yellow, bright in color'**
He said: Some jurists negotiated with me regarding His Almighty's saying in Surat Al-Baqarah: 'Yellow, bright in its color' (Safra'u faqi'un lawnuha), that the color of the cow was black. He began to criticize that and argue that the color is yellow. I say: It is known that the more likely view is that the color was yellow, because it is emphasized by 'faqi' (bright/intense). Just as black is emphasized by 'halik' and 'hanik', white by 'yaqiq' and 'lahiq', red by 'qani' and 'dharihi', green by 'nadir' and 'midham', yellow by 'nasi' and 'faqi' and 'waris', blue by 'khutbani', and ash-grey by 'radhani'. However, if exegesis arrives and transmission is established regarding something, it is not possible other than accepting it and acting by it in its place without exceeding that place with it. This is if it opposes a rule; if it can be preferred, it is preferred, just as some preferred this by His Almighty's saying: 'It throws sparks like the huge castle, as if they were yellow camels (jamalat sufr).' Meaning black camels tending towards yellowness. They said: And fire is black and dark.

**Etiquette in speaking about the Greats**
He said when mentioning the incidents of the Arabs: And among that is what was reported about Umar bin Al-Khattab, that he summoned Abu Musa al-Ash'ari and those under him of governors. Among them was Al-Rabi' bin Ziyad al-Harithi. He went to Yarfa', the freedman of Umar, and asked him what promotes one with him and sells well to him. He indicated roughness of living. So he went and wore a wool cloak and a dark turban and double-layered boots and attended before him among the governors. Umar looked him up and down, and his gaze fell only on him. He brought him close and asked about his condition, then advised Abu Musa al-Ash'ari regarding him. Then Ibn al-Athir said: 'I have used this in an investiture (taqlid) for some kings from the Diwan of the Caliphate, so I said: And if you seek help in your work from anyone, then set up observations upon him, and do not be satisfied with what you knew of the beginning of his condition, for conditions change like the changing of bodies. And beware of being deceived by the righteousness of the appearance as Umar bin Al-Khattab was deceived by Al-Rabi' bin Ziyad.'

I say: His saying 'as Umar was deceived' contains bad etiquette towards Umar, may God be pleased with him, by attributing deception to him. In this, there is a doubt for the owner of the investiture, for he will say to himself: 'If someone like Umar was deceived, what is my thought of myself?' so negligence will occur from him. Politeness in such a case is better, and pushing deception away from him is more appropriate. Do you not see His Almighty's saying narrating from Joseph, peace be upon him: 'After Satan induced dissension between me and my brothers,' attributing what happened between them to Satan out of politeness towards his brothers, peace be upon them. If someone like Umar bin Al-Khattab, may God be pleased with him, was deceived despite his caution and strictness in religion, what is thought of others? Al-Mughira bin Shu'ba said: 'I have not seen anyone more resolute than Umar. By God, he had merit that prevented him from panicking, and intellect that prevented him from being deceived.' Abu Bakr al-Khara'iti said: 'May God have mercy on Umar, how insightful he was by the light of God regarding God, and how physiognomic. By God, he was as the poet said: Insightful into the consequences of matters by his opinion / as if he has in today an eye towards tomorrow.' It is reported about Abu al-Abbas Ahmad bin Abdullah bin al-Hutay'ah that he used to say: 'The happiness of Islam was folded in the shroud of Umar bin Al-Khattab.' How excellent is the poet's saying: 'My arguments against you when alone are many / but when present, I am defeated / I cannot say you wronged me / God knows that I am wronged.' Look at the politeness of this poet and his kindness with his beloved and his reverence for him. It would have been better if he had said: 'And if you seek help in your work from anyone, do not trust from him the shine of a mirage, and uncover with the hand of your observation the veil of his biography, and be alert to his affairs, so do not be satisfied with the populated exterior and forget the ruined interior, and imagine from his cunning what Al-Rabi' bin Ziyad used as a ruse against Umar bin Al-Khattab.' For attributing the ruse to Al-Rabi' is better in etiquette than attributing deception to Umar, may God be pleased with him.

**Denial of taking the title 'Al-Nasir' for Sultan Saladin**
He said: I found a letter by Ibn Ziyadah al-Baghdadi written to King Al-Nasir Saladin including matters disapproved of him by the Diwan of the Caliphate. Among them is that he took the title 'Al-Nasir' (The Victor/Helper), and that is the title of the Commander of the Faithful. Then Ibn al-Athir assessed the letter and said: 'I did not find a defect in it except in this chapter which contains the discussion of the title, for he did not bring speech fitting the rest of the mentioned chapters, but brought speech containing badness, like his saying: What the master deems good is forbidden for the slave, and things of this pattern.' Then Ibn al-Athir, may God have mercy on him, mentioned what he composed regarding this meaning for himself, saying: 'It is known that Prophets and Caliphs have characteristics they are exclusive to by rule of singularity, and no one of the people has the right to share with them in it the sharing of peers. The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, conducted that in things he stipulated by his ruling, among them that he forbade others to combine his Kunya and his Name, and this is a justification for the Commander of the Faithful to be exclusive in a matter by which he is famous and for others forbidden.' He cited the rest of the rhyme, and there is no cream in it, so I established it.

I say: Before wading in with him, I present the difference between the Name (Ism), the Kunya, and the Title (Laqab). That is, the proper noun indicating a specific person, if it begins with 'Abu' like Abu Bakr and Abu Hafs, or with 'Umm' like Umm Kulthum, Umm al-Banin, and Umm al-Mu'minin, it is the Kunya. If it implies elevation of the named one like Ma' al-Sama' (Water of the Sky), Dhu Ru'ayn, Dhu al-Nurayn, Dhat al-Nitaqayn, and Dhu al-Janahayn—and included in this are the titles of the Umayyad and Abbasid Caliphs like Al-Hadi, Al-Mahdi, Al-Rashid, Al-Amin, and Al-Ma'mun, and included is the terminology of people like Shams al-Din, Badr al-Din, Najm al-Din and other titles of the People of the Book like Shams al-Dawla and Taj al-Mulk—or implies lowliness of the named one like Quffa, Batta, Al-Uqayshir, and Al-Ahwas, then this is the Title (Laqab). If it is for indication of the essence of the named one and his specification, like Zayd, Amr, Bakr, and Khalid, this is the Name (Ism). Once this is established, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Do not combine my name and my kunya.' His meaning is that no one of his nation should be called Muhammad Abu al-Qasim. As for Al-Nasir, Al-Adid, Al-Qadir, Al-Mustansir and the like, this is neither a kunya nor a name according to what is established. Furthermore, jurists differed on using the kunya Abu al-Qasim on three schools of thought: Al-Shafi'i, may God have mercy on him, and those who agreed with him held that it is not lawful for anyone to use it as a kunya whether his name is Muhammad or otherwise. Malik, may God have mercy on him, held that it is permissible to use it as a kunya for one whose name is Muhammad and for others. Some held that it is permissible for one whose name is not Muhammad and not permissible for one whose name is Muhammad. Al-Rafi'i said: 'This third view seems to be more correct, because people have not ceased using it as a kunya in all ages without denial.'

Sheikh Muhyiddin al-Nawawi, may God have mercy on him, said: 'And what the owner of this school said contains opposition to the apparent meaning of the Hadith. As for the consensus of people on doing it, while among those using it as a kunya are prominent Imams and people of influence (Ahl al-Hall wa al-Aqd) who are followed in religion, this contains strengthening for Malik's school, may God have mercy on him, regarding its absolute permissibility. They would have understood the prohibition as specific to his lifetime, peace and blessings be upon him, due to the famous reason for the prohibition regarding the Jews using the kunya Abu al-Qasim and calling out 'O Abu al-Qasim' seeking to annoy. This meaning has ceased.' End quote. I say: Among those who used the kunya Abu al-Qasim is Muhammad ibn al-Hanafiyyah. It is said: The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, said to Ali, may God be pleased with him: 'A boy will be born to you after me, and I have gifted him my name and my kunya, and it is not lawful for anyone after him.' And Muhammad ibn Abi Bakr, Muhammad ibn Talha, Muhammad ibn Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas, Muhammad ibn Abd al-Rahman ibn Awf, Muhammad ibn Ja'far ibn Abi Talib, Muhammad ibn Hatib ibn Abi Balta'a, and Muhammad ibn al-Ash'ath ibn Qays. I heard about the specific properties of the Prophets: As for the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, his specific properties are known in Sharia. Among them: the obligation of Duha prayer, sacrifice (Udhiya), Witr, Tahajjud, Siwak, giving the wife choice to stay or separate, the prohibition of writing and poetry, keeping a wife who dislikes him, fleeing from the enemy in war, not sheathing weapons after drawing them until attaining something from the enemy, permissibility of continuous fasting (wisal), the fifth (khums) and the chosen share of booty (safi al-maghnam), entering Mecca without ihram (halal), making his estate charity not inherited, marriage by the word of 'gift' from the wife without dowry, guardian, or witnesses, and while in Ihram, and marrying more than four, and whomever he chose became forbidden for the husband to marry and he was obliged to divorce her, and the prohibition of his wives after his death to the Ummah, so their marriage is not lawful to anyone. As for those other than them from the rest of their nations, no one has a specific property distinguishing him in terms of Sharia. So look at Ibn al-Athir, may God have mercy on him, he did not match the denial with the citation. If King Al-Nasir had answered him about that and said: 'The servant did not combine the kunya of the Commander of the Faithful and his name, nor singled out one of them, so what is the face of denial upon me?' he would have had the right to say that. Furthermore, King Al-Nasir, may God Almighty have mercy on him, did not name himself with this title while Al-Nasir was a Caliph among the Abbasids. Rather, Al-Adid, one of the Fatimid Caliphs in Egypt, when he appointed him vizier in the year 564 AH, titled him with this title, and the Caliph in Baghdad at that time was Al-Mustadi' Bi-Amr Allah.

**The Letter of Ibn Ziyadah al-Baghdadi**
As for Ibn Ziyadah's saying: 'And all that the master deems good is forbidden for the slave,' it is appropriate, and perhaps he brought it in a form better than this, and it came during his speech naturally. Ibn al-Athir did not mention what he brought so its beauty or ugliness could be known. Ibn Ziyadah's speech was not present with me when commenting on this chapter, and perhaps I will find it later and establish it in the margin. I stood upon Ibn Ziyadah's speech later, and what he concluded the chapter of denial on the title with was: 'And it is strange that the Commander of the Faithful is addressed by one marked with kingship with what was not his, and he competes regarding what belongs to another. And among the elegant wisdom in concise speech: That which is proper for the master is forbidden for the slave.' End quote. I say: This rhymed phrase is a verse of poetry from verses written by Amr bin Mas'adah to Al-Ma'mun with a horse he gifted him, which was dark with a blaze: 'O Imam whom no one approaches / when a Imam is counted / We have sent a steed / whose like cannot be sought / His face is morning but / the rest of the body is darkness / And that which is proper...' the verse. Al-Qadi Al-Fadil, may God have mercy on him, answered Ibn Ziyadah's letter with a lengthy reply, but he was gentle in it and not harsh, and outnumbered and not baring teeth. Then Judge Muhyiddin ibn Abd al-Zahir, may God Almighty have mercy on him, dictated a reply to the mentioned letter on behalf of Saladin, lengthening it to the limit, although he competed and discussed, and forced and peeled. Al-Qadi Al-Fadil, may God have mercy on him, has an apparent excuse at that time for flattering, due to the greatness of the position of the Caliphate in that time. By my life, this letter weakened the arm of King Al-Nasir and lowered him, and the notable people who had authority in other than his lands refrained from saying anything but Sultan Saladin instead of King Al-Nasir, due to the Caliph's denial of that. Perhaps this matter remains to this time, for only Sultan Saladin is said mostly. These two replies I have established in the thirteenth part of the Tadhkira (Memorandum) which I collected.

**Rhetoric and Eloquence**

He said in the eighth chapter on Eloquence (Fasaha) and Rhetoric (Balagha), when mentioning Rhetoric, after establishing that Rhetoric is for meanings and Eloquence is for words: 'Rhetoric is comprehensive of words and meanings, and it is more specific than Eloquence, like the human compared to the animal. For every human is an animal, but not every animal is a human. Likewise, it is said: Every rhetorical speech is eloquent, but not every eloquent speech is rhetorical. It is distinguished from Eloquence from every other aspect other than general and specific, which is that it only exists in word and meaning on the condition of composition (tarkib), for a single word is not called Rhetoric, but is called Eloquence, since the description specific to Eloquence, which is beauty, exists in it. As for Rhetoric, it does not exist in it due to its emptiness of useful meaning that organizes speech.'

I say: He claimed that this second differentiator is other than the first, but it is the very same one and its lie. For he first intended: Every eloquent speech can be called rhetorical, but not the reverse. The meaning of this is, if we say: 'Stop, let us weep at the memory of a beloved and a dwelling' (Qifa nabki...), this speech is rhetorical considering that its meaning reached in the molding of its composition a limit that fulfills the complete intent. And it is eloquent considering the clarity of its vocabulary, its beauty, and its sweetness in hearing. If we dismantle this composition and take every individual word of it, every individual is eloquent, but not rhetorical due to the lack of composition in meaning. So Eloquence became more general than Rhetoric because it is found in singularity and composition. And Rhetoric became more specific because it only covers the compound. So wherever Rhetoric is found with the sweetness of words, Eloquence is found, but not the reverse. So it is correct that Rhetoric is like Humanity in its specificity, and Eloquence is like Animality in its generality. This meaning exists exactly in the second differentiator he presented. For he said: Rhetoric is only in word and meaning on the condition of composition... to the end. So contemplate his words, and what I said will appear to you.

**Defining the meaning of Rhetoric and Eloquence**
What I say is: Between Rhetoric and Eloquence, there is generality from one aspect and specificity from another. Explanation: As for the generality of Rhetoric, it covers eloquent speech, i.e., beautiful and clear, and non-eloquent speech, i.e., strange and wild. As for the generality of Eloquence, it covers compound words only. As for the specificity of Eloquence, it covers only sweet, used words. So it is proven that between Rhetoric and Eloquence there is generality from one aspect and specificity from another. The like of this, Ibn al-Athir does not notice.

**Divisions of the Science of Bayan (Imagery)**
He said in this chapter: 'As for the divisions of the Science of Bayan from Eloquence and Rhetoric, they are not so because they were deduced by observation and the judgment of reason without the layer of language, and there was no need in them for transmission (tawqif). Rather, words and meanings were taken in a specific form, and reason judged them with the merit of beauty that no other shares. For every knower of the secrets of speech in any language knows that bringing out meanings in beautiful, pleasing words that the ear delights in and nature does not recoil from, is better than bringing them out in ugly, detestable words that the ear recoils from. Even if the layer of language wanted otherwise, we would not imitate him.'

I say: He claimed that this is pure reason. If he meant by 'Bayan' what the masters of Rhetoric agreed upon—which is one of the divisions of the Science of Rhetoric applied to knowing Reality (Haqiqa), Metaphor (Majaz), Simile (Tashbih), Metonymy (Kinaya), and Allusion (Isti'ara)—then among Metaphor is the linguistic one, like 'Salah' (Prayer). The Lawgiver used it in this specific form comprising standing, reciting, bowing, prostrating, remembrance, peace, and supplication. In the origin of language, it applies only to supplication, which is a part of this form, so He named it by the name of its part. Thus, knowing this metaphor depended on its reality (original meaning), and that reality is not known except by transmission, not by reason. And that which depends on what depends on knowing a thing depends on that thing.

**Allusion (Isti'ara) and Metonymy (Kinaya)**
As for Allusion (Isti'ara), the scholars of Bayan differed: is it a linguistic metaphor or a rational one? The majority went to the view that it is a linguistic metaphor, contrary to the author of 'Al-Miftah' who held it is rational. The proof of the majority is that if you said: 'I have a lion fully armed,' and you mean the brave man, the word 'lion' upon verification is used in other than what it was placed for, because you understand that he has a man he likened to the lion. The tool of simile was omitted for exaggeration, but understanding the meaning of Alif, Sin, and Dal depends on transmission. As for Metonymy (Kinaya), among its divisions is a section dependent on transmission. Like the poet's saying: 'The brother of Lakhm lent you a garment from him / congratulations on the new shirt / Your father wanted your mother when she was led in wedding / but no daughter of Sa'd was found for your mother.'

'And Abu Ubaid cast a cloak / upon you, so you became the most clothed of the people of Najd / God showed me your eye in the quiver / and your eye is the eye of Bashar bin Burd.' The poet meant by 'brother of Lakhm' the Judham tribe, and by 'daughter of Sa'd' the Udhra tribe [known for chaste love or virginity], and by 'Abu Ubaid' leprosy [Al-Baras], and by 'eye of Bashar' blindness. And the saying of Muhammad bin Abdun about wine turning to vinegar: 'Verily, in the path of amusement is a cup of wine / that came to us with the taste of its covenant not fixed / It imitated the daughter of Bistam bin Qais in the morning / and went like the body of Al-Shanfara after Thabit.' He meant by 'daughter of Bistam' reddish wine (Sahba'), and by 'body of Al-Shanfara' his saying: 'Give it to me, O Sawad bin Amr / for my body after my friend is vinegar (khall).' And the saying of the other: 'He claims drinking in a cup and a bowl / and the mother of Antara al-Absi suffices him.' Meaning 'Zabiba' (Raisin) because it is the name of Antara al-Absi's mother. Were it not for transmission, nothing of these metonymies would be known, and reason has no field here. So it has become clear that some of Bayan is transmitted. If he meant by Bayan the Science of Meanings (Ilm al-Ma'ani)—which is what is known by tracking the properties of word structures, of the conditions of predicative attribution, conditions of the subject, conditions of the predicate, separation and connection, brevity and verbosity, and conditions of demand—then most of that depends on transmission for its knowledge, since the predicate and subject are the Mubtada' and Khabar, and the conditions of each are varied, from advancing and delaying each, making them definite or indefinite, omitting this sometimes and that other times, and the coming of the subject sometimes as a noun and sometimes as a verb, either past or present. Were it not for fear of elongation, I would have given examples of that, but they are known from Grammar. All of that is originally what transmission brought. And this is the bulk of the Science of Meanings. So it is proven that Bayan is not rational as Ibn al-Athir claimed, but some is rational and some is transmitted. Furthermore, people have raised objections to the Science of Meanings, saying: If it were intuitive, it would not need learning and codification, and mentioning it would be dispensed with. And if it were acquired (kasbi), it would require another science, and it would circle or regress infinitely. And whatever leads to that is false. It was answered that not all of it is intuitive so that follows. Rather, some is intuitive perceived by sound taste and straight mind, and some is acquired taken by transmission. Since people are on three levels: The first are owners of sound nature, the pure Arabs who bring speech by their instinct to its proper places; these are dispensed from learning it because it is instinct and nature for them. The second level are the rough ones, owners of crudeness and repelling natures who have no feeling for the meanings of speech, nor aptitude to acquire that; these are also dispensed from learning it, for there is no benefit for them in it. The third level are the intermediate ones, between these and those; they may be correct sometimes in their thoughts and may err. These are the ones for whom this tool was placed. If they observe its codified laws and established limits, they are further from error. In that case, this class cannot dispense with learning this tool.

**Explanations of the Grammarians**
He said in this chapter also: 'And that which the grammarians burden themselves with of causal explanations (ta'lil) is weak and does not stand on the touchstone of observation.'
I say: Ibn Abi al-Hadid answered him in 'Al-Falak Al-Da'ir' about that. But the speech was not matured with him, and it needs a remaining appendage. Which is to say to him: It seems you did not look into this science with true looking, nor saw what Ibn al-Sarraj, Al-Rummani, Abu Ali, Al-Sirafi and those after them like Ibn Jinni mentioned in 'Al-Khasa'is' and 'Sirr al-Sina'a' and Ibn al-Anbari in 'Asrar al-Arabiyya' and others, of good explanation for the rules of grammar, and the correspondences they revealed, even if there is leniency in some because they committed to explaining everything transmitted from the Arabs. Just as Abu Ali committed in 'Al-Hujjah' to explaining the Seven Readings, and Ibn Jinni in 'Al-Muhtasib' in explaining the Anomalous Readings, not all of which match the rules of Grammar in appearance, especially the reading of Abu Amr, may God have mercy on him, because he was the most grounded of them in grammar. For this reason, grammarians criticized Ibn Amir, may God have mercy on him, in his famous reading of His Almighty's saying: 'Wa kadhalika zuyyina likathirin min al-mushrikina qatlu awladahum shuraka'ihim' (And thus the killing of their children was made appealing to many of the polytheists by their partners). By changing 'zuyyina' to passive, raising 'qatlu' as a subject, installing the Dal of 'awladahum' as the object of the source (masdar) which is 'qatl', and genitizing 'shuraka'ihim' because it is the actor of the source and genitized by annexation, and the source is not annexed except to its actor.

So Ibn Amir separated between the Source (Masdar) and its Actor (Fa'il) which is the annexed-to, which is other than what the grammarians established. They were excessive in criticizing him, yet it is permissible. It came from the Arabs often in their poetry, and Sheikh Jamal al-Din ibn Malik, may God have mercy on him, cited numerous witnesses for it in the explanation of 'Al-Kafiya', and prevented the opponent by saying this chapter is permissible in poetic necessity, and there is no necessity in the Quran. Al-Kawashi defended Ibn Amir in his Tafsir and supported this reading. This is the state of the jurists; most of their explanations for what was transmitted in the rulings of the noble Sharia are the ultimate in goodness and strength, and in some there is leniency. Like one who wanted to explain some rituals of Hajj, for it is not as strong as others. Al-Ghazali in 'Al-Ihya' spoke about this nicely. Similarly the state of the theologians (Mutakallimun), for some of their proofs do not reach strength in what they brought regarding the origin of the world and the soul, proving Oneness, and the non-existence of direction. Sometimes they have few issues whose proofs are weak, not reaching in certainty and decisiveness and binding the opponent the amount of those. Were it not for that, disagreement would not have occurred in Grammar between Basrans and Kufans, nor between the owners of schools in branches, like the four Imams and those other than them of the follower jurists and the literalists, may God be pleased with them all, nor between the theologians in the principles of religion from the Ash'aris, Mu'tazilis, Imamis, Kharijis, and Hashawis. It is as if he looked at the saying of Ibn Faris the author of 'Al-Mujmal': 'A slender, well-formed woman passed us / Turkish, attributed to a Turk / Gazing with a captivating, languid glance / weaker than the argument of a grammarian.' Does he not know that in poetry and rhetoric, the slightest doubt circulates, and the smallest gleam illuminates? The poet's saying here is only relative to necessary matters, like the mutual exclusion of opposites, that one is half of two, and that a single body does not occupy two spaces together at one time and the like. Although some people denied these axioms and attacked their validity while admitting sensory perceptions. And some people denied sensory perceptions and attacked them while being certain of axioms. And some people attacked both and denied sensory perceptions and axioms, and they are the Sophists. It is told that Salih bin Abd al-Quddus lost a son, so Abu al-Hudhayl went to him accompanied by Al-Nazzam who was a young lad. He saw his grief and said to him: 'I do not know a face for your grief since people to you are like crops!' Salih said: 'O Abu al-Hudhayl, I only grieve for him because he did not read the Book of Doubts.' He said: 'What is it?' He said: 'A book I wrote; whoever reads it doubts what was until he imagines it was not, and what was not until he thinks it was.' Al-Nazzam said to him: 'Then doubt regarding your son that he did not die even if he died, and act as if he lived until he read the book even if he did not live until he read it.' Salih was dumbfounded and silenced. If the matter reached this limit in obstinacy, what is your thought of one who explains the nominative of the subject and the accusative of the object and the operation of 'Lam' for jussive and 'In' for condition and answer and other things? The door of dialectic is open to anyone who wants to prevent something. For this reason it is said: If you debate a Mu'tazili on the issue of Vision (Ru'ya), stick to the side of prevention (denial). Whoever wants to deny something denies it and tires his opponent, so he cannot conquer him. 'Nothing is correct in understandings / if the day needs proof.' Yes, if your opponent sticks to the truth and intends it, you win the desire from him, and pull him after obstinacy to correctness smoothly led. But if he is obstinate, ignorant, or denying, then you are striking cold iron and have wasted your blowing in the ash. 'No proof stands for the people of love / regarding the whiteness of a morning or the blackness / of a night.' And O Ibn al-Athir: If the explanations of the grammarians were weak and did not stand on the touchstone of observation, then what stands on the touchstone of observation from the explanations of the masters of Meanings (Ma'ani), being what they are? Most of what they rely on are rhetorical semblances not definitive. If they were opposed in them, they would stop in many of them. Sheikh Taqi al-Din ibn Daqiq al-Eid, may God Almighty have mercy on him, used to say: 'The science of Meanings and Bayan is until now not matured by nature.' Sheikh Fath al-Din ibn Sayyid al-Nas told me this about him in the Egyptian lands in the year 728 AH, for he was his special student. I do not doubt that many arguments are stronger, more decisive, and closer to certainty than many arguments of the masters of Meanings; indeed, between them is the comparative form (Af'al). 'So bring a decisive proof regarding that / Or leave things covered / And enter us into the wide relationship.'

**What the Writer and Poet share**
He said in the ninth chapter on the pillars of writing: 'That the writer is one who excels in the opening (Matla') and the closing (Maqta'), or it should be built upon the intent of the letter.' Then he said: 'And this is shared by the writer and the poet.'

I say: This contains leniency, for the poet does not always open his poem with what indicates his intent. For one who praises seeks support and aid with money, a mount, intercession, or seeking an office, then he starts that poem with ghazal (love poetry) describing his beloved, or describing passion, estrangement, longing, or travel—how does that happen for him? Yes, if it is pure praise without ghazal, that fits it, and mostly praise is stripped of ghazal if it is about an incident that occurred to the praised one, so the poet congratulates him either on an office appointment, victory over an enemy, a newborn, safety from an accident that befell him, congratulations on health, recovery, or other new incidents. Were it not for fear of elongation, I would mention witnesses for that. As for the writer, if he writes to one below him, equal to him, or higher than him, such that addressing him with supplication is possible, he needs the supplication to be appropriate to what the letter contains of longing, loneliness, gift, request for a gift, intercession, asking for a command, thanks, congratulations, condolences, or whatever fits the situation. This type has been maintained only by the late writers, especially in investitures (taqalid) and signatures (tawaqi'), for they observed that. Were it not for fear of elongation, I would have cited a sufficient amount of that. However, the people of this era do not need alerting to this, because this matter has become famous among its writers. It has remained the ultimate goal sought from the writer. So much so that it is said: He opened his investiture or signature or letter with such-and-such. And he mentions the name of the owner of the investiture in the first rhyme, or alerts to the meaning of what the letter contained. So among them is the predecessor and among them is the failing. Often the name of the addressee and the function coincide, so the writer alerts to the meaning. Do you not see how excellent is the saying of... who wrote an investiture for heir apparent for Sultan Al-Malik Al-Ashraf Salah al-Din, saying: 'Praise be to God who made the King most noble (Al-Ashraf) goodness of the religion (Salah al-Din).' So he did not borrow anything for him. The like of this happened to me in a signature I wrote for the Chief Judge of the Hanafis, Imad al-Din Ali, for teaching at the Qaymaziyya Madrasa, so I said: 'Praise be to God who made Imad al-Din (Pillar of Religion) High (Ali).' So I did not borrow anything for him. This happens often. And the saying of Judge Muhyiddin ibn Abd al-Zahir, writing an investiture for heir apparent for Sultan Al-Malik Al-Salih Ala' al-Din Ali on behalf of his father Sultan Al-Malik Al-Mansur, saying: 'Praise be to God who honored the throne of kingship with its Ali (High one), and guarded it from him with his Wasi (Guardian), and supported his Mansur (Victor) with a Mahdi (Guided) heir apparent.' And the saying of Judge Ala' al-Din ibn Abd al-Zahir, may God Almighty have mercy on him, in an investiture he wrote for Rukn al-Din Baybars al-Muzaffar, when he took possession on behalf of our master the Commander of the Faithful Abu al-Rabi' Sulayman, may God prolong his days, opening it by saying: 'It is from Solomon (Sulayman) and it is In the Name of God the Most Gracious the Most Merciful.' And Fakhr al-Din ibn Luqman wrote on behalf of Al-Malik Al-Sa'id son of Al-Malik Al-Zahir, may God have mercy on them both, an investiture for the ministry of Burhan al-Din al-Sinjari, opening it with His Almighty's saying: 'O people, a Burhan (Proof) has come to you from your Lord.' In this glimpse is sufficiency. But it appeared first that the poet is not bound like the writer to observe openings.

**How the Creative Writer benefits from Literary Heritage**
He said in the tenth chapter on the path to learning writing: 'Second, that he mixes the writing of the predecessors with what he innovates for himself of good addition: either in improving words or improving meanings.' Then he said: 'Except that this path is very rugged, and none can do it except one whom God has provided with an attacking tongue and an embroidering mind. Its difficulties have been eased for me and its passes humbled, and I was stingy to show that because of the suffering I endured in attaining it.'
I say: He walked a path and Al-Qadi Al-Fadil a path: 'They turned to my destruction and I turned to satisfaction / difference is between their path and my path.' For the Judge, may God have mercy on him, amazed when he eased, and Ibn al-Athir, may God forgive him, saddened when he saddened. Although most of what he brought in his path is: unravelling verse (hall al-manzoum), and embedding proverbs. He is not the father of this virginity (idea), nor the stringer of that nugget. Where is his speech compared to the speech of the Vizier Abu al-Walid ibn Zaydun: Whoever stands upon his correspondence knows his good arrival at this art and his subtle means. Especially his letter he wrote on the tongue of Wallada bint al-Mustakfi to the Vizier Abu Amir ibn Abdus, and the letter he wrote to Ibn Jahwar seeking his sympathy. For he brought in these two letters wonders and marvels, and included in them proverbs, incidents, and unravelling of verses what increased, and diffused his ambergris in every club, because he gathered in them, so he called out, and strung the pearls of that as twins and singles, so every letter came... 'Hearing it moves the sides of highness / and sends the rapture of intellects and excites.'

There, the value of this man is known in his extensive reading, the spread of his shadow, and the utmost of his elevation. It was even said: His prose is more like verse.
