Ibn Khalaf parsed the Hamasa and added to it in a volume he named 'Al-Manthur al-Baha'i' and claimed in it that he was the one who invented unravelling verse, just as Al-Khalil bin Ahmad invented Prosody. As for Ibn al-Athir, he increased the unravelling, and brought in it what is forbidden and what is lawful, and increased his embroidery in his cloaks, and exaggerated his stringing in his necklaces. 'The cheek is beautiful with one mole / and becomes little with many moles.' He brought in it the fat and the lean, and did not bring a new thing without coupling it with the worn out. Unravelling verse is only one type, and a section that if lost, he would not be finding of it. Whatever does not allow lightness to promote it, and sweetness to couple it with hearing and marry it, its earring does not cling to the hearing, nor does its condition pass with acceptance. I liken it only to a necklace whose beads were scattered, and a garden whose flowers withered. So what beauty is there for poetry whose meter betrayed it, and what freshness for a garden whose rain shunned it? Unless the composer is of sound nature, straight thought, correcting for the poet what he missed, sharpening his sword and straightening his spear, either by avoiding what he did not deviate from, or bringing a compatible thing not possible due to strictness of meter, or by abbreviating what the meaning stands without, or by increasing the blossom of its branches, or by quality of casting, or perfection of weaving. Here the capable power appears, and the proofs of eloquence become clear. 'Not for the connection of one who calls then comes / is the sweetness of the connection of one who calls then refuses.'

As for Al-Qadi Al-Fadil, may God have mercy on him, he walked a strange path, and showed wondrous arts. Some claimed that his main reliance was on memorizing the words of Ibn Abi al-Shakhba, and that he used to recall most of his speech. Some claimed he relied on the speech of Ibn Abi al-Khisal, and some claimed he relied on the speech of Al-Badi'. Far from it, there is not in the speech of any one of them that euphoria, nor for a speaker other than him that step in attaining favor, nor for a correspondent his beauty which split the hearts of men if not cutting the hands of women. While he addresses you with speech, suddenly he has given you cups of wine. And while he mimics your blowing wind, suddenly he has bewitched your core. And while he speaks like people customarily, suddenly he has listed burning stars. And while he has turned his back to you, suddenly he has turned the face to you. And while he walks with you on the soil, suddenly he struts at the Pleiades. 'If it is of pearls, pearls are not like this / And if it is magic, indeed this is wondrous.' Here I present a portion of his speech to be a title for the rest, and a piece to be a scale between him and others. Of that is a letter he wrote describing a letter written by Muwaffaq al-Din Khalid bin Muhadhdhab al-Din al-Qaysarani in gold, which is:

'The servant stood upon what the fingers of the Presence adorned—the one whose cloud, if it rains, creates a garden immediately, and if real magic is missing, it is she whose expression blew into the panic of her pen. So he moved from approval to glorification because its letters are beads of the rosary, and cleared preference from weighting with the first thing the eye shook hands with of novelty (tarf) and the glance of pleasantry (milh). So he took from it a garden adorned with fire, and a night sash-wrapped with day, and a meadow watered with streams of wine, and branches of pens opened with gold blossoms, and a cloud of gold melted, the flash of its lightning almost taking away sight. Exalted is He who softened iron for David, peace be upon him, and gold for her, and awakened by him the grandfather of this industry after he slept among creation, so he woke. And he informed people that the pen in the hand of Ibn al-Bawwab is for beating not for delight (tarab), and that the value is yours from it and from him regarding what is written in this industry. He adorned it with full moons and gave it what he gave his father, a crescent from waning, and delayed its time and advanced his time, and granted it precedence and denied him catching up.

Among Alifs, the Hamzas have accustomed their branches as doves; and Lam-Alifs, after it the lover envies them for the embrace of their soft figures; and Sads that quenched the thirst of thirsty eyes and hovering hearts; and Waws reminding of what is in the garden of temples of curves; and Mims whose mouths approached their mouths to attain the harvest of sips; and Sins like the serration in those teeth; and Dals indicating (dalat) obedience to their writer by the bending of backs; and Jims like beaks hunting hearts that flutter at the frights of admiration like birds. In it is what souls desire and eyes delight in. Khalid is eternal (khalid) in it, and his greeting in it is praise, and his hand strikes in molten gold while creation strikes in cold iron. It is the hand that strings the crowns of kings with its pearls, and reveals the sign of generosity on its papers by what it reveals of its gold dust. I did not think before his hand that a cloud rains gold, nor that water draws ink from fire, nor that its pens are swords that shed the blood of wealth and made it flow as rivers. Nor before his glance that twilight does not fear the rising of dawn, nor that the color of connection shakes off the color of abandonment, nor that the night clings to the side of lightning and does not depart, nor that the gold of the afternoon flows with the blackness of the pitch-dark night. Nor that a noble hand claims from the signs of its pen and the miracles of its generosity that the rock parts with solidity, and that skill marches its star over thirst so it speaks directly to the watered source of freshness. The scripts of the virtuous were nothing but an experiment before its editing now, nor were their pens anything but wood it kindled upon gold so it melted for it and softened. Nor is calligraphy reckoned except by its hand, so it changed the clothes of mourning for it and unveiled the brides of its letters, their bodies perfumed with saffron, and rose the pupil of the eye of beneficence with the proof that it only glances in blackness. It prostrated to it, and prostration is its duty because it is below crowns, and kissed it, and kissing is its right because Paradise converses from it the houris of Paradise. And how not to prefer its essence by detailing, and meet its letters by kissing, when people wrote by hand and he wrote by eye, and people obtained from this industry after the Battle of Hunayn the shoes of Hunayn (nothing), while she won what she showed of her blossom to the onlookers of gold, and alchemy became correct for her, because he wrote with half a dinar a line worth a thousand dinars. And that he has in its day—nay in its rivers—a long swimming, and that despite its light weight and few lines, it costs a heavy burden of thanks. And how does the scale of praise not lighten against rivers of his argument with molten gold? And how does the delegation of thanks go astray when she guided it with locks of flame? He unfolded it and folded it until he almost broke it, and grazed a gaze in it that did not tire of it, so the last thing he contemplated was the first thing he glanced at, and forgot due to his fascination to worship his doctrine (madhhab - also means gilded) on a letter or on a paper. And he arrived at it as he measures his arrival, so he increased in thirst despite much sipping and drinking, and it blinded him when it covered him, and much light blinds the sight of eyes.'

And from that is what he described the tents among a number of letters, which is:
'As for the tents, they have worn out and become mixed, and thinned so they mixed the cup of clouds with a mood, and met distress with us—and our distress was that we saw relief in them. In them are patches from the sky, as if hearing took them in the tearing of clothes. If the winds blow, they are in their advancing and retreating in a persistent removal, and a malicious incitement from Satan. They divorced us while still in our ropes, and stabbed while still in our shackles. If the wind sends a sign, their necks remain submissive to it. If we sit in them, it is on the middle of the road while they are sitting on the road of the calamity (Qari'a). If they fall at night, their fall has no raising (ref. Quran). They have the wounds of needles from time which do not stitch, and from them are ruins upon time which the eye believes sometimes and denies. Their sky has opened and split, and listened to its Lord and was obligated. There remains no skin in their hide to blame, nor a hold in their patience to pull. It is as if they and their sisters, when the winds blow, are the criminals seeing the punishment, and the ropes are cut off with them. Whereby you see their protection shaking, and the obstacle has entered upon them truly as an obstacle. Their pillars are branches shaken by the hot wind, and their ribbons are sparks flown by the striker. But if clouds rise, they draw the swords of their lightning, and chain the torrents of their rain; they are wounded in front of those swords, and thrown behind those torrents. They wish what Noah's son wished on the day of no protector, and you see them like water ducks while we are between drowned and floating. We beat them every day above the limit (hadd), and take them in the summer with the war of heat and in the winter with the cold of cold.'

And from that is a letter he issued from Ba'rin, which is:
'The settlement is in Ba'rin, where the sky brought out its burdens and opened locks from its spouts, and the horses of thunder galloped wearing their coverings of clouds. The robe of night is washed by the water of clouds, and the ghost of darkness is killed by the sword of lightning. The crow of the horizon is a falcon in the atmosphere, except that it is drawing the bow of Qazah (Rainbow), and it is as if the scorpions of darkness are snakes in the snow, so let the night of its companion be the night of the snake-bitten. As if the locations of thunder are the clatter of women's jewelry, so it neither sleeps nor lets sleep. As if the morning has melted into the night as drops. As if the lightning, when it equaled the clouds between the two shells of night and day, said: 'Bring me, I will pour molten copper upon it.' The wing of the draped night is wet so it does not fly, and the dove of morning slowed contrary to what it intended in Noah's message so it does not march. The winds have stormed and broke the sticks of Najd and crushed them, and the clouds galloped their horses so the lightning was their white markings and nose-spots. As for the tents whose skins matured by the kindle of the sun and turned black, then were sprinkled with the tears of clouds so their eyelids relaxed after they were tight. They are nothing but eyes from which kohl flowed with tears, and black horses whose hobbles were untied by the winds from the tent-ropes. The dispute continues between them and the winds until they tear the clothes from their war as the clouds tore them from their rapture. We persist in tying their tails (tunub), to enter into the contract of their reckoning (hasab). Far from it, their figures were robbed in the compass, and their souls exited by the winds. If the sun rises, the East throws cups that settle on the sight, not the Dinars of Abu al-Tayyib (Mutanabbi) which flee from the fingertips. The winds did not seek refuge in their side, and refuse the ropes from releasing them in the rein of recklessness, except resembling a sandgrouse whose wing was caught by a trap, and a mote whose eye was shaken by a catch and refused to leave. The torrents increased until these tents became bubbles upon them, and the thunder mumbled reading so their standing settled between prostrating and bowing. I am in them like Uthman in his house, and the calamity has begun its siege. The arrows of the rain do not cease drowning, and I do not cease ditching against the torrent for myself. We have returned to the first creation, so we returned in this water as a clot ('alaqa). No ingratitude to God, for I am thrown on the roads of calamities, meeting what greyed life of separation mixing with the grey of the parting (hair). I did not fear that time would move me from the degree of its plucked harvest, to the path of its sweeping streams. Never was seen stranger than me, barren while I complain of treacherous ponds, and drought-stricken complaining of the darkness of rainy nights. May God uglify Ba'rin, even if the Lion of Islam took shelter in a lair ('arin) of it, and I am innocent of it by the number of the sands of Yabrin.'

From that: 'And that direction, although it is Western (Gharibah), the West (Gharb) is the repository of lights, the treasure of the sun's dinar, and the estuary of the rivers of the day.'
From that: 'In summary, if Rhetoric is a religion, then one who does not unify Him has committed heresy; and if it is a sword, then one who does not gird it has exposed himself to the edge; and if it is a bedding, then what it does not birth has been exiled from the back of Rhetoric.'
From that: 'If you possessed time, you would have ridden its nights as dark horses, and girded its days as sharp swords, and gifted its suns and moons as dinars and dirhams. Your days are weddings, as if no funerals for money took place in them. Generosity is a ring in your hands, and the soul of Hatim is in the engraving of that ring.'
From that: 'So may God refresh that spirit, and open for it the doors of Paradise, for it is the last of what it hoped for of openings (Futuh).'
From that regarding the thanks for his favor: 'By God, his favor is like the sun in clarity; I do not deny it. If it were permissible to worship the sun in God's religion, I would have worshipped it. For it is a sun that never cast a hand (ray/favor) on a disbeliever, nor placed a hand except on a grateful one.'
From that: 'If the speech from me reached the hearing as it reached the heart, and if you saw his sword dyed from its seat in my chest, I would not have sensed the war. If he determined to strike, I would move him so he becomes of the struck (darb - type/minting) not of the striking (darb).' 
From that: 'Hearts are good, and rains are pouring. There has become upon the side of every crop of them a splint showing itself, and upon the ear of every earring of them a pearl trembling.'
From that: 'So may I not lack those breaths which are precious things (Nafa'is), and those noble ladies which are brides, and those jewels which please me that they expose my honor, and those arrows which are, by God, my target.'
From that: 'We trusted in the success of the request, and held onto the horns of Hamah, so we obtained the milking (halab) of Aleppo (Halab).'
From that mentioning the Nile: 'Its current pushes, pushing back the chest of drought with the hand of fertility, and suckling the mothers of its canals until their sons are with grain and grass.'
From that: 'The wastelands have spread what filled them of the sheets of mirage, and there roared in them what was born illegitimately on the bed of clouds.'
From that: 'If the beautiful forgiveness familiar from this House pardons him, then by their pardon God sharpened their edge, and by their amnesty God succeeded their effort, and by their following of their father, mercy be upon him, God Almighty raised their grandfather (luck/status).'

From that: 'And God is between us and the separation (Al-Bayn), so how abundant is its intrusion and entry between lovers.'
From that: 'His noble letter arrived as an answer, nay a reward (thawab) for my effaced letter, and the cheer of the page of his hidden kindness shone, and every cheer with which there is no hiding is Bishr al-Hafi.'
From that: 'As for the poems, I am awaiting their arrival by any script that happens, for their Arabic is not assassinated by the barbarism of the translator, and the light of its truth is known from the darkness of falsehood. Whatever harms the beauties of Sahban (eloquent man) to run on the tongue of Baqil (stammerer).' 
From that: 'Happiness whose green pasture does not wither, security not saddened by the Great Terror, obeyed by the penetration of its disposal the white (sword) and the brown (spear), beloved of the pen so that even if the sword opposed it, it would be said to it: your hater is the cut-off one (abtar).' 
From that: 'And He did not deprive me of his favor which breaks the seals of the pages of affection, and overflows the paths of praise, and his covenant which combined with the lasting of the myrtle the freshness of the rose, and with the appearance of the garden the quenching of the arrival (wird).'
From that: 'Until this flood clears from us, and until the handkerchiefs of the eyes dry, for they were squeezed by tears.'
From that: 'And He ransomed him with his allies and brothers, and no dignity for his enemies and no blessing for his envier. And He kept for time his sovereignty which protected his sons from the evil of his play.'
From that: 'Two letters arrived from our master expanding the chest, gladdening the secret, and removing the worry. They met me with conquest (Fath - also vowel 'a') and I met them with embrace (Damm - also vowel 'u').'
From that: 'The noble decree arrived from the Mighty Diwan, so its light refused going astray for it, and its shining and unveiling granted it guidance and calm. Its joy and ink (habir) filled the fear of the hope-filled. Its crime and guilt did not return until its garden and silk became its shield. The gaze of his eye trained in a garden, nose to nose (unf unf - fresh), that nothing expresses it except its perfume ('abir). It removed sins from him and settled him in high degrees, so it is his bracelet, his wall, and his bed.'
From that: 'He divided so he was just, and gave abundantly so he excelled, and reached so there was no sufficiency in reaching, and opened flowers whose like was not reached by the arm of a seeker. To God is it of a letter, and to God is his pen; this one reported what was permissible, and this one imitated what he crafted.'
From that: 'As for the letter to the debtor of beauty, may God combine wealth with beauty for him, and relieve him from the agreement of these two rhymes so that beauty becomes abundant wealth (al-jamal al-jamm al-mal).'
From that: 'Grace is in God's hand, He gives it to whom He serves. He has increased him from it so he did not lack his grace. No competitor competes with him except he was foolish, and was a greengrocer (baqlah) in the path of the torrent.'
From that: 'Every word is connected to a moan, and in every heart from his sadness is fire, and in every house from his favor is a paradise.'
From that: 'I did not reach the place of health from it, except I had turned pale and was cut off, and said the rest of the bright predecessor. The cloud of merit is too shy to narrow until it almost raises the one standing with the palm.'
From that: 'He enriched him by the guarding of his word from his cautioning, and enriched the King from using his arrow by his paper.'
From that: 'May He perpetuate his mastery over his people, and protect him by the fertility of his saddlebag from the barrenness of his place. May we not lack from his word what testifies that it is honey (shahd) truly, not a gift (nihla) he claimed (nahalah) nor a sculptured palm tree (nahila nakhla).'
From that: 'And may He destroy every enemy of his and humiliate him, and make life a speck in the eye and harm for him. I stood from them upon woven, chain-mail rhetoric, and hidden precious jewels, and fruits he gathered from the good tree of rhetoric, while some people gather from the cursed tree.'
From that: 'He is that branch which He watered until it wrapped in its leaves, and strutted in its silk and brocade, and white dawn spoke directly to him after he could not attain its blue.'
From that: 'People spent the night surrounding the fortress, and fires surrounding them and wrapping them. The tails of its tongues were let down on his face and draped from behind him. Its blasts were hellish, its fuel people and stones, and the calamity calls out: Tiberias, I mean you, and hear, O neighbor.'
From that: 'Kings cease not to be standing at his door, and destines are swords for him. Creation are guests for him in the abode of the world. And the religion, the religion of truth, teaches people that if swords are drawn to exact from him, 'my swords' (su-yufi - will fulfill).'

I say: How did you see these arranged pearls and agreed beauties? Did any other bring this pattern, or win these points in the treasures of writers ever? 'This is speech veiled from kings / so do not humiliate it by increasing it to the commoners.' His mention will appear during this book, around which its cups revolve and its suns shine.

**Al-Safadi criticizes Ibn al-Athir in some of his composition**
As for Ibn al-Athir's saying, may God have mercy on him, in this chapter which I presented: 'Except one whom God gave an attacking (hajjam) tongue and an embroidering (raqqam) mind.' I say: I do not know what to say in this. What is the relation between 'hajjam' and 'raqqam'? Furthermore, borrowing 'embroidering' (raqm) for the mind (khatir) is far-fetched. Embroidery is truly for the hand and metaphorically for the pen. What is the meaning of the 'attacking tongue'? If he had said a 'speaking (qawwal) tongue' and a 'roaming (jawwal) mind', or a 'tongue of sharp edge' and a 'heart that does not fear war', or a 'composing (nazzam) tongue' and 'embroidering fingertips', or the like, it would have been better.

He said in this chapter: 'Whoever stands upon what I mentioned knows that I did not bring a fabricated thing (shay'an fariyya), and that God has placed under my mind a stream (sariyya) from the daughters of thoughts.'
I say: He is here in a station of magnifying what he brought in the art of writing of unravelling verse and noble verses. So his saying 'shay'an fariyya' contradicts this station, because 'fariy' is a great thing or a fabricated, manufactured thing. If he said: 'I did not bring a great thing' or 'a fabricated thing', it would not be appropriate. As for 'Sariyy', it is the small river. Whoever held that it is Jesus, peace be upon him, meaning one of the noble people (sarat), he is mistaken. Labid says describing wild donkeys: 'They mediated the width of the stream (sariyy) and split / a filled source, its reeds neighboring.' So Sariyy is the small river. And Masjura is an adjective for the filled spring. How excellent is the saying of Abu al-Miqdam al-Khuza'i from his famous poem in riddles: 'And a stream (sariyyan) I saw amidst people / staying, not wanting to depart from them / Wine is drunk beside it, and their drink / when their mill turns is urine.' Al-Sariyy: The small river, and the context of speech is upon it. The context of the noble Verse indicates the invalidity of the saying of one who said it is a metonymy for Jesus, peace be upon him, because He Almighty said: 'Eat and drink' (kuli wa ishrabi). Meaning: Eat from the fresh dates, and drink from the river. If this is established, I do not know the meaning of his saying 'under my thoughts a stream (sariyya) from the daughters of thoughts.' If he meant what he claimed that Sariyy is Jesus, peace be upon him, he should have said 'Sariyyat' because it is an adjective for 'daughters'. And if the intended is the river, there is no meaning to it. If he said: 'He knows that I filled from that quenching (rayya), and that God has placed under my thought a flow (jaryya) of this type.'
He said also after that: 'And he who knows them among them is satisfied with the margins and edges, and content from its pearls with knowing what is in the shells.'
I say: I do not know what the meaning of this second context is? For there is nothing in shells except pearls. If he said: 'And leaves the pearls and gathers the shells,' it would have been better.
He said: 'And if he extracted from it what I extracted, and deduced from it what I deduced, he would wander with it in every valley, and take every provision for walking its path.'
I say: This last rhyme is dissolved and cold, with no meaning under it. If he said: 'He would wander with it in every valley, and rise for it in the manifestation of hills and descend in the concealing of lowlands,' it would have been better.

**Ibn al-Athir claims creativity in a letter of his condemning Old Age**
He said in this chapter: From that is what I mentioned in a chapter of a book containing the blame of gray hair, so I said: 'Life, all life, is in the age of novelty (youth), and what comes after it is only called the age of raggedness. There is no summer resort for pleasure after forty nor a spring. It is the end of the sound strength of the four natures. If a man passes it, the fruits of his life approach their estimation (khars), and his increase becomes like the increase of the diminutive, indicating its decrease. He becomes after that called 'Father' after he was called 'Son'. He wears from gray hair a robe whose train he does not drag in pride, nor is he boastful of it in beauty. If it is said that the best of clothes as a mark is white, it is said: Except this robe, for it is excluded. Suffice it of atrocity that loved ones look at it with the look of a hater. Were it not that fading is after it, the word ignition (ishti'al) would not be borrowed for it. Some people deceive its color with the dye of henna, and that is nothing but mourning for the loss of youth. He is a liar in this act of his, and the familiarity of truth is not hidden from the loneliness of the liar. It is self-deception that it finds solace for its deserted palace and its lofty castle, and going out in a patched garment seems good to it while it sees it with the eye of a new garment.' Then he said: Some of this is taken from the poetry of Ibn al-Rumi. Which is his saying: 'I saw the dye of a man after his greying / as mourning for the prime of youth he wears.' However, in this chapter are many meanings not found in other speech.

I say: He claimed that he invented the meanings in this chapter. I mention verses indicating his speech was taken from them. Abu al-Tayyib said: 'The tool of life is health and youth / so if they turn away from a man, he turns away.' Al-Tihami said also: 'My fresh part of the world is youth and its prime / so if it passes, my desires have passed.' Ibn Abi Hasina said: 'As if the youth climbs a ladder of life / until he passes forty and descends.' Sibt al-Ta'awidhi said: 'Highness of age has broken / my activity with gray hair / How did they name it highness ('uluww) / when it is a start in descent?' Abu al-Tayyib said regarding the meaning that the increase of the diminutive is a decrease: 'And he was a son of an enemy, they multiplied him / he has the Ya's of the letters of Anaysiyan (diminutive of Insan).' And how excellent is the saying of Ibn Qalaqis: 'In the matter of my signature and my affair is a biography / that baffled the tongues of the intelligent eloquent ones / Its increase judged decrease upon it / like the guest when the Nun of the intruder (Dayfan) increased.'

Abu al-Tayyib said: 'When my eye glanced at the whiteness of gray hair / it saw my decrease in my increase.' Ibn Saradar said: 'I did not weep that gray hair arrived, but / I weep because the appointment (of death) approaches / The hair of a youth is his leaves, so if it withers / the branches dry up on its traces.' Ibn Abd Rabbih said: 'If they call you their uncle, then it is / a lineage that increases you in ruin with them.' Abu al-Tayyib said: 'Go far, a distance of whiteness that has no whiteness / You are blacker in my eye than darkness.' Al-Ghazzi said: 'The flower of life weakened and withered / the flower of living is a flower in the back of the head / Hidden from me almost before the ignition of the / head was that fading is in ignition.'
He said: From this meaning is my saying also: 'It is taking noble traits from their sky and earth, and undertaking their transfer among people and their imposition. He adorned himself with the names of the months until some of them became envious of others. So Muharram is for the one seeking refuge in his sanctuary (haram), Safar for the one hoping for the endeavor of his foot, Rabi' for the seeker of his gift, and Rajab for the sayings of his scolders.' This is taken from Al-Farazdaq's saying: 'Your two hands: a hand in which is the spring (Rabi') of people / and in the other are the months of the sacred (Haram).' Poets have said much about this, but I managed a management that no one other than me managed.

I say: What management? He did not deny a thing but he became acquainted. People used the names of the months and brought them sweet, sweet, and firmly placed. Like the saying of the poet about a miser: 'He adorned himself with the names of months, so his palm / is Jumada (frozen/dry) and he gathered Al-Muharram (forbidden) upon it.' The other said, excelling in every way: 'A fawn smiling with pearly teeth / rosy-cheeked, beautiful mouth / The blamer blames me for his love / and Sha'ban (the blamer) did not know that I am Rajab (deaf/honored).' The Arabs used to call Sha'ban 'Al-Adhil' (The Blamer) before Islam, and Rajab 'Al-Asamm' (The Deaf). How excellent is the saying of Al-Qadi Al-Fadil, may God have mercy on him: 'God took charge of realizing his intent, purifying his resource, building the structures of his happiness, and immortalizing the dwellings of his sovereignty, until God's gifts are organized for him in twos and ones, and he wears the security of Rajab in Sha'ban and the fertility of Rabi' in Jumada.' And his saying also: 'It is water, except it is Zulal (pure), and magic except it is Halal (lawful), and the fresh Rose except it is far from boredom. The days of standing upon it are days of Eid between the purity of Ramadan and the fertility of Shawwal.' And his saying also returning to the mention of his letter: 'So he prostrated to its niche and submitted (sallam), and counted its lines as smiling mouths (mabsim), and stood upon it the standing of a lover upon the ruins, speaking to it while it does not speak. His eyelid poured rain—and it was Jumada—with his tears, and it was Al-Muharram on his cheek.' And the saying of Ibn Sana' al-Mulk: 'Active of beautiful figure, cheek, and jewelry / why did they claim the beautiful woman is lazy (miksall - rhymes with Shawwal)? / The ignorance of my passion overlooked my piety through her / O Ramadan, Shawwal has overshadowed you.' As for using the names of months as double entendres (Tawriya), among the best is the saying of Judge Muhyiddin Abdullah ibn Abd al-Zahir: 'Beware of denying Ja'far / that imaginary one and his companions / For the Nile of Egypt, how many a Ja'far (stream) / imagined (mukhayyal) does it have coming out of its gate (Bab)?' How ingenious are these two verses and how subtle this imagination. And the saying of Ibn Quzul: 'We have become weary of the water of Tell al-Ujul / and hated hearing he-said and it-was-said / And among the ordeal we are in / is the heat of Tammuz returning (Ab - August/returned) in Aylul.' And the saying of As'ad bin Mamati: 'Magic blew at dawn (Sahar) / and the flowers resembled the stars (Zuhar - Venus) / And the camphor of dew wet / the clothes of the tree leaves / And the nightingale, since seeing / the forbidden (Muharram) of the garden, whistled (Safar - month Safar).' And the saying of Al-Siraj al-Warraq from verses: 'She wanted to extinguish the lamp (Siraj - the poet) / with it, so she doubled its flame / And she contained Tuba (Coptic month/Tree in Paradise) with it, so / our talk among people became its door (Babah - Coptic month).' And the saying of Ibn al-Sa'ati: 'Joseph has a Joseph; if a crisis occurs / he is feared and hoped for, and in his rulings is an Umar / All months are spring (Rabi') from his bounties / where the treasuries of his wealth are zero (Safar).' 

**Discussing an example by Ibn al-Athir**
He said: From that is what I mentioned in reclaiming affection—and he cited the chapter, and at its end: 'Patience is the best thing used in the estrangement of brothers. And water, if it flows in a place then deviates from it, inevitably it will return to that place.'

I say: I do not know what the meaning of this is. For water, if it deviates from a place, it only deviates due to the lowness of the place to which it deviated compared to the place from which it deviated. Either by a trench dug, or by a collapse of the earth itself. In that case, the water returns backwards and turns away from the high ground, and descends to the low ground. This is what is understood from the word 'water deviated' (inharafa). When the matter is so, water does not return to it, unless he claims that the supply of water strengthens its push so it increases until it rises above the depression, and finds no space to occupy other than that which it deviated from. This is not understood from his mere speech. If he said: 'For rain, if its downpour stops from a place, inevitably it will return at a time to that place.' Or: 'For water, if it shuns the place of its flow at a time, inevitably it will turn back to that place.' Or: 'If its irrigation is cut off from a place,' or what fits that, other than the word 'deviated'. How sweet is the saying of Al-Qadi Al-Fadil: 'Water may return to its watering place, and the star to its rising place.' How excellent is the saying of the poet regarding the meaning of Ibn al-Athir's saying: 'I will be patient, the patience of a free man without power / over patience, but by way of beautification / Perhaps one day mercy will return you / to me, so you meet me with the face of favor.'

**Discussing another example by Ibn al-Athir**
He said: From that is what I mentioned in describing wine, which is: 'Wine, the pleasure of its intoxication does not fulfill the distress of its hangover. It is clumsy of fingertips, foul of tongue, and its feminine gender indicates to you that it is among those lacking in intellect and religion. The way of tyranny has been known from it in its rulings; were it not for that, it would not have exclusively claimed the heads for the crime of its feet.' This is better than the saying of the poet, and stranger and subtler, because he said: 'I remembered its ancient grudges when it became / in time trodden by the feet of the pressers / It softened for them until they became intoxicated and it took control / of them, so it shouted among them for revenge.'

I say: As for attributing fingertips, tongue, intellect, and religion to wine, it is strange. Stranger than that is making feet for heads. Stranger than both is his claiming that his speech is subtler, better, and stranger than the poet's saying, while the difference is apparent like the morning. It is as if he wanted to say that the hand of its drinker is clumsy, his tongue foul, and his intellect and religion deficient. If he attributed that to the drinking companion in blaming wine, it would be a defamation of it. But adding limbs, intellect, and religion to it is not permissible except with an extremely far-fetched interpretation. How excellent is the saying of Abu Tammam: 'Clumsy, its bubbles play with minds / like the play of actions (verbs) with names (nouns).' And the saying of the poet: 'Its drinkers described wine that it / contains joy and expels worry / They spoke truth; it fluttered with their minds and religion / Have you seen one lacking religion distressed?' And the saying of Ibn Sana' al-Mulk: 'Your bride, O drinkers, is divorced / even if she tempted every beholder with her beauty / I paid her my wealth and my mind in advance / She said: And the gardens of bliss are my deferred payment.' It is said: Sulayman bin Abd al-Malik handed Nusayb a cup. He said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, I only reached you by my mind. If you see fit not to separate between my mind and me, then do so.' And the saying of Al-Siraj al-Warraq: 'The bad omen of the Mother of Vices, wine, is a bad omen / that exceeded the limit, so listen to what is counted / For it has imprisonment in the jars, and for the purifier / crucifixion, and for the drinker lashes.' As for his saying: 'It exclusively claimed the heads for the crime of its feet.' The pronoun must refer either to it or to the heads, and both are not permissible. How excellent is the saying of Ibn Zuhr al-Ishbili: 'Pillowing their cheeks on palms / intoxication assassinated them as it assassinated me / I ceased not giving them drink and drinking their leftovers / until I became drunk and what attained them attained me / The cup knows how to take its revenge / I tilted its vessel so it tilted me.' Abu Tammam said in a poem: 'If the hand attains it with vengeance, it stays dignified / on its grudge until it takes retaliation from the foot / And it wrestles its cupbearer by the equity of its drinking / and wrestles them by tyranny in the form of justice.' As for his saying: 'Its feminine gender indicates to you that it is among those lacking in intellect and religion.' How excellently did Al-Mutanabbi use this in describing the world (Al-Dunya - feminine), saying: 'The character of beautiful women is in it, so I do not know / for this did people feminize its name or not?'

He said: From that is what I mentioned in encouraging travel (lit. Westernization/Estrangement - Tagharrub), which is: 'Were it not for being away (Tagharrub), the daughters of shells (pearls) would not have ascended to the honor of necks, nor would the dust of stones (kohl) have ascended to the light of eyes.' Then he said: Likewise my saying in this meaning, which is: 'In movement is elevation for those of obscure destiny. Were it not for that, the crescent would not have swept the robe of fullness (full moon), and wet aloe-wood is firewood in its homelands, and musk is blood in the navels of its gazelles. Were it not for the arrow separating from its bowstring, it would not have attained the merit of hitting. Were it not for the spear separating from its growing place, it would not have adorned itself with the glory of fingertips nor the honor of the waving cloth. This chapter is a decisive speech in its meaning, and of what thoughts have not found easy to build its structure. Some of it is taken from poetry, and some of it the mind offered without precedent, and it testifies for itself.'

I say: His saying 'ascended' (irtaqat) first, and 'ascended' (irtaqa) second contains a defect due to repetition. If he had said in one of them 'connected' (ittasal) or 'rose' (sama) or otherwise, it would have been better. Likewise 'building its structure' (ibtina' mabnahu); the like of this is criticized in speech. Al-Sahib bin Abbad was criticized for his saying: 'I compose love poetry (ushabbib) but by high traits I compose / and I attribute lineage (ansub) but by glories I attribute / I have a youthful passion but to the presence of highness / and I have a thirst but from glory I drink.' The poem was named 'The Lakin-iyya' (The But-poem) due to the frequency of 'but' (lakin) in it. All these meanings have been circulated by poets and they increased in them. Of that is the saying of Ibn Saradar: 'Shake your mounts in the wilderness / and leave the beautiful women to the palaces / Were it not for being away (tagharrub), the pearls of the seas / would not have ascended to the necks (nuhur).' And the saying of Sibt al-Ta'awidhi: 'They said move away and travel, you will earn honor / for the pearl is not cherished until it separates from the shell.' And the saying of Ibn Qalaqis: 'Travel if you attempt a destiny / the crescent traveled so it became a full moon / And water gains sweetness as it flows / and becomes foul as it settles / And by the movement of precious pearls / a sea was exchanged for a neck.' Ibn Qalaqis and Ibn al-Athir, may God have mercy on them both, were from one era. For Ibn Qalaqis died in 567 AH, and Ibn al-Athir died in 637 AH; Ibn Qalaqis was born in 532 AH, and Ibn al-Athir in 558 AH. So Ibn al-Athir lived longer. The saying of Ibn al-Sa'ati, who is of his era: 'Be dispensed of every land by its sister / and if its dwelling is sweet with large-eyed maidens / For were it not for the separation of pearls from the shells of their sea / a neck and a forehead would have denied them.' And the saying of the poet: 'Lions, were it not for separating from the forest, would not have preyed / and the arrow, were it not for separating from the bow, would not have hit / And gold dust is like soil cast in its places / and aloe-wood in its land is a type of firewood.' And the saying of Abu al-Ala al-Ma'arri: 'And the Samhari spear, its value is not honored / until its flexible shaft travels from its forest.' And I said from this material: 'Travel, you will attain the ranks of glories and highness / like the pearl traveled so it became in crowns / And likewise the crescent of the horizon, if it abandoned night-travel / the shame of decrease would not have separated from it.' And I said also: 'Travel, you will attain ranks of pride and highness / for musk of creation is nothing / but blood in the navel of gazelles / And the spear when it separated from the homeland became / with a banner flapping and a crown of a spearhead.'

He said: From that is what I mentioned in blaming the world (Al-Dunya), which is: 'The miseries of the world are mixed with things souls are created to love. And all that bodies find sweet of foods harms them from the side of their medicine. For this reason, the benefit of Myrobalan (Halilaj) is blamed and the harm of Almond-sweet (Lawzinaj) is blamed. Stranger than that is that a human does not benefit from a thing of its pleasure except it harms him from the side of his reward. He is like one who benefits by warming himself at a fire while it is burning his clothes. A proverb has been coined for that, and it is said that all that benefits the liver is harmful to the spleen.'

I say: Look at this weakness (rakaka) and colloquialism. Do you not see it more resembling the speech of old women, midwives, when they start preaching and striking proverbs? Is this how the world is described in the state of blame? Did he not hear anything of the speech of Ali bin Abi Talib, may God be pleased with him, when a man said to him: 'Describe the world for us.' He said: 'What shall I describe of a house whose beginning is suffering, its end is annihilation, its lawful is accountability, and its forbidden is punishment; whoever becomes rich in it is tempted, and whoever becomes poor in it grieves.' Nor anything of some sayings of the wise about it, like the saying of some: 'The world is a hope before you, a term (death) looking down upon you, a tempting devil, and desires dragging the rein; it calls you so you answer, and you hope for it so you are disappointed.' Did he not hear the ascetic poems (Zuhdiyyat) of Abu Nuwas, which include: 'People are nothing but a perishing one and son of a perishing one / and possessor of a lineage rooted in the perishing ones.'

'If a wise man tests the world, it reveals / to him an enemy in the clothes of a friend.' Even Al-Rashid or Al-Ma'mun said: 'If the world described itself, it would not have described with more than the saying of Abu Nuwas.' Did he not hear anything of the sayings of Abu al-Atahiyah, Salih bin Abd al-Quddus, and Mahmud al-Warraq, and those who exposed themselves to blaming it among poets like Al-Mutanabbi and Abu Tammam and others? Did he not hear Al-Zamakhshari's saying: 'You are sweet to them then you pass (tahliyin thumma tamurriyn), and you settle for them then you become bitter (tahullin thumma tamurrin).' The first is from sweetness and passing, and the second from settling and bitterness. Did he not stand upon the letters of Al-Ma'arri in blaming the world? Does he not say in some of his letters: 'If the world were a bride she would have been divorced, but she is a mother who became destitute. Her child loves her despite disobedience, and she turns them away from attaining rights. What is with us and you, O mother of stink (Dafar)? Does the destruction of abundance not satisfy you? You tired me with insolence, so how about with toothlessness? You grieved me as a young woman, so how about as a perishable old woman? Far from it, neither old age nor weariness afflicted you, but that is for your children who drank from your vessel...' It is long, in which he mentioned those who passed away of the notables of nations. It is of the resonant letters. And Ibn al-Shibl al-Baghdadi says: 'We are but between a claw and a fang / of calamities whose lions are training / We wish, and in the wish is shortening of life / so we become as women forgot weaving / Health of the man is a path to sickness / and the path of annihilation is this survival / By that which we are nourished we die and live / The most killing disease for souls is the medicine / What we met of the treachery of a world, may it not be / nor may its taking and giving be / Soles under thunder and mirage / from which a clumsy prostitute sipped / Its generosity returns upon it, so whenever / the morning gives, the evening takes back / Rarely does the soul accompany the body / so why the misery and why the suffering? / May God uglify a pleasure for our misery / attained by mothers and fathers / We, were it not for existence, would not feel pain of loss / so our bringing into existence is a tribulation upon us.' Leave all this. Did he not stand upon the Nubatian Sermons and see his speech in them, and follow his example and recite his recitation, until he says: 'Myrobalan and Almond-sweet and liver and spleen.' People mention the like of this, but they insert it into phrasing that is masculine, having impact on the soul. 

He said: From that is what I mentioned in Asceticism (Zuhd), which is: 'People in the world belong to the current hour, just as souls are not residents in it.'
I say: I do not know what the meaning of the simile here is, and the face of the relationship in that. For his saying: 'Just as' (kama), the Kaf is for simile, and there is no relation between 'they are sons of the current hour' and 'that they cease/depart'. If he deleted the word 'kama' (just as), the meaning would be straight, because it returns: 'And souls in it are not residents.' Do you not see that some people criticized Abu al-Tayyib for his saying: 'The snows confused my paths for me / so as if they, with their whiteness, are black.' 'And likewise the generous one, if he stays in a town / the gold flows in it and the water stands.' They said: By what thing did he liken the staying of the generous one? What preceded it is not suitable for that. The answer to that: When he said that snows blocked the paths for him so they returned with their whiteness black (in effect), he likened that to the state of the generous one, that solid gold flows due to him and liquid water freezes. This contradiction is like that one. This place is among what is asked about regarding Mutanabbi's poetry.

He said at the end of this chapter: 'The utmost of a human's requirement is that his life be extended, and he be given respite in the extension of his trace. As for his long life, gray hair opposes it, which is non-existence in existence, and it is the brother of death in everything except inhabiting graves. The limbs by which desires are perceived, you see each of them has changed, and became like the effaced ruin which has no reliance. So Layla is not Layla, nor is Al-Nawar; nor are hearings hearings, nor sights sights.'

I say: This is of that pattern in weakness and ugliness, especially this last part. The dissolution of these words and their fall is not hidden from one who has the slightest alertness and little taste. It is as if he wanted to follow the example of Abu Tammam where he said: 'You are not you, nor are the dwellings dwellings / Passion has dried up and desires have ended.' But where is the soil from the Pleiades, and oh the distance between the back of the neck and the face. From the second half, the benefit of repetition in the first half is known. It is strange that he said in the fourth type regarding emphasizing two pronouns, and cited the saying of Abu al-Tayyib: 'A tribe, you are you, and you are from them / and your grandfather is Bishr the King, the Gallant.'

I did not cite it choosing it, but I used it as an example to show the emphasis of the detached pronoun with the detached. Otherwise, the verse is not pleasing because its casting is a casting bare of beauty.

I say: I wish I knew what coating is on his own saying: 'So Layla is not Layla...' As for Abu Tammam, he addressed himself like one denying what was of his passion for those dwellings he stood upon after his solace and the passing of his desires. He had the right to say: You are not that one who was first, nor are these dwellings those that were first. Meaning as if his self became other than that one, and the dwellings were changed to another description. How excellent is the saying of Al-Haziri the Paper-merchant: 'I left you, so go to whom you love / for your deed has cooled the fire of passion / And treachery has made you ugly in my eyes / and the wood of love has been left withered / And I have become seeing you with the eye of solace / and I used to see you with the eye of love.' It is known that the eye did not change in its essence, nor was there an eye and it was exchanged for another. Rather, solace necessitated showing him with the eye of ugliness, and love necessitated showing him with the eye of beauty. Of this is the saying of... 'The eye of satisfaction is blunt to every defect / just as the eye of discontent reveals bad deeds.' This circulates on people's tongues. They say about one from whom a trait changes against them: 'It is as if he went and another came.' This from Abu Tammam is the ultimate in beauty in its category.

As for the saying of Abu al-Tayyib, under it is meaning that clothes it with superior beauty, because this is the most praiseworthy thing for the tribe he mentioned. Because he said: A tribe you are from, and you are you; meaning: What a tribe it is, because you are from them and you are that great one. So he delayed the conjunct from the conjoined like his saying: '... Upon you, and the mercy of God, peace.' Sheikh Taj al-Din al-Kindi estimated it another estimation, and this is better despite the necessity in it. It is as if Ibn al-Athir, may God have mercy on him, glimpsed the meaning of the verses that appeared for some poets of 'Al-Dhakhira' by Ibn Bassam, which are: 'She became a decayed bone / her essential and accidental differentia departed from her / Her animal entity vanished / and her logical expression perished / Her three powers of soul vanished / verily all of that is a hidden matter / And the five senses which were in her / and for their perception was a lively action / All those attributes went / and it is impossible for the eternal to go.' He wanted to bring this meaning but spoiled it, and demolished what this poet brought and built. Some people claim these verses are by the Chief Abu Ali ibn Sina (Avicenna), and Ibn Bassam established them in 'Al-Dhakhira' for a Maghrebi. But the Chief's poem on the Soul which begins: 'A dove descended to you from the highest place / possessing pride and refusal' is the ultimate in beauty, and no one has the like of it in its category, and its fame prevents listing it. The virtuous have cared for it, quintupled it (made takhmis), and explained it. How excellent is his saying when he mentioned it at death: 'It was as if it were a lightning flash that shone in the sanctuary / then folded as if it never flashed.'

**Models of Ibn al-Athir's composition and the discussion around them**
He said: From that is what I mentioned in describing speech with eloquence, which is a chapter of a letter, so I said: 'He has the expression (Bayan) which breaks the order of the unique pearl, and the freshness of his new dress does not wear out. It is above glorious speech (kalam majid), and below the Glorious Quran (Quran Majid).' 
I say: We have not seen anyone who praised speech or eulogized it with the like of this. In the arts of praise and types of eulogy there is ample scope away from that. Do you not see that the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, is the Master of the Children of Adam. Despite this, I have not heard anyone praise another saying to him: You are below the Prophet, peace be upon him. Because the word 'below' and 'less' and 'under' are not used in the side of the praised one. And the speech of God Almighty, it is established and proven that it is not in the power of humans to bring a Surah like it, so all speech is below it. So his saying: 'Speech below the Glorious Quran' has no meaning under it because it is of the category of acquiring the acquired (tawdih al-wadihat - stating the obvious). The like of this, according to Sheikh Jamal al-Din ibn Malik and those who follow him, is not called speech (Kalam) because it did not provide a complete benefit that was not with the addressee, like your saying: 'The sky is above the earth,' because it is known to everyone. If you say: He meant by that politeness. I say: The field did not narrow on him, nor did the narrowness of the station confine him to this, such that he needs to bring something in which he makes reservations. Nothing threw him into that except the word 'Al-Majid' (The Glorious) and 'Al-Majid', seeking the pun (Jinas).

He said: And if they abbreviate a description, he said: 'It sways the hearing of the rapture-prone (tarub), and lightens the dignity of hearts, and represents white signs (miracles) without joining to pockets (reference to Moses' hand), and appears in the earth not tired (laghib) when the tribulation of fatigue touches others.'

I say: If it sways the hearing of the rapture-prone (tarub), there is no great praise in this. That is because the form 'fa'ul' is an exaggeration for one who gets enraptured. 'Tarub' is not said except for one who inclines to the slightest pleasure, and moves for the least grace. Like 'akul' (glutton) and 'sharub' (heavy drinker) for one who eats and drinks much of what passes him. If the one who inclines to rapture and repeats that is enraptured by this speech, there is no merit in this necessitating his praise. For this reason it is said: 'One prepared for a thing, the slightest cause suffices him.' Praise is only to say: 'It sways one who does not relax for rapture.' As he said in the second: 'And lightens the dignity of hearts.' For this is what is customary in praise. If you say: This reflects on Al-Buhturi in his saying: 'Swaying the hearing of the suffering rapture-prone / from the songs of Ma'bad and Aqid.' I say: This supports what I said, because he said: It sways the hearing of the suffering rapture-prone *from* listening to Ma'bad and Aqid, who are the origin of singing. If it turns one who is of this description away from his pleasure to hearing it, that is praise; so it is of the category of 'It makes the forbearing light and tempts the ascetic.' This was only pure for Al-Buhturi by his saying: 'from the songs of Ma'bad'. If Ibn al-Athir said: 'It sways the rapture-prone from his songs by his eloquence,' I would not have raised this objection against him. This which I said is what is customary in praise. Do you not see the saying of Al-Nabigha al-Dhubyani: 'If she presented herself to a gray-haired monk / worshipper of the God, celibate, devout / He would gaze at her splendor and the beauty of her talk / and think it guidance though he is not guided.' And the saying of Imru' al-Qais: 'To the like of her the forbearing one gazes with passion / when she grows tall between a shield and a shift.' How excellent is the saying of Kushajim regarding a lute player, from verses: 'His pegs turned in it so they differed / like the difference of hands when clasped / If he moved it behind a defeated one / on a post-horse, he would turn and look back.' And I said: 'She touched the second strings of her lute with fingertips / that toyed with the core of the submissive pious one / And she sang, so if she wished, the sweetness of her word / would have turned the rein of the rushing lightning / And I wondered at the East Wind as it did not stop / in rapture, but it has no ear that hears.'

As for his saying: 'And appears in the earth not tired (laghib),' I have not heard of anyone praising eloquent speech with the like of this. Speech is not described with fatigue or weariness. But this is of the category of adding intellect, religion, and limbs to wine in the chapter that passed. Did he not know that weariness is of the attributes of bodies and their appendages during movement and its persistence? Speech does not tire; rather the fatigue is for the limb of the one who spoke it, and the book does not tire; rather the writer who wrote it. How excellent is the saying of the poet: 'If he takes the paper he deposits in his scroll / a thicket of flowers or a necklace of jewels / He protected every thought from the wrestling of his reflection / and put down the weight of thinking from the pens.' If Ibn al-Athir intended the writer from whom this letter issued which he described, there is nothing in the context of speech indicating him. Al-Wahid criticized Abu al-Tayyib for his saying: 'All swords, if striking is prolonged with them / weariness touches them other than the sword of the State (Sayf al-Dawla).' He said: Weariness does not attach to swords unless he brought it as a metaphor in the place of dulling of the edge.

He said: 'When I stood upon it I said: Glory be to Him who gave our master and was not stingy, and singled him out with the prophethood of expression (Nubuwwat al-Bayan) except that he was not sent (as a messenger). Were it not that Revelation has closed its door, it would be said this is a revealed book. God has chosen good for the possessors of eloquence that they did not live in his era, and were not tested with the disease of envy which burns them with the kindling of its ember. If they were safe from that, their sayings were not safe from his sayings which erased them the erasing of ink. They were remaining after him, but when he came they became as they became to the graves.'

I say: In this there is bad etiquette as there is. A human has an alternative to such praise that exits him from these straits. His saying: 'Singled him out with the prophethood of expression except that he was not sent' is taken from the saying of Abu al-Ala al-Ma'arri: 'Were it not for the interruption of Revelation after Muhammad / we would have said Muhammad is a substitute for his father / He is like him in merit except that / Gabriel did not come to him with a message.' The sayer of the like of this has disbelieved.

He said: 'And verily his words have a taste whose flavor is known from among speech, and the lightness of spirits is known from among the heaviness of bodies. If he were not known by his taste, he would be known by his mark, and the morning is not disputed in its shining, nor does it lack proof of its lights. It is known that the root is known by its branch, and the saying is known by its tone.'
I say: His saying: 'And verily his words have a taste whose flavor is known from among speech,' how excellent is what Ibn Amira ibn al-Abbar answered with regarding a letter sent to him, coming within the answer:

'Slowly, O you who fulfill his knowledge, blowing with the magic of his pen. Do you think your station in Rhetoric is hidden while its road is clear? And its aim plays with minds. Do you lower yourself while you have risen, or hide while you have wrapped yourself? We knew you, O Sawdah, and the suit of Utarid (Mercury - scribe of planets) was famous for beauty and quality.' And his saying: 'And the morning is not disputed in its shining,' the two rhymes. Taken from the saying of Abu al-Tayyib: 'Nothing is correct in understandings / if the day needs proof.' And from the saying of Al-Ghazzi: 'Do not seek proof of his nobilities / your seeking proof of the morning is cold.' And his saying: 'And it is known that the root is known by its branch' is taken from the saying of Abu al-Tayyib: 'His actions are a lineage, even if he did not say with them / My grandfather is Al-Khasib, we knew the root by the branch.' Although Al-Mutanabbi took it from Al-Buhturi where he says: 'I do not count lineage for a youth / unless his lineage is in his deeds.' I have transferred this meaning to Ghazal, so I said about a beautiful one I saw in a window (taqa): 'I saw in a window a youth like the full moon / so I said who is under this fresh Ban tree (Bana)? / They said you judged while not seeing his stature / I said: I knew the branch by the fruit.'

He said: 'And the precious things of these necklaces are not revealed except by his breaths; their pearls are his word, and their strings are his paper.' Then he said: From this category is my saying also which is: 'Words like the flapping of banners and the roaring of lions, and meanings indicating by their sharpening that they are the swords and that hearts sheathing them are the scabbards, so the contemplator imagines them a clamor of stabbing or a race track.'
I say: He did not match in this joint upon the joint. For he likened them to the flapping of banners and the roaring of lions. So what entry is there in these two for 'a race track' afterwards, when horses were not mentioned? Proportion requires saying: 'A clamor of stabbing, a forest of lions, and a duel of knights.' Such descriptions are not in any speech, unless speech containing threat and reprimand or terrifying an enemy or what follows that course is described. Do you not see how excellent is the saying of Al-Buhturi: 'A blame with the tips of rhymes as if it is / a blame with the tips of broken spears.'

There is no harm in citing some of the speech of Al-Qadi Al-Fadil, may God have mercy on him, in describing incoming correspondence, so you may know, O standing upon these papers, how eulogy should be. Of that is his saying: 'His letter reached me so there reached me from it what reached me (or what connected me), and I knew of his rhetoric what was ignorant of me, and I drank from the sea of his speech what drank me and ate me, and I rose by it in rank although it brought me down from the back of speech. For they are wonders, the secret of rhetoric was not spread before them; and occurrences of a mind whose qualities were clear, so it is what ascended him and clarified him the occurrences; and strange things that became easy and abundant, so sometimes I say the boldness of a source (nab') and sometimes the flow of a spring (nabi'). It contained pearls except that they are words as Abu al-Tayyib said, and revived the living of longing except that as Abu Tammam said if he died from his preoccupation with separation he would not know. So I ransomed its hand having extended a shadow of script that almost shortens a shadow of luck. To God is its pen which grew long and exceeded, so it is as if the cut (of the nib) never diminished it.'

And his saying: 'I do not reckon pens were made prostrating except because his scroll is a prayer-niche (Mihrab), nor that they were named mute (khurs) except before our master blew into their panic the wonder of this correctness. Nor that they lay down in their inkwells except for what is blown into them of his spirit in their sleeping place. Nor did their heads turn black except because they are Abbasid flags which the Presence took with its hand. Inevitably they protect the sanctuary, shed blood and spare blood, and the rein is sash-wrapped with them, and he sends them so the knights know that in the book/writers (Kuttab) are knights. And the sermons (Khutaba) stand with what you wrote so tongues know that in hands, just as in mouths, is a tongue. I have wondered at these pens: their tongues are cut so they speak eloquently, and their noses are mutilated by sharpening so they come out sound/correct (Sahiha) and display a beautiful one (Maliha). They are but a sign in the white hand of our master, Mosaic (Musawiyya), and its material in eloquence is Alawid (Alawiyya), and were it not for exaggeration I would say Upper/Heavenly (Uluwwiyya).'

And his saying: 'If the magic of expression claimed that it fulfills the easiest of his rights, and bears fruit of what is obligated of thanks for his branches and roots, I would expose the falsehood of its magic, and make it taste the evil outcome of its affair, and crucify the magical thoughts on the trunks of pens, and tie their tongues as magic ties tongues from speech.'

And his saying: 'My noble (Karimi) letter in terms of attributing it to him, my Wounded/Spoken-to (Kalimi - ref Moses) in terms of attributing it to the white hand of his hands; my Messianic (Masihi) in terms that it revived the dead of intimacy; my Muhammadan (Muhammadi) in terms that it almost is, by what he blew into my panic, a Holy Spirit. So may I not lack his address which bestows upon days the day of Eid, and upon nights the night of the wedding. So may God keep him for the Arabic tongue, for were it not for him it would be cornered not narrated, driven away not stored. Were it not for him, its letters would have changed from their states, and Eloquence would have refused that the legs of letters be among its tools. Its standing Alif would sit, and its sleeping Ba would die, and the bending of the back of its Dal would increase until its cheek touches the dust and it lowers, and the teeth of its Sin would fall out until there remains no molar for it to bite on.'

And his saying: 'He stood upon it while thanks for the One who bestowed it was not stopping (waqif), rather it dripped (wakaf), and sought rain from it, the downpour of clouds, so it did not cut off for him nor hold back (kaff), and saw a structure of explanation (tibyan); if the competitors saw it, their building would be brought down from the foundations so the roof would fall upon them. To God is he of an eloquent one; if he speaks, speech with him is more abundant than the water of the eye on the day of separation (Bayn), and if another desires speech, it is less with him than the water of the Taff (Karbala) on the day of Hussein.'

And his saying in answer to a letter by Sheikh Taj al-Din al-Kindi: 'I thought him—and God realized the thought in him—to have ascended the causes (ropes to heaven) and taken the word from the drops and the paper from the clouds. I believed in the validity of his charm (ruqya), and verified his picking of stars when he brought them in brilliant and pure wording. I said to the group: The speech of the Crown (Taj) is the Crown (Taj) of speech, and kingship is in Kindah, and its pens were swords and its swords are now pens.'

And his saying: 'So I stood from it upon the vessel (zarf) of wit (zarf), and the masterpiece of the glance (tarf), and I almost worshipped him from it upon a letter (harf - also edge), and every letter is that letter. Were it not for my fear that Time would notice his place in my heart, and my fear that I define him by his good deed from him so I tempt it (Time) regarding it to lift the burdens of my war, I would have said a saying that lowers the first and last of this industry, and executed among them arrows that a rock of a face would not protect a poet from, nor a shield of armor a writer. They are nothing but signs (verses), each one bigger than its sister, and thoughts provided for on all Fridays if thoughts are given their provisions on their Sabbath.'

And his saying: 'Noble letters, their words almost smile, and their meanings speak. Their letters almost become pupils (anasi) for the eye of the traveler (masar), and their lines almost unveil brides having jewelry of vowels and scattering of dots.'

And his saying: 'A letter splendid (sani) of meanings, Sin-rhymed (Sini) of rhymes. It is the right of its Sin that Iqbal (approach/prosperity) be pure for it, for the Sin accompanies the verb and purifies it for the future (Istiqbal). This is a horizon where there is no flying except for the eagle and its son, and a sea in which there is no swimming except for one who brings pearls from his mouth and enters the sea in his sleeve. I did not mean by the sea here anything but his noble hand; as for the sea (ocean), I did not mean it.'

And his saying: 'The letters of the Assembly—may God refresh its heart and grant its nearness—cease not to be the weapons of his allies against Time if they fear its war. They comfort their hoper, and despair their competitor. The hearing becomes fertile by them, and benefit backs itself by them. Were it not that they change our characters against us and create envy in them, and bind our hands if we undertake competition with a rope of palm-fiber (masad).' 

And his saying: 'Our master, there is no expression (bayan) after his expression. Between his jaws is a sword, while between the jaws of every human is a tongue. So say, O his pens, for the blades in the scabbards have become mute. And strut, O Taghlib daughter of Wa'il, for preference has been given by the eloquent ones while they are coerced. And the confessor of his merit has succeeded, and he knew that the disbelievers (ungrateful) will not succeed.'

And his saying: 'He stood upon the Mim-rhyme (Mimiyya) so the flood (Tufan) of it circulated around him, and life from it was spirit and basil. It is of what a King dictated, if a devil dictates poetry. I wondered at the flow of those rhymes, and saw poets bring what they composed in the narrowness of valleys, while his mind and pen brought what they cast in the vast deserts (fyafi). Every verse of it is a Diwan, just as its sayer is a human ransomed by a thousand humans. Just as his pen is short, its nose was not mutilated except to take the revenge of the pen from the spearhead.'

I say: Mentioning the 'Fyafi' (deserts) in the saying of Al-Qadi Al-Fadil, and the beautiful pun he composed in this rhyme: I had written to our Sheikh Hafiz Fath al-Din Muhammad ibn Sayyid al-Nas some verses, and he answered me with verse and prose. Among the prose: 'Nay, that is the lawful healing magic. Nay, those powers (quwa) in the rhymes (qawafi). Nay, those intents (maqasid) that killed (aqsadat) desires in the exiles (manafi).' So I wrote the answer to him, and from it: 'He devoted himself from it to the Kaaba of Rhetoric, so how beautiful is what he spread in my greeting (istilami) and folded in my circumambulation (tawafi). The bird of the heart wanted to rise with the answer, but the strength went from the primaries (qawadim), and hunger (khawa) appeared in the coverts (khawafi).' Returning to the speech of Al-Fadil.

And his saying: 'But the unarmed (A'zal) Simak star withdrew from people, and the people of the high degrees rose and the people of the low level fell. People wasted arrows and you hit the kill-spot with one of them. You are the Thrower (Rami) and other than you is the loving/seeking one (Ra'im). You are the Protector (Hami) and other than you is the hovering one (Ha'im). Your letters are flowers and your books are calyxes. Your pen is the waterer and your thoughts are the clouds. Your saying is held stingily and highly valued. If you said: O horses of pens, ride! you filled the earth with neighing and assault. Meanings rushed to you light and heavy, and announced Hajj among them to consciences on every lean mount and on foot. You are the present one and the unseen is presence. You are the Master and other than you is the chaste/concealed (Hasur). Ears are inclined (Suwar) to what you say in Damascus. If you struck water, sparks would fly; and if you neighbored the rose of the cheek, you would be a neighbor to the violet of the whiskers.'

And his saying: 'To God is he of a book like a Surah, every verse (Sign) in it is a prostration (Sajda). He met it with humility as if the pen of the writer is the Rod (of Moses) and his paper is the Cloak.'

And his saying: 'These books are but battalions, and these letters are but sharp swords. The lines in them are but boats, and the breath from them is but dust revealing the morning, the revealing of darkness.'

And his saying: 'As if its pen was stored for the kingdom weaving its brocade, and a jeweler creating its ornaments. As if it is a prince and speech is its subjects, so it disposes its command and prohibition. As if God Glory be to Him deposited in its mind a cloud and its book a garden, making the pen its water-wheel and the inkwell its pool.'

And his saying: 'I was relieved when I drew water—despite the distance of my land—from his cloud, and sheltered the dome of inkwells from his pains with his hair (limamih). He returned the time of Rama to me as it is with its gazelles (aramih), and rose upon me the risings of crescents—are they anything but the clippings (qulama) of his pens (aqlamih)?'

Let this be the last of what I cite for Al-Qadi Al-Fadil of this type, although that is a drop from a basin, and a flower from a garden.

**Suitability of Word to Meaning**
He said in a chapter after what passed: 'Two pens of calligraphy were attached to our master, one attributed to ink (midad), and the other attributed to spears (si'ad).'
I say: As for attributing the pen to ink, it is permissible. As for attributing the other to spears (si'ad), I do not know what it is. For 'Si'ad' are spears that grow straight and do not need straightening. So attributing spears to Si'ad, or Si'ad to spears is of the category of attributing a thing to itself, which is not permissible. Spears are only attributed to flags, or spearheads, or stabbing, just as pens are attributed to ink and writing.

He said: From that is what I mentioned in describing the pen, so I said: 'God inspired his pen what He inspired the bees, except that they shelter in the rugged place and it shelters in the easy place. It is of its nature to gather from fruits having souls, not having sleeves/calyxes (akmam), and it brings out from its spittle a drink of different taste in which is healing for understandings.'
I say: His saying 'fruits having souls not having sleeves' is not appropriate, since proportion requires saying: 'having souls not having bodies' or 'having shawls (tayalis) not having sleeves', to match between soul and body, and shawl and sleeve. Then attributing soul to fruit is a matter outside of custom, and it has not been heard of fruit having a soul and fruit not having a soul. If exaggeration in describing the fruit is intended, it is said it is congealed water or embodied air. How excellent is the saying of Abu al-Tayyib: 'It has fruit indicating to you from it / drinks standing without vessels.'

**Wording and Composition**
He said in the first section of the first essay: Likewise His Almighty's saying occurred: 'Verily this is my brother, he has ninety-nine ewes, and I have one ewe (li na'jah wahidah).' The word 'li' (for me/I have) is like the word 'tu'dhi' (harming) and it came in the verse integrated, related to what is after it. If it comes cut off, it does not come fitting, like the saying of Abu al-Tayyib: 'Wishes end up defeated short of his demand / so he does not say to a thing: would that that were mine (layta dhalika li).'
I say: What did he deny of this word? What he mentioned is but a mere claim. This word 'li' has fallen firmly placed. The rhyme, if it comes firmly placed, is of good composition and sweet flow. As for the word 'tu'dhi' in his saying: 'Manhood is sweet to him while it harms (tu'dhi),' it came weak, unlike 'li' in the mentioned verse. This is not criticized in this verse, unless the word 'bi' (with me/in me) is criticized in his saying: 'I visit them while the blackness of night intercedes for me (li) / and I turn back while the whiteness of morning incites against me (bi).' I have not seen anyone who criticized this verse or this rhyme; rather it is counted among the beauties unique to Abu al-Tayyib, because of the correspondence of five to five in it. This number did not happen for another. Likewise the word 'tu'dhi' which he criticized, if it fell as a rhyme firmly placed, would not be criticized. How excellent is the saying of Sheikh Majd al-Din ibn al-Zahir al-Irbili: 'My heart and my glance, this flows blood and that / is short of creation, You are All-Knowing of its wound (qarhih) / They are two witnesses to Your love, but / the modification (ta'dil - legal credibility) of each is in its wounding (jarhih) / The heart is Your old dwelling, so if You find / in it other than You of creation, then remove him (nahhih).' Look at this third rhyme, how sweet and firmly placed; no other stands in its place. If it fell in other than the rhyme, it would not have this sweetness and mastery. Likewise the word 'li' in Abu al-Tayyib's saying. Of this mastery in rhyme is the saying of Ibn Abi Hilal al-Qayrawani from verses: 'He guides to highness, so there is no traveler / the roads of highness except he was his guide (dalilah) / He surpassed creation in merit until if / it was said who is the unique one of creation? It would be said: It is he (huwah).' How excellent is Al-Qadi Al-Fadil's use, may God have mercy on him, of the word 'li' in rhyme where he said: 'I praised the People of the House (Ahl al-Bayt) among you with what / men bore witness that that verse (Bayt) is mine (li).'

**Is Surah Al-Najm rhymed on the letter Ya?**
He said in this section: The talk digressed to His Almighty's saying: 'That, then, is an unfair division (qismatun diza).' That Surah Al-Najm is rhymed on the letter Ya.
I say: Consideration in the heads of verses (qara'in) and rhymes is not by the written form, but by the pronunciation. The Surah is rhymed on the Alif Maqsura. But he was deceived by the drawing of the verse heads with Ya, looking at the origin of the word. No one says that 'sughra' and 'kubra' and 'diza' and 'ma'wa' and 'muntaha' and the like, if occurring in verse heads or poetic rhyme, are on the letter Ya. Rather, all that is of the category of Alif Maqsura like 'hubla' and 'dunya'. It was only written with Ya looking at the origin of the word being from those with Ya. For you say: Al-Ma'wa from 'awaytu', and Al-Muntaha from 'intahaytu', and Hawa from 'hawaytu', and Ghawa from 'ghawaytu'. If the origin of the word is Waw, it is written with Alif. Like 'dunya' because it is from 'danawtu', and 'raja' from 'rajawtu' in one of the two views. Some claimed that is to avoid combining two likes. I do not think Ibn al-Athir, may God have mercy on him, was ignorant of this, but it is negligence, nothing else.

'They are two witnesses to your love, but / the credibility of each lies in its wounding / The heart is your old home, so if you find / anyone other than yourself in it among creation, remove him.' Look at this third rhyme (nahhih - remove him), how sweet and firmly placed it is; no other word could stand in its place. If it had fallen elsewhere than in the rhyme, it would not have had this sweetness and mastery. The same applies to the word 'li' (mine/for me) in the saying of Abu al-Tayyib. Of this mastery in rhyme is the saying of Ibn Abi Hilal al-Qayrawani in verses: 'He guides to the heights, so there is no traveler / of the paths of highness unless he was his guide / He surpassed creation in merit until, verily / if it were said: Who is the unique one of creation? It would be said: It is He (Huwah).'
