How excellent is the usage of Al-Qadi Al-Fadil, may God have mercy on him, of the word 'li' in the rhyme where he said: 'And I praised the People of the House among you with that which / men testified that that verse (house/bayt) is mine (li).'

**Is Surah Al-Najm rhymed on the letter Ya?**
He said in this section, having digressed to His Almighty's saying: 'That, then, is an unfair division (diza)': That Surah Al-Najm is rhymed on the letter Ya.
I say: Consideration regarding the heads of verses and rhymes lies not in the script, but in the pronunciation. The Surah is rhymed on the Alif Maqsura. However, he was deceived by the drawing of the verse-heads with 'Ya' in view of the origin of the word. No one says that 'sughra', 'kubra', 'diza', 'ma'wa', 'muntaha', and the like, if occurring in verse-heads or poetic rhyme, are on the letter Ya. Rather, all of that is of the category of Alif Maqsura like 'hubla' and 'dunya'. It was written with Ya only in view of the word's origin being from roots with Ya. For you say: Al-Ma'wa from 'awaytu', and Al-Muntaha from 'intahaytu', and Hawa from 'hawaytu', and Ghawa from 'ghawaytu'. If the origin of the word is Waw, it is written with Alif, like 'dunya' because it is from 'danawtu', and 'raja' from 'rajawtu' in one of the two opinions. Some claimed that [the spelling] is to dislike combining two likes. I do not think Ibn al-Athir, may God have mercy on him, was ignorant of this, but it is negligence and nothing else.

**Appropriateness of Word to Meaning and Models of Ibn Nubata's Sermons**
He said also in this section, citing the saying of Al-Farazdaq: 'Were it not for shyness, I would have increased your head with a wound / which, if probed, its sides would remain boiling / A shaggy (sharanbatha), gray-haired woman; whoever sees what is in her / resembles [her], even between the five-span stature and the child.' He said: 'Sharanbatha' is among the words whose usage is permissible in poetry, and it is not detestable here, except that if it appeared in prose speech of a letter or sermon, that would be criticized in its user.
I say: A few lines before this, he cited the saying of Ta'abbata Sharra: 'He remains in a wasteland and spends the evening in another / lonely (jahishan) and riding bareback the backs of the paths.' He said: The word 'jahishan' is of the objectionable, ugly words. It is said to him: Glory be to God, the time is not old (i.e., you just said it), your statement contradicted itself in one page. I see that 'jahishan' is lighter on the hearing than 'sharanbatha'. If this 'sharanbatha' appeared in the Nile it would muddy it, and turn its sweet Euphrates water to salty bitter and change it. If it were a mole on the cheek of the sun it would uglify it, and cancel its beauties which illuminated the days and adorned them.

He said: It appeared in the sermons of Sheikh Al-Khatib Ibn Nubata, like his saying in a sermon mentioning the terrors of Resurrection: 'Its evil intensified (iqmatarra) and its punishment rose high (ishmakharra), so it was neither pleasant nor palatable.'
I say: Al-Khatib, may God have mercy on him, is among the eloquent rhetoricians who place speech in its proper places and give every station what it deserves. Because mentioning the Fire and the Resurrection is a terrifying matter and requires grandiose words that horrify the hearing, make tears flow, make skins shiver, and break livers. Nothing fits the descriptions of the Fire other than these words like: iqmatarra (intensified), ishmakharra (rose high), isbatarra (extended), izba'arra (bristled), ikfaharra (became dark/grim), iqsha'arra (shuddered), ibdha'arra (panicked), itlakhmma (became murky), idlahamma (became dark), iqtahama (intruded), and ihtadama (raged).

**Topics and Words**
Just as descriptions of Paradise have words specific to them, sweet, easy, and delightful to the hearing. Like: its breeze softened, its bliss lasted, its shade fluttered, its cool water cleared, and its Tasnim (fountain) was sweet. Do you not see that Praise (Madih) has words specific to it, and Satire (Hija') has words specific to it? So the head (ra's) and the parting of hair (farq) are mentioned in praise, while the brain (dimagh) and the back of the neck (qadhal) are mentioned in satire. Abu Zubayd al-Ta'i's description of the lion in the presence of the Companions in the assembly of Uthman, may God be pleased with him, supports this speech. Among what he said was:

'For his mucus membranes there is a snoring sound, for his chest a wheezing, for his glance a flash, and for his wrists a cracking sound. It is as if he treads on dry stalks or steps on severed trees. Suddenly, a head like a shield, a cheek like a whetstone, and two red-hot eyes as if they are two lamps being lit. A neck thick and fleshy, a dewlap flabby, withers high like a saddle-frame, a chest broad and hairless, a humerus twisted, a forearm strong, and a hand rough of claws leading to talons like hooks. He struck with his hand and raised dust, bared his teeth and revealed fangs like pickaxes, polished not blunt, and a wide mouth like a piercing cave. Then he stretched and pointed with his hands, then spurred his hips with his legs until his length became double. Then he sat on his hind legs and shuddered, then stood and frowned, then scowled and bristled. By the One whose House is in the sky, we did not fear him except for the first brother of ours from Fazara, huge of slaughter-build. He (the lion) broke his neck then killed him on the spot, then shook him a shake that crushed his back and ripped his belly, and began lapping his blood. I incited my companions, but after hesitation they advanced, so we yelled at him. He attacked, shuddering with a mane as if it were a yearling porcupine, and snatched a man from among us, thick and pot-bellied, then shook him a shake that caused his joints to separate. Then he growled and rumbled, then exhaled and babbled, then roared and gargled, then glanced. By God, I imagined lightning flying from under his eyelids to his left and right. Hands trembled, legs knocked together, ribs creaked, ears buzzed, backs touched (in fear), eyes stared, thoughts worsened, and backs slumped. Then he strutted and circled, then stared and gazed sharply. Behold, he had red-hot eyes like the glow of sparks, as if they were chipped by chisels from the side of a stone. His color is rosy, his roar is thunder, his forehead is great, and his head is grim. If you faced him you would say he is armored, and if you turned your back you would say he is restraining. When the night darkens, he seeks and senses. His terror is severe, his evil is stubborn, and his good is distant. When he divides, he oppresses; when he duels, he smashes; when he attains, he acts unjustly.' Then he recited:
'Frowning, stubborn, proud, arrogant / Bold against enemies, a conqueror of the peer / His claws are rough and his eyes in the darkness / are like the ember of Ghadha wood, evil flying in his face / He indicates with sharp fangs, as if they are / daggers when the wide mouth retracts from them.'
The narrator said: One of those present broke wind. Uthman, may God be pleased with him, said to him: 'Hush, may God break your mouth, for you have terrified the Muslims.'
Look at these words and their impact on the soul; they are like lions devouring or snakes swallowing. Is it appropriate for any of them to be in the description of a gazelle or a peacock? No. I wonder at him that the like of this was hidden from him.

**Appropriateness of Word to Rhyme (Saj')**
He said in the first type regarding Rhymed Prose (Saj'): From that is what I wrote in answer to a letter concerning the running away of a slave boy. I said: 'As for the noble indication regarding the matter of the slave boy escaping from service, the foal (muhr) may flee from his fodder, and the moth may fly into his fire.'
I say: As for the moth, it is not appropriate to say about it: 'It *may* (qad) fly into its fire.' For 'qad' here is for minimization (taqlil), like 'The steed may stumble.' As he said: 'And the foal may flee from his fodder.' As for the moth, it does not see fire except it throws itself into it. This is the norm. It is not so for the foal, for the norm in its case is that if it sees fodder it comes to it, and rarely does it flee from it. Abu al-Ala al-Ma'arri said describing a lion: 'He appeared, so he called the moth with his eyes / just as the two kindlers of darkness call it.'

**Discussion on a meaning Ibn al-Athir erred in within his composition**
As for coordinating affirmation with negation, it is not permissible in the like of this. It is better to say: 'The foal may flee from his fodder, and the man may distance himself from his brother.'
He said, mentioning the investiture (taqlid) he cited in opposition to Al-Sabi regarding the Syndicate of Ashraaf: 'After this (Amma ba'd), every speech that is not begun with the praise of God is cut off (ajdham), and every book not marked with His name is not known (mu'lam). Based on this, His praise descends in speech to the station of limbs in the body, and His name descends in the book to the station of embroidery in clothes. We have combined in this book of ours between Naming (Basmala) and Praising (Hamdala), and made one of them a key for blessing and the other a cause for increase. Then We followed them with prayer (Salat) upon our Master Muhammad whom God supported with the Glorious Quran, and made his testimony before every witness, and upon his family and companions who were guided to the good of speech, and guided to a praiseworthy path.'

**Return to Beginning with Praise**

I say: He claimed that he praised God and mentioned His name, and prayed upon the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and upon his family. Yet, no praising issued from him, nor mention of God's name—unless it was in the beginning of the investiture 'In the name of God the Most Gracious the Most Merciful'—nor prayer. Because if you say 'Praising God is obligatory, and mentioning His name is desirable, and praying upon His Messenger and upon his family and companions is designated,' you have not performed praise, nor mentioning of the name, nor prayer. You only informed about the praise being obligatory, the mention being desirable, and the prayer being designated. Similar to this is if you said: 'Glory be to God the number of birds' feathers, and Praise be to God the number of ocean waves,' you have not brought a glorification and praise equivalent to those two numbers and equal to them. The meaning of this is from your saying: 'God deserves of praises and glorification the number of that.' The like of these things must be guarded against, otherwise there is room for challenging him.

**Divisions of Tasri' (Internal Rhyme in the first verse)**
He said, having mentioned Tasri' and divided it into seven sections: He made the first [rank] what each hemistich is independent in itself, and exemplified it by the saying of Imru' al-Qais: 'Afatim mahlan ba'da hadha at-tadalluli...' (O Fatima, gently, some of this coquetry...) the verse. He made the second rank that the first hemistich be independent in itself not needing the one following it, but if the one following it comes, it is linked to it. He exemplified it with the saying of Imru' al-Qais: 'Qifa nabki min dhikra habibin wa manzili...' (Halt, let us weep from the memory of a lover and a dwelling...) the verse. He made the third rank that the poet is chosen to place each hemistich in the place of its brother. He exemplified it with the saying of Ibn Hajjaj al-Baghdadi: 'Min shurut al-sabuh fi al-mahrajan / khiffat al-shurb ma' khuluww al-makan' (Among the conditions of the morning drink in the festival / is lightness of the drink with the emptiness of the place). For this verse, its first hemistich can be made second, and its second hemistich first. This is like the second rank in quality.

I say: This third rank is more worthy to be the first than the first he mentioned, because the like of this type is rarer than the first, and in it is an indication of the poet's mastery and the quality of his nature. Of this has come from Al-Ghazzi: 'Lawla tadhakkur ma taqadama 'ahduhu / ma raja'a al-qalba al-mudallaha wajduhu' (Were it not for remembering what its time has passed / his passion would not have returned to the bewildered heart). And likewise his saying also: 'Dhahaba al-siba fa-tanaqqabi aw fa-isfiri / la hazza fiki li-dhi qadhalin musfiri' (Youth has gone, so veil or unveil / there is no luck in you for one of bared graying head). And for Ibn Qalaqis al-Iskandari: 'Al-haya min ghuyuthik al-bariqat / wal-jana min usulik al-basiqat' (Rain is from your flashing clouds / and harvest is from your tall roots). And likewise his saying also: 'Addid wa da' dhikr al-tasabi 'addid / ya ghafilan 'amma yarahu fi al-ghad' (Count and leave the mention of youthful passion, count / O one heedless of what he sees in the morrow). And for Ibn al-Sa'ati: 'Ma kuntu bil-baki wala al-mutabaki / lawla waqa'i' tarfik al-fattaki' (I would not be crying nor feigning crying / were it not for the battles of your lethal glance). And likewise his saying also: 'Billahi ya rusul al-riyah / kayfa al-sabil ila janah' (By God, O messengers of the winds / how is the way to a wing/Janah?). Do you not see that every verse of these verses contains what is in the one he made first and an increase? So it is more worthy of precedence. It is conditioned in it that every hemistich of it be independent in itself, not needing the other, with the possibility of making the beginning an end and the end a beginning. Ibn Abi al-Hadid critiqued him in the division of Tasri' in his book but did not notice this.

**His discussion on Jinas (Paronomasia/Pun)**
He said regarding Jinas: The second section of what resembles Jinas is that the words be equal in weight, different in composition by one letter only. Then he exemplified it with His Almighty's saying: 'Wujuhun yawma'idhin nadirah, ila rabbiha nazirah' (Faces that day will be radiant, looking at their Lord). And he exemplified with His Almighty's saying: 'Wa hum yanhawna 'anhu wa yan'awna 'anhu' (And they forbid it and distance themselves from it). Then he said: And in a manner like this occurred his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: 'Al-Khayl ma'qud bi-nawasiha al-Khayr' (Horses, goodness is tied to their forelocks). And the saying of Abu Tammam: 'Yamudduna min aydin 'awasin 'awasim / tasulu bi-asyafin qawadin qawadib' (They extend resisting, protecting hands / attacking with destroying, cutting swords). And the saying of Al-Buhturi: 'Min kulli saji al-tarf aghyada ajyada / wa muhafhaf al-kashhayn ahwa ahwar' (Of every languid-eyed, soft-necked, long-necked one / and slim-waisted, dark-lipped, intense-black-eyed one). Then he said: Likewise his saying: 'Shawajir armahin tuqatti' baynaha / shawajir arhamin malumin qatu'uha' (Intersecting spears cutting between them / intersecting wombs (kinship) whose cutter is blamed).

I say: He started the division by stating the words must be equal in weight and different in composition by *one letter*. Nothing of the examples he mentioned holds true to this except His Almighty's saying: 'Wa hum yanhawna 'anhu' the verse, and His Almighty's saying: 'Wujuhun yawma'idhin nadirah' the verse, and the Hadith he mentioned. As for ''awasin' and ''awasim', and 'qawadin' and 'qawadib', one of the two words exceeded the other by a letter and did not just differ. Likewise 'arham' and 'armah', one word differed from the other by two letters in order/arrangement. So what he stipulated was missed, and this has no entry into what he mentioned. Ibn Abi al-Hadid raised objections against him in Jinas regarding things but did not notice this. Ibn al-Athir confused matters in Jinas greatly and did not improve its arrangement.

I have written a book on that and named it 'Jinan al-Jinas' (The Gardens of Puns), in which I divided Jinas into what division was possible, coming to nearly sixty sections. Whoever wants the editing of Jinas in its sections, let him stand upon it there.

**Reversed Jinas (Al-Jinas Al-Ma'kus)**
He said: The fourth section of what resembles Jinas is called the Reversed (Al-Ma'kus). Then he cited: 'Adat al-sadat sadat al-'adat' (The habits of masters are the masters of habits), and 'Shiyam al-ahrar ahrar al-shiyam' (The characters of the free are the free-est of characters), and what resembles that, and cited many things for himself and others.

I say: This type has no entry into the chapter of Jinas. It is from the chapter of 'Returning the ends to the beginnings' (Radd al-a'jaz 'ala al-sudur), which is a chapter independent in itself. Among the best that came in it is his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: 'Jar al-dar ahaqqu bi-dar al-jar' (The neighbor of the house is more entitled to the house of the neighbor). And the saying of Al-Arjani: 'Shibtu ana wa iltaha habibi / hatta bi-raghmi salawtu 'anhu / ibyadda dhaka al-sawad minni / wa iswadda dhaka al-bayad minhu' (I turned gray and my beloved grew a beard / until against my will I found solace from him / That blackness turned white from me / and that whiteness turned black from him). And the saying of Afif al-Din al-Tilimsani, which has extra craftsmanship: 'Ya bi-abi ma'atif wa a'yun / yasulu minha ramih wa nabil / fa-hadhihi dhawabil nawadir / wa hadhihi nawazir dhawabil' (Oh, may my father be ransomed for curves and eyes / from which attack a lancer and an archer / For these are lean [spears] that are fresh / and these are looks that are lean/languid). Do you not see that 'dhawabil' and 'nawadir' in the first are other than 'dhawabil' and 'nawazir' in the second? If Ibn al-Athir counted the like of this in the chapter of Jinas, that would be a correct statement. For the words agreed and the meanings differed. Among what I said regarding that: 'Ada'a nuski 'idhar misk / fa-kayfa tarki lihaz turki / tanka siham al-jufun minhu / wa muqlati la tazal tabki / qada 'ala admu'i bi-safkin / yaqdi biha fi dami bi-safki / wa shakka qalbi bi-rumh qaddin / qadda fu'adi bi-ghayr shakki' (A musk-like cheek-hair wasted my piety / so how can I leave the glance of my Turk? / The arrows of eyelids hurt from him / and my eye ceases not to weep / He decreed shedding for my tears / judging by them regarding my blood with shedding / And he pierced my heart with the spear of a figure / that cut my heart without doubt). So 'Shakk' (pierced) and 'Qadd' (figure) in the first are other than 'Shakk' (doubt) and 'Qadd' (cut) in the second. Among what I composed in a pattern other than this: 'Qad faqa ghusn al-naqa habibi / wa akhjal al-badr fi al-tamam / dhaka qawam bi-la muhayya / wa dha muhayya bi-la qawam' (My beloved surpassed the branch of the sandy hill / and shamed the full moon in perfection / That is a stature without a face / and this is a face without a stature). It is said: A petition was raised to Al-Qadi Al-Fadil with the name of two muezzins to be employed, one named Murtada and the other Ziyada. He wrote upon it: 'Amma Ziyada fa-Murtada, wa amma Murtada fa-ziyada' (As for Ziyada, he is accepted/Murtada; and as for Murtada, he is excess/Ziyada). So he employed Ziyada and dismissed Murtada. This is the ultimate in beauty.

**The 'Shielded' Jinas (Al-Jinas Al-Mujannab)**
He said in the fifth section resembling Jinas, called Al-Mujannab. Then he began citing evidence for that with the poet's saying: 'Aba al-Abbas la tahsab bi-anni / li-shaybi min hula al-ash'ar 'ari / fa-li tab'un ka-salsalin ma'inin / zulalin min dhura al-ahjar jari / idha ma akat al-adwar zandan / fa-li zandun 'ala al-adwar wari' (O Abu al-Abbas, do not think that I / due to my gray hair am naked of the ornaments of poetry / For I have a nature like flowing fresh water / pure, running from the peaks of stones / If cycles blunt a fire-stick / I have a fire-stick striking fire upon the cycles). Then he said: This section has a point of view for me, because it is closer to 'Luzum ma la yalzam' (Requiring what is not required) than to Jinas. He began to explain that with things he was arbitrary in.

I say: The correct view is that this is one of the sections of Jinas. It is the type called 'Al-Muzdawij' (The Paired). 'Requiring what is not required' is a chapter tied to itself, having no entry in this, nor this in it. For 'Luzum' is that the poet or writer brings in the rhyme a letter or more before the rhyme letter (Rawi), committing to the occurrence of that in every rhyme. As occurred in Al-Ma'arri's saying: 'La tatlubanna bi-alatin laka rutbatan / qalam al-baligh bi-ghayr hazzin mighzal / sakana al-simakan al-sama' kilahuma / hadha lahu rumhun wa hadha a'zal' (Do not seek a rank by a tool you have / the pen of the eloquent without luck is a spindle / The two Simak stars inhabited the sky, both of them / this one has a spear and this one is unarmed). For Al-Ma'arri committed to the Zay before the Rawi which is the Lam. If he had said with that: 'mu'awwal', 'awwal', and 'afdal', the rhyme would be valid, but the occurrence of the Zay is 'Requiring what is not required'. And as you say: Al-Hamam, Al-Ghamam, Al-Tamam, Al-Kamam. Or: Al-Budur, Al-Sudur, or Al-Shudhur, Al-Nudhur. For the Mim, Dal, and Dhal are 'Requiring what is not required'. It is permissible that you say with Al-Hamam: Al-Salam; and with Al-Budur: Al-Qubur; and with Al-Shudhur: Al-Harur. On this condition Al-Ma'arri built his 'Luzumiyyat' from beginning to end. As for what Ibn al-Athir cited, it was not so, because before the first Alif is 'Ayn, the second Jim, and the third Waw. So the Luzum is missed. Of what happened to me on the pattern of Abu al-Fath al-Busti: 'Tadhakkartu 'ayshan marra hulwan bikum fa-hal / li-ayyamina tilka al-dhawahib wahib / wa ma insarafat amal nafsi li-ghayrikum / wa la ana 'an hadhi al-ragha'ib gha'ib / sa-asbiru karhan fi al-hawa ghayr ta'i'in / la'alla zamani bi-al-haba'ib ayib' (I remembered a life that passed sweet with you, so is there / for those days of ours gone a giver? / My soul's hopes did not turn to other than you / nor am I from these desires absent / I will be patient unwillingly in love, not obedient / perhaps my time with the loved ones is returning). And I said also: 'Bi-nafsi man idha iddakara ikti'abi / wa anni la ara al-awzar zara / yabit wa lil-tuqa haras 'alayhi / wa li fa-idha ra'a al-ashar hara' (By my soul is one who, if he remembers my depression / and that I do not see the burdens, he visits / He spends the night while piety has a guard on him / and I [spend it], so if he sees the magic times, he is bewildered).

'Wa li qalbun idha iddakara al-zaman al / ladhi nilna bihi al-awtar tara' (And I have a heart that if it remembers the time / in which we attained desires, it flies). And I said also: 'In anta asbahta rabba amrin / fa-la tu'irhu libas bas / wa in tamadat bika al-amani / la tu'irha min qiyas yas' (If you become the master of a matter / do not lend it the clothing of misery / And if wishes go far with you / do not lend them the measure of despair).

**Requiring What is Not Required (Luzum Ma La Yalzam)**
He said in the fourth type regarding 'Luzum ma la yalzam': From that is what I mentioned in the midst of a letter containing the blame of a coward, so I said: 'If a calamity befalls him, fright possesses him (malakahu al-faraq), and if he goes astray in a matter he does not believe/feel safe unless drowning overtakes him (adrakahu al-gharaq).'
I say: In the second rhyme there is a lack of correspondence (mutabaqa). Misguidance (Dalal) is only opposed by Guidance (Huda), and Faith/Safety (Iman) is only opposed by Disbelief/Fear (Kufr). It should be said in that: 'If he denies a blessing he does not believe, and if he strays in a matter he is not guided.' This is among the counted defects. Abu al-Tayyib was criticized for his saying: 'Nazartu ila al-ladhina ara mulukan / ka-annaka mustaqimun fi mahal' (I looked at those I consider kings / as if you are straight in an absurdity/impossibility). This was in the presence of Sayf al-Dawla. It was said to him: Straight is only opposed by Crooked, and the craft requires you to say: 'As if you are straight in crookedness.' Sayf al-Dawla said to him: 'If the rhyme was ending in Jim, how would you have done in the second verse?' Abu al-Tayyib said without hesitation: 'I would say: Fa-in tufuq al-anam wa anta minhum / fa-inna al-misk ba'd dam al-dajaj (If you surpass people while being of them / then musk is some of the blood of chickens).' His quick wit was admired. However, this happened to Al-Mutanabbi often in his poetry. Of that is his saying: 'Wa li-kull 'ayn qurratun fi qurbihi / hatta ka-anna maghibahu al-aqdha' (Every eye has coolness in his nearness / until as if his absence is specks/motes). Coolness is only opposed by heat/warmth, and the speck is opposed by clearing/polishing. And his saying: 'Wa lam ya'zum li-naqsin kana fihi / wa lam yazal al-amir wa lan yazala' (He did not become great due to a deficiency that was in him / and the Prince ceased not nor will cease). Greatness is opposed by insignificance, and deficiency is opposed by completeness or perfection. And his saying: 'Wa innahu al-mushir 'alayka fi bi-dallatin / fa-al-hurr mumtahan bi-awlad al-zina' (And he is the one advising you in error / for the freeborn is tested by the sons of adultery). The freeborn is opposed by the slave/mean. Although interpretation is possible for Abu al-Tayyib in these and their likes, it is better for them to be as I mentioned. This type is frequent in his poetry.

**Discussion on a meaning Ibn al-Athir erred in within his composition**
As for Ibn al-Athir, may God Almighty have mercy on him, bringing two rhymes whose Luzum (constraint) is of the lightest possible, and counting them as Luzum and citing them in his book from his speech—this is strange. Even if the whole letter from beginning to end was with the Luzum of Ra before Qaf, it would not be a big deal. Did he not see the book 'Al-Luzumiyyat' by Abu al-Ala, which is a large volume composed on the letters of the alphabet? Did he not see the 'Maqamat al-Tamimiyyah', which are fifty Maqamas composed by Al-Saraqusti, constrained (malzumah) from beginning to end? Sheikh Sharaf al-Din Abd al-Aziz, Sheikh of the Sheikhs, has collected a good part of his poetry in the chapter of Luzum, bringing in it the meters of Prosody and their variations, and the poetry is the ultimate in beauty, subtlety of composition, quality of meanings, and delicacy of words. Of that is his saying: 'Mutayyam wadda fi 'aynayhi law khaba'ak / madha yadiruka law 'arraftahu naba'ak / in aththarat muqlati fi wajnatayka fa-qad / naka'ta qalbi biha ad'af ma naka'ak / admayta khaddayka idh admayta li kabidi / ansif wa qul li tura bi-al-sharri man bada'ak' (An enslaved lover wished he could hide you in his eyes / what would harm you if you informed him of your news? / If my eye left a mark on your cheeks, then / you have reopened the wound of my heart with them double what it wounded you / You bled your cheeks when you bled my liver for me / be fair and tell me, do you see who began with evil?). From it: 'Qad qultu lil-sajf lamma an hujibta bihi / ya sajf laytaka qad akhfayta li rasha'ak / wa ya munamnam khatti 'aridayhi la-qad / qara'ka muhjatahu al-'ani wa ma qara'ak / wa anta ya man yusamini ila sharafi / laqad wasi'ta idhan ad'afa ma mala'ak / hadha wa sarhuka yar'a fi hima kala'i / fa-la ra'a sarhaka al-Bari wa la kala'ak / qul ma bada laka min lu'min li-dhi karamin / fa-law nabahta tuwal al-dahr ma khasa'ak' (I said to the curtain when you were veiled by it / O curtain, would that you hid my fawn for me / O decorated one of the script of his whiskers, indeed / the suffering one read his soul to you while he did not read you / And you, O one who rivals me in my honor / you have contained then double what filled you / This, while your flock grazes in the sanctuary of my pasture / so may the Creator not tend your flock nor protect you / Say what appears to you of meanness to one of generosity / for even if you barked all time, he would not shoo you away). Look at the subtlety of this composition and its flow, and these rhymes and their firmness in their places. How sweet they are in their locations! If you isolated them from their composition, they would not have this beauty. How strong is their composition in their structure itself, yet they are not, in isolation, sweet to the hearing. Here the ability of the composer appears. How sweet is his saying: 'So may the Creator not tend your flock nor protect you.' Then Ibn al-Athir, may God have mercy on him, cited after those two rhymes something else from his speech, rhyme by rhyme also, like: 'babih wa ighbabih', 'ardan wa ardan', 'anzaltuhu wa hawwaltuhu', 'atrafiha wa atrafiha', 'suknah wa yumnah'. That is not of the rare beauty. As came in the speech of Al-Qadi Al-Fadil, may God Almighty have mercy on him, in his saying: 'And the favoring (in'am) which is the reality (haqiqa) and what is other than it is metaphor (majaz); and the merit (fadl) and decision (fasl) which arrived with elaboration (ishab) and brevity (ijaz); and the beautiful deed immortalizing mention, for it is the fulfillment (tanjiz) of the promise of immortality even if metaphor (injaz - poetic license/metaphor) is permitted in it.'

And in his saying: 'I knew favoring by the robes of honor (khila'), and whoever guarantees in the stations of debate the folding of its tongue (tayy lisan), the Kingdom guarantees for him that he struts in its shawl (taylasan), and settles him from the blackness of robes in the robe of its pupil (insan).' And in his saying describing a night: 'In a night like the waves of the sea, having stars like the bubbles of the river (nahr), and it has gathered worries and mobilized (hashad) them, and guided their strays and recited (anshad) them. So I say when it stretches its back (sulb): May God cut your back (sulb), and when will I see the pillar of dawn while God has hastened crucifixion (salb) upon it.' And in his saying: 'I ascended the peak of forty and did not leave the peak of twenty, and said to the soul: Nissan (April) made me forget what Tishrin (October/November) is to Tishrin.' And in his saying: 'His saying made me lonely: I sent the letter seeking and asking permission (musta'dhina), and how do you see regarding a group I sought with rights for our master (ustadhina); and I found the wind of his letter and the spirit of his nearness, so we returned to the custom ('adah) and our days returned ('adat), and we turned to the best and our speech softened, and we revisited desires (muna) and they did not cross the mind, and if they crossed, they are all wishful thinking (kullu muna).' Such is Luzum when beautiful, and such are the eloquent tongued, not what Ibn al-Athir brought of bad dates (hashaf), and drove of the lean which the hearing rejected and did not sip. 

I happened to compose verses with double rhyme (thuna), there is no harm in establishing some of them here. I said: 'Ad'uka ya mujid al-ashya' min 'adami / wa sani' al-'alam al-'ulwi wa al-ardi / in kunta ta'ridu yawm al-hashr li 'amalan / fa-la tuqaddir lahu tulan 'ala 'ardi' (I call You, O Originator of things from non-existence / and Maker of the upper and lower world / If You present a deed for me on the Day of Gathering / do not estimate for it a length against my honor/'ard). And I said also: 'Ya sahiban dhayal al-siba fi al-hawa / ablaytahu fi al-ghayy wa huwa al-qashib / faghsil bi-dam' al-'ayn thawb al-tuqa / wa naqqihi min qabl 'asr al-mashib' (O dragger of the tail of youth in passion / you wore it out in error while it was new / So wash with the tear of the eye the garment of piety / and clean it before the age of gray hair). And I said also: 'Wajadtu fi 'ishrat sahbi adhan / lamma lazimtu al-bayt fi al-waqt zal / ya 'ajaban min ash'ariyyin ghada / yahmadu ra'y al-nas fi al-i'tizal' (I found harm in the company of my friends / when I stuck to the house immediately it vanished / Oh wonder at an Ash'ari who became / praising the opinion of people regarding withdrawal/Mu'tazilism). And I said also: 'Inna al-latafa lam tazal / 'inda al-akabir fashiyah / a-ra'ayta 'umraka fi al-wara / tarfan raqiq al-hashiyah' (Verily subtlety ceases not / to be spreading among the great ones / Have you seen in your life among people / a periphery/companion (tarf) thin of margin/nature?). And I said also: 'La tar'a lil-mallaq 'ahdan wa la / tusghi li-ma nammaqahu wa ikhtalaq / fa-anta tadri ma janathu yadu al-r / rami 'ala al-tayr bi-ra'y al-malaq' (Do not observe a covenant for the flatterer nor / listen to what he embellished and fabricated / For you know what the hand of the archer committed / against the bird by grazing the flatterer/valerian). And I said also: 'Atani wa qad awda al-suhad bi-naziri / yumazziq junh al-layl bariqu fihi / fa-qultu lahu ya tayyib al-asl hakadha / akhadhta al-kara minni wa 'ayni fihi' (He came to me while sleeplessness had destroyed my eye / the lightning of his mouth tearing the wing of night / I said to him: O one of good origin, like this / you took sleep from me while my eye was on/in it). And I said also: 'Inna 'ayni mudh ghaba shakhsuka 'anha / ya'mur al-suhd fi karaha wa yanha / bi-dumu'in ka-annahunna al-ghawadi / la tasal ma jara 'ala al-khadd minha' (My eye, since your person was absent from it / sleeplessness commands and forbids regarding its sleep / With tears as if they are morning clouds / do not ask what ran/occurred on the cheek from them). And I said also: 'Faddaytu habiban darraj al-husn wajhahu / fa-sabba 'ala khaddayhi dhawb 'aqiq / idha 'ayana al-rawd al-mudabbaj khaddahu / yaqul lana hadha akhi wa shaqiqi' (I ransomed a beloved whose face beauty reddened / so it poured melted agate on his cheeks / If the brocaded garden sees his cheek / it says to us: This is my brother and my full brother/anemone). And I said also: 'Anfaqtu kanz mada'ihi fi thaghrihi / wa jama'tu fihi li-kull ma'na sharid / wa talabtu minhu jaza' dhalik qublatan / fa-aba wa raha taghazzuli fi al-barid' (I spent the treasure of my praises on his mouth / and gathered in it every fleeing meaning / And I asked him for a kiss as a reward for that / but he refused, and my flirtation went in the cold/post). And I said also: 'Waqafa al-qadib li-qaddihi lamma masha / wa jarat dumu' al-'ayn fi tahsilihi / rasha kasahu al-husn minhu hullatan / ja'at bi-jumlayiha 'ala tafsilihi' (The branch stood for his figure when he walked / and the tears of the eye flowed in acquiring him / A fawn whom beauty clothed from him a suit / that came in its sum according to its detail/tailoring). And I said also: 'Qalu wa qad madat bi-ghusn al-naqa / asrafta fi al-hubb bi-la fa'idah / fa-qultu manhum al-hawa lam yakun / yashba' in ladhdhat lahu al-ma'idah' (They said, while she swayed with the branch of the dune / You have exceeded in love without benefit / So I said: The glutton of passion is not / satisfied if the table is sweet to him). And I said also: 'Lamma tana'aytum 'ankum / ma zala 'anni 'ana'i / wa law qafaltum ilaykum / fatahtu bab al-hana'i' (When you distanced yourselves from you / my suffering did not cease from me / And if you returned (locked) to you / I would have opened the door of happiness). And I said also: 'Kun kayfa shi'ta fa-inna qad / raka qad ghala 'indi wa 'azza / mata al-suluww ta'ish an / t ama ra'ayta al-sabr 'azza' (Be how you wish, for your / value has become high with me and dear / Solace died, may you live / Did you not see patience give condolences?). And I said also: 'Lahu fi khaddihi ayat husn / wa laysa li-'aqdiha fi al-hubb faskh / wa rayhan al-'idhar lahu hawash / 'ala narin lahuma bi-al-ruh taskhu' (He has in his cheek signs of beauty / and there is no annulment for their contract in love / And the basil of the cheek-hair has margins / upon a fire for which they are generous with the spirit). And I said also: 'Ya 'ajaban min ma'shar sukruhum / athbatahum fi 'alam al-mahw / wa kull ka's shamsuha ashraqat / wa yawmuhum 'arin min al-sahw' (Oh wonder at a group whose drunkenness / established them in the world of erasure / And every cup, its sun shone / and their day is naked of sobriety/cloudless). And I said also: 'Rasha'un sara bi-qalbi / wa ana ashkuru sayrah / fa-saba sabri lamma / lam yajid al-qalb ghayrah' (A fawn traveled with my heart / and I thank his journey / So he captured my patience when / the heart did not find other than him/jealousy). 

I say: I did not establish these verses for the Luzum (constraint) in them necessarily, for that only came in them implicitly and consequently. Rather, I established them for the Tawriya (double entendre) in them. That is apparent to one who contemplates their places.

And I wrote upon the arrival of the cavalcade of our master the Sultan—may God immortalize his reign—from the Noble Hijaz in the year 733 AH to our master the King of Princes in the Guarded Damascus—may God strengthen his victories: 'May God double the blessing of the High Presence and gladden him with what perfumed existence of the news of his Sultan, and delight him with the return of his King after attaining his desires (awtar) to his homelands (awtan), and fill his hearing with what filled the heart of Islam with joy until its well (qalib) overflowed with happiness without its ropes (ashtan). This correspondence issued to the High Presence folding upon a peace (salam) that the full moon seeks refuge from its decrease by its perfection, and spreading a praise (thana') for which the dove danced with its cooing on the sides of its branches, and clarifying to his noble knowledge that we wrote it after the arrival of our Noble Cavalcade to the seat of his kingdom at the Citadel of the Mountain which we settled its dwelling, and illuminated its horizon with the light of our Noble Face. It was like ambiguous words, but when we analyzed/settled (halalna) it, its meaning appeared. We arrived at it while it was more longing for us than withered gardens for clouds, and more fond than one yearning for the breezes of the sanctuary and the cooing of doves, and more looking forward than the night traveler in darkness for the rising of the full moon. So we adorned its sky, cleared its darkness, moistened the thirst of its longings, and untied the hand of loneliness that had taken hold of its collars. This while Victory is the guest of the side of our leading horses (jana'ib), and Triumph is the servant of the stirrup of our mounts (raka'ib), and Happiness travels before us, and Existence calls us with support from all directions. The lightnings have sent in the horizons the kindnesses of good news perfumed, and the saints (Awliya) have surrounded our cavalcade so our preceding favors did not fall short of them when we saw them sworn (muhallafa/allied). We have performed, by God's praise and grace, the rituals of Hajj, and raised our voice with the Call (Nida) and our palms with dew (Nada), so people saw how the clamor ('Ajj) is, and how the pouring (Thajj) of rain is. We breathed from our night travel with the fire of lightning while the charcoal of darkness was in flames. We turned from Mecca—may God honor it—to Medina—may God cherish it—so we did not march from a Sanctuary (Haram) except to a Sanctuary (Haram). So we attained by God Almighty's grace what we wished (ammana) and hoped (ammalna), and performed the trust (Amana) to longing in enjoying the Noble Chamber just as we carried it. We spoke directly to that Noble Station with peace (Salam) upon arrival at the Request (Sul), and were alone with him so there was no messenger (Rasul) between us and the Messenger. Let the High Presence take his share of this glad tiding by which Islam rejoiced, and the sides of pulpits swayed for it, and the fingertips of flags counted its gifts, and even the mouths of inkwells spoke its praises with the tongues of pens. Let him not burden the subjects in this glad tiding with anything, so that the nearness (Qurba) is innocent of impurities, empty of defects, for thunderbolts muddy the generosity of clouds, and boredom spoils the connection of loved ones. May God keep the Presence for a happiness whose melodious tunes we hear, and a praise for which the sides of scrolls sway and the tongues of pens chant in the hands of Arabizing writers by His grace and generosity.' Most of what I compose, I bring it constrained (Malzum), and the sermon (Khutba) of this book is constrained.

He said in Luzum also: It has appeared for the Arabs some of that. Of what came of it is the saying of some of them in the verses of Al-Hamasa: 'Inna allati za'amat fu'adaka mllaha / khalaqat hawaka kama khalaqat hawa laha' (Verily she who claimed your heart bored her / created your love just as she created love for her) and he cited the famous verses.
I say: This is not of Luzum in anything. The rhyme is the Lam and the Ha is a connection (Sila). Do you not see that if he said in some of its rhymes: 'aqarraha' or 'asammaha', that would not be permissible. This type is frequent in Arab poetry and is not Luzum, like the saying of Kuthayyir Azza: 'Khalilayya hadha rab'u 'Azzata fa'qila / qalusaykuma thumma inzila haythu hallat' (O my two friends, this is the quarter of Azza, so hobble / your two young camels then descend where she settled). It is a long poem, the rhyme in it is the Lam. And the verses of Al-Hamasa by Amr bin Ma'di Yakrib: 'Wa lamma ra'aytu al-khayla zawran ka-annaha / jidalu zar'in ursilat fasbatarrat' (And when I saw the horses tilting as if they were / stalks of crops sent/released so they straightened). The rhyme in it is the Ra. Although Ibn al-Athir made it of the chapter of Luzum, and this is closer to Luzum than the first. If he had cited this and claimed it was Luzum, he would have had some semblance of an argument. For Abu Tammam and others consider the rhyme here to be the Ta. Abu Tammam composed a Ta-rhymed poem (Ta'iyya) on this. Which is: 'Nusa'iluha ayya al-mawatini hallat / wa ayya diyarin awtanatha wa ayyat' (We ask her which homelands she settled / and which dwellings she inhabited and where). Likewise the Ta'iyya of Sharaf al-Din ibn al-Farid, the Poem of the Way (Nazm al-Suluk), and the other short one. But the verifiers do not permit that and criticize it. The verses of Salma bin Rabi'a, the poet of Al-Hamasa: 'Hallat Tumadiru ghurbatan fa-htallat / faljan wa ahluka bi-al-liwa fa-l-hallat' (Tumadir settled in estrangement so she occupied / Falj, while your family is at Al-Liwa, strictly/then the Basket). Long verses where he made the rhyme nothing but the Lam. Likewise the saying of Sulayman bin Qutayba al-Adawi from the poets of Al-Hamasa: 'Marartu 'ala abyati ali Muhammadin / fa-lam araha ka-'ahdiha yawma hallat' (I passed by the houses of the family of Muhammad / and did not see them as I knew them the day she settled). In Al-Hamasa there is much of this type. As for the verses of Al-Hamasa: 'Wa harbin yadijju al-qawmu min nafyaniha / dajija al-jimali al-jillati al-dabirat' (And a war from whose spray the people clamor / the clamor of great sore-backed camels), it is of the chapter of Luzum. As for the ones Ibn al-Athir cited, no.

So it is from the chapter of Luzum, whereas the ones Ibn al-Athir cited are not.
He said: Some have mentioned in this type what appeared in the verses of Al-Hamasa. Which is: 'Wa fishatin laysat ka-hadhi al-fish'. Then he cited the verses and said: This is not from the chapter of Luzum. He began to deduce the correctness of his claim, either with something erred in, or something whose correctness was hidden from him. I say: These verses are from the chapter of Luzum, evidenced by the fact that if he said in them 'hush', it would be permissible. As for his reasoning with 'arsh' (throne) and 'taysh' (recklessness), it is not conceded to him. Waw and Ya occur as 'Ridf' (letter before the rhyme letter) just as you say: 'qusur' and 'qasir', and 'kusur' and 'kasir'. This is more famous and apparent than to need citation.

He said in Luzum also: Know that if the last word of poetry or rhymed prose intervals is made diminutive (tasghir), then that is attached to Luzum. Then he cited the poet's saying: 'Azza 'ala Layla bi-dhi sudayr / su'u mabiti laylata al-ghumayr' (It was hard on Layla at Dhu Sudayr / the badness of my overnight stay the night of Al-Ghumayr). He cited it to the end. 
I say: That is not of Luzum. For 'timra', 'zahra', 'sadra', 'sahra', 'matra', and 'qamra'—if all their words are un-diminutive, there is no Luzum in them. Yes, if the rhymes he mentioned were 'qumayra', 'ghumayra', 'umayra', 'jumayra', 'sumayra', and 'numayra', that would be counted as Luzum due to the presence of the Mim. The composer does not burden himself with the like of what he cited, nor bind himself to anything; rather, every Ra-rhyme or non-Ba-rhyme can be made diminutive. Among the wonders of this man, may God have mercy on him, is that he counts the like of this as Luzum, then says two lines later: 'Perhaps some ignorant people fall into this place and insert into it what is not of it. Like His Almighty's saying: 'Inna al-muttaqina fi jannatin wa na'im. Fikihina bima atahum rabbuhum wa waqahum rabbuhum 'adhaba al-jahim.' (Verily the righteous are in gardens and bliss. Enjoying what their Lord gave them, and their Lord protected them from the punishment of Hellfire). This does not enter into the chapter of Luzum, because the origin in it is 'ni'am' and 'jahim'. And the Ya is of the letters of extension and softness.'

I say: Of natural speech is the saying of the poet: 'Law arada Allahu khayran / wa salahan li-muhibbih / naqala riqqata khadday / hi ila qaswati qalbih' (If God wanted good / and righteousness for His lover / He would have transferred the softness of his cheeks / to the hardness of his heart). Likewise this man, had God guided him in this station, his speech here would have transferred him to what he mentioned of the Diminutive, and he would have said: 'The Ya here is for Diminutive so there is no consideration for it because the origin is: 'sadar' and 'ghamar' in 'sudayr' and 'ghumayr'.' However, I have wasted these two verses I cited here as an example, for they are nobler than such. Nothing is said here except: 'May I be your ransom, do not commit adultery and do not give charity.' As for the noble Verses he cited, they are of the chapter of Luzum. For it is permissible in Rhymed Prose (Saj') to say: 'samum' and 'hamim', combining Waw and Ya as preceded. As for 'jahim', 'na'im', and 'hamim', it is of the chapter of Luzum. He confused this chapter just as he confused Jinas. Although Luzum ma la yalzam and Jinas are of the clear Badi' (Embellishment), and whoever occupied himself with that would notice them in the beginnings due to their clarity. I wondered at Ibn Abi al-Hadid that he did not notice these things.

**When is the word 'Khawd' (delicate woman) beautiful or ugly?**
He said in the sixth type regarding the difference of word forms and their agreement, after mentioning the word 'Khawd' and that it is: 'In the noun which is 'khawd', it is beautiful and pleasing, but if it comes in the form of the verb it is not pleasing.' Then he cited the saying of Abu Tammam: 'Wa ila bani Abd al-Karim tawahqat / ratka al-na'ami ra'a al-tariqa fa-khawwada' (And to the Banu Abd al-Karim they rushed / the trot of the ostrich that saw the path and hurried/khawwada). And the verse of Al-Hamasa: 'Aqulu li-nafsi hina khawwada ra'luha / ruwaydaki lamma tushfiqi hina mushfiqi' (I say to my soul when its chicks hurried/khawwada / Gently, you have not feared when it is time to fear). Then he judged the first as heavy and ugly, and the second as light and beautiful. He argued for this that it appeared here by rule of metaphor (majaz), and there by rule of reality (haqiqa).

I say: How abundant is this man's arbitrariness and his claims without support. Even if it were, it is weaker than a house founded on the brink of a crumbling cliff. That is because from the beginning of the book to its end, he argues that the sweetness of a word and its beauty is a matter returning to the composition of its letters and the pleasure of its location in the hearing, and that this is a matter attested to by sense (hiss). It is said to him: If the matter is so, there is no consideration here for meaning. If meaning affected the word with sweetness, 'harkulah' for a woman trembling in limbs and buttocks would be sweet. And if meaning affected the word with weakness, the word 'sa'ir' (blaze) and 'hayf' (injustice) would be heavy to the hearing. Since sweetness and heaviness do not relate to meaning, we know that meaning has no account in eloquence. In that case, his saying: 'Khawd' in the first is heavy because it is reality, and in the second is beautiful because it is metaphor, is a mere claim. Because the Kha, the stressed Waw, and the Dal did not change form or structure in the two places. Metaphor and Reality are two semantic matters having no relation to the word.

It is said to him: You said: 'The explanations grammarians burden themselves with are weak and do not stand on the touchstone of observation.' Is this explanation you brought strong, standing on the touchstone of observation, having no defect or blemish? 'Is this the stabbing of one who cures thirst / and the advance of a man who criticized men!'

**Is the word 'Immah' (Leadership) with Kasra eloquent?**
He said also in this chapter, having mentioned 'Immah' with Kasra on the Hamza: 'I saw the author of the book Al-Fasih mentioning it among what he chose of eloquent words. Oh, would that I knew what he saw of its eloquence.' Then he increased in degrading him and did much of that.
I say: Abu al-Abbas Tha'lab, may God have mercy on him, mentioned that only adhering to its occurrence for the sake of the chapter he convened for that. He said: 'Chapter of the vowel-broken beginning (Maksur awwaluhu), and the vowel-joined (Madmum) with difference of meaning.' So he was compelled to mention it and mention its likes: of 'Khitba', 'Sifr', 'Rihla', and 'Ishra', adhering to the occurrence of what came in that. The broken might be sweeter, and the joined might be sweeter. The Imams of language, if they say 'eloquent' (fasih), do not necessarily mean sweetness and beauty; rather they mean frequency of usage. Sweetness might come after that implicitly and consequently. Therefore, you hear them saying: The correct language in 'Zi'baq' (Mercury) and 'Zi'bir' (Nap of cloth) is Hamza (glottal stop) without easing (tashil), even though easing is lighter and sweeter than Hamza, so the 'Fasih' is Hamza. Likewise their saying 'Sam'u' (Hearing) with moving the Mim is more eloquent than stillness (Sam'c), yet sense testifies that stillness is lighter and better. So every sweet thing is eloquent, but not the reverse.

He said regarding that also: 'Likewise Fa'ula with Fatha on Fa and Damma on 'Ayn has only one noun [participle] which is Fa'il, and no difference occurs in it except what is anomalous. But Fa'ila with Fatha on Fa and Kasra on 'Ayn, difference occurs in its active participle (ism fa'il) in approval and disapproval because it has three weights: Fa'il, Fa'il, and Fa'lan. You say from it: Hamida fahuwa Hamid and Hamdan.'

I say: Verily Fa'ula with Damma on 'Ayn, its active participle is not restricted to Fa'il. Rather it may come on Fa'al. Like 'Jabuna fahuwa Jaban' (Cowardly), and 'Hasunat al-mar'ah fahiya Hasan' (Chaste). It may come on Fa'al with moving the 'Ayn, like 'Batula fahuwa Batal' (Hero) and 'Hasuna fahuwa Hasan' (Beautiful). It may come on Fual with Damma on Fa like 'Furata al-ma' fahuwa Furat' (Sweet water), and 'Dakhuma fahuwa Dukham' (Huge), and 'Shaju'a fahuwa Shuja'' (Brave). It may come on Fa'ul like 'Hasurat... Hasur', and 'Azzat fahiya 'Azuz'. It may come on Fa'il like 'Hamuda... Hamid' (Sour). It may come on Fa'r like 'Ghamura... Ghamr' (Inexperienced), and 'Saluba... Salb' (Hard). It may come on Fa'il like 'Nadusa... Nadis' (Intelligent) and 'Yaquza... Yaqiz' (Alert). It may come on Fa'l with stillness on 'Ayn like 'Dakhuma... Dakhm', 'Sahula... Sahl', 'Sa'uba... Sa'b', 'Shahuma... Shahm'. As for if it is of the verbs of inherent qualities (Sajaya) like Zarufa, Sharafa, 'Azuma, Kabura, then its active participle is on the weight of Fa'il; you say in that: Zarif, Sharif, 'Azim, Kabir.

As for Fa'ila with Kasra on 'Ayn, he released the expression and claimed its active participle comes on three weights: Fa'il, Fa'il, and Fa'lan. The rule in that is that the verb is not devoid of three forms: Fa'ala with Fatha on 'Ayn like Daraba, Fa'ila with Kasra on 'Ayn like 'Alima, and Fa'ula with Damma on 'Ayn like Zarufa. As for the first, its active participle is regular (muttarid) in analogy on Fa'il, like Daraba... Darib, Dhahaba... Dhahib, Ghalaba... Ghalib, Naqasa... Naqis, Kamula... Kamil [Note: Kamula is usually u, Kamil is for a/u]. As for the second, Fa'ila with Kasra on 'Ayn, its active participle on Fa'il is heard (sama'i), one does not exceed that transmission, and analogy has no entry in that. Like your saying: Amina... Amin, Salima... Salim, Sakhita... Sakhit, Radiya... Radin. As for the regularity of the active participle of Fa'ila on Fa'il, it is if it is intransitive, which is the verb of accidental state ('arad) that is unstable. Like your saying: Fariha... Farih (Happy), Gharitha... Gharith (Hungry), Batira... Batir, Ashira... Ashir; this is regular. If it is transitive as Ibn al-Athir mentioned in Hamida, its active participle is not regular on Fa'il. As for 'Hamid' (on Fa'il pattern), I never heard it. I think Ibn Khalawayh in the book 'Laysa' said: 'There is nothing among nouns built on three names like: Rahima... Rahim, Rahim, Rahman, except Salima... Salim, Salim, Salman, and Nadima... Nadim, Nadim, Nadman.' It is said: He claimed the like of this in the assembly of Sayf al-Dawla bin Hamdan, and this rule was mentioned while Ibn Khalawayh was present. He said: 'One remains from the lineage of the Prince, which is Hamida... Hamid, Hamid, Hamdan.' This is among the beauties of Ibn Khalawayh. Had 'Hamid' (on Fa'il pattern) been among its agents, it would have been mentioned at that time. If Fa'ila is of verbs of colors and defects, its active participle is on Af'al, like 'Awira... A'war, Hawila... Ahwal, Jahira... Ajhar, Kadira... Akdar. Likewise Khadira, Sawida, Safira—whenever it is of colors, its active participle is Af'al.

As for if Fa'ila is for fullness and heat of the belly, it is Fa'lan with stillness on the 'Ayn, like: Shabi'a... Shab'an, 'Atisha... 'Atshan, Sadiya... Sadiyan, Rawiya... Rayyan, Sakira... Sakran. As for the third, Fa'ula with Damma on 'Ayn, discussion on its active participle has preceded. This is the rule regarding the structures of active participles from the three forms, not what he claimed and released.

**Regarding Verbal Complexity (Mu'azala Lafziyya)**
He said regarding Verbal Complexity: From that is some of them: 'Wa qabru Harbin bi-makanin qafr / wa laysa qurba qabri Harbin qabr' (And the grave of Harb is in a desolate place / and there is no grave near the grave of Harb). These Qafs and Ras are like a chain in their succession, and there is no hiding the heaviness in that. Similarly, the saying of Al-Hariri in his Maqamat occurred: 'Wa izwarra man kana lahu za'iran / wa 'afa 'afi al-'urfi 'irfanahu' (And he turned away who was a visitor to him / and the seeker of favor loathed knowing him/his favor).
I say: As for the verse he mentioned first, he is excused in it, and all masters of Meanings and Bayan mentioned it and stipulated it, but did not couple it with Al-Hariri's saying. This is of his arbitrariness and obstinacy. For Al-Hariri's verse has nothing but an abundance of Jinas (puns), and this is a craft, so how does he count it a defect? If it were so, every Jinas repeated in a verse or paragraph would be complexity according to his view, but it is not so. If he had glimpsed the secret in the heaviness of that [first] verse, he would not have coupled it with Al-Hariri's saying. The cause of heaviness in that verse is not the repetition of letters necessarily, for that is part of the cause, but rather it is the advancing of letters over one another, with repetition in his saying: 'qurba qabr'. So much so that this verse became famous such that intelligent people are tested by reciting it three times consecutively in one breath, and hardly anyone is safe from stumbling in it. The cause of that is advancing some letters over others and delaying them. This is not specific to this verse, but to everything whose letters repeated advanced and delayed. Ibn Sana' al-Mulk, among the smoothest of late poets in poetry and subtlest, has the like of this in his saying: 'Wasaftuki wa al-lahi yu'anidu bi-al-'adhal / fa-kuntu Aba Dharrin wa kana Aba Jahl / lahu shahida zurin min al-nahyi wa al-nuha / 'alayki wa min 'aynayki li shahida 'adl / habibatu hadha al-qalbi min qabli khalqihi / yuhibbuki qalbi qabla khalqiki bal qabli' (I described you while the blamer opposes with blame / so I was Abu Dharr and he was Abu Jahl / He has two witnesses of falsehood from prohibition and intellect / against you, and from your eyes I have two just witnesses / Beloved of this heart from before its creation / my heart loves you before your creation, nay before me). Look at the first two verses, how smooth they are, and how heavy this third is. What is its cause other than advancing letters sometimes and delaying them sometimes in 'qabli' and 'qalbi', 'qalb' and 'qabl'. As for Al-Hariri's verse, it has nothing but the repetition of the letters of its Jinas, and advancing and delaying are non-existent in it. Do you not see that 'Ayn is before Fa in both times, and 'Ayn is before Ra, and Ra is before Fa in both times? This is apparent. Sharaf al-Din ibn al-Farid, may God have mercy on him, in his Ta'iyya brings Jinas in the verse often repeated, like his saying: 'Aya zajiran humra al-awrak tarika al / mawarik min akwariha ka-al-arikah' (O driver of the red-hipped [camels], leaving the / pads of their saddles like the couch). It does not contain the entanglement and heaviness on the tongue as in his saying: 'Wa la hilma li fi hamli ma fika nalani / yu'addi li-hamdi aw li-madhi mawaddati / wa 'adi da'awi al-qili wa al-qali wanju min / 'awadi da'awi sidquha qasdu sum'ati / wa kallaftuha la bal kafaltu qiyamaha / bi-taklifiha hatta kafaltu bi-kulfati' (I have no forbearance in bearing what attained me regarding you / leading to my praise or praising my affection / And oppose the claims of hate and the hater, and escape from / the consequences of claims whose truth is intending my reputation / And I burdened it, nay I guaranteed its standing / by burdening it until I guaranteed with my trouble). What is the cause of that other than advancing letters in this sometimes, and delaying them sometimes, and listing them in order in the first without advancing and delaying? So know that. I do not deny that excessive Jinas repeated in a verse or paragraph is not free of some heaviness. I only disputed him in making Al-Hariri's saying of the category of the verse that is like a scorpion's charm or some spiritual incantations. People have frequently cited it as evidence and it became a proverb in the anxiety of words.

Deepening words (taq'ir) is known and people have mentioned it. Of that is that Isa bin Umar the Grammarian or Abu Alqama the Grammarian fell from his donkey and fainted. When he woke up and saw people gathering around him, he said: 'Ma lakum taka'ka'tum 'alayya taka'ku'akum 'ala dhi jinnah, ifranqi'u 'anni yarhamukum Allah' (Why have you gathered/taka'ka'tum upon me like your gathering upon a possessed man? Disperse/ifranqi'u from me, may God have mercy on you). One of them said: 'Leave him, for his Jinn speaks in Hindi.' And of that is the news of Umm al-Haytham with the woman who complained to her of pain in her back. She asked her the cause. She said: 'Kuntu wahma bi-dakkah, fa-hadartu ma'dubah, fa-akaltu hayzabah min firas hal'ah fa-i'taratni zalkhah.' She replied: 'Innaki la-dhatu khuza'balat.' (You are full of nonsense/riddles). The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'The most hated of you to me are the garrulous (thartharun), the pompous (mutafayhiqun), the affectatious (mutashaddiqun).' All these words refer to those who are pedantic in speech. Tharthar is from 'ayn tharthara' if its water is abundant; Mutafayhiq is from 'tafayhaqa al-ghadir' if it overflows; and Mutashaddiq is one who opens his jaw corners wide.

**Types of Complexity**

He said regarding Complexity (Mu'azala): The fifth section of Complexity is that multiple adjectives occur in one manner. Like the saying of Abu Tammam—and he recited verses for him including: 'Tamikuhu nahduhu mudakhiluhu / malmumuhu muhza'illuhu ajaduh' (Its height, its rise, its interweaving / its gathering, its bounding, its firmness). Then he said: This verse is of the complexity that pulls teeth.
I say: The heaviness of the verse is not from the multiplicity of adjectives, but from his saying 'tamikuhu' and 'muhza'illuhu'. Multiplicity of adjectives itself contains no heaviness or complexity if they come with sweet words. As you say if describing a stature: 'Qawimuhu, ahyafuhu, na'imuhu, ladnuhu, rayyanuhu' (Its straightness, its slimness, its softness, its flexibility, its lushness). If you delete the Ha (suffix), it increases in beauty. Like the saying of Judge Shams al-Din Ahmad ibn Khallikan: 'Qasaman bi-wajhika wa huwa badrun tali'un / wa bi-layli turratika allati ka-al-ghayhabi / wa bi-qamatin laka ka-al-qadib rakibtu fi / akhatiriha fi al-hubb as'aba markabi / wa yutibu mabsimaka al-shahiyya al-barida al / 'adhba al-namira al-lu'lu'iyya al-ashnaba' (An oath by your face which is a rising full moon / and by the night of your lock which is like darkness / And by a stature of yours like a branch, I rode in / risking for it in love the hardest mount / And your appetizing, cold, sweet / pure, pearly, cool mouth is good). Among what I said in this type: 'Qasaman bi-nadir qaddika al-ladn al-qawi / m al-ahyaf al-muta'attif al-rayyani / wa bi-jafniya al-dami al-qarih al-hami' al / hami al-mulithth al-hatil al-hattani / ma li 'ala dhull al-jafa sabrun wa la / jaldun yusa'iduni 'ala al-hijrani' (An oath by the freshness of your flexible, straight / slim, bending, lush figure / And by my bloody, wounded, shedding / pouring, persistent, raining, pouring eyelid / I have no patience over the humiliation of estrangement nor / endurance to help me with abandonment). Sense judges between us and one who claims this is of the chapter of Verbal Complexity. As for Abu Tammam's verse, it is from a poem in which two like it occurred: 'Marinuhu ladnuhu muthaqqafuhu / 'arrasuhu fi al-akuffi mashashuhu / muttariduh' Then he said: 'Musaffuhu tharruhu musahhihuhu / wabiluhu mustahilluhu baraduh'.

He said, having cited the saying of Abu al-Tayyib: 'Fa-la yubrimu al-amr alladhi huwa halil / wa la yahlulu al-amr alladhi huwa yubrim' (He does not settle the matter which is dissolving / nor dissolve the matter which is settling).

**Refuting Partisanship**
It reached me about Abu al-Ala that he used to be partisan to Abu al-Tayyib, so much so that he used to call him 'The Poet' and call other poets by their names. Ibn al-Athir increased in blaming Al-Ma'arri and said: 'God combined for him blindness in sight and insight.'
I say: Al-Ma'arri is excused in preferring Al-Mutanabbi over others, and he is not an innovator in preferring him over other poets, for most people are on this doctrine. Neither Al-Ma'arri nor others who preferred him believe he is infallible, not falling into error. But the man, if he excelled, no one caught up with him. He has no peer in my view except Al-Qadi Al-Fadil, may God Almighty have mercy on him. For Al-Fadil similarly falls in some times to the lowest depth, then leaps a leap for which the Pleiades are soil, leaving those who follow his trace stopping at his steps having returned backwards. Like his saying: 'And my thoughts are weary (kalilah), and my disposals are few (qalilah), and my protection (hamiyati) is as you know it (hama-ha), and the mixing (khulta) is confusion (takhlit), so if our master hears a son of a lip (word) about me, it is a foundling (laqit).' Similarly Abu al-Tayyib, while you see him according to the custom of poets from medium to bad, suddenly he brings a good thing leaving people shaking off the dust of his precedence from their chests, and he sits on the beds of the horizon reassured while poets wander in their valley. As he said: 'Fa-dhi al-dar akhda' min mumisin / wa amkar min kaffati al-habili' (For this abode is more deceiving than a prostitute / and more cunning than the net of a hunter). Then he followed it with his saying: 'Tafana al-rijalu 'ala hubbiha / wa ma yahsuluna 'ala ta'ili' (Men perished over love of her / and they do not obtain any benefit). And as he said mourning Sayf al-Dawla's mother: 'Atathunna al-musiba ghafilat / wa dam' al-huzn fi dam' al-dalali' (Calamity came to them unaware / and the tear of grief was in the tear of coquetry). Then he said: 'Wa ma al-ta'nith li-ism al-shams 'ayb / wa la al-tadhkir fakhr lil-hilali' (Femininity is no defect for the name of the sun / nor is masculinity a pride for the crescent). And as he said in it: 'Ra'aytuka fi al-ladhina ara mulukan / ka-annaka mustaqimun fi mahal' (I saw you among those I consider kings / as if you are straight in an absurdity). Then he followed it with his saying: 'Fa-in tufuq al-anam wa anta minhum / fa-inna al-misk ba'd dam al-ghazali' (If you surpass people while you are of them / then musk is some of the blood of the gazelle). And as he said in mourning the son of Sayf al-Dawla: 'Bina minka fawqa al-raml ma bika fi al-raml / fa-hadha alladhi yudni ka-dhaka alladhi yubli' (We have from you above the sand what you have in the sand / for this which wastes (us) is like that which decays (you)). Then he followed it: 'Ka-annaka absarta alladhi bi wa khiftahu / idha mitta fa-khtarta al-himam 'ala al-thukli' (As if you saw what is in me and feared it / if you died, so you chose death over bereavement). And as he said: 'Layta al-mada'ih tastawfi manaqibahu / fa-ma kulaybun wa ahlu al-a'sur al-uwali' (Would that praises exhaust his virtues / for what is Kulayb and the people of the first ages?). Then he followed it with his saying: 'Khudh ma tarahu wa da' shay'an sami'ta bihi / fi tal'at al-shams ma yughnika 'an zujali' (Take what you see and leave a thing you heard of / in the rising of the sun is what dispenses you with Saturn). And as he said: 'Nalumuka ya 'Aliyyu li-ghayr dhanbin / li-annaka qad zarayta 'ala al-'ibadi' (We blame you, O Ali, for no sin / because you have looked down on the servants). Then he says after this: 'Ka-anna al-hama fi al-hayja 'uyun / wa qad tubi'at suyufuka min ruqadi' (As if the heads in battle are eyes / and your swords were printed from sleep). 'Wa qad suni'at al-asinna min humumin / fa-ma yakhturna illa fi fu'adi' (And spearheads were made from worries / so they do not flash/occur except in a heart). These two verses, even if their thefts (plagiarism) are counted, there is not in the source what has this brocade nor contains this coating. And as he said:

'Wa shibh al-shay' munjadhib ilayhi / wa ashbahuna bi-dunyana al-tugham' (And the like of a thing is attracted to it / and the most like of us to our world are the rabble). Then he follows it with his saying: 'Wa law lam ya'lu illa dhu mahallin / ta'ala al-jaysh wa inhatta al-qatam' (If none rose but one of rank / the army would rise and the dust would fall). And as he said: 'Adhummu ila hadha al-zaman uhaylahu / fa-a'lamuhum fadm wa ahzamuhum waghd' (I blame to this time its little people / for their most knowledgeable is stupid and their most resolute is a scoundrel). Then he follows them with his saying: 'Wa min nakad al-dunya 'ala al-hurr an yara / 'aduwwan lahu ma min sadaqatihi budd' (And of the misery of the world upon the free man is that he sees / an enemy whom he has no escape from befriending). It is said that when he claimed prophethood, he was asked: What is your miracle? He said: My saying 'Wa min nakad al-dunya...'. And as he said: 'Sa-tabki shajwaha farasi wa muhri / safa'ih dam'uha ma' al-jusum' (My mare and my colt will weep their sorrow / broad swords whose tear is the water of bodies). Then he says after this: 'Wa kam min 'a'ib qawlan sahihan / wa afatuhu min al-fahm al-saqim' (How many a fault-finder of a correct statement / while his defect is from the sick understanding). And as he said: 'Sahiba al-nas qablana dha al-zamana / wa 'anahum min sha'nihi ma 'anana' (People accompanied this time before us / and what concerned us of its affair concerned them). Then he says: 'Wa idha lam yakun min al-mawt budd / fa-min al-'ajz an takuna jabana' (And if there is no escape from death / it is of inability that you be a coward). And as he said: 'Nitaj ra'yika fi waqtin 'ala 'ajalin / ka-lafz harfin wa'ahu sami'un fahim' (The result of your opinion in a time on haste / is like the utterance of a letter understood by a comprehending listener). Then he says: 'Sadamthum bi-khamisin anta ghurratuhu / wa samhariyyatuhu fi wajhihi ghumum / fa-kana athbata ma fihi jusumuhum / yasqutna hawlaka wa al-arwah tanhazim' (You shocked them with an army of which you are the blaze / and its spears in its face are clouds / So the most steady thing in it was their bodies / falling around you while the spirits were defeated). And as he said: 'Wa innama yablugh al-insan taqatuhu / ma kull mashiyat bi-al-rijl shamlal' (A human only reaches his capacity / not every gait with the leg is brisk). Then he says: 'Dhikr al-fata 'umruhu al-thani wa hajatuhu / ma qatahu, wa fudul al-'aysh ashghal' (The mention of a youth is his second life, and his need / is what nourishes him, and excess of living is busy-work). This verse contains three proverbs. And as he said: 'Ajibtu li-man lahu qadd wa hadd / wa yanbu nabwat al-qasm al-kaham' (I wondered at one having a stature and an edge / yet dulls the dullness of the blunt breakage). Then he says: 'Wa lam ara fi 'uyub al-nas shay'an / ka-naqs al-qadirin 'ala al-tamam' (I have not seen in the faults of people anything / like the deficiency of those capable of perfection). And as he said: 'Dharini anal ma la yunal min al-'ula / fa-sa'b al-'ula fi al-sa'b wa al-sahl fi al-sahl' (Let me attain what is not attained of highness / for the difficult of highness is in the difficult and the easy in the easy). Then he says: 'Turidina luqyan al-ma'ali rakhisatan / wa la budda duna al-shahd min ibar al-nahl' (You want the meeting of high matters cheaply / but there is no escape, before the honey, from the needles of the bees). And as he said: 'Aba Shuja'in bi-Farisin 'Adud al-Dawla / Fannakhusru Shahanshaha / asamiyan lam tazidhu ma'rifatan / wa innama ladhdhatan dhakarnaha' (Abu Shuja' in Persia, Adud al-Dawla / Fannakhusru Shahanshah / names that did not increase him in definition / but for pleasure we mentioned them). This is a little of much, and few of abundant. But this amount is sufficient in indicating what he has of good. So look at his decline and his elevation. But where is his elevation! These two men, their mention has traveled, their command is established, and their wine has intoxicated minds. 'And in fatigue is one who envies the sun its light / and claims to bring a like for it.' For Al-Qadi Al-Fadil, may God have mercy on him, was unique in correspondence, and Al-Mutanabbi was unique in poetry despite what they had of decline, but the decline of Al-Mutanabbi is lower and uglier. If people, when they saw a generous one being stingy at a time, or a brave one fleeing at a time, or a skilled craftsman falling short at a time, threw them with blame and attacked them and did not count charity for them, there would not be in existence a generous one, nor a brave one, nor a skilled craftsman, nor an eloquent orator, nor an excellent poet. The consideration is by the majority and most, and the little is pardoned, for infallibility is not stipulated except for the Messengers, God's blessings and peace be upon them.

Al-Ma'arri has two verses preferring Abu al-Tayyib over Abu Tammam, which are: 'Ma Habibun illa adibun wa lakin / ma arahu yuqaribu al-Mutanabbi / dha al-ma'ani al-ghara'ib al-la'i asharna / jufuni dahran wa tayyamna qalbi' (Habib [Abu Tammam] is but a littérateur, but / I do not see him approaching Al-Mutanabbi / Possessor of strange meanings which made sleepless / my eyelids for a time and enslaved my heart). When Abu al-Ala finished classifying the book 'Al-Lami' al-Azizi' in explaining the Diwan of Abu al-Tayyib and it was read to him, the group began describing it. He said: 'As if Al-Mutanabbi looked at me with the glance of the unseen when saying: Ana alladhi nazara al-a'ma ila adabi / wa asma'at kalimati man bihi samam (I am the one whose literature the blind looked at / and my words made the deaf hear).' It is said: If Al-Ma'arri was alone from those he did not trust, he would say: 'Hand me the miracle of Ahmad,' meaning the Diwan of Abu al-Tayyib. If he was in other than privacy he would say: 'The Poet.' This is similar to what is told of Plato, that if he sat for people and speech was requested of him, he would say: 'Wait until the People arrive,' or perhaps he said: 'Wait until the Intellect arrives,' meaning Aristotle. He used to call the Diwan of Abu Tammam 'Dhikra Habib' (Memory of Habib/Beloved) and call the Diwan of Al-Buhturi 'Abath al-Walid' (The Play of Walid/Child). This allows praise and blame. As for praise, because the play of a child (Walid) is sweet to hearts. As for blame, because play in itself is blameworthy to the wise. And he calls the Diwan of Ibn Hani al-Maghribi 'Raha tathanu quruna' (A mill grinding horns). By my life, Abu al-Ala al-Ma'arri was not fair to Ibn Hani in this naming. Is he not the one who says in the Ra-rhyme poem:

'Wa janaytum thamara al-waqa'i'i yani'an / bi-al-nasri min waraq al-hadid al-akhdari' (And you gathered the fruit of battles ripe / with victory from the green leaves of iron). And from it: 'La ya'kulu al-sirhan shilwa ta'inihim / mimma 'alayhi min al-qana al-mutakassiri' (The wolf does not eat the corpse of their stabbed one / due to what is upon him of broken spears). Some people err in this verse and say: It is closer to blame than praise, because he described them that due to the large number gathering against one of their enemies, they break spears in stabbing him until they kill him, so broken spears gather on him preventing the wolf from eating him. The matter is not so, because 'the stabbed one' is intended to be from the praised ones themselves. The meaning: If a stabbed one from them dies, he does not die except after a large creation of enemies gather against him. So the stabbed one is from the praised ones, not their enemy, and this is the ultimate praise. Does he not have that Fa-rhyme poem, and what is in it of likening stars until he ended at mentioning Suha, saying: 'Ka-anna suhaha 'ashiqun bayna 'uwwadin / fa-awinatan yabdu wa awinata yakhfa' (As if its Suha is a lover among visitors / so sometimes he appears and sometimes hides). It is famous and all good. Does he not have the Dal-rhyme poem beginning: 'Imsahu 'an naziri kuhla al-suhad / wa unfudu 'an madja'i shawka al-qatad / aw khudhu minni ma abqaytum / la uhibbu al-jisma maslub al-fu'ad' (Wipe from my eye the kohl of sleeplessness / and shake off from my bed the thorns of tragacanth / Or take from me what you left / I do not love the body robbed of the heart). From it in describing armor: 'Kullu raqraq al-hawashi fawqahu / ka-'uyunin min afa'in aw jarad / fa-'ala al-ajsadi waqdun min sana / wa 'ala al-madhiyyi sabghun min jasad' (Every shimmering-sided one upon him / is like eyes of vipers or locusts / So upon the bodies is a fuel of light / and upon the armor is a dye of saffron/body). Does he not have the other Fa-rhyme poem in which he says: 'Wa laqad hazaztu ghusunaha bi-thimariha / wa hasartuhunna muhafhafan fa-muhafhafa / fa-radadtuha min rahatayhi marratan / wa sharibtuha min muqlatayhi qarqafa / ma kana aftakani law ikhtarat-tu yadi / min nazirayka 'ala raqibika murhafa' (I shook its branches with their fruits / and bent them slender one by slender one / I returned it from his palms once / and drank it from his eyes as strong wine / How deadly I would have been if I drew my hand / from your glances a sword against your watcher). Does he not have the Kaf-rhyme poem starting: 'Fatakatu tarfika am suyufu abik / wa ku'usu khamrika am marashifu fik / ajladu murhafatin wa fatku mahajirin / la anti rahimatun wa la ahluk' (The lethal attacks of your glance or the swords of your father / and the cups of your wine or the sipping-places of your mouth? / Skins of swords and lethality of eyes / neither you are merciful nor your family). From it: 'Mana'uki min sinat al-kara wa saraw fa-law / 'atharu bi-tayfin tariqin zannuk / wa da'awki nashwa ma saqawki mudamatan / lamma tamayala 'atfuki ittahamuk' (They prevented you from the slumber of sleep and traveled, so if / they stumbled on a visiting phantom they suspected you / And called you intoxicated; they did not give you wine / when your side swayed, they accused you). He has beautiful things. As for his transitions (takhallusat), they are of the best kind. But Al-Ma'arri was prejudiced against him. As for Abu al-Tayyib, it is of his happiness that nearly forty virtuous scholars explained his Diwan. Among them Al-Wahidi, and suffice you; and among them Imam Fakhr al-Din. Sheikh Taj al-Din al-Kindi, may God have mercy on him, has marginalia on his Diwan better than the margins of temples on the margins of cheeks, containing abundant benefits and important rules of strange language, parsing, and meaning having no peer. I have listed those who explained his Diwan in his biography in the book 'Al-Wafi bi-al-Wafayat'. The Vizier Al-Maghribi said in the book 'Adab al-Khawass', having said 'Al-Mutanabbi', and our Maghrebi brothers say 'Al-Mutanabbih'. I said: This is a good distortion from the Maghrebis, and it is not fitting that he be called Al-Mutanabbi (The Prophesier). Sheikh Taj al-Din used to narrate two verses for Abu al-Tayyib with a chain of transmission connected to him, not in his Diwan: 'A-bi-'ayni muftaqirin ilayka nazartani / fa-ahantani wa qadhaftani min haliq / lastu al-maluma ana al-malumu li-annani / anzaltu amali bi-ghayr al-Khaliq' (Is it with the eye of one in need of you that you looked at me? / So you insulted me and cast me from a high place / I am not the blamed one; I am the blamed one because I / landed my hopes on other than the Creator). On the whole, Abu al-Tayyib was granted happiness in his poetry what others were not granted. Among those who criticized him and attacked him were Al-Sahib bin Abbad in small booklets, and among them Ibn Waki' in 'Al-Munsif'. Ibn Sharaf al-Qayrawani said in 'Abkar al-Afkar': He is more unjust than Sodom. Al-Wahid al-Maghribi attacked him and Ibn Jinni severely. Among them Al-Hatimi in a small treatise, and another treatise Al-Hatimi dictated regarding his defects, a small volume. He has 'Al-Muwazana' (Comparison) between him and Abu Tammam. Al-Jurjani, may God have mercy on him, has the book 'Al-Wasata' (Mediation) between Al-Mutanabbi and his opponents; he was not free in it from siding against him. Among them Al-Nasih ibn al-Dahhan in a treatise he named 'Al-Risala al-Sa'idiyya' in the Kindian objections. The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'If a human were like a arrow-shaft (qidh), people would say: If only.'
