There is no answer for one who criticizes his good poetry except what he said describing his poem: 'Bi-dhi al-ghabawati min inshadiha samam / kama tadurru riyah al-wardi bi-al-ju'ali' (In the stupid one is deafness from reciting it / just as the winds of the rose harm the dung beetle).

**Regarding connecting Hamzat al-Qat' and cutting Hamzat al-Wasl**
He said in Verbal Complexity also: From this section is connecting the Cutting Hamza (Hamzat al-Qat'), which is counted among poetic licenses not permissible in prose, and likewise cutting the Connecting Hamza (Hamzat al-Wasl). Then he cited the saying of Abu Tammam:

'Fa-asbaha yalqani al-zamanu min ajilihi / bi-i'zami mawludin wa ra'fati walidi' (So time began meeting me due to him / with the honoring of a newborn and the compassion of a father). 
I say: As for cutting Hamzat al-Wasl, he is excused in counting it a defect, and in my view it is like shortening the extended (madd) in ugliness. Connecting Hamzat al-Qat' I see as extending the shortened, which is better. That is because you transfer the heavier to the lighter in them, unlike those two where you transfer the lighter to the heavier. As for making Abu Tammam's saying 'min ajilihi' (from his sake - transferring vowel) something permissible only in poetry and verbal complexity in words, the matter is not so. This is from the chapter of Transfer (Naql), and the readers of Tajwid know that and do not call it connecting the Hamza, rather transferring the vowel from the moving letter to the silent one. Like His Almighty's saying 'Wa law-annahum sabaru' (If they had been patient). The Waw of 'Law' is silent; if they wanted transfer, they transferred the vowel of the Hamza following it to it. They said: 'Wa lawannahum'. This is famous, apparent, not denied. They recited His Almighty's saying: 'Min ajili dhalika katabna 'ala bani Isra'il' (Because of that We decreed upon the Children of Israel) by transferring the vowel of Hamza to the Nun in 'min'. This is like the saying of Abu Tammam. If this rule is regular in the Quran, all of it from beginning to end, how does he prevent it and make it of poetic necessities and complexity in words? Yes, it is ugly in the like of Al-Mutanabbi's saying: 'Yuwassituhu al-mafuza kulla yawmin / tulabu al-talibina la al-intizaru' (He centers him in the desert every day / the pursuit of seekers not the waiting). And his saying also: 'Wa shiddatu al-zanni la al-istidlalu' (And strength of suspicion/opinion not deduction). For even if it is according to the rule, it is heavy as you see.

**Semantic Industry**
He said in the second essay on Semantic Industry, mentioning the wisdom of the Greeks and their sciences, that Abu Nuwas, Muslim bin al-Walid, Abu Tammam, Al-Buhturi, Abu al-Tayyib and others like Abd al-Hamid, Ibn al-Amid, and Al-Sabi did not learn anything from the books of the Greeks and brought what they brought. Then he exemplified with himself that he did not observe that and brought what he brought, and claimed here what he claimed for himself.

I say: My dispute here is only in his judgment that these did not engage with anything of that. I say to him: From where did you know this to judge by it? As for your claim for yourself, I do not oppose you in it, for people know themselves best. As for Abu Nuwas, it is said that he used to engage in Fiqh until it was said of him: Abu Nuwas is a jurist whom poetry overcame, and Al-Shafi'i is a poet whom Fiqh overcame. With that, no Fiqh appeared from him, just as no engagement with Greek sciences appeared from him. Absence of evidence does not indicate absence of the thing evidenced. Furthermore, he was in the time of Al-Rashid, Al-Amin, and Al-Ma'mun, and these sciences became famous in their days, especially in the time of Al-Ma'mun, for he arranged gold for those who translated Greek books into Arabic like Hunayn ibn Ishaq, Ibn Bakhtishu', and others. Do you not see Abu Nuwas said: 'Fa-qul li-man yadda'i fi al-'ilmi falsafatan / hafizta shay'an wa ghabat 'anka ashya'' (Say to one who claims philosophy in knowledge / you memorized a thing and things were absent from you). If you say: This indicates his rejection of these sciences and leaving them, I say: He only said this in the context of verses inciting intoxication, repelling hangover with wine, addiction to that, indulgence in pleasures, and continuing drinking and gatherings of intimacy, until he ended his speech with this verse in response to those advocating wisdom, and that taking much wine is forbidden rationally, and excess of it is harmful medically. So he began to fool the wise man in his opinion and say: You memorized a thing of wisdom, and things were absent from you of the pleasures of addiction to drink and rejoicing, according to the custom of poets in incitement. Then he said in it: 'La tahzur al-'afwa in kunta imra'an harijan / fa-inna hazraka bi-al-dini izra'' (Do not ban pardon if you are a critical man / for your banning in religion is contempt). This is according to the custom of poets in their debauchery, otherwise the correct view is the prohibition of wine. And Abu Nuwas's saying: 'Abaha al-'Iraqiyyu al-nabidha wa shurbahu / wa qala: haramani al-mudamatu wa al-sakru / wa qala al-Hijaziyyu: al-sharaban wahidun / fa-hallat lana min bayni qawlayhima al-khamru / sa-akhudhu min qawlayhima tarafayhima / wa ashrabuha la faraqa al-wazira al-wizru' (The Iraqi permitted Nabidh and its drinking / and said: Wine and drunkenness are forbidden / And the Hijazi said: The two drinks are one / so wine became lawful for us between their two sayings / I will take from their sayings their two sides / and drink it; may the burden not separate from the bearer). Whoever looks closely at these verses knows that Abu Nuwas was a logician, for his deduction of the permissibility of wine from the premises of the speech of the Iraqi jurist and the Hijazi indicates that. This is according to the custom of poetic metaphor, otherwise the correct view is the prohibition of wine.

**Is it true that some poets and writers reviewed the wisdom of Greeks and their sciences?**
As for Abu al-Tayyib, he said: 'I and Abu Tammam are wise men (Hakims), and the poet is Al-Buhturi.' The speech of these two poets indicates that they were not bare of something of the sciences of philosophy. Especially Al-Mutanabbi; the 'Hatimiya' indicates he used to look into the speech of the people (philosophers). Do you not see his saying praising Ibn al-Amid:

'Man mubligh al-A'rabi anni ba'daha / jalastu Ristalis wa al-Iskandara / wa sami'tu Batlaymus darisa kutubihi / mutabaddiyan mutamallikan mutahaddira' (Who will convey to the Bedouins that after it / I sat with Aristotle and Alexander / And heard Ptolemy studying his books / while being a Bedouin, a King, and a civilian?). This is far from issuing from one who did not look into the books of the people (philosophers). Al-Ma'arri said, citing Abu al-Tayyib's saying: 'Ilfu hadha al-hawa'i awqa'a fi al-an / fusi anna al-himama murru al-madhaqi / wa al-asa qabla furqat al-ruhi 'ajzun / wa al-asa la yakunu ba'da al-firaqi' (Familiarity with this air has cast into souls / that death is bitter of taste / And sorrow before the separation of the soul is inability / and sorrow does not exist after separation). These two verses are better than a book of Greek books, for their extremity in truth and good observation. If he had nothing but them, that would suffice him in honor. As for Ibn al-Amid, Ibn Khallikan, may God Almighty have mercy on him, said in his biography: 'He was expansive in the sciences of philosophy and astronomy.' I say: The two Ra-rhymed verses mentioned by Abu al-Tayyib in his praise support what Ibn Khallikan said. I say: Is he not the companion of Al-Sahib bin Abbad, and he was of the men of the Mu'tazila, and has a work in their principles? It is impossible that a Mu'tazili does not look into books of philosophy. As for Ibn Abi al-Hadid, he answered him regarding his claim that a human does not need logic nor these sciences in 'Al-Falak Al-Da'ir'. The correct view is that whoever is ignorant of a thing is an enemy to it.

**Witnessing the State and its role in extracting meanings**
He said in this: Among what helps in extracting meanings is witnessing the state (shahid al-hal).
I say: I do not deny that witnessing the state in the external helps in conceptualizing meanings, but deducing meanings does not require witnessing. A group of blind people have come into existence who did not witness forms in the external, yet brought wonderful similes. Like Bashar bin Burd where he said: 'Ka-anna muthara al-nag'i fawqa ru'usina / wa asyafuna laylun tahawa kawakibuhu' (As if the raised dust above our heads / and our swords are a night whose stars are falling). And like Abu al-Ala al-Ma'arri where he says: 'Wa laha hilalun mithlu nunin ajadaha / bi-dhawb al-nudari al-katibu ibnu hilali' (And a crescent appeared like a Nun [letter N] done well / with molten gold by the scribe Ibn Hilal). And where he says: 'Laylati hadhihi 'arusun min al-zan / ji 'alayha qala'idun min jumani / wa suhaylun ka-wajnat al-hubbi fi al-law / ni wa qalb al-muhibbi fi al-khafaqani / thumma shaba al-duja wa khafa min al-haj / ri fa-ghatta al-mashiba bi-al-za'farani' (This night of mine is a bride of the Zanj / upon her are necklaces of pearls / And Canopus is like the cheek of love in color / and the heart of the lover in throbbing / Then darkness turned gray and feared abandonment / so it covered the gray hair with saffron). He has many things of strange simile. And like Abu al-Baqa al-Ukbari where he says: 'Wa ghadirin raqqat hawashihi hatta / bana fi qa'rihi alladhi kana sakha / wa ka-anna al-tuyura idh waradathu / min safa ma'ihi tazuqqu firakha' (And a pool whose edges thinned until / appeared in its bottom that which sank / And as if the birds, when they came to it / from the purity of its water, were feeding chicks). How sweet is the saying of Abu Tahir Haydar in the like of this: 'Wa dahiyatin waradat biha ghadiran / yuqaddaru min safa' al-ma'i arda / ka-anna al-wahsha haythu taghibbu fihi / yuqabbilu ba'duha lil-shawqi ba'da' (And a morning I arrived with it at a pool / estimated from the purity of water to be ground / As if the wild beasts, where they drink in it / kiss each other out of longing). And like a group who preceded of the blind like Abu al-Ayna and Ibn Sidah the author of 'Al-Muhkam', and Al-Shatibi, may God have mercy on him, and others of those who brought strange things, and did not use the sense of sight. If you say: These, even if they did not see or witness, heard what others said and likened as others likened. I say: I do not dispute you in that, but I intended that simile does not require the external form. The poet may conceptualize the meaning in his mind without seeing it in the external, and generate the meaning from another meaning. Like the saying of Ibn al-Mu'tazz: 'Wa ara al-thurayya fi al-sama'i ka-annaha / qadamun tabaddat min thiyabi hidadi' (I see the Pleiades in the sky as if it is / a foot appearing from robes of mourning). For he generated this meaning from the saying of the other: 'Ka-anna ku'usa al-sharbi wa al-laylu muzlimun / wujuhu 'adhara fi malahifa sudi' (As if the cups of the drink while the night is dark / are faces of virgins in black wraps). And as Ibn al-Dharwi said mentioning the Nubians in praise of Saladin: 'Sudun wa tahmarru al-zuba hawlaha / ka-a'yun al-rumdi badat lil-usah / aw la fa-sumrun tantahiha al-qana / mithlu dinanin buzilat lil-suqah' (Blacks, and swords turn red around them / like eyes of ophthalmia appearing to physicians / Or no, brown ones [spears] aiming at them / like jars tapped for cupbearers). For he generated this first meaning from the saying of Al-Arjani: 'Wa ka-anna kulla shaqiqatin muhmarratin / kuhilat mahajiruha bi-ahmara qani / 'aynun li-insanin wa qad ramidat fa-ma / yabdu li-ramiqiha siwa al-insani' (As if every reddened anemone / whose sockets were kohled with deep red / Is an eye of a human that has ophthalmia, so nothing / appears to its beholder except the pupil/human). And he generated the second meaning from the saying of Abu al-Ala al-Ma'arri in likening lightning: 'Idha ma ihtaja ahmar mustatiran / hasibta al-layla zanjiyyan jariha' (When it agitated red and flying / you thought the night a wounded Zanj). By my life, he managed this second simile nicely. And as I generated from the saying of Al-Husri: 'Al-nasu ka-al-ardi wa minha hum / min khashin al-lamsi wa min layyin / marwun tashakka al-rajulu minhu al-adha / wa ithmidun yuj'alu fi al-a'yun' (People are like the earth and from it they are / of rough touch and of soft / Flint from which a man complains of harm / and antimony put in eyes). So I transferred it to the famous meaning of Al-Mutanabbi and said:

'Mawlan tafarru'a min kiramin wajhuhum / wa bananuhum lil-mujtali wa al-mujtani / sadu al-anama 'ulan wa hum min jinsihim / wa min al-hijarati ithmidun fi al-a'yuni' (A master branched from nobles whose face / and fingertips are for the beholder and the gatherer / They ruled people in highness while they are of their genus / and from stones is antimony in the eyes). And I also generated from the saying of some Arabs: 'Ka-anna hilalahu mir'atu qaynin / laha shatrun yaluhu min al-ghilafi' (As if its crescent is the mirror of a blacksmith / having a half appearing from the sheath). So I said regarding the cheek-hair ('idhar): 'Qultu idh qila li tasalla fa-hadha / sudghuhu qad daja wa kana yuniru / hiya mir'atu khaddihi ghaba minha / fi ghilaf al-'idhar shay'un yasiru' (I said when told to find solace: This / temple of his has darkened while it was shining / It is the mirror of his cheek, disappeared from it / in the sheath of the cheek-hair a small thing). Or he reverses the meaning to its opposite, which is frequent in simile, because simile falls between two ends, similar and likened-to. If you likened stars to sparks, it is permissible to liken sparks to stars. If you likened lightning to a sword, it is permissible to liken a sword to lightning. If you likened the crescent to a nail clipping, it is permissible to liken a nail clipping to a crescent. Ibn al-Mu'tazz said: 'Wa laha daw'u hilalin kada yafdahun / mithla al-qulamati idh quddat min al-zufuri' (And the light of a crescent appeared, almost exposing us / like the clipping when cut from the nail). Sa'd al-Din ibn Arabi reversed that and said about a beautiful one cutting his nails: 'Ab'adta zufraka wa huwa ba'duka fa-alladhi / yahwaka ajdaru bi-al-bu'ad al-atwali' (You distanced your nail while it is part of you, so the one who / loves you is more worthy of the longer distance). So he answered me: 'A-tazunnuni qallamtuha / 'an hajatin, la bal li-ma'nan 'anna li / li-urika ya man bi-al-hilali yaqisuni / anna al-hilala qulamatun min anmuli' (Do you think I clipped them / out of need? No, but for a meaning that occurred to me / To show you, O who measures me by the crescent / that the crescent is a clipping from my fingertips). How excellent is the saying of Al-Hasan bin Ibrahim al-Natri regarding scissors, fingertips, clippings, and nails: 'Ma 'amilun yahki idha ista'maltahu / wa a'anahu khamsun bi-hinna yaduru / saqran yasidu ahillatan yalma'na min / a'la budurin tahtahunna buhuru' (What worker resembles, if you use it / and five help it with which it turns / A falcon hunting crescents shining from / above full moons beneath which are seas?). And I reversed the saying of some of them regarding roses: 'Ka-anna ihmirara al-wardi wa al-tallu fawqahu / khududun tawala fawqaha al-dam'u bi-al-wakfi' (As if the redness of the rose and the dew upon it / are cheeks upon which tears followed in dripping). So I said from verses: 'Aqsamtu ma saja'at wurq al-hama'imi fi / rawdin 'ala mithli 'atfayha wa la sadahat / wa kullama i'tadalat bi-al-mayli qamatuha / ra'aytuha fawqa husn al-ghusni qad rajahat / wa ma iktasa khadduha min lu'lu'in 'araqan / lakinnaha wardatun bi-al-talli qad rashahat' (I swore the doves did not coo in / a garden on the like of her sides nor sang / And whenever her stature straightened with leaning / I saw her outweigh the beauty of the branch / And her cheek was not clothed with pearls of sweat / but she is a rose that sweated with dew). And I also reversed the simile appearing in His Almighty's saying 'And it runs with them in waves like mountains'. So I said: 'Qad rakkabna 'ala al-baridi li-misrin / bahra ramlin 'ajajuhu 'ajjaju / fa-'akasna al-tashbiha lamma jarayna / fi jibalin ka-annaha amwaju' (We rode on the post to Egypt / a sea of sand whose dust billows / So we reversed the simile when we ran / in mountains as if they were waves). The like of this is called the victory of the branch over the root, just as if you likened the dry date stalk to the crescent, the branch to the figure, the narcissus to eyes, night to hair, and morning to the mouth. It is famous.

**The Merit of Al-Mutanabbi in his Lamiyya in Sayf al-Dawla's Tent**
He said after citing Al-Mutanabbi's verses on the tent beginning: 'A-yanfa'u fi al-khaymati al-'adhdhalu' (Does scolding benefit in the tent?), and he quoted fifteen verses from it: These verses have comprised numerous meanings, and it suffices Al-Mutanabbi in merit to bring their like.
I say: Where is this speech regarding Al-Mutanabbi compared to the speech when citing his saying: 'Fa-la tubrimu al-aqdaru ma huwa halil...' (Destinies do not settle what is dissolving...) the verse, and the disparagement and attack on Al-Ma'arri for preferring him.

**Did Abu Nuwas innovate in his verses 'The wine is circulated upon us in a golden cup'?**
He said after citing Abu Nuwas's verses: 'Tudaru 'alayna al-rahu fi 'asjadiyyatin...' (The wine is circulated upon us in a golden cup...) the three verses. Scholars have increased in describing these verses and this meaning, and their saying about it is that it is an innovated meaning. It is told about Al-Jahiz that he said: Poets have ceased not transmitting meanings old and new except this meaning, for Abu Nuwas was unique in innovating it. I do not know what I say to these except to say: You have exceeded the limit of increase, and among current proverbs: 'Without this the donkey is sold.' The eloquence of this poetry in my view is the described, not this meaning. For there is great cost/burden in it. Because Abu Nuwas saw a cup of gold with pictures so he narrated it in his poetry. What I have regarding this is that it is of witnessed meanings, for this wine did not carry except little water, and it submerged the pictures of this cup to the place of their pockets, and the water in it was little to the extent of the caps on their heads. This is a narration of a state witnessed by sight.

I say: Suffice it for this man, may God have mercy on him, to say the like of this. I do not know a book of the mother books of literature like 'Al-Rawda' by Al-Mubarrad, 'Al-Dhakhira' by Ibn Bassam, and 'Zahr al-Adab' by Al-Husri except it contained the mention of these verses and praise for them. Suffice you speech praised by Abu Uthman Amr al-Jahiz, who is among the most skilled Imams of literature, most knowing of what he says, and most insightful of the perceptions of minds. His saying in the like of this is proof, and what he established regarding the verses is the clear path. How excellent is the saying of Al-Qadi Al-Fadil: 'As for Al-Jahiz, may God have mercy on him, there is none of us, assembly of writers, but who entered the neighborhood of his books, launched a raid, and came out with a burden on the shoulder from them.' Al-Fadil, may God have mercy on him, was fond of mentioning him in his correspondence, and mentioning his works. Even if he had nothing in books of literature except the book 'Al-Bayan wa al-Tabyin', that would suffice him in pride. It is said: Among what God favored the nation of Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, over other nations is Umar bin Al-Khattab with his politics, Al-Hasan al-Basri with his knowledge, and Al-Jahiz with his expression. It is told of him that he said: 'I entered the Diwan of correspondence in Baghdad, and saw people who polished their clothes, aligned their turbans, and embroidered their cloaks. Then I tested them, and found them as God Almighty said: 'As for the foam, it goes as scum,' clean exteriors and silly interiors. 'So woe to them for what their hands have written, and woe to them for what they earn.'' Among his answers is what is told that he met Al-Jammaz in a gathering in Basra. Al-Jammaz said to him: 'How many fires are in the language?' He said: 'Fire of war, fire of trees, fire of the glow-worm, fire of the stomach, and the known fire.' He said to him: 'You left the most eloquent of fires.' He said: 'And what is it?' He said: 'The fire of your mother's pussy which, whenever a group is thrown into it, its keepers ask it.' Al-Jahiz said: 'As for my mother's fire, I have judged that it has keepers. The matter is regarding your mother's pussy which is told: Are you full? And it says: Is there any more?' Al-Jahiz is too famous to be mentioned with virtues. I recount what Al-Jahiz said. For Ibn al-Athir, may God have mercy on him, promoted the talk. What the Imams of literature reported from him is that he said: 'We found meanings are turned over, and some taken from others, except the saying of Antara regarding the fly: 'Wa khala al-dhubabu biha fa-laysa bi-barihin / ghariidan ka-fi'l al-sharibi al-mutarannimi / hazijan yahukku dhira'ahu bi-dhira'ihi / qadh al-mukibbi 'ala al-zinadi al-ajdhami' (And the fly was alone with it so it is not leaving / singing like the action of the humming drinker / Buzzing, rubbing his arm with his arm / the striking of the one bending over the flint, the amputee). And the saying of Abu Nuwas regarding the pictures of the cup: 'Tudaru 'alayna al-rahu fi 'asjadiyyatin...' (Wine is circulated upon us in a golden cup...) and he recited the verses.' End.

Ibn Bassam said in 'Al-Dhakhira', mentioning that Abu Nuwas generated this meaning from the saying of Imru' al-Qais: 'Fa-lamma istatabu sabba fi al-sahni nisfahu / wa shujjat bi-ma'in ghayri tarqin wa la kadiri' (When they found it good, he poured half of it in the bowl / and it was mixed with water neither muddy nor turbid). So he made the drink and the water halves due to the strength of the drink. Abu Nuwas climbed over it and hid it with what he occupied speech with of mentioning the engraved pictures, except that it is a beautiful theft. Abu Nuwas repeated this meaning out of admiration for it in places. Like his saying: 'Banayna 'ala Kisra sama'a mudamatin / mukallalatan hafatuha bi-nujumi / fa-law rudda fi Kisra bin Sasan ruhuhu / idhan lastafana duna kulli nadimi' (We built over Kisra a sky of wine / crowned at its edges with stars / If his spirit were returned to Kisra bin Sasan / then he would have chosen us over every drinking companion). Al-Nashi' took it and generated an extra meaning on it, saying: 'Fi ka'siha suwarun tazunnu li-husniha / 'araban barazna min al-hijali wa ghida / wa idha al-mizaju atharaha fa-tanamnamat / dhahaban wa durran taw'aman wa farida / fa-ka-annahunna labisna dhaka majasidan / wa ja'alna dha li-nuhurihinna 'uquda' (In its cup are pictures you think for their beauty / are Arab women appearing from canopies and young ladies / And if the mixture stirs it, it embellishes / gold and pearls, twin and single / As if they wore that as bodysuits / and made this as necklaces for their necks). Ibn al-Mu'tazz said: 'Wa ka'sin min zujajin fihi usdun / fara'isuhunna albabu al-rijali' (And a cup of glass in which are lions / their prey are the minds of men). Ibn Battal al-Batalyawsi alluded to this, saying: 'Wa ghabin min al-akwasi fiha dharaghimun / min al-rahi, albabu al-rijali farisuha / qara'at biha sinna al-humumi fa-aqla'at / wa qad kada yastu bi-al-fu'adi rasisuhu' (And a forest of cups in which are lions / of wine, the minds of men are their prey / I knocked the tooth of worries with it so they desisted / while their fever almost attacked the heart). Abu Tammam ibn Rabah said: 'Wa kasin bada Kisra biha fi qararatin / ghariqan, wa lakin fi khalijin min al-khamri / wa ma sawwarathu Farisun 'abathan bihi / wa lakinnahum ja'u bi-akhfa min al-sihri / asharu bi-ma danu lahu fi hayatihi / fa-numi ilayhi bi-al-sujudi wa la nadri' (And a cup in which Kisra appeared in a bottom / drowning, but in a gulf of wine / Persia did not depict him in vain / but they brought something more hidden than magic / They indicated what they submitted to him in his life / so we indicated to him with prostration while we do not know).

This is what Ibn Bassam cited regarding the meaning of the engraved cup. There is no harm in citing what came regarding that for late poets. Of that is the saying of Ibn Sana' al-Mulk: 'Ma al-durru illa dha al-haba / b wa innani bi-al-durri adra / shi'ri wa shi'ra fi al-sama / ' wa fi ku'usika alfu shi'ra / mannat 'alayka wa la kama / mannat 'ala ashla'i Kisra' (Pearls are nothing but this bubble / and I am most knowing of pearls / My poetry and Sirius (Shi'ra) are in the sky / and in your cups are a thousand Sirius / It favored you, and not as / it favored the remains of Kisra).

'Al-khalqu lamma 'asha qad / sajudu lahu taw'an wa qasra / wa al-kullu lamma mata qad / sajudu lahu fi al-ka'si sukra' (Creation, when he lived / prostrated to him obediently and forcefully / And all, when he died / prostrated to him in the cup out of drunkenness). It is not hidden to the intelligent that this is taken from the saying of Abu Tammam ibn Rabah which preceded, and it is better than this. And his saying also: 'Ala inna shurraba al-mudami humu al-nas / wa ghayruhum fihim jununun wa waswas / fa-ya layta anni mithla Kisra musawwarun / fa-laysa yazalu al-dahra fi kaffihi kas' (Verily the drinkers of wine are the people / and others have madness and whisperings / O would that I were like Kisra depicted / so a cup ceases not to be in his hand forever). This is taken from the saying of Abu Firas. It will come later. And his saying also, which is the ultimate in beauty: 'Sharibna 'ala hadha wa dhaka mudamatan / badat ka-al-'aqiqi al-ratbi wa al-dhahabi al-rakhs / u'ida lana fi ka'siha shakhsu Qaysarin / wa Kisra, fa-kadat tab'athu al-ruha fi al-shakhs / Qayasiratun fi qasri Kisra wa rubbama / majanna fa-qulna bal masakina fi khass' (We drank to this and that a wine / appearing like wet agate and soft gold / The figure of Caesar was returned to us in its cup / and Kisra, so it almost resurrected the spirit in the figure / Caesars in the palace of Kisra, and perhaps / we joked and said: Nay, poor people in a hut). And the saying of Ibn Qalaqis al-Iskandari: 'Law lam yusibha al-ma'u hina tawaqqadat / bi-yadi al-mudiri la-khiftu an yatas'ara / wa banaytuha qasran saqaytu bi-rahati / Kisra Anushirwan fihi wa Qaysara' (If water did not hit it when it ignited / in the hand of the manager, I would have feared it would blaze / And I built it as a palace in which I gave drink with my palm / to Kisra Anushirwan and Caesar). And his saying also: 'Anhakat jismaha al-sinina fa-lawla / 'urfuha lam yakun biha dha i'tirafi / fa-ahni fi al-ka'si jisma Kisra bi-rahin / tab'athu al-ruha minhu fi al-a'tafi' (Years wore out its body, so were it not for / its smell, there would be no recognition of it / It bent in the cup the body of Kisra with a wine / resurrecting the spirit from him in the sides). The saying of Ibn Sana' al-Mulk which preceded is more perfect in beauty. And his saying also: 'Bi-zujajatin darat wa fi janabatiha / Kisra Anushirwan fi iywanihi / khala'at 'ala 'atfayhi khil'ata qahwatin / wa salabtuha fa-ghadawtu fi sultanihi' (With a glass that circulated, and on its sides / Kisra Anushirwan in his Iwan / It bestowed on his sides a robe of coffee / and I robbed it so I became in his authority). Meaning he wore it by drinking it, so he became in his authority, due to the might the drunkard finds. As Al-Munakhkhal the poet of Al-Hamasa said: 'Wa idha sakirtu fa-innani / rabbu al-Khawarnaqi wa al-Sadir / wa idha sahawtu fa-innani / rabbu al-shuwayhati wa al-ba'ir' (And if I get drunk then I am / lord of Al-Khawarnaq and Al-Sadir / And if I sober up then I am / lord of the little sheep and the camel). And the saying of Ibn al-Dharwi: 'Wa musawwarin naza'tu fi / hi 'ala al-mudamati Qaysara / wa salabtuhu mutawwajan / hatta raja'tu musawwara / wa madaytu min 'iqyanihi / wa lujaynihi aghna al-wara' (And a depicted one regarding whom I disputed / over the wine against Caesar / And I robbed him crowned / until I returned bracelet-wearing / And I proceeded from his gold / and his silver the richest of creation). And the saying of Ibn Qalaqis also: 'Wa zujajatin hayyaka minha Qaysaru / wa ka-annama huwa fi jawanibi qasrihi / ma albasathu al-rahu thawban mudhhaban / illa wa qalladahu al-hababu bi-durrihi' (And a glass from which Caesar greeted you / and as if he is in the sides of his palace / Wine did not clothe him in a gilded robe / except the bubbles garlanded him with its pearls). This is taken from the saying of Al-Nashi', and it preceded. How excellent is the saying of Abu Firas: 'A-ghamamu ma yudrika kayfa qitaluna / wa al-khaylu tahta al-nag'i ka-al-ashbahi / natfu wa narsubu fi al-dima'i ka-annana / suwaru al-fawarisi fi ku'usi al-rahi' (O cloud, what lets you know how our fighting is / while horses under the dust are like ghosts / We float and sink in blood as if we are / pictures of knights in cups of wine). Included in what happened to me, containing Tawriya (double entendre): 'Ku'us al-mudami tuhibbu al-safa / fa-kun li-tasawiriha mubtila / wa da'ha sawadhija min naqshiha / fa-ahsanu ma dhahhibat bi-al-tila' (Cups of wine love purity / so be an abolisher/Mubtila of their pictures / And leave them plain of their engraving / for the best they are gilded is with the coating/wine - Tila). And I said also embedding the famous verse, and I demolished from it what I demolished to match the meaning I imagined: 'Wa mashmulatin qad hama Kisra bi-ka'siha / fa-adha yunadi wa huwa fiha musawwaru / waqaftu li-shawqi min wara'i zujajatin / ila al-rahi min farti al-sababati anzuru' (And a chilled wine whose cup Kisra loved / so he became calling out while he is depicted in it / I stood for my longing from behind a glass / looking at the wine from excessive passion). 

As for the saying of Antara regarding the fly, the sheikhs of literature claimed it is of the sterile (unique) similes. Ibn al-Rumi took it and said: 'Wa adhka nasim al-rawdi ray'ana zillihi / wa ghanna mughanni al-tayri fihi fa-rajja'a / wa gharrada rab'iyyu al-dhubabi khilalahu / kama hathhathat al-nudmanu sanjan musharra'a / fa-kanat araninu al-dhubabi hunakum / 'ala shadawati al-tayri darban muwaqqa'a' (The breeze of the garden kindled the prime of its shade / and the singer of birds sang in it and echoed / And the spring fly chirped through it / as drinking companions shook a raised cymbal / So the buzzing of flies there was / upon the songs of birds a rhythmic beat). And Ibn Abdun said: 'Saru wa misku al-dayaji ghayru manhubin / wa turratu al-sharqi ghaflun duna tadhhibi / 'ala ruban lam yazal shadi al-dhubabi biha / yulqi bi-aniqi malfuzin wa madrubi' (They traveled while the musk of darknesses was not looted / and the edge of the East was plain without gilding / Upon hills where the chanting of the fly ceases not / to cast elegant uttered and beaten [rhythms]). He took it from the saying of Al-Muthaqqib al-Abdi mentioning the she-camel: 'Wa tastami'u al-dhubaba idha taghanna / ka-taghridi al-hamami 'ala al-ghusuni' (She listens to the fly when it sings / like the warbling of doves on branches). And the saying of Al-Uqayshir: 'Wa qad taqumu 'ala ra'si muna''amatun / laha idha taribat min sawtiha ghanaju / fa-tarfa'u al-sawta ahyanan wa takhfiduhu / kama yatinnu dhubabu al-rawdati al-haziju' (And a soft woman may stand at my head / having, if enraptured by her voice, coquetry / She raises the voice sometimes and lowers it / as the buzzing garden fly hums). Ibn Abdun took his saying from the saying of Al-Akhtal describing a wild bull. Which is: 'Faridan yughannihi dhubbanu al-riyadi / kama ghanna al-ghuwatu bi-sanjin 'inda aswari' (Alone, the flies of the gardens sing to him / as the seducers sang with a cymbal at walls). Abu Bakr bin Sa'd al-Batalyawsi said: 'Ka-anna ahazija al-dhubabi asaqifun / laha min azahiri al-riyadi maharibu' (As if the hummings of the fly are bishops / having niches from the flowers of the gardens).

No one dared this meaning before Antara. However, Dhu al-Rumma transferred the meaning of the description to the cricket (Jundub), saying: 'Ka-anna rijlayhi rijla muqtifin 'ajilin / idha tajadhaba min bardayhi tarnimu' (As if his two legs are the legs of a hasty plucker / if a humming pulls from his two garments). Al-Salami said regarding a wasp, and excelled: 'Wa labisu lawnin wahidin wa huwa ta'irun / mulawwanatu abradihi wa huwa waqi'u / agharru muhashsha al-taylasani mudajjaju / wa sudu al-manaya fi hashahu wada'i'u / idha hakka a'la ra'sihi fa-ka-annama / bi-salifatayhi min yadayhi jawami'u / bada farisiyya al-ziyyi ya'qidu khasrahu / wa mi'zaruhu al-tibriyyu asfaru faqi'u / yurajji'u alhana al-gharidi wa ma'badin / wa yasqi ku'usan mil'uha al-sammu naqi'u' (Wearing one color while flying / his robes are colored while landing / White-faced, cloak-bordered, armed / and black deaths are deposits in his gut / If he scratches the top of his head, it is as if / in his whiskers from his hands are unions / He appeared Persian of dress tying his waist / and his gold apron is bright yellow / He echoes the tunes of Al-Gharid and Ma'bad / and serves cups whose fill is soaking poison). His saying: 'If he scratches the top of his head...' the verse, is from the saying of Muslim bin al-Walid: 'Fa-ghattat bi-aydiha thimara nuhuriha / ka-aydi al-asari athqalatha al-jawami'u' (She covered with her hands the fruits of her neck / like the hands of prisoners weighed down by shackles). Al-Salami transferred this meaning to the wasp when he generated it from here, and shared with Antara the description as a hidden sharing. Thus is correct poetic imagination. How sweet is the saying of some poets: 'Fi'lu al-adibi idha khala bi-humumihi / fi'lu al-dhubabi yarinnu 'inda faraghihi / fa-tarahu yafruku rahatayhi nadamatan / minhu wa yutbi'uha bi-latmi dimaghihi' (The action of the writer if alone with his worries / is the action of the fly buzzing at his leisure / You see him rubbing his palms in regret / regarding it, and following it with slapping his brain). I only cited these pieces regarding the depicted cup and the fly and increased in them because this place is of the notches of literature and strange meanings. Perhaps this amount has not gathered for anyone in them. As for his saying 'Without this the donkey is sold', the origin of this proverb is that a man wanted to buy a donkey from another called Abu Yasar. He began describing it and exaggerating until he said: 'You hunt ostriches with it hobbled.' He said to him: 'Compare, O Abu Yasar; without this the donkey sells (yanfaqu).' 'Compare' (Shakih) means approach, i.e., do not exaggerate.

He said: Likewise occurred his saying: 'Ya shaqiqa al-nafsi min hakamin / numta 'an layli wa lam anam / fasqini al-bikra allati i'tajarat / bi-khimar al-shaybi fi al-rahimi' (O twin of the soul from Hakam / you slept through my night and I did not sleep / So give me the virgin [wine] who veiled herself / with the veil of gray hair in the womb). This is an invented meaning not preceded, and it is subtle; due to its subtlety it almost joins meanings extracted without a depicted witness of state. He cited a story that happened in the presence of Al-Rashid regarding extracting its meaning, which is famous.

I say: Abu Nuwas is among those who have meanings whose exterior is easy and interior is difficult, in the utmost subtlety. Like his saying: 'Ama tara al-shamsa hallat al-hamala / wa taba waznu al-zamani wa i'tadala / wa ghannat al-tayru ba'da 'ujmatiha / wa istawfat al-rahu hawlaha kamala' (Do you not see the sun has entered Aries / and the weight of time has become good and balanced / And birds sang after their silence / and the wine fulfilled its year completely?). The place of difficulty in it is 'and the wine fulfilled its year'. They said: From the time of pressing the wine until the sun enters Aries is not but six months or thereabouts, so his claim that the wine fulfilled the year completely is not correct, for the year (hawl) is twelve months. The answer is from aspects: First, and it is the strongest, that the pronoun in 'hawlaha' (its year/orbit) does not refer to the wine, but refers to the sun. As if he said: And the wine fulfilled the orbit of the sun completely. Second, that intended by 'Hawl' here is the limit and completion, and the meaning: The wine fulfilled its maturity and fitness to be used and sipped. In this period the fitness of wine ends, and everything that reached a limit sought from it has fulfilled its 'hawl'. As if from: It changed (hala) from its form to another form. This is what is understood from his speech. Likewise his saying: 'Zallat humayya al-ka'si tabsutuna / hatta tahattaka baynana al-sitru / fi majlisin dahika al-sururu bihi / 'an najidhayhi, wa hallat al-khamru' (The fever of the cup continued to relax us / until the veil was torn between us / In a gathering where joy laughed / showing its molars, and wine became lawful). They mentioned four faces in this: First, that the goodness of the place and perfection of joy permitted its prohibition according to the custom of poets in their exaggerations. Second, that he had sworn to himself not to consume wine until he met his beloved, so the meeting was an exit from his oath. Like the saying of Imru' al-Qais: 'Hallat li al-khamru wa kuntu imra'an / 'an shurbiha fi shughulin shagheli' (Wine became lawful for me, and I was a man / occupied from drinking it by a distraction). Third, he means by 'hallat' descended/settled, from settling in a place. Fourth: He means they deemed it lawful by entering into drunkenness and the absence of their mind. I stood in the Egyptian lands upon a part containing speech by Abu Abdullah Muhammad bin Abdullah al-Khatib on the poet's saying: 'Bidun mafariquna taghli marajiluna / na'su bi-amwalina athara aydina' (White are our partings, boiling are our cauldrons / we heal with our wealth the traces of our hands). He mentioned regarding his saying: 'White are our partings' two hundred and three faces in the probability of the meaning of these two words. I found two verses for Abu al-Hasan al-Tusi the Jurist, the meaning of the second of which is asked about: 'Mannaynanni hinan fa-lamma / an malaltu min al-tamanni / 'arradna li bi-al-wasli hatta / qultu qad, a'radna 'anni' (They gave me false hopes for a time, so when / I became bored of wishing / They hinted to me of connection until / I said 'Enough' (qad), they turned away from me).

The difficulty in it is: How do they hint to him of connection, while he claims they turned away from him? The one turning away does not hint at connection. The answer: 'Qad' here means 'Hasbu' (Enough/Suffice), and that is one of its usages. Like the saying of Abu Tammam: 'Qaduka itta'ib arbaita fi al-ghulawa' (Enough of you, hold back, you exceeded in excess). i.e., Sufficient for you. The meaning: They gave me hope for a time until I got bored, then they hinted to me of connection until, when I said 'This is enough for me', they turned away from me. Two verses happened for me in what I said, the second is difficult, which are: 'Qala wa qad absara dam'i daman / hadha wa ma ra'atka bi-al-bayni / fa-qultu: lamma faniyat admu'i / bakaytu bi-al-dam'i bi-la 'ayni' (He said, having seen my tear as blood / This, while she did not frighten you with separation / So I said: When my tears perished / I wept with the tear (dam') without 'ayn' (eye/letter 'ayn)). The difficulty in that is: How does he confess that his tears perished and ran out, then say after that: I wept with the tear without an eye? And how does weeping without an eye happen? The answer: He said first he saw him weeping blood so he denied that to him. So he said when tears ran out and no tear remained for me, I wept with blood. The 'Ayn here is intended to be one of the letters of the alphabet, the sister of the dotted Ghayn, not the eye which is the limb of human sight. For 'Dam'' (Tear), if you delete the 'Ayn from it, it becomes 'Dam' (Blood).

**Can a meaning be invented from a non-invented meaning?**
He said: Know that an innovated meaning may be extracted from a meaning that is not innovated. From that is the saying of the poet known as Ibn al-Sarraj regarding the cheetah (Fahd): 'Tanafasa al-laylu fihi wa al-naharu ma'an / fa-qammasahu bi-jilbabin min al-muqali' (Night and day competed in it together / so they clothed it in a robe of eyeballs). This is not of the strange meanings, but it is a good simile falling in its place. A poet from the people of Mosul called Ibn Musanhir came after him and extracted from this verse a strange meaning, saying: 'Wa naqqatathu hiba'an kay yusalimaha / min al-manaya ni'aju al-ramli bi-al-hadaqi' (And the ewes of the sand dotted him as a gift so he would make peace with them / from deaths, with [their] pupils). 

I say: The first of Ibn al-Sarraj's verses: 'Shathnu al-barathini fi fihi wa fi yadihi / ma lil-qawadibi wa al-'assalati al-dhubuli / wa al-shamsu mudh laqqabu bi-al-ghazalati lam / tatlu' li-khifatihi illa 'ala wajali' (Rough of claws, in his mouth and in his hand / is what belongs to sharp swords and pliable spears / And the sun, since they nicknamed it 'Gazelle' (Ghazala), did not / rise due to fear of him except in dread). I do not know the meaning of his saying: 'He extracted from it a strange meaning.' What strange thing did the second one bring? The strange meaning is that the whiteness and blackness of the cheetah resemble eyes. This is the spirit of this meaning. As for 'Night and day competed in it', and 'The ewes made peace with him and dotted him', it is not a big deal. As for extracting a strange meaning from another meaning, it is like the saying of Muslim bin al-Walid: 'Tazallama al-malu wa al-a'da'u min yadihi / la zala lil-mali wa al-a'da'i zallama' (Wealth and enemies complained of injustice from his hand / May he cease not to be an oppressor to wealth and enemies). He extracted it from the saying of Abu Nuwas: 'Bahha sawtu al-mali mimma / minka yad'u wa yasihu' (The voice of wealth became hoarse from / calling and shouting because of you). Muslim's saying is more eloquent and his meaning more profound. Extractions of meanings from meanings less than them in strangeness happened to me. Of that is the saying of Baylik al-Qibjaqi al-Ma'arri regarding the Citron (Utrujj): 'Wa utrujjatin ja'at ilayka hadiyyatan / fa-shabbahtu minha al-riha riha habibi / idha nazarat 'ayni ilayha tamaththalat / bi-kaffi maridin maddaha li-tabibi' (And a citron came to you as a gift / so I likened its smell to the smell of a beloved / If my eye looks at it, it represents / the hand of a sick man extending it to a doctor). I extracted another meaning from it and said: 'Aya husna utrujjin yaluhu li-naziri / 'alayhi min al-awraqi khudru al-ghala'ili / haka mustahaman ghayyara al-baynu halahu / wa qad 'adda ayyama al-jafa bi-al-anamili' (O beauty of a citron appearing to my sight / upon it from leaves are green tunics / It resembled a lover whose state separation changed / and has counted the days of estrangement with fingertips). From that is the saying of Shihab al-Din al-Talla'fari: 'Jaraytu bi-hamra'i al-kumayti ila al-shaqra / mafarra al-hawa tiban wa a'radtu 'an Maqra' (I ran with the red bay wine to the blond/sorrel horse / the escape of passion in goodness and turned away from Maqra). I extracted another meaning from it and said: 'Wa hamra'a lamma tarashshaftuha / janaytu al-masarrata fima janaytu / wa nultu al-masarrati duna al-wara / li-anni sabaqtuhum bi-al-kumayt' (And a red one, when I sipped it / I gathered joy in what I gathered / And attained joys to the exclusion of people / because I beat them with the Kumayt (dark red wine/bay horse)). And from that is the saying of Mahyar al-Daylami: 'Hal al-sabiqu al-'ajlanu yamliku amrahu / fa-ma kullu sayri al-ya'mulati wakhidu / ruwaydan bi-akhfafi al-mataya fa-innama / tudasu jibahun fi al-thara wa khududu' (Does the hasty preceder own his affair? / For not all the march of camels is a trot / Gently with the hoofs of the mounts, for only / foreheads in the soil and cheeks are being trodden). I extracted another meaning from it and said: 'Adha nasimu Dimashqa hayyahu al-haya / yamshi al-huwayna fi zilali himaha / wa ka-annahu min ma'iha wa hidabiha / ma dasa illa a'yunan wa jibaha' (The breeze of Damascus—may rain greet it—became / walking slowly in the shadows of its sanctuary / As if, from its water and its hills / it trod nothing but eyes and foreheads). And from that is the saying of Ibn al-Tilimsani: 'Saqin yurini qalbahu qaswatan / wa kullu saqin qalbuhu qasi' (A cupbearer showing me his heart as hardness / and every 'Saqin' (cupbearer/leg), its heart (middle letter) is Qaf (Qasi - hard)). I extracted another meaning from it and said: 'Qalb al-danni min ahabba fa-adhat / nafhatu al-naddi min humayyahu tuhda / qala li i'jab fa-qultu ghayra 'ajibin / kullu dannin qallabtahu kana nadda' (The heart of the cask (Dann) is who he loved, so / the scent of aloes-wood (Nadd) became gifted from its fever / He said to me: Wonder! I said not wondering: / Every Dann (cask), if you reversed it, becomes Nadd (aloes-wood)). Among the best I stood upon regarding the cheetah is the saying of the poet: 'Wa muttasifin bi-al-fatki 'inda iktisabihi / 'ala zufrihi shibhu al-dima'i wa nabihi / ka-anna mahata al-fulki lamma intaha bihi / madahu ila sirbi al-maha wa intihabihi /

'Ramat-hu bi-shuhbi al-jawwi khawfa intiqamihi / fa-atfa'aha fi 'asjadin min ihabihi' (She threw him with the shooting stars of the sky fearing his revenge / so he extinguished them in the gold of his skin).

**Discussing a model of Ibn al-Athir's composition**
He said: From that is what I mentioned in a chapter of a book on besieging a town, mentioning fighting with the mangonel (Manjaniq), so I said: 'So we encamped within sight and earshot of it, and surrounded it like the ring around the finger. Mangonels were set up so they created clouds difficult to lead, exclusive to the hills (ruba) to the exclusion of the lowlands (wahad). They ceased not to bombard the boulders of the wall with a shower of their boulders, and surprise it with their thunders before their lightnings, and the lightnings of clouds are before their thunders, until they left the rugged of it plain, and the populated a wasteland.' In this are two strange meanings: First, that these clouds are exclusive to the hills not the lowlands; and the other, that their thunders are before their lightnings.

I say: I do not know what the meaning of his saying in likening dust to 'clouds difficult to lead' is. And his claiming that restricting clouds to hills without lowlands is a strange matter. In this is arbitrariness; some clouds water lowlands and not hills, and some the opposite, this is a sensed matter. If it watered the hills and dried the lowlands, it was exclusive to the hills, and vice versa. How excellent is the saying of Abu al-Ala al-Ma'arri: 'Wa law anna al-sahaba hama bi-'aqlin / la-ma arwa ma'a al-nakhli al-qatada / wa law a'ta 'ala qadr al-ma'ali / saqa al-hadabati wa ijtanaba al-wahada' (If the cloud poured with reason / it would not have watered the tragacanth with the palm trees / And if it gave according to the measure of highness / it would have watered the hills and avoided the lowlands). Likewise his claim that lightnings in clouds are before thunders is a non-necessary matter, for lightnings may be seen after thunders, although mostly they are before. There is no harm in citing something of the speech of Al-Qadi Al-Fadil, may God Almighty have mercy on him, here in mentioning the mangonel. From that: 'The servant wrote while the mangonels had silenced their Muslim index finger (subbaba - hinting at Tashahhud), and the lack of surrender (taslim) was for the truce of the submitting (mustaslima) town.' From it: 'The siege continues on Safed, and thick, severe mangonels have been set up against it, gathering the descriptions of the Zabaninyah (Angels of Hell). We do not hear in the night and day except the first and the second, and may God grant success to the third in the worship of the three (Trinity). The town is a knot, and the Sultan's happiness is blowing in the knots. Its side has not listened until now to the mangonel, nor has its nose been rubbed in the dust from the towers.' From that: 'They did not snatch the snatching until a piercing meteor followed them, nor did they cast themselves into the trench until swords cast them from every side, nor did they advance against the sky of mangonels because it had been adorned by the fighters with the adornment of stars.' From that: 'After setting up mangonels throwing stones of alternating calamities. If ropes follow them bidding farewell, it is imagined that they are stars possessing tails (comets). And after the address of grave matters warned them against obstinacy, and holes shook the sides of walls and the fruit of towers fell.' From that: 'I am descending upon a spring (eyes) whose roaring deafens the hearing, above mountains whose cloud-pile blinds the eye, under a sky whose unveiling this morning made me suspicious. Before me is fighting in which its director passes the cup of death, and behind me are stones of mangonels which, if the dots of the letters of the Zodiac saw them, their lines would be erased.' From that: 'And the mangonel knelt judging it, and the tongue of its rope disputing with it. The servant under the Islamic mangonel exposes the face to the Frankish mangonel, and moves the pieces of barricades like the moving of chess pieces, where shields are pawns and Jafatis (siege engines) are rooks, and where citadels are prey and stones are love/grain and mangonels are traps.' From that: 'They tightened on Acre with wooden towers that struck the ranks with stone towers, and advanced with mangonels warring against God and His Messenger, so their hands and feet were cut off from opposite sides.' From that: 'In the frontier are mangonels whose salary is not suspended, nor its striker observed. The biggest of them is what killed the fighter by crushing, and the smallest is what made the pawn of the head a rook.' From that: 'We had descended upon this city and wanted to respect its mouth (Thagh - frontier), and save it from its breaching and gap. But when it was the second day of Adha, and patience had reached from us the limit of one who has no blame in drawing near by sacrificing it, and it was decreed that its hill be thrown down to the forehead, and that it not be taken by trust (Amman) but taken by the right hand (Yamin/Oath), so the mangonels laid it down and the holes slaughtered it, and blood flowed from it immediately necessitating the South wind from its towers.' From the composition of our Sheikh Judge Shihab al-Din Mahmud, may God have mercy on him, from a poem he composed on the conquest of Al-Marqab: 'Wa amtaratha al-majaniqu allati nasha'at / wa lam yakun qablaha yahmi bihi al-mataru / wa kana lil-kasri minha kullama sana'u / min jinsiha wa li-aydi al-hadmi ma 'amaru / ka-annaha wa majaniqa al-ifrinji laha / fara'isu al-usdi idh azfaruha al-zufuru / wa kam shaka al-hisnu ma yalqa fa-ma iktarathat / ya qalbaha a-hadidun anta am hajaru' (And mangonels rained upon it which rose / and rain did not pour with it before / And there was for breaking from it whatever they made / of its kind, and for the hands of demolition whatever they built / As if they and the Frankish mangonels to them / are prey of lions when their claws are fingernails / How often the fortress complained of what it met but she did not care / O her heart, are you iron or stone?). And from a letter written by Judge Taj al-Din Ahmad ibn al-Athir regarding this conquest also:

'And mangonels launch towards them the arrows of their bows, and it is imagined they are striving towards them with their ropes and sticks. They are among the fiercest opponents to fortresses. If they aim at (ammat) a fortress, it is judged that it is not a protected Imam (Imam Ma'sum). Whenever creation doubted in the instruments of conquest, it was not among the doubters. If it descends in the courtyard of a people, evil is the morning of those warned. It is called to war so it speaks (tukallim - or wounds), and no prayer of war was established at a fortress except that fortress was among those who prostrate and submit (yusallim).' Ibn al-Sa'ati said: 'Wa mata yuhawilu baldatan lam yathnihi / hashdu al-juyushi biha wa la bu'du al-mada / hatamat majaniquhu thanaya suriha / fa-ra'ayta dhaka al-thaghra thaghran adrada' (When he attempts a town, he is not turned back / by the gathering of armies in it nor the distance of range / His mangonels smashed the central incisors of its wall / so you saw that gap (Thaghr - mouth) a toothless mouth).

**Models of Ibn al-Athir's composition in which he claims precedence**
He said: From that is what I described regarding the enemy's descent to besiege a town of the lands of the one written about, and that was in the time of winter. Much snow fell on the enemy so he became besieged by it. I said: 'The fighting of lightnings hastened him before the banners, and snow surrounded him so it became trenches intervening between him and the trenches. Winter met his army with its army of cold. The sky faced him with its dusty face not its green one. The earth is like a loaf of pure white bread (qursat al-naqi), and perhaps it is the land of his gathering (Mahshar).' Then he started mentioning the invention of the meaning from the Prophetic Hadith: 'You will be gathered on a white land like a loaf of pure white bread (qursat al-naqi),' meaning the white bread. He hummed and buzzed about that.

I say: Wonder is at him recording these things, collecting and citing them, and preaching after each one a sermon for himself, claiming in it that rhetoric in others is metaphor and in his speech reality, and that he brought necklaces of pearls while others brought a beads and he is not satisfied to say agate. I have cited a letter by Al-Qadi Al-Fadil previously which he issued from Ba'rin, mentioning rains, snows, and tents, and he brought in it beauties that Ibn al-Athir has no hands in, nor do two Farqad stars revolve on its pole for a writer. From the speech of Al-Qadi Al-Fadil: 'As for the snows, that expression (bayan) which connected them kindled them, nay gifted them to the chests which are the houses of the fire of longing, so it cooled/cheered them (athlajaha). The lands were represented as if the Master spread his honor ('ard) over them, and it pleased me that his silver pleased that space ('ard). He showed me the stars in this year having advised in its fertility, so they descended themselves, and appeared visible in the day with their running and retreating ones. It is worthy to be a year washing the dirt of disbelief with the soap of its snow, and giving glad tidings to the Nasiri determination from this foam of what is under it of its pure victory.' From that: 'If God uncovers the mask of doubt, it will be the most worthy station of leaving. You will see nothing but the gathering of insects (hasharat), nay the removing of regrets (hasrat). Its day is piebald with worry and snow, and the spender in it turns his palms over what he spent.' From a letter written by Judge Muhyiddin ibn Qarnus to Judge Taj al-Din ibn al-Athir: 'When he wrote it attacking, the face of the horizon was frowning with clouds, and the mouth of Hama was smiling with snow. Stillness appeared on it, where the centuries (or horns/peaks) turned gray. The servant was overlooking a place surrounded by fruit, and the tree turns its palms over what it spent of its life. It became ascetic so it stripped of the silk of its leaves and wore the cotton of its flowers. You see nothing but trees standing on their roots, and vineyards with empty trellises, and falling snow like scattered moths, and mountains of clouds like fluffed wool.' From the answer of Judge Muhyiddin ibn Abd al-Zahir to this letter: 'Our heading out was then when the mountains were clothed in snows, and storms surrounded us from every side, a surrounding having no openings. In a season in which the sky opened its doors with what its aggregate has no segments (fusul) from those places, nor for the dye of frost tanning the skin of the soil any endurance from fading (nusul). So we returned to the side of Homs, even if the year did not please us. We said all that is forgiven beside what the interest of Islam indicated, covering the specific and general of them. We faced those windy regions, and the distant dwellings on the remote stages, with the thinness of skins fighting against the ice/frost (jalid), and faces facing from those backs what arrival at the pools of death is closer to than the jugular vein. How often the sun wrapped itself seeking protection from its cold (qarr) in a squirrel fur of clouds. How often its eye closed from one whose eyelids did not taste sleep nor covet slumber. How often the freezing cold (zamharir) cast the silver of its snows so it was sound upon casting (sabk). How often news from Imru' al-Qais recited at Al-Nabk 'Qifa nabki' (Stop let us weep). This while the severe cold (Zamita) had extended its washed sheet over the lands and servants, and souls became killed by it not sick. As if it is the streaking of gray hair on the partings, or white sand sprinkled on the lines of those parchments.' Judge Muhyiddin ibn Abd al-Zahir, may God Almighty have mercy on him, has several pieces on the velvet rug (Qatifa) describing its cold. Including his saying: 'Hadhi al-qatifatu allati / la tushtaha 'aqlan wa naqla' (This velvet rug which / is not desired by reason or tradition).

'Hushiyat bi-bardin yabisin / fa-li-ajli dhaka al-hashwi tuqla' (It was stuffed with dry cold / so for the sake of that stuffing it is hated). And his saying also: 'Ala dhammi al-qatifati ijtama'na / wa in hushiyat bi-bardin qad takarrar / wa qad adha 'alayha lil-zamita / bayadun mithlama qad dharra sukkar / wa lam yakun al-mukaffanu ghayra shakhsin / yakunu ila nawahiha musayyar' (We agreed on blaming the velvet rug / even if it was stuffed with cold that repeated / And there became upon it from the severe cold / a whiteness like sugar sprinkled / And the shrouded one was no other than a person / who is made to travel to its regions). The verses of Shihab al-Din al-Shaghuri are famous regarding snow. They are: 'Qad akhmada al-jamra fi kanun hina qadah / wa ajmada al-khamra fi kanun kulla qadah / ya jubbat al-zabadani anti musfiratun / 'an husni wajhin idha wajhu al-zamani kalah / fa-al-thalju qutnun 'alayki al-suhbu tandifuhu / wa al-jawwu yahlijuhu wa al-qawsu qawsu qazah' (He extinguished the ember in Kanun (Dec/Jan) when he struck fire / and froze the wine in Kanun in every cup / O Jubbah (gown/village) of Zabadani, you are unveiling / a beautiful face when the face of time scowls / The snow is cotton upon you, the clouds tease it / and the atmosphere gins it, and the bow is the bow of Qazah (Rainbow)). From this is the saying of Abu al-Fadl the Writer: 'Wa atrabana ghaymun yumazihu shamsahu / fa-tustaru tawran bi-al-sahabi wa taksifu / tara qazahan fi al-jawwi yaftahu qawsahu / mukibban 'ala qutnin min al-thalji yandifu' (A cloud delighted us joking with its sun / so it is covered sometimes by the cloud and eclipses / You see Qazah in the atmosphere opening his bow / bending over cotton of snow teasing it). It is said that snow fell once in Baghdad, so some poets of that era said: 'Ya sudura al-'iraqi lam nara thaljan / qablaha halla fi nawahi al-'iraqi / innama 'amma zulmukum sa'ira al-na / si fa-shabat dhawa'ibu al-afaqi' (O chests/leaders of Iraq, we did not see snow / before it settled in the regions of Iraq / Rather your injustice covered all the people / so the locks of the horizons turned gray). Included in what happened to me regarding that: 'Tabban laha min baldatin la ara / fiha maqami wadiha al-nahji / li-annaha fi wajhi sukkaniha / wa ahliha tabsuqu bi-al-thalji' (Perish a town in which I do not see / my stay as clear of path / Because in the face of its inhabitants / and its people, it spits with snow).

**Beauty in Ibn Baqi's verses: 'By my father is a gazelle my eye flirted with'**
He said, citing in the beauties of meanings the saying of the poet: 'Bi-abi ghazalun ghazalathu muqlati / bayna al-'udhaybi wa bayna shattay bariqi...' (By my father is a gazelle my eye flirted with / between Al-Udhayb and the two banks of Bariq...) the verses. This is of the ultimate beauty and charm. Its meanings were so light on the hearts that they almost danced. The last verse is the one described with innovation, and by it and its likes eyes acknowledged the merit of ears...

I say: These verses are by Ibn Baqi, and Ibn al-Abbar cited them in 'Tuhfat al-Qadim'. Then he said: Some people of our era attributed rudeness to Ibn Baqi in his saying: 'Ab'adtuhu 'an muhjatin tashtaquhu' (I distanced him from a soul/blood that misses him). If he had said: 'I distanced from him ribs (adali'a) that miss him,' it would have been better. Then he cited after that for Abu al-Hakam Ja'far bin Yahya bin Attal al-Dani: 'Hubbuka ladhdha bi-kulli ma'na / ila karan milta aw suhadi / in kana la budda min ruqadin / fa-adlu'i haka 'an wisadi / wa nam 'ala khafqiha huduwwan / ka-al-tifli fi nahnahi al-mihadi' (Your love is sweet in every meaning / whether you incline to sleep or sleeplessness / If there must be sleep / then here are my ribs as a pillow / And sleep on their throbbing quietly / like the child in the rocking of the cradle). When I stood upon what Ibn al-Abbar mentioned of the objection to Ibn Baqi, and the verses of Ibn al-Attal, it occurred to me that this should be verse. So I versified that on the rhyme of Ibn Baqi and his meter: 'Ab'adtuhu min ba'di ma zahzahtuhu / ma anta 'inda dhawi al-gharam bi-'ashiqi / hadha yadullu al-nasa minka 'ala al-jafa / idh laysa hadha fi'la sabbin wamiqi / in shi'ta qul ab'adtu 'anhu adalu'i / li-yakuna fi'la al-mustahami al-sadiqi / aw qul fa-bata 'ala idtirabi jawanih / ka-al-tifli mudtaji'an bi-mahdin khafiqi' (I distanced him after I nudged him / You are not, among those of passion, a lover / This indicates to people harshness from you / since this is not the act of a loving yearner / If you wish, say: I distanced my ribs from him / to be the act of the truthful infatuated one / Or say: So he spent the night on the disturbance of flanks / like a child lying in a throbbing cradle). Look at what he deemed good, praised, and preferred, how people raised objections to it and criticized it. By my life, it is good criticism, a precise approach, and a valid objection. 

As for the throbbing (khafq) of the heart and its disturbance from the lover, the later poets have subtle intents in it. Of that is the saying of Al-Haziri the Paper-merchant: 'Yaqulu li hina wafa / qad nilta ma tartajihi / fa-ma li-qalbika qad ja / 'a khafquhu ya'tarihi / fa-qultu wasluka 'ursun / wa al-qalbu yarqusu fihi' (He says to me when he fulfilled: / You have attained what you hope for / So why has your heart come / with its throbbing afflicting it? / So I said: Your connection is a wedding / and the heart dances in it). And the saying of... 'La tunkiru khafaqana qalbin / ja'a al-habibu ilayhi za'ir / ma tilka illa daruhu / duqqat lahu fiha basha'ir' (Do not deny the throbbing of a heart / to which the beloved came as a visitor / That is but his house / drums of good news were beaten for him in it). And the saying of Ibn Sana' al-Mulk: 'Ama wa-Allahi lawla khawfu sakhtik / la-hana 'alayya ma alqa bi-rahtik / malakta al-khafiqayni fa-tihta 'ujban / wa laysa huma siwa qalbi wa qurtik' (Nay, by God, were it not for fear of your anger / what I meet from your group would be easy for me / You possessed the two throbbing ones (East and West / or Heart and Earring) and wandered in pride / and they are nothing but my heart and your earring). And the saying of Abu al-Walid ibn al-Jannan al-Shatibi: 'Wa abika lam yakhfaq janani innama / taraban bi-ayyami al-'aqiqi yusaffiqu / la yadda'i fihi al-fu'adu khufuqahu / fa-wishahu man ahwa la-'amri akhfaqu' (By your father, my heart did not throb, rather / out of rapture for the days of Al-Aqiq it claps / The heart does not claim its throbbing in it / for the sash of the one I love, by my life, is more throbbing). And the saying of the other: 'Malaka al-qurta wa al-fu'ada fa-haqqun / an yusamma bi-maliki al-khafiqayni / wahidu al-husni fi al-wara thaniyu al-ghus / ni idha masa thalithu al-qamarayni' (He possessed the earring and the heart, so it is right / that he be named the owner of the two throbbing ones / The unique one of beauty in creation, the second of the branch / if he sways, the third of the two moons). And the saying of Al-Badr Yusuf bin Lulu al-Dhahabi: 'Wa ahwa fatiru al-ajfani alma / rashiqun qadduhu rakhsu al-banani'

'Tamallaka qurtuhu wa al-qalbu minni / fa-sara lahu bi-dhaka al-khafiqani' (His earring and the heart from me took possession / so he had by that the two throbbing ones). And the saying of Ibn Sana' al-Mulk from a eulogy: 'Awsa'ta fika al-dahra 'atban mu'liman / fa-ajabani bi-al-buhti wa al-buhtani / qalbi yuhasibuhu 'ala ijramihi / wa ya'udduha bi-anamili al-khafaqani' (I expanded painful blame against Time regarding you / so it answered me with slander and falsehood / My heart holds it accountable for its crimes / and counts them with the fingertips of throbbing). How excellent is the saying of Al-Qadi Al-Fadil also: 'Wa qad khafaqat rayatuhu fa-ka-annaha / anamilun fi 'umri al-'aduwwi tuhasibuhu' (And his banners fluttered/throbbed as if they were / fingertips counting/accountable in the life of the enemy). And the saying of Mu'in al-Din bin Tulwa: 'Lam ansahu idh qala ayna tuhilluni / hadharan 'alayya min al-khayali al-tariqi / fa-ajabtuhu: qalbi fa-qala ta'ajjuban: / a-ra'ayta 'umraka sakinan fi khafiqi' (I did not forget him when he said: Where do you settle me / fearing for me from the visiting phantom? / So I answered him: My heart. He said in wonder: / Have you ever seen a dweller in a throbbing/moving thing?). It is taken from the saying: 'Wa sakanta qalban khafiqan / ya sakinan fi ghayri sakin' (You inhabited a throbbing heart / O dweller in a non-stationary thing). How excellent is the saying of Al-Siraj al-Warraq: 'Ya sakinan qalbi dhakartuka qablahu / a-ra'ayta qabli man bada bi-al-sakini / wa ja'altuhu waqfan 'alayka wa qad ghada / mutaharrikan bi-khilafi qalbi al-amini' (O dweller of my heart, I remembered you before it / Have you seen before me anyone who began with a Sukun (silent letter)? / And I made it an endowment (Waqf) upon you while it became / moving (Mutaharrik) contrary to the heart of the Amin). And the saying of Shams al-Din Muhammad ibn al-Tilimsani: 'Ya sakinan qalbi al-mu'anna / wa laysa fihi siwah thani / li-ayyi ma'nan kasarta qalbi / wa ma iltaqa fihi sakinani' (O dweller of my suffering heart / and there is no second in it other than him / For what meaning did you break (Kasra - vowel) my heart / while two Sukuns did not meet in it?). This meaning, I saw a group of the people of the era fond of it and deeming it good, but it is corrupt. That is because the heart is a vessel for the two dwellers, and the vessel is other than the contained. The rule is that if two Sukuns meet, the second of them is broken (given Kasra). If his heart broke, it is not strange because it is other than the two dwellers (Sakins) and is not one of them. So his denial of it has no meaning. Contemplate that, its corruption will appear. From the meaning of Mu'in al-Din bin Tulwa is the saying of Ibn Sana' al-Mulk, but he walked another path with it where he said: 'Min kulli muhtakimi al-ajfani yukhrijuna / min ardi salwatina fi al-hubbi sahiruhu / ya'wi ila khafiqi al-qalbi al-shajiyyi bihi / fa-a'jab li-man wakruhu fi al-hubbi ta'iruhu' (From every ruler of eyelids, his charmer takes us out / from the land of our solace in love / He shelters in the throbbing of the heart grieved by him / So wonder at one whose nest in love is his flying bird). And his saying: 'Ya ta'ira al-husni alladhi wakruhu / qad halla min qalbi fi ta'iri' (O bird of beauty whose nest / has settled from my heart in a flying thing). And his saying also: 'Wa ta'iru husnin tara qalbi bi-husnihi / fa-ya 'ajaban min ta'irin wakru ta'iri' (And a bird of beauty, my heart flew with his beauty / So oh wonder at a bird whose nest is a bird). From this is the saying of Ibn Qalaqis describing a boat: 'Wa nahnu fi manzelin yasri bi-sakinihi / fasma' haditha muqimin baytuhu ghad' (We are in a house that travels with its dweller / so hear the story of a resident whose house is a goer). Included in what I said regarding the throbbing of the heart: 'Lamma raqadtu ata khayaluka baghtatan / fa-ghada fu'adi khafiqan yatamawwaju / law anna sahbi shahaduni fi al-kara / wa al-qalbu yarqusu fi al-khayali tafaraju' (When I slept, your phantom came suddenly / so my heart became throbbing, surging / If my friends had witnessed me in sleep / while the heart was dancing in the imagination, they would have watched). And from my saying also: 'Hasbi alladhi alqahu fika min al-jafa / wa 'ala al-sahih fa-ba'du dhaka kafani / fanzur ila qalbi idha qabaltuhu / ya ghusnu kayfa yatiru bi-al-khafaqani' (Sufficient for me is what I meet in you of harshness / and correctly, some of that sufficed me / So look at my heart if I face it / O branch, how it flies with throbbing).

**The best said regarding Wine and its Cup**
He said: Likewise came the saying of some Maghrebis regarding wine and its cup, which is: 'Thaqulat zujajatun atatna furragha / hatta idha muli'at bi-sarfi al-rahi / khaffat fa-kadat an tatira bi-ma hawat / wa kadha al-jusumu takhiffu bi-al-arwahi' (Glass bottles came to us heavy when empty / until when they were filled with pure wine / They lightened and almost flew with what they contained / and likewise bodies lighten with spirits/souls). This is an innovated meaning. I bear witness that it does to minds the act of wine in intoxication, and thins as it thinned in subtlety, and diffuses as it diffused in fragrance.

I say: They are by Abu Ali Idris al-Yamani. The origin of the meaning is by Ibn al-Mu'tazz where he said: 'Wazanna al-ka'sa farighatan wa mal'a / fa-kana al-waznu baynahuma sawa'' (We weighed the cup empty and full / so the weight between them was equal). But he increased it in exaggeration, which is that cups gained lightness by wine. Then he wanted an example for that in the external world, so he found nothing but the spirit and the body. Similar to this is the saying of Al-Khwarizmi: 'Ra'aytuka in aysarta khayyamta 'indana / lizaman wa in a'sarta zurta limama / fa-ma anta illa al-badru in qalla daw'uhu / aghabba wa in zada al-diya'u aqama' (I saw you, if you became rich you camped with us / clinging, and if you became poor you visited rarely / You are nothing but the full moon; if its light decreases / it visits rarely, and if the light increases it stays). He took the meaning originally from the saying of Ibrahim bin al-Abbas al-Suli regarding Ibn al-Zayyat: 'Yu'rafu al-ab'adu in athra wa la / yu'rafu al-adna idha ma iftaqara' (The distant one is known if he becomes rich / and the near one is not known if he becomes poor). When he wanted to strike an example for that in the external world, he found nothing but the moon and its light. Such is the case of Idris al-Yamani with Ibn al-Mu'tazz. Ibn Hamdis has this exact meaning, for he said: 'Wa ka'si nashwana fiha al-shamsu bazighatun / batat tudimu ila al-isbahi lathma famih / takhiffu mal'a wa tu'ti al-thiqla farighatan / ka-al-jismi 'inda wujudi al-ruhi aw 'adamih' (And the cup of a drunkard in which the sun is rising / spent the night continuing to kiss his mouth until morning / It lightens when full and gives heaviness when empty / like the body upon the presence of the spirit or its absence). And he said also: 'Jisamun tujammi'u sharbuhu ladhthatina / wa 'uquluna bi-al-sukri minhu tabaddadu / wa yakhiffu mal'ana wa yathqulu farighan / ka-al-jismi yu'damu ruhuhu aw yujadu' (Bodies whose drink gathers our pleasures / while our minds are scattered by drunkenness from it / And it lightens when full and becomes heavy when empty / like the body whose spirit is lost or found).

However, Ibn Hamdis conveyed the complete meaning in a single verse, whereas Idris al-Yamani conveyed it in two verses. Yet, Idris's composition clings more to the heart, has a greater impact on the soul, and is sweeter to the ear. Close to this meaning is the saying of Abu al-Ala al-Ma'arri in Al-Luzumiyat: 'The cask was nothing but a generic thing... until the choicest wine defined it / Like Adam, who was fashioned from dust... and the breath of the Spirit honored him.' Both of them climbed upon this meaning and transferred it to heaviness and lightness; otherwise, it is the same. Speaking of lightness in wine and flying, how sweet is the saying of Abu al-Husayn al-Fukayk: 'A virgin (wine) wooed, when water mixed with her... she showed us foam in a fit of anger / She almost flew away in aversion when he touched her... were it not for the nets (bubbles) she forged from the bubbles.' Models of Ibn al-Athir's composition in which he claims superiority: He said: 'Something of this type came to me in prose, and I will mention a portion here. Among that is what I mentioned in describing a beautiful image, so I said: It is clothed in the freshest garment of beauty, and created from clay other than the clay of people. Just as it increased in beauty, so too it increased in goodness. Desires agreed upon it until it became beloved to every heart. If it shook hands with the rose, its leaves would become perfumed, and if it passed over the water lily at night, its eyes would open.' I say: What is strange in these meanings? And what creativity is there to establish and wonder at and be pleased by? As for the first, it is taken from the saying: 'A child of kingship, as if God fashioned him... from musk, and decreed the creation of mankind from clay.' It is not hidden that this is more praiseworthy and better. As for the second, it is taken from the saying of Al-Buhturi: 'You were poured into the glass (heart) of every heart... so you are beloved to every soul.' And the saying of Ibn Lankak: 'You were squeezed from the blood of hearts, so you do not... look but that you are attached to hearts.' As for his saying 'If it shook hands with the rose, its leaves would become perfumed,' what merit is there for the one described with this quality when the rose is already fragrant, whether a Zanj (black person) or anyone else shakes its hand? This is redundant (tahsil al-hasil). If he had said: 'If it shook hands with the tamarisk, the scent of the ban-tree would diffuse from it; and if it passed over the water lily at night, it would wake its sleepy eye,' it would have been better. For if Abu al-Aswad al-Du'ali or Abu Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan shook hands with the rose, it would still smell good. Praise is only achieved when the person imparts fragrance to what has no fragrance and imparts beauty to what is not known for beauty. Do you not see that they criticized Kuthayyir Azza for his saying: 'No meadow in the rugged ground, soil fragrant... watered by dew on its wormwood and chamomile / Is more fragrant than the sleeves of Azza at midnight... when she has kindled her fire with fresh aloeswood.' It was said to him: 'If this were a Zanj woman and her firewood was fresh aloeswood, her scent would be good and her sleeve perfumed. Why did you not say as Imru' al-Qais said: Do you not see that whenever I come to her at night... I find fragrance in her, even if she has not applied perfume.' For this reason, they approved of the saying of the poet: 'And her scent is more fragrant than her perfume... and perfume contains musk and ambergris.' Look at this poet; when he established that she applies perfume, he made her natural scent better than it. Bashar ibn Burd exaggerated in his saying: 'And if an onion were brought near her... the perfume would overcome the smell of the onion.' However, mentioning the onion made this meaning ugly. It is told that some Shia recited to Abu Mujalid the saying of Al-Sayyid Al-Himyari: 'I swear by God and His signs... and man is responsible for what he says / That Ali ibn Abi Talib... is naturally molded upon guidance and righteousness / That is the one whom, in one night... Michael and Gabriel greeted / Michael among a thousand and Gabriel among... a thousand, and Israfil followed them / On the day of Badr, he scattered them all... as if they were flocks of birds (Ababil).' Abu Mujalid said to him: 'O you, the poet did not praise your companion, but rather satirized him in two places. First, he claimed that Ali, may God honor his face, was naturally molded upon righteousness and guidance, and whoever is molded upon a matter is not praised for it because he did not earn it through his effort. Second, he claimed that he was supported in his wars by angels; thus, he has no virtue in victory, because if Abu Hayya al-Numayri were supported by these, he would have conquered enemies.' Abu Umar al-Zahid mentioned this in the book Al-Yaqutah. Thus, it is proven by the likes of this that there is no praise in his saying: 'If it shook hands with the rose, its leaves would become perfumed.' This is supported by the fact that he realized this in the second rhymed phrase (saj'), so he said: 'And if it passed over the water lily at night, its eyes would open.' He specified 'at night' because in the day its leaves are open. Among the curious things poets have said about the water lily is the saying of Al-Khubz Arzi:

'It feared boredom if its stay was prolonged... so it began to appear at times and hide / As if, when it appears from its rising points... it is a lover kissing a loved one while keeping watch.' I mentioned here the saying of some later poets regarding a rosebud: 'A rose raced to you from the gardens... and came to you before its time, uninvited / It coveted to kiss you when it saw you, so it gathered... its mouth towards you like one seeking a kiss.' This is among the beauties of 'Tadmin' (implication/quoting) which transferred from its origin, because Al-Mutanabbi said about the she-camel in a part of his poem: 'And what changes me is the pulling of the rein to her heart... her mouth towards you like one seeking a kiss.' Although he took it from Ibn Babak, that Tadmin was beautiful. For Ibn Babak said: 'Winter arrived and robbed the blossoms of their joy... the action of gray hair on the hair of a man's lock / A rose opened then returned gathering itself... just as mouths gather for kisses.' How beautiful is the saying of Mujir al-Din Muhammad ibn Tamim regarding the water lily: 'The yellow water lily has come to resemble... the stars, leaving no likeness for them / The eye dives into it when the day... is revealed, and in the darkness, it dives into them (the stars).' He used 'the eye' (al-'ayn) here with two meanings: the first is the seeing eye, and the second is the flowing spring (or literal water). And the saying of Ibn Hamdis al-Siqilli: 'Drink by the pool of a water lily... yellow of petals, green / As if its flowers brought forth... tongues of fire from the water.'
