How delicate is the saying of Al-Tanukhi in a set of verses: 'It grew accustomed to the waters, resembling them in subtlety... until it could not bear to part from its form / So it stands at times, then raises its head... with effeminacy, swaying, and breaking / As if it is, in the water, a follower of a sect... whom obsession tempted that he is not yet pure.' And the saying of another: 'As if its water lily is a lover... watching the face of the beloved during his day / Until when the night reveals its curtain... and the beloved departs towards the gloomy one / He closes his eyes, hoping to see... in sleep the one he won recently.' The other exaggerated in wit when he said: 'As if, when it disappeared at the time of its evening... into the water and the freshness of its stature was veiled / It was a lover whose beloved threatened to abandon him... unjustly, so he drowned himself out of passion.' Al-Wajih ibn al-Dharwi said, satirizing the Egyptian water lily: 'And a water lily that showed us an interior... with the green exterior, like an ember of dragon's blood / So I likened it, when I intended its satire... to the cups of a cupper containing traces of blood.' A model of Ibn al-Athir's composition in condemning gray hair, in which he claims creativity. He said: 'Among that is what I mentioned in condemning gray hair, so I said: Gray hair is poverty, not wealth (Yesar), and darkness, not lights (Anwar). It is the first death that burns with a fire of worry more intense in fuel than fire. And if a people say it is majesty, they have crushed with it and not clarified (Jallu - pun on majesty), and they gave a verdict describing it without knowledge, so they went astray and led astray. I see it only as a plough (Mihrath) for life, and the tool of ploughing never entered the house of a people but that they were humiliated. Among the wonders of its affair is that it is the boring one whose distance is feared, and the creation whose removal is hated, and when youth was lost, it was a replacement for it, but there is no replacement for it when it is lost.' I say: After finishing this section, he began to hum as usual, claiming that the meaning he invented is comparing gray hair to a ploughing tool. People have compared gray hair to things, among them the ignition of fire, and the Great Quran spoke of it in the Almighty's saying: 'And the head has flared with gray hair.' Al-Arjani said: 'Gray hair has ignited my worn head quickly... and wax melts at the ignition of the head / So if she was frightened by whiteness in its color... long has she been pleased by blackness in its color.' Among them is comparing it to dawn. He said: 'They said wake up from the slumber of amusement and youth... for a wondrous dawn has appeared in your darkness / So I said: My friends, leave me and my pleasure... for sleep is sweet at dawn.' Among them is comparing it to stars, he said... Among them is comparing it to smiling. Abu Tammam said: 'She saw his smiling (gray hair) and her agitation was stirred... and her passion said to the tear: Pour out / So do not let the flashing of gray hair keep you awake... for that is the smile of opinion and manners.' Among them is comparing it to bubbles. He said... Among them is comparing it to dust. Ibn al-Mu'taz said: 'Sharir turned away and resolved to abandon me... and set her conscience to treachery / She said: You have aged and grayed. I said to her... This is the dust of the battles of time.'

Among them is comparing it to a sword. He said: 'If I abstain from error and youth... for long have sins enticed me / A sword for gray hair is drawn... and I said blossoms appeared on its branch.' Among them is comparing it to flowers. Al-Ghazzi said: 'Gray hair shone, so I apologized to it... and said blossoms appeared on its branch / As if the beloved's mouth was assembled in... my parting hair, what shone from her smiling teeth.' Among them is comparing it to the owl and the sandgrouse, like the saying of Al-Shafi'i, may Allah be pleased with him, in his verses among which are: 'O owl that has nested upon my head... despite me, when its crow flew away.' Al-Ghazzi said: 'A sandgrouse in guidance was my gray hair... even if its excavation named it a crow.' Al-Siraj al-Warraq compared it to safflower (Qurtum), and this was good because he, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, was blonde. So he said: 'The saffron (gold color) is gone from me... and the safflower of my gray hair has appeared / And the one who has owned my neck... rejected me because of my fault.' A Bedouin was asked about gray hair: 'What is this whiteness in your head?' He said: 'A foam churned by days and silver cast by experiences.' How beautiful is the saying of Al-Qadi Al-Fadil, may Allah have mercy on him: 'Away from me, after the passing of amusement and play... for I do not see in myself what my desire demands / Life is like a cup and days mix it... and gray hair in it is a speck in the place of bubbles.' It was compared to appropriate things other than these, but I have not seen anyone compare it to a ploughing tool. What is the relevance between a ploughing tool and gray hair? What is the face of similarity? This is not from the category of comparing the tangible to the tangible, nor the tangible to the intellectual. I do not know what it is. As for comparing old age to the ploughing itself, it is permissible. As for his saying 'poverty (I'dam) not wealth (Yesar),' it is taken from the saying of Al-Mutanabbi: 'Youth showed me the spirit in my body... and gray hair showed me the spirit in my substitute.' As for his saying 'darkness, not lights,' it is taken from the saying of Abu Tammam: 'It has a sight in the eye, white and pure... but in the heart, it is black and dark.' And the saying of Abu al-Tayyib: 'You have distanced a whiteness that has no whiteness... you are blacker in my eye than darkness.' How beautiful is the saying of Al-Ghazzi: 'How can the gazelles (women) not flee from gray hair... and it is the habit of gazelles to flee / It is a dark white, and every whiteness... other than in the eye and the parting, is light.' As for his saying: 'It is the first death' - the Saj' (rhyme), Mahmud al-Warraq said: 'Gray hair is one of the two deaths.' Others said: 'Gray hair is a cloud raining sorrows.' As for his saying: 'And if a people say it is majesty' - the Saj', I was reminded by it of the saying of some later poets: 'They said a man's youth is amusement and delusion... and behind it is the gray hair of dignity, and there is no doubt / And what dignity is there for a man stripped of youth... with gray hair before him and gray hair behind him.' As for his saying: 'It is the boring one whose distance is feared,' it is taken from the saying of Muslim ibn al-Walid, and the saying of Muslim is utmost beauty: 'Gray hair is hateful, and I hate that it leaves me... wonder at a thing loved despite hatred / Youth passes and a substitute comes after it... and gray hair goes, missing with the missing.' It was said: Al-Mundhir ibn Abi Sabra looked at Abu al-Aswad al-Du'ali who was wearing a patched shirt and said to him: 'How patient you are with this shirt?' He said: 'Perhaps a boring thing cannot be parted with.' So he sent him a chest of clothes. Sulayman ibn Wahb looked in the mirror and saw gray hair, so he said: 'A fault, may we not lack it.' Mention of gray hair came in the correspondence of Al-Fadil, saying: 'Whoever climbs the peak of seventy descends to the bottom, and whoever lives a long life falls into the long and broad (trouble). The days of gray hair are all white (days), yet we are not of those who fast the White Days.' How delicate is the saying of Ibn al-Mu'taz: 'O soul, you have burdened me with my sins... O soul, desist from your desire and repent / And how can there be passion after youth has gone... and the scissors of my gray hair have cut the blame of my youth.' How sweet is the saying: 'O night traveler in the belly of a wasteland... to cross rough and smooth terrain in the desert / You have crossed the sand dune of gray hair and separated from it... and after the sand dune is nothing but the place of prayer.' And by some poet: 'When I saw gray hair appearing on my cheeks... I became certain that connection (Al-Wasl) is reaching me from you.' Perhaps one might understand from this verse something other than what the composer intended, imagining that he thinks gray hair is a cause for connection, which is contrary to the custom of poets, for they always say that gray hair is the cause of beautiful women fleeing from lovers. How beautiful is the saying of Khalid al-Katib regarding this:

'When she saw gray hair befalling my parting... she turned away the turning of a beautified partisan / And I began to seek her connection with humility... while gray hair signaled her not to do so.' The poet intended this customary meaning. Wasil bin Ata al-Ghazal, the head of the Mu'tazila, had a distinct lisp in the letter Ra, so he used to avoid the Ra in his speech, and you would hardly hear a word from him containing a Ra. It is said he was tested to read the beginning of Surah Bara'ah (at-Tawbah), so he read without thought or deliberation: 'A covenant from Allah and His Prophet to those you have covenanted from the corrupt (Fasiqin - instead of Mushrikin which has Ra), so wander in the earth two crescents by two crescents (Hilalayn Hilalayn - instead of Arba'at Ashhur/Four Months).' It reached him that Bashar ibn Burd satirized him, so he said without thinking: 'Has the time not come for this blind atheist surnamed Abu Mu'adh to have someone kill him? By Allah, were it not that assassination (Ghila) is a trait of the Ghaliyah (sect), I would have sent someone to slit (Yab'aj - instead of Baqara) his belly on his lying place (Mudtaja' - instead of Firash), then he would only be a Sadusi or 'Uqayli.' He said 'blind' (A'ma) and did not say 'sightless' (Darir), he said 'atheist' (Mulhid) and did not say 'disbeliever' (Kafir), he said 'Abu Mu'adh' and did not say 'Bashar ibn Burd' or 'Al-Mar'i', he said 'assassination' (Ghila) and did not say 'treachery' (Ghadr), he said 'Ghaliyah' and did not say 'Mughiriyah' or 'Mansuriyah', he said 'sent' (Ba'athtu) and did not say 'dispatched' (Sayyartu), he said 'slit' (Yab'aj) and did not say 'rip open' (Yabqar), he said 'lying place' (Mudtaja') and did not say 'bed' (Firash). By mentioning 'Uqayl and Sadus, he referred to Bashar ibn Burd's claim of belonging to them. Some poet praised him saying: 'He turns wheat (Burr) into Qamh in his speech... and avoided the Ra until he devised a trick for poetry / He could not handle rain (Matar) and speech rushed him... so he came with Ghaith out of fear of Matar.' For this reason, the poet said that verse. He compared connection (Wasl) to Wasil, and compared gray hair to the Ra. His meaning is that she shuns him with the shunning of Wasil for the Ra. Another said and did better: 'Prepare a lisp, if Wasil were present... to hear it, Wasil would not have dropped the Ra.' Al-Ramadi said regarding a beautiful lisping person: 'Neither does the Ra hope for connection (Wisal), nor do I... Abandonment brings us together, so we are alike / If I am alone, I write it on my palm... and sit wailing, I and the Ra.' Al-Arjani said: 'Wasil bin Ata abandoned the Ra... in addressing the people among the orators / And I will abandon the Qaf and the Ra... along with the Dad from the letters of the alphabet.' Discussion of a model of Ibn al-Athir's composition. He said: 'Likewise, I wrote a letter of this type to some friends, joking with him, so I said: He should thank me for branding him with my satire instead of my praise, for I only named him so that the sacrificial animal (Udhiyah) would be prohibited through him on the Day of Sacrifice (Adahi). There is no doubt that our master is counted among the cattle (An'am), except that he is of those with horns, and horns are equipment in dispute.' I say: What meaning is this to boast about? And saying: 'This is a meaning I invented and have not heard from anyone before me.' If he had limited himself to the first two rhymed phrases, it would have been better than explaining their meaning afterwards. He removed the splendor of wit and humor by what he brought of explanation. It has been said that the condition of humor is that it should not be hidden nor explicit, but in between. Do you not see the saying of Al-Siraj al-Warraq regarding one named Al-Safi: 'Accidents intervened between me... between Al-Safi and me / So I will not die until... I see Al-Safi with my eye.' How sweet it is. If he had said: 'So I will not die until I see him as a pure friend (Safi)' or 'with one eye', meaning one-eyed, it would not have this charm, nor this beauty that strikes the heart. Or if he began to explain it afterwards and clarify what he symbolized, this sweetness would have gone. Look at how beautiful is the saying of Al-Jazzar Abu al-Husayn, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him: 'If the Butcher (Jazzar) hunted the souls of enemies... on the day of your Eid, I would be the first hunter / But they felt safe from my knife due to their deficiency... Indeed, the sacrifice is not (valid) with a defective one.' And his saying also: 'I advised you, so listen to the advice of a lover... and I am indeed trustworthy in what I said / It is of sound opinion that you do not cause war between us... for I am a butcher and you are fat.' If he (Ibn al-Athir) had said: 'He should thank me for branding him with my satire among creation, for I only named him so that the sacrificial animal would be prohibited through him,' it would have been better. For his saying: 'The sacrificial animal on the Day of Sacrifice' is like saying: 'Eid on the day of Eid,' and 'Fasting on the day of fasting.' It is known that 'Dahaya' (sacrifices) is only applied to what is slaughtered during the days of Tashriq, and what is slaughtered of animals at other times is not called that. Likewise, the Friday prayer (Jumu'ah) is only applied to the known prayer at the specific time, and if there is a prayer at another time, it is not Jumu'ah. A model of Ibn al-Athir's composition claiming creativity.

But it was nothing but that he said after that verse: 'O you whom I do not name nor use a kunya for, and I mention another while he is the one I mean. Do not be among those given the kingdom of beauty and did not look at its demise, and knew his place in hearts and was unjust in his coyness. Do not be deceived by the saying of one who saw beauty as an eraser of bad deeds. And know that the blamer says: Humility is enough of a blamer. Often love vanishes due to the crimes of rejection, and increase in the definition (hadd) is a decrease in the defined (mahdud). It has been said: Beauty has a Zakat (alms-tax) like the Zakat of wealth, and its Zakat according to the scholars of love is nothing but expression of connection (Wisal). This is a charity distributed to its owners, and one does not wait for the year (hawl) to pass to make it obligatory. Rather, it is continuous with the renewal of days. Those deserving of it are one category, and it is not said that they are eight categories. These are the ones specified for freeing slaves (necks), and the neck of love is more bound than a neck freed by a contract (Kitabah). So exit, O my master, from this obligatory right, otherwise you come to a seeker of desires, and what a seeker. And do not say this is a debtor who counts the nights in his procrastination, and I promise him and promises are provision for his like. For this is a commodity with which you dealt with me once mocking and once enchanting. And among the circulating proverbs is that experience makes the naive skilled. By my life, the practice of love renews knowledge for its owner, and insight even if he is, as is said, blind. The sayer lied: Expose the one you love to love... then leave him for Iblis to tame him. If the training is, as said, for Iblis, I do not see him having done anything in what he did. I see you resisted him with the resistance of a full-grown horse while you are young. There is no doubt that you demolish the building he constructs, and that you are an exception among those who entered the rule of exception. I am now a fault-finder of him, and blaming him. So where are his whisperings which are more deceptive than traps? And where is his saying: I will come to them from the right and the left? And where are his soldiers who steal what is in the sky, who run through them like the course of blood? All of this news has become void to me, just as his effect has become void to me. If arrogance overtakes him because I mocked the validation of his actions, let him untie the logic of this need of mine so I know he is capable of untying its knot. Otherwise, let him hide his head and erase his whispering. If he has a throne on the sea, let him dismantle his throne, and let him know that magic is not in his knot and blowing, but it is in the Yellow (gold/Dinar) and its inscription. Here I am, I have sent what makes resolve dissolved and affection granted. I only say that I sent a beloved (Dinar) to a beloved, and both have their place in the heart, rather the heart is created from her love. How noble it is while it is a means to its like; its beauty is from his beauty, even if its shape is not from his shape. No describer described it but that what he saw of it was above what he narrated. Among the strangest and best of its descriptions is that no two-faced person was seen as esteemed (Wajih) except it. There is no doubt that if it travels in a matter, it is subtle in opening its doors, and handles its roughness so it exchanges it with its arrow, and its distance so it exchanges it with its nearness. If I sent other than it, I would fear that it would not be truthful in its embassy, and that it would go as an ambassador and return as a lover. For there is no trust over beauty, and in its like betrayal is excused. There is no blame on minds if they forget the resolve of their guidance there, and see what the shoulder of their effort cannot bear. Who is the one whose armor is strong against those arrows, or seeks salvation from them when a barrier is placed between him and the desire? This is what prevented me except from sending a purse or a letter; one of them is beneficent in embassy, and the other is a veil over the secret. And peace, God willing.' I say: When he finished this letter, he began as usual to over-praise his speech for what he invented of mentioning Zakat and describing the Dinar in the sense of the Hadith, and that what occurred to him was not achieved by Al-Hariri nor did anyone precede him to it. I say: I have never heard nor seen, nor do I hear or see, anyone who corresponded with his beloved with such things, threatening that love vanishes with rejection, and increase in the definition is a decrease in the defined, and that connection is a Zakat obligatory upon you, and do not say it is annual but at all times, so exit from this obligatory right upon you, and do not say I am a debtor easy to seek, for how much do you mock me? I am not as I was, and experience makes the naive skilled. Then he began condemning Iblis, scolding and rebuking him, saying that he is not the owner of whispering, seduction, and magic, but it belongs to the Dinar, and here I have prepared something of that. Nothing remained after that but to equip the beloved to the beloved (the coin to the person). Then he began describing the Dinar. Yes, this expression and threat are suitable for the right of an enemy who exited from friendship to enmity, or a ruler of most injustice and corruption in the land and people, whom neither warning nor caution benefited, or a slave who exited the obedience of his master and did not fear his authority.

He said in a section mentioning a gift of fresh dates (Rutab) to some kings of the Levant: 'When the road carried it alone, envy arose for other fruits, a desire; and there was none of them but said: Oh, I wish I were fresh dates (Rutab).' I say: What eloquence is in this expression, and what rhetoric is upon this meaning which has no benefit under it? Where is this compared to the saying of Abu al-Husayn al-Jazzar: 'I said when the cupbearer poured... the wine upon the ground / Out of jealousy for it from me... I wish I were dust.' For this one brought the wording of the Great Quran, so it had an impact on the hearing and sweetness in the heart. If his saying 'I wish I were fresh dates' was part of a verse, or part of a couplet, or part of a proverb or a meaning circulated in something, and he transferred it to this, it would have been good. And from the speech of Al-Qadi Al-Fadil, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, in answer to the Caliph: 'The letter arrived containing what revealed the title of intention, even if it was a book, and affirmed the blessing even if it rose and was a cloud (Sahab), requiring the limit of obedience. And to that noble foot the believer says: I wish I were dust.' Then Ibn al-Athir said: 'And there was none of them but said (Man Qala).' So he applied 'Man' (who - for rational beings) to what is irrational. And it is only for rational beings. And fruits do not reason. If he had said: 'And there was no type of them but said,' he would have escaped that. It might be excused for him that when he placed the types of fruit in the position of rational beings in speech, he applied 'Man' to them. Like the Almighty's saying: 'Then He said to it and to the earth, Come willingly or unwillingly. They said: We come obediently (Ta'i'in).' This plural form expressed with letters is only for rational beings. But when He placed them in the position of rational beings in speech and obedience, He gave them the plural of rational beings. The answer: This is not like that. The difference between the noble verse and his speech is that in the noble verse, He applied that because their speech preceded. So it indicated that they were placed in the position of rational beings. As for Ibn al-Athir, he applied 'Man' to what is irrational from the first instance, so it was not good. With the likes of this, Al-Mutanabbi escaped the criticism of Ibn Waki' and others against him, in his saying: 'And everything that Allah created... and what He did not create is despised in my ambition... like a hair in my parting.' They said: Among what Allah Almighty created are the Prophets, Messengers, and Angels. This implies declaring him a disbeliever and indicates his heresy. The answer regarding Al-Mutanabbi is that he said 'And everything that (Ma)' and did not say 'And everyone who (Man)'. For 'Ma' is for the irrational according to the correct view. By this, the Messengers exit from it due to the honor of their rank and the elevation of their station above this, and the Angels, peace and blessings of Allah be upon them. Similarly, some ignorant people raised an objection to His Almighty's saying: 'Indeed, you and what you worship other than Allah are the firewood of Hell.' He said: And among them are those who worshipped the Messiah. The bereft one did not know that 'Ma' in His Almighty's saying 'and what you worship' is for the irrational. So it covers idols, stars, and the like, and excludes the Messiah, peace be upon him, from that. Discussion of a letter by Ibn al-Athir from a lover to a beloved. He said: 'Among that is an occurrence regarding which some of my friends tasked me to dictate to them, and it is a tender note from a lover to a beloved.' Then he began to list it, and it is long. He opened it with the saying of the poet: 'And when it is said: Whom do you love? My tongue... skips you, while you are that one in the heart.' When I saw that he started the letter with the verse of Abu Tammam, I said: 'Perhaps behind this lightning is rain, and he holds to this vanguard in gentleness according to the custom of addressing lovers, their submission, and the humility of their asking in seeking connection, or complaining of abandonment, or the tenderness of blame in breaking a promise or inclining to the opposite. For if tenderness, kindness, and submissiveness were created for anything, I do not see anyone more deserving of them than lovers in these stations.' How sweet is the saying of the poet: 'He passes from his palm a wine... more delicious than the negligence of the watcher / As if, when clarified and presented... it is the complaint of a lover to a beloved.'

I do not think of this beloved except that he had resolved to visit this lover, but the messenger intercepted him on the road with this letter and the Dinar. When he stood upon it and saw this 'favor' and the obligation placed upon him, he turned back after cursing the messenger, tearing his clothes, plucking his beard, spitting in his face, cursing the one who sent him, tearing the paper into shreds, trampling the crumbs of the paper with his feet, and saying whatever insults came to mind. He would elaborate on the right of the letter writer with what he deserves and throw the Dinar he sent into the air. At that, he would be brief, and silent about his wrong, not victorious. Did he not stand upon the poetry of the enamored Arabs who addressed their loved ones and pleaded in seeking connection, and were gentle in seeking satisfaction and help with love? Is this how Qays ibn Dharih, Abdullah ibn al-Ajlan al-Nahdi, Urwa ibn Hizam, Abu Dhu'ayb, Qays al-Majnun, Jamil Buthayna, and Kuthayyir Azza spoke? Is this how Umar ibn Abi Rabi'a, Al-Harith ibn Khalid, and Al-Abbas ibn al-Ahnaf flirted? Did he not hear the saying of Abu al-Tayyib: 'Increase my soul in pain, I will increase in love for you... The most ignorant of people is a lover who holds a grudge.' And the saying of Abu Firas: 'He did evil, so the evil increased him in favor... A beloved, despite what came from him, is a beloved / The two slanderers count his sins against me... And from where can a beautiful face have sins?' And the saying of the other: 'If it saddened me that you touched me with an offense... It pleased me that I crossed your mind.' And the saying of the other: 'Your abandonment indicates... That I crossed your minds.' Did he not hear the saying of Al-Ma'arri: 'For other than me is Zakat of beauty, so if there is... Zakat of beauty, then remember a wayfarer (Ibn Sabil).' How sweet is the saying: 'So remember a wayfarer.' If she pays Zakat of beauty, he did not order her to spend it on him nor make it obligatory upon her, but said: If there is anything, then remember the wayfarer who is deserving. Of this is the saying of Kuthayyir Azza: 'If the coolness of her upper teeth is gifted... To one poorer than me, then I am indeed poor.' Although its meaning is problematic if you contemplate it deeply, and this is not the place to discuss it. How delicate is Ibn Sana' al-Mulk in his saying: 'And a beauty who has not passed twenty years (Hujjah)... I say to her a saying in which is correctness / Upon you is Zakat, so make it our connection... For your life is in the twenties, and that is a Nisab (threshold for Zakat).' And the saying of Nasir al-Din ibn al-Naqib: 'Zakat of beauty has become obligatory upon you... And in it, like in wealth, is a right / So do not turn it away from me, for I am... The poor one deserving of its expenditure.' Did he not hear the saying of Jamil ibn Ma'mar al-Udhri: 'There is no good in love that stands still, not moved... By accidents of despair, or frequented by greed / If her patience or my anxiety were with her... I would know what to do and what to leave.' And the saying of Abu al-Tayyib: 'And the sweetest love is that whose owner doubts the connection... And in abandonment, he is forever fearing and guarding.' And the saying of Kushajim: 'Were it not for the chase of hunting, there would be no pleasure... So chase me with connection a little / This drink is the brother of life, and it has... No pleasure until it hits a thirst.' And the saying of Al-Abbas ibn al-Ahnaf: 'And the best of the days of passion is your day which... Is frightened by abandonment and by blame / If there is no anger or satisfaction in love... Then where are the sweetnesses of messages and letters?' And the saying of Ulayya bint al-Mahdi: 'Love is placed upon injustice, so if... The beloved were fair in it, it would be ugly / It is not approved in the law of passion... For a lover to be good at composing arguments.' Did he not hear the saying of Muhammad ibn Bashir al-Khariji: 'I wanted patience from you, but hindered me... An attachment in my heart from your love, old / It remains despite the doubt of time and its changes... And despite your harshness, indeed it is noble.' How beautiful is the saying of Al-Abbas ibn al-Ahnaf when he scolded his loved ones for procrastination in connection: 'As if there was no passion between me and you... And my rope was not connected to your rope / And indeed, I am shy for you from a narrator... Who narrates about you regarding boredom and procrastination.' Al-Shibli, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, narrated saying: 'I saw on a Friday a madman at the Mosque of Rusafa standing naked saying: I am the madman of Allah, I am the madman of Allah. I said: Why do you not enter the mosque, cover yourself, and pray? He recited saying: They say visit us and fulfill the duty of our right... But my state has dropped their rights from me / When they saw my state and did not disdain it... And did not disdain from it, I disdained them for myself.'

I said: This is another type different from what we are discussing, and the paths of seriousness are different from the paths of joking. Among what I said: 'And if my secret is exposed in passion tomorrow... and the night-talkers speak of my ardor / Or it is said: This poor one, the origin of his madness... is the magic of eyes, and he has no helpers / Is this permissible in the law of passion? And who... issued a fatwa that the blood of the lover is unavenged (Jabbar)? / I knew that your love is the origin of my affliction... So upon your rejection, not upon me, is the shame.' Did he not hear what lovers were content with, like Jamil where he says: 'I am content from you, O Buthayna, with that which... If the slanderer knew it, his anxieties would settle / With "No" and "I cannot" and with hope... And with the promise until the procrastinator becomes bored of the promise / And with the hasty glance, and with the year passing... Its ends, while we do not meet at its beginnings.' And Jahdar where he says: 'Does not the night gather the mother of Amr... And us? So that is closeness for us / She looks at the crescent as I see it... And the day rises over her as it rose over me.' And the other where he says: 'Look at the flying vulture (star) every night... For I am looking at it in the evening / Perhaps my eye and your eye will meet at it... So we both complain of what the consciences conceal.' And Abu al-Ala al-Ma'arri where he says: 'He met you in the year that passed and did not... Ask you except for a kiss in the coming (year) / Indeed, the miser, when the span is extended for him... In generosity, giving the gift becomes easy for him.' As for his mentioning Iblis, calling for his help, and urging his whispering and adorning falsehood to him, it is strange. Does he not know that if a lover says to his beloved: 'Nothing makes you visit me and be affectionate to me except Iblis with his whispering,' the beloved will visualize that before his eyes and say: 'Indeed, these matters are from the act of Iblis and obeying Satan in following prohibited taboos.' So he returns to abandonment and puts on the slogan of harshness, repulsion, and turning away. He would be like a sleeper whom another woke from negligence. Some said: I had a friend who was not shy with me nor I with him. He said to me one day: 'O my brother, you know my love for so-and-so, and I have never been able to get anything from her. She visited me today, and I would like you to be with us, for I am not shy with you.' I agreed to that. When I came to his place, and my eye fell on the girl, I saw the most beautiful of women. Then we indulged in eating, drinking, and talking. My friend asked me to sing, and I was good at it. It was as if Allah Almighty made me forget everything I memorized except this tune: 'Of the modest women, she did not disgrace her brother... And did not raise a shame for her father.' When the girl heard it, she said: 'You did well, by Allah! Repeat it, O my brother.' So I repeated it. She jumped up standing and said: 'I am repentant to Allah. By Allah, I would not disgrace my brother nor raise shame for my father.' The young man strove for her return, but she did not do so and left. He said to me: 'Woe to you, what made you do what you did?' I said: 'By Allah, it is not something I intended, but it was cast upon my tongue.' Look at the benefit of what I mentioned. The most appropriate in seeking connection is to say: 'I ask Allah to incline your heart towards me, inspire you to seize the reward in me, and grant you mercy for me so that you may enter Paradise.' As the poet misled his beloved in his saying: 'You accused me of a sin while I was not a sinner... And burdened me in love with what I cannot bear / My seeking of connection is not greed for survival... But it is a reward I drive to you.' And as the other misled where he said: 'Rise with us, may my soul be your ransom... Let us make doubt certainty / For how long, O my beloved... Will the speaker sin regarding us?' I have stood upon part of a letter from the speech of Ibn Sana' al-Mulk, which is: 'And I, by Allah, am defeated in your matter. The reason is that I am the lover and you are the beloved. I do not fight you so as to deceive you, nor do I betray your love, nor do I clatter against you so as to cheat you and distress your heart. Do what you wish, for I am the patient one. Kill how you wish, for I am the thankful one. Say to me, for I have hearing that loves your speech. Turn, you will see my hopes fluttering around you. Act, for you are excused. Be arrogant, for I am not harmed but pleased. Return to the affection that is between us, for every sin of yours is forgiven.' End. I said: And to Allah belongs the Vizier Abu al-Walid ibn Zaydun where he says: 'Between me and you is what, if you wished, would not be lost... A secret, if secrets were spread, would not be spread / O seller of his share of me, even if life were offered... To me for my share of him, I would not sell / It suffices you that if you burdened my heart with what... The hearts of people cannot bear, it would bear / Be arrogant, I will bear; be arrogant, I will be patient; be mighty, I will be humble... Turn away, I will approach; speak, I will listen; command, I will obey.'

And the other where he said: 'Far from it! Forgetfulness does not pull my rein... Ever, nor does blame win over my consolation / Cut the connection or turn away from me deliberately... The nature of passion is stamped on your desire, my character.' And Mahasin al-Shawa where he says: 'I submit, but he does not bring me near; I return, but he does not return... I refrain, but he does not refrain; I give generously, but he does not give / Be relaxed, I will be humble; be unjust, I will protect; threaten, I will return... Be content, I will contain; attack, I will connect; threaten, I will guide.' And where he says also: 'May I be your ransom, O one who feigned connection... And denied me connection in his love / For beauty has meanings in you by which... Women go astray and men are distracted / You frighten, are observed, show favor, are loved... You show enmity, are treated as an enemy, show loyalty, are treated with loyalty / O one upon whom I have staked the excess of wasting away of my body... In him, and my heart upon torture and hardship / Separate, bring near, cut, connect, reveal, hide, be stingy, be generous... Betray, fulfill, drag, be just, be angry, be pleased, live, die.' And the Vizier Abu Shuja' Fatik where he said: 'O one who sickened by his tyranny and harshness... My heart, and O one who left me as meat on a butcher's block / Be how you wish, for I do not hate what... Pleases you, even if what pleases you is shedding my blood / Turn away, expose, drag, abandon, repel, connect... Be rough, be soft, be pleased, be angry, forgive, take revenge / In every case, I am the criminal, the wrongdoer, and you... Are the beneficent, of good character and traits.' And Ibn Rawaha al-Hamawi: 'If my killing is sweet to you... Then increase the abandonment in my punishment / Perhaps the standing will be prolonged between me... And you by Allah in the Account.' This is more and more famous than to be cited as evidence. As for attributing magic and its knot to Iblis, it is strange. Magic and knots are only for humans to use Iblis and his soldiers; so magic is for the human, not the devil. How sweet is the saying of... when he cried out to Iblis out of wit: 'The wine, O Iblis, if you do not stand... And expand the trick in returning it / The market of sins will not sell, nor... Will you succeed, O Iblis, after it.' As for his claim in describing the Dinar as two-faced and that he was not preceded in it, the first to describe it as such was Al-Hariri, who said in his Maqamat: 'Perish it for a deceitful hypocrite... Yellow, two-faced like a hypocrite / Appearing in two situations to the eye of the observer... The ornament of a beloved and the color of a lover.' Mention of the Dinar came in the Maqamat of Badi' al-Zaman al-Hamadhani, saying: 'So accompany for me an enemy in the cloak of a friend, from the origin of brass, calling to disbelief (Kufr), dancing on victory (Zafar), like the circle of the eye, removing the weight of debt, and hypocrisy with two faces.' How beautiful is the saying of Nasir al-Din ibn al-Naqib, riddling about the Dinar: 'What is a thing people yearn for... The yearning of lovers for the beloved / They beat it and hung it, but... It increased in honor by the beating and hanging.' As for his saying: 'It goes as an ambassador and returns as a lover, and there is no trust over beauty,' it is taken from the saying of Abu al-Tayyib: 'What is wrong with us all, lovesick, O messenger... I love and your heart is the consumed one / Whenever the one I sent to her returned... He was jealous of me and betrayed in what he said / Her eyes corrupted the trusts between us... And hearts betrayed minds.' From here Al-Arjani also took it, saying: 'I swear, the breeze returned sick... When it traveled from me to you as a messenger / It came because of the suffering of your love, repeating... A breath that people steal, long / And it saw for your love that it had betrayed me... So it began dragging trails of shame.' And from here is the saying of Ibn Sana' al-Mulk also: 'He went as a messenger and came to me as a lover... And an obstacle hindered him from my message / And he returned not with the answer but with burning passion... That silenced him while passion spoke through him.' However, Al-Arjani covered up his theft. He said in condolence for a wife who died and then her child died: 'The most saddening condolences are those in which a lost one is followed by a lost one, especially if it combines Sa'd al-Akhbiyah and Sa'd al-Su'ud.' Then he said: 'Neither he who wept nor he who lamented paid them their due, nor he who wrote poetry nor he who wrote letters. Would that one of them were ransomed by the other, so the one ransomed by gold lived as a dirham.' Then he listed the rest of the letter, which is long, lean, and ugly, except that after finishing it, he began to buzz and hum about the saying 'Sa'd al-Akhbiyah' and 'Sa'd al-Su'ud' and that they are two stations of the moon's stations, marveling at this agreement. Discussion of a model of Ibn al-Athir's composition.

I say: He blew into no fire, and circled around no sanctuary. That is not a great matter, nor something to call attention to after finishing it. Rather, it is of the middle rank; it does not descend to his usual lowness, nor does it rise to the height of Al-Qadi Al-Fadil. People have used the names of stations and stars in their speech seriously and jokingly. Like the saying of Saif al-Din al-Mashadd ibn Qizil: 'My heart went astray among your tents (Abyat)... And the winds (Ahwiyah) fan its fire / O slaughterer (Dhabih) of sleep with my eye, do you not... Have mercy on a heart that went astray in the tents (Akhbiyah).' And his saying also: 'O valley of al-Shaqraa... How many picnics you have gathered / Thickets whose water flows... There is no likeness to its goodness / And how many a full moon pleasing the eye... Became through you in the forehead (Jabhah).' And his saying also: 'He appeared in the armor like the spear... In the sides and the brownness / O God, what a full moon... Pleasing the eye in the nose-ring/Cancre (Nathrah).' And the saying of the notary Burhan al-Din ibn al-Faqih Nasr: 'In your service I did not attain benefit... And the scale of my deficiency through you is tipping / For in the eye from my tears is a scattering (Nathrah)... And in the heart from your fortune (Sa'd) is a slaughterer (Dhabih).' Among the best metonymies is the saying of another: 'Do you not see me enduring my passion for you... And bearing from you what cannot be borne / When the stars of the sky rose... And the Bucket (Dalw) leaned and the Cubit (Dhra') rose.' And the saying of Muhammad Sibt al-Ta'awidhi: 'So I spent the night and she spent the night by my side... Both of us counting the stations (Manazil) on her / She shows me the Belly (Butayn), but I... Reciprocate and show her the Claws (Zubana).' And the saying of another from verses: 'So I hastened him from entering the toilet... With obeyed ignorance and obeyed forbearance / So I drowned him with the star of the Belly... And he quenched me with the star of the Cubit.' As for his saying: 'Would that if one of them were ransomed by the other,' better than this is the saying of Al-Mutanabbi: 'Would that the rising of the two suns was absent... And would that the absent of the two suns did not set.' The completion of the rhyme (Saj') is half a verse from this poem by Abu al-Tayyib, the first of which is: 'Their time had divided the two persons between you... So the one ransomed by gold lived as a dirham.' He said: 'And from this chapter is what I mentioned in a hunting epistle describing pellet bows (Qasi al-Bunduq) and their bearers.' Then he quoted it. I say: It is also of the middle quality; it is neither in the high nor the low. I was reminded by the path he took in it of what came for some Persian writers, I think, regarding the bow for arrows. For it is unique in its beauty, quick in its wit to snatch minds, and its craftsmanship left no pleasure after it for souls in repetitions. It is: Epistle of Ibn al-Athir describing pellet bows and their bearers. 'And they ask you about Dhul-Qarnayn. Say, I will recite to you a mention of him. A sage molded on correctness, guiding to the paths of rectitude. Traces of his might are famous upon those of wood. And they ask you about the crescents (Ahillah). Say, yellow without illness. A galaxy from which shooting stars fall. A tower with two bodies rising with the ominous bird. A devil whose sun of victory rises between his horns. A rebellious one who does not calm down except by rubbing his ears. A composite image having no composition of organization, except what their backs carried, or the intestines, or what mixed with bone. A mount differing from other cattle; its standing is by hand and their standing is by feet. A moving thing biting on the molar of patience in adversity and prosperity. Whoever accompanied it for the blink of an eye walked on air. So say about Nun (the whale/fish) that swallowed a messenger (Jonah) then cast him into the wilderness. A shackled one upon whom the free is carried. Driven by the neck, suspended from the neck of his shoulder. Slender, he stuck his belly to his back, until the daughters of his chest appeared to onlookers, and his kidneys sank into his waist, due to the dominance of his attracting and holding powers over his pushing and destroying powers. Gripped, approaching the fast one, and separating from him at the cutting. A decrepit one upon whom century after century passed, so his back bent. His reclining place is not set up except on the hand. He recites when he opens his mouth: I stripped my bones of their flesh so I left them... Bare, exposed before you and restricted / Take my hand then uncover the garment, you will see... The wasting of my body, but I cover myself. Bent of back, leaning on a staff, he throws it and behold it is a snake moving. He avoided the spears of Khatt and the swords, his friends... As for the bent bows, he settled them and avoided.'

'He turned to taking spears from the daring men, and the stirrers of heroes handled them with the forearm. A humped instrument warning of death, and a lean curved one like the letter Nun. Emaciated ones yearning over the thickness of their livers, affectionate ones moaning for the separation of their children. A branch tied with twisted silk fringes, striking with its two arrows into the tenths of a killed heart. Thick, strong, hard-hearted, harsh-natured. Appointed to seize souls, having wings, two or three or four. A worn-out one roaring when soft in a horn. Gathering to the belly of the youth the curvature of the old man. Exhausted, its aorta almost cut. Bent-backed, approaching the age of sixty...' It is long, filling a booklet, and all of it is of this model. A group opposed (imitated/competed with) it, among them Judge Nasir al-Din ibn al-Munir, who made three or more, and others. But none of them split dust for it (could match it), nor did anything run from the train behind it except what was stumbling. As for the pellet (Bunduq), our Sheikh Judge Shihab al-Din Abu al-Thana Mahmud, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, has a resonant epistle on it. The pearl crowds with the gold bead in it like seeds in a pomegranate. He recorded it in his book titled Husn al-Tawassul. It is of utmost beauty, and at the summit of literary classes. Were it not for its length, I would have recorded it here, and provided the poverty of this composition with its wealth. Ibn al-Rumi has a long 'Ayn-rhymed poem in Rajaz meter about the pellet and archers. And Muhammad Sibt al-Ta'awidhi has a poem about pellet shooting, the beginning of which is: 'Greetings, O abode of passion, from an abode... And may the pouring clouds not miss you.' It is of utmost beauty, and it is in his Diwan. Among the best of what I mentioned regarding the pellet bow is the saying of Ibn Waddah al-Mursi: 'Wonder at the generous bow, for it... Did not observe the right of the doves of the branches / It became a death for them while it was a sanctuary... And such is the ruling of the vicissitudes of time.' As for me, I wrote a decree (Tawqi') regarding arbitration between pellet archers; there is no harm in recording it here. It is: 'Praise be to Allah, whose praise has never ceased to be obligatory, whose support is a giver of every good, whose thanks attract blessings and block retributions, and whose remembrance removes misery and earns bliss. We praise Him for His blessings, for which we throw down varieties of birds with praise, and clip their wings with thanks so they have no power to fly. We bear witness that there is no god but Allah alone, having no partner, a testimony with which we have no excuse for not winning Paradise, and by which we do not find our souls on the Day of Resurrection except in the crops of green birds. And we bear witness that Muhammad is His servant and messenger, the best of those whom people of rank advanced, and the noblest of those who judged with justice stripped of doubt and suspicion. May Allah bless him and his family and companions, who were in wars its breaking eagles, and its knights who satiated the clawed and beaked (birds/beasts) with the flesh of enemies. How praised is the Archer in his aim, and feet strove for him in ranks, foot by foot. And peace be upon him abundantly. To proceed. Since shooting with pellets is an art undertaken by Caliphs and Kings, and Princes and Great Ones have followed a path in it of subtle taking and novel behavior, training with it during boredom to relax their souls, gathering fruits of desire in recreation from the trellises of their plants, appearing to what pleases the eye and frightens the bird in their outings, and attaining with clay pellets from birds what others do not attain with their hunting falcons or hawks. They have discarded the distractors of attachment in attaining high ranks, and donned the slogan of truthfulness among themselves while they are people of affection. They prevented their eyelids from approaching the watering places of sleep except briefly. They appeared with faces that are full moons and bows that are crescents. They moved in hunting eagles like the movement of the Rook (in chess). They hunted birds in the air when they scattered clay pills from every bow that is like a trap. They shouted over the strings, and the birds were drinking companions on the pure wine of waters, among its victims. They plucked the flowers of every garden that brought forth its water and pasture. This path needed controls to be observed in its conditions, and to drag the tails of its garments over the main road, so that every archer stands at the limit of his bird, and probes the depth of another by his precedence. To secure against dispute in ranks, and to save the people of this method from the fault-finder and blamer. The High Isfahsalaari, Amiri, Shihabi Seat (Majlis) was the one who dragged his cloak over the galaxy in it, and became the son of its root in knowledge and recognition. The birds rejoice at the melody of his strings, and the gallbladders of birds burst out of jealousy from the color of his dust. The galaxy wishes it were a path for him, the sun a pellet-holder, and the sky a flatterer. The colored rainbow wishes it were his bow, the Eagle (star) his bird, and the stars his pellets. How often has he made the embroidered robes of the garden contain what his hunting killed. How often did he go out in groups while the birds were lined up above them, so he hunted a full moon when he raced it. How often has he stained in the battlefield of the air a victim whose feathers were like woven chainmail. How often has he sent the pellet and it was a piercing arrow because it was of molded black mud.

'Therefore, the High, Mawlawi, Sultani, Maliki, Nasiri Command—may his omen remain blessed, and his pearl hidden in the drawers of compliance—has decreed that arbitration between pellet archers in protected Damascus be delegated to him, according to the custom of those before him in the established rule among archers. So let him undertake that with an authority in which he relies on the truth in the path of duty, and demonstrates his policy for which eyes stare, as if the tops of every eyelid were tied to an eyebrow. Let him observe the right of this path in keeping his covenant. Let him run on the familiar path of this sect, for every human being We have fastened his bird (fate/omen) to his neck, such that he places every deserving person in his rank which he does not exceed, accepts from the archer the claim of his game due to him, and rejects what the archers do not count and do not reckon. Being verified in what is brought to him for judgment, not letting a tail drag over his fault. Editing the matter of the victim regarding whom the archer has become, due to his infatuation, like Majnun Layla. Proceeding in that according to the familiar habit, and the rule which is described by the clear method. Let him receive this blessing with thanks by which he deserves an increase of every good, and recite verses of praise for this Solomonic command which judged him even regarding birds. And Allah undertakes his management, and reforms the exterior of his judgment and the secret. God willing.' Is it a condition of eloquent simile that the thing be compared to what is bigger and greater than it? He said in the eighth type of simile: It has been said: One of the conditions of eloquence in simile is to compare a thing to what is bigger and greater than it. From here, some writers of the people of Egypt erred in mentioning a fortress among the mountain fortresses, comparing it: 'A head (Hama) upon which the cloud is a turban, and a fingertip which the afternoon stained, and it is as if the crescent is a nail clipping for it.' Then he began to criticize this and say: What magnitude does a fingertip have to compare a fortress to it? And he prolonged with objection and answer. I say: Ibn Abi al-Hadid discussed this with him, and something of his criticism remains on this. It is that the one who claimed that eloquence of simile requires comparing a thing to what is bigger and greater, I discuss with him and say: On this basis, the predominance of the branch over the origin in simile is invalidated, and we declare wrong the likes of Dhu al-Rummah in his saying: 'And sand dunes like the hips of virgins I crossed... when the dark nights clothed them.' For he compared sand dunes to what is smaller and more insignificant than them, because the hips of virgins are less than dunes. Nor do we approve of the likes of the saying of Abu Bakr Muhammad ibn Hashim: 'And Jupiter in the middle of the sky, you think it... while its light is like trembling mercury / A nail of yellow gold that I set... in a ring, and the stone is of turquoise.' For the sphere of the sky and Jupiter are bigger than the stone and the nail. Nor the saying of Ibn Qizil: 'A season as if the full moon in it is a singer... appearing, and its halo with it is his tambourine / And as if the rainbow is a gilded harp... and as if the downpour of rain is its strings.' Examples like this are many. And everything in the upper world cannot be compared to anything in the earthly world because it is more insignificant and smaller, just as the Pleiades are compared to a withered narcissus, the crescent to a nail clipping and a horseshoe, lightning to a sword, the sun to a mirror, stars to a lamp, and the rainbow to the trains of a bride. All that falls under this category would not be permissible to compare, and if done, it would not be eloquent according to this decision. Far from it! This blocks the door of beauty. As for fortresses, poets have compared them to fingertips. Among them is Al-Ghazzi where he says: 'Blocking the simple terrain, descending from the peak of the... lofty mountain to the bottom of the valley / Until the blessed fortress became a pinky finger... in a ring of thumb and steed.' Ibn al-Athir used that himself, saying in a previous section: 'We landed from it within sight and hearing, and surrounded it like the ring surrounds the finger.' Ibn Qizil compared them to the eye, saying: 'Indeed, fortresses are like eyes, their lashes are... their battlements, and their eyelids are the walls / Likewise their sockets are the trenches around them... and their guardians are the eyelashes.' Whoever criticizes the saying of Al-Qadi Al-Fadil: 'And we descended at Qal'at Najm (Star Fortress), and it is a star in a cloud, and an eagle in an eagle (rugged place), and a head for which the cloud is a turban, and a fingertip which if the afternoon stained, it is as if the crescent is a nail clipping for it.' It is not appropriate for a debater debating him except to withhold speech about him. Is the attack on this anything but the saying of one who did not reach the bunch of grapes? 'As if your critic reveals your beauties... by it, and praises you to me and tempts me.' It suffices him that he criticized such expressions whose beauty dazzled when it appeared, and became in every side of its face a moon. Al-Fadil's saying resembles the saying of Ibn Khafajah: 'In a green hollow adorned with Arak trees... or the head of a mountain turbaned with clouds.'

And from the composition of our Sheikh Shihab al-Din Mahmud, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, describing a fortress: 'A fortress that wore the stars as earrings and the clouds as a tunic. Its top soared to the sky and its base anchored in the boundaries. You imagine the sun, when it rises, moving in its towers. And one who overlooks Suha (a star) thinks it is a wick in his lamp. Nothing of what is named 'bird' rises above it except the eagle of the sky and its Mirzam (star). Nothing gazes at the adorned women of its towers except the eye of the sun and the eyes that twinkle from its stars. Around it, of the mountains, is every lofty one; the eagle of the atmosphere fears crossing its rugged terrain. The winds stop weary if they climb its hills. Eyes fear, if they gaze at it, to traverse the sockets beneath it. Thought imagines the image of ascending to it, then does not reach it until hearts reach the throats. Around it, of valleys, are trenches; the months are not known from them except by their halves, and crescents are not known in them except by their descriptions.' Ka'b al-Ashqari said describing a fortress: 'Soaring beneath the sky as if it were... a summer cloud from which its rain has departed / The mountain goats do not reach its high peaks... nor the birds, except its eagle and vulture / The children of its people were never frightened by the wolf... nor did its dogs bark at anything but the stars.' The two Khalidis said: 'And a fortress whose bottom the Capella (Al-Ayyuq) embraced... and whose heights surpassed the belt of Gemini / The rain is not known when the clouds are at it... a land whose two sides are trodden by equals / When the cloud appears, its inhabitant wades... in its pools before its spouts pour / Its watchtower is counted among the stars of the spheres... if it were to run in their courses / On the peak of a lofty one, filled with might... with pride, while it is filled with fat / It has an eagle, the eagle of the atmosphere hovering... beneath it, so it is hidden in its coverts.' They also said regarding that: 'And a shaven one (fortress) that boasted over those who see it... with its high watchtower and difficult ascent / The atmosphere buttons the pocket of its clouds over it... and dresses it in a necklace of its shooting stars / When lightning travels, it appears through it... as the Virgin appears through the gaps of clouds / I soared to it with determination shining in the darkness... cutting in great matters and rising in difficulty / So I revealed it, with torn pocket by spears... and left it with cheek stuck to the dust.' Discussion regarding simile in the verses of a poet. He said in the second type of simile, after citing the poet's saying: 'As if it (the wine) and as if the bearer of its cup... when he stood polishing/displaying it to the drinking companions / Were the morning sun dancing, so dotted its face... the full moon of darkness with the stars of Gemini.' That he compared the cupbearer to the full moon, the wine to the sun, and the bubbles upon it to the stars. I say: He claimed that he compared three things to three things. But he did not compare the cupbearer, nor is there in the two verses anything indicating his comparison. However, the poet imagined that he compared the cupbearer and did not mention him, and Ibn al-Athir, may Allah have mercy on him, imitated him in his illusion. Their meaning is: The wine in its bubbles is as if it were a sun that danced, so the full moon dotted it with stars, using its dancing as a metonymy for its agitation when mixed. Mentioning the full moon here is good because it accompanies the stars, and it is the largest of them in the view of the eye, not in the mind if one thinks about astronomy. So it was appropriate for it to have the stars at its disposal to dot the sun with them. Mentioning the full moon here is a matter by way of digression; when he mentioned the dots, he wanted to attribute their action to a doer from whom they issued, so it was appropriate to mention the full moon. If it were deleted from the speech, the meaning would be complete in the origin, as is said: 'As if the wine is a sun that danced and was dotted with stars.' The poet established the tool of simile for the cupbearer in his saying: 'As if it and as if the bearer of its cup.' But he did not bring a stored comparison for him. So the poet is deluded, and Ibn al-Athir is an imitator, and both of them were deceived by the mention of the country (Note: Likely meant 'Full Moon' - Badr, misprint in text or context). For the custom has been to compare the cupbearer to the full moon, and the wine to the sun. Like the poet's saying: 'Pour it for me, daughter of a vine... aged ten and five / A moon bearing a sun... spent the night displaying it to us.' And the saying of another: 'And a cupbearer like the crescent circulating a sun... to the companions in something like the crescent.' And the saying of Ibn al-Rumi: 'I saw him with the cup between a mouth... of his and five fingers / So as if it and as if its drinker... are a moon kissing the cheek of the sun.'

If the poet had compared the cupbearer, he would have said: 'A sun circulated by a full moon' or 'carried by it.' These two verses are famous among literary people, and perhaps no one noticed this criticism. I do not say: Because the poet introduced the indicators of simile to the stir of dust and their swords, and brought one object of comparison which is the night, and his saying: 'its stars falling' is in the position of an adjective for the night, so it is an appendage of the night. If he had said: 'A night whose stars fall, and lightning marks it and dawn variegates it,' all of that would be nothing but the object of comparison. If it were a case of comparing two to two, he would have said: 'A night and stars falling.' As Imru' al-Qais said: 'As if the hearts of birds, wet and dry... at her nest are jujubes and withered dates.' This which I mentioned is established on the touchstone of examination, not a claim devoid of evidence and proof. Al-Akawwak has a verse which is the verse of Bashar ibn Burd. It is: 'As if the rising of dust and the white swords around it... are the height of a night that revealed stars.' How beautiful is the saying of Ibn Qadi Mila: 'We spent the night by the Euphrates circulating it... at night, so the Nile shone from its brilliance / As if it were a sun and the hand of its circulator... among us was mid-morning and the mouth of the companion was late afternoon.' The saying of Abu Yazid al-Asi is more appropriate than this, for he said: 'The envier who blamed him for... seeing smallpox on his cheek faulted him / But his face is like a full moon... upon which they placed the Pleiades as a veil.' Because the Pleiades may be seen with the full moon, whereas stars are not seen with the sun. It can be said about it: For this reason he said: 'dotted it out of joy with stars,' for whoever is dotted with something has become distinct from it and separated. It is also possible to interpret the two verses cited by Ibn al-Athir, but it is far-fetched. Discussion of models of simile from Ibn al-Athir's composition. He said in Simile: 'Among that is what I wrote as part of a letter to the Divan of the Caliphate mentioning the descent of the disbelieving enemy upon Acre. I said: The enemy surrounded it as lips surround the front teeth (Thughur - also means frontiers), and descended upon it like the descent of darkness upon light.' I say: There is no exaggeration in that, because lips do not surround the teeth. Encompassing (Ihata) is the inclusion of the surrounded by the surrounder from every side, like the circle around the dot, the element of water around the globe of the earth, and the white of the eye around the black. As for lips, they are covering, not surrounding. The perfect example of that is the saying of Al-Hariri, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him: 'And groups of people surrounded him, like the halo surrounding the moon and the calyxes surrounding the fruit.' And the saying of Al-Qadi Al-Fadil: 'He preserved it with a preservation breaking habits, and made his favors surround necks like the surrounding of necklaces.' Lips are not like that; they only cover the exterior, not the interior. His saying: 'descent of darkness upon light' is not bad, relating disbelievers to darkness, and the frontier of Acre to light because it was in the hands of believers. How sweet is the saying of Al-Qadi Al-Fadil, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, in a letter regarding the conquest of Tiberias: 'The servant reached Tiberias in the morning and attacked it like the attack of a phantom (in dreams), and broke its virginity with the sword.' He said: 'Among that is what I mentioned in a section of a letter to some friends, saying: I compared his letter in its arrival and contraction only to the look of the beloved in his approach and turning away. Both matters are like an arrow in the pain of its impact and the pain of its extraction. And the yearning one is he whose passion is famous in the states of his connection and disconnection.' I say: This is taken from the saying of the poet... 'Woe to him if she looks and if she turns away... The impact of arrowheads and their extraction is painful.' Skill in simile in a verse by Al-Buhturi. He said, citing the saying of Al-Buhturi: 'You see him in the darkness of war and imagine him... a moon charging at men with a star.' In this simile are three things against three things, for he compared the dust to darkness, the praised one to the moon, and the spearhead to the star. This is rare beauty. I say: This is of the type previously mentioned regarding his saying on the poet: 'As if it and as if the bearer of its cup...' the two verses. There the poet was deluded and he imitated him, and here he is alone in the delusion without Al-Buhturi, because Al-Buhturi did not say: 'You see him in the dust of war when he charges at men with his spear, a moon roaming in the darkness with a star.' If the verse were understood this way, it would be a comparison of three to three. But there is nothing in the verse except one simile because he said: 'You see him in the darkness of war and imagine him a moon.'

This is the meaning upon which the verse is built. As for his saying: 'charging at men with a star,' it is one of the appendages of the moon. Do you not see that the sentence is in the accusative position as an adjective for 'moon'. It is strange that he claimed Al-Buhturi compared dust to darkness, whereas Al-Buhturi made the dust itself darkness. If the mention of darkness had come in the second hemistich of the verse, it would have entered into the object of comparison and been included between the moon and the star, but its mention came in the original subject of comparison. How beautiful is the saying of Al-Mu'tamid ibn Abbad: 'When you stormed the war armored... and veiled your face with the helmet / We considered your face the morning sun... upon which is a cloud of ambergris.' And the saying of Ibn al-Zaqqaq: 'If you were witnessing him while he covered the war... strutting in a flowing coat of iron / You would have seen from him, while the sword was in his hand... a sea shedding the blood of enemies with a stream.' And the saying of Al-Ghazzi: 'Stabbing has robbed the spearheads of their color... so what was blue became dyed red (safflower) in the upper chests / And our swords in the coats of mail are as if they are... streams flowing between blossoming flowers.' And his saying also: 'How many a blamed war from which you do not distinguish... from its knights except the blades and the eyes / Wading in blood that turned red under its smooth armor... as anemones grow around a pond.' This is taken from the saying of Abu al-Tayyib: 'His horses are accustomed not to chew grain... if the heads are not raised beside the nosebags / And they do not approach ponds unless their water... is from blood like basil under anemones.' Among what I said in this genre: 'And swords, when they pass into wounds... I said this is violet in anemone / The body seeks its soul from their blades... and their blood is between the Naqa and the Aqiq (places/colors).' As for what resembles the saying of Al-Buhturi cited by Ibn al-Athir, it is the saying of Abu Firas, I think: 'You returned from them with spoils, and their hearts... had in them a dragging army due to fear of you / And you came with the spear preceding you, as came... the deceiving star before the morning.' He said: 'Among the cold (bad) similes is the saying of Abu al-Tayyib: And red blood flowed upon the leaves... so it was like oranges (Naranj) on branches.' I say: By my life, he is excused in this, and it is one of the slips of Al-Mutanabbi in which he falls low. This verse is from that poem which he opened with his saying: 'Opinion is before the bravery of the brave... it is first and that is the second place' - the five verses. Look at this opening, and the wisdom and proverbs that follow it with eloquence and rhetoric. In this poem is the like of his saying: 'And they imagined play, war, and stabbing in the... battle other than stabbing in the square.' And from it describing the defeated enemy: 'Rain of clouds covers them, detailed... with sword, spear, and lance.' And before the verse cited by Ibn al-Athir: 'The trees of the mountains blackened their hair... as if there were hovering crows in it.' When Abu al-Mutarrif ibn Abi Bakr al-Makhzumi reversed the meaning of Abu al-Tayyib in comparing an orange in a river, it came out beautiful. For he said: 'And a view whose beauty kept me awake... of a blue (water) flowing like a speckled snake / I saw it carrying an orange... floating, red like dragon's blood / And the east wind rolled it on its surface... when it set out throwing it / So I thought it a sword of war drawn... shaken, and containing a drop of blood.' Ibn Fathun said regarding that: 'The water over its purity has an orange... floating in it while its waves ripple / Red, deep in color, as if it is... a star glowing in the middle of the galaxy.' So he conveyed the meaning in two verses, and Abu al-Mutarrif in four, so he prolonged. The saying of Abu al-Mutarrif reminded me of the saying of Al-Qadi Iyad, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him: 'As if the crops and their heads... when the hands of the winds appeared in them / Were battalions fleeing in defeat... Anemones in them were wounds.' Discussion of another model from Ibn al-Athir's composition. He said in the first section of the fourth type regarding Iltifat (Apostrophe/Grammatical Shift), after discussing the Iltifat in Surah Al-Fatiha from address to third person, and finishing that: 'Look at this place, and the harmony of these noble meanings, which feet almost tread upon and understandings, despite their proximity, overlook.'

I say: Is this how one speaks after mentioning the secrets of the Noble Quran and clarifying its obscurities? What benefit is there in his saying: 'Noble meanings' and his politeness in saying 'feet almost tread upon them!' It would have been better if he had said: 'Look at these noble meanings, how their suns have become exposed, and insights are distracted from perceiving their light.' Or to say: 'Crowns almost fall upon the partings (of hair), and minds are devoid of necklaces from its arranged pearls.' Iltifat in some verses. He said regarding Iltifat, citing the Almighty's saying: 'Then He directed Himself to the heaven while it was smoke' - the verse. He only shifted from the third person to the address in His Almighty's saying: 'And We adorned the nearest heaven' because a group of people other than those following religious law believe that stars are not in the nearest heaven, and that they are not for protection or stoning. So when the speech reached here, He shifted from addressing the absent to addressing Himself because it is important among the importances of rhetoric in belief, and it contains a denial of the denying sect believing in its falsehood. I say: Their belief that they are not in the nearest heaven and not for stoning is a type based on the belief in the pre-existence of the world, and that Allah Almighty is a cause by essence without the creation of the world and the Choosing Doer. According to what he established, attributing the action in creating the heavens in two days, and inspiring its affair in them to the Speaker, would be more appropriate than being a report about another, because it is the Origin. Care for the Origin is more appropriate than care for the Branch, because if the Origin is established, the Branch is established, and not vice versa. If this were more appropriate, He would not have shifted from it. But He shifted from it for a wisdom that did not appear to Ibn al-Athir. Inserting Grammar. He said in the fourth type regarding emphasizing two pronouns: Perhaps it is said in this place: Pronouns are mentioned in grammar books, so what need is there to mention them here? He did not know that grammarians do not mention what I mentioned, because this is specific to eloquence and rhetoric, and those do not address it. They only mention the number of pronouns, and that the detached ones are such and the attached are such, and do not go beyond that. As for me, I presented in this type a matter outside the grammatical matter. I say: The grammar of the ancients was mostly meanings (Ma'ani) and rhetoric (Bayan), such as Al-Rummani, Abu Ali al-Farisi, and Ibn Jinni despite their later time. Most of what is now recorded in the science of Ma'ani is mentioned in the books of those people. But when Imam Abd al-Qahir al-Jurjani came, he stripped these points which are not syntax necessarily, gathered them, recorded them, categorized them, and arranged them, so it became a science standing on its own head. People after him, like Al-Sakkaki and others, became alert and doors opened for them. For this reason, whoever is not masterful in grammar cannot speak on this. Do you not see that Al-Zamakhshari, when he was knowledgeable in grammar, found easy in his exegesis what was not easy for others? By his ability in syntax and looking into the secrets of Arabic and explaining its rules, he presented those problems and answered them with those dancing answers. Through grammar, he extended, became skilled, and deepened, and his training in the arts of poetry and prose alerted him to that. Even Imam Fakhr al-Din in his exegesis, you see him in all other sciences not imitating anyone, but when Ma'ani and Bayan come, he imitates Al-Zamakhshari in that and says: 'Mahmud al-Khwarizmi said' and 'The author of Al-Kashhaf said.' For this reason, scholars said: Whoever looks into Al-Kashhaf and is not knowledgeable in Arabic and principles of religion becomes a Mu'tazilite. The establishment of the science of Ma'ani and Bayan resembles nothing but Fiqh (Jurisprudence). For jurists in ancient times, among the Tabi'un, were only Hadith scholars. When Abu Hanifa, may Allah be pleased with him, came, he recorded Fiqh and established its rules, and measured what no Hadith reached him about against what Hadith had reached him about. People came after him and extended the ropes in it, and doors were opened for them. Jurists became unique with this science from the Hadith scholars. Jurists specialized in knowing rulings and deduction, and left the knowledge of Hadith paths, names of narrators, and its sound from its sick to the Hadith scholars. For this reason, you hear them say: So-and-so is of the Hadith-scholar Jurists. The notables of jurists were only distinguished by their undertaking of the art of Hadith. Look at the Imams of the schools like Al-Shafi'i, Abu Hanifa, Malik, Ahmad ibn Hanbal, Abu Dawood al-Zahiri, Al-Thawri, Al-Awza'i, and Sa'id ibn al-Musayyib, may Allah be pleased with them; you find them among the great Hadith scholars.

It is said: The reason Abu Hanifa established Fiqh and recorded it is that in his time, two men came to a bathhouse and entrusted the owner with a deposit that had a form, and they entered the bath. Then one of them came out, asked for the deposit, took it, and went on his way. When the other came out, he asked the bathhouse keeper for it. He told him: Your friend went out and took it. So he went to the judges of that time and complained to them. They obligated the keeper to pay it to the present adversary and said to him: You were negligent; it was your duty not to give the deposit except to both of them together as they entrusted you together. The man remained in confusion, not knowing what to do. Abu Hanifa met him and asked him about his state when he saw him thinking and confused. He informed him of his case. He said to him: Tell your adversary: The money is with me, so bring your friend to me so I can give the deposit to both of you. If he brings him, you have caught your adversary. That was the cause of the bathhouse keeper's salvation from that predicament. At that point, Abu Hanifa began recording Fiqh, and the mentioned issue was the first thing he established. Similarly, Principles of Jurisprudence (Usul al-Fiqh) was undertaken by the Mujtahid knowledgeable in the sciences needed to deduce the ruling from the verse and Hadith, having the power to look into the clear and ambiguous, the abrogating and abrogated, the literal and metaphorical, the soundness of Hadith from its weakness, the trustworthiness of narrators, and preferring one of two Hadiths over the other if they are equal in soundness according to what agrees with the rules and relies on legal analogy. The likes of this require abundant sciences. So Al-Shafi'i, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, came and established Principles of Jurisprudence, gathering what was scattered in sciences: from language in knowing the homonym, the contrast, the synonym, the literal, the metaphorical, the metaphor, and the metonymy. And from grammar in knowing condition and penalty, connected and disconnected exception, ordered conjunction and unordered conjunction, immediate and delayed, prepositions and their differing meanings, and ambiguous nouns, and so on. And from logic in knowing the indication of conformity, inclusion, and implication, knowing genus and species, difference and property, general accident, premises and conclusion, productive syllogism, and other things the jurist needs from the rules of debate and knowing fallacies. And what is needed of knowing the soundness, weakness, and goodness of Hadith, and so on. Al-Shafi'i, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, made it a science standing on its own head, even if its parts were scattered in sciences. Then people came after him and added to it what was possible. Likewise, the science of Ma'ani and Bayan was extracted from grammar, recorded, and made into an art standing on its own head. Regarding emphasizing two pronouns. He said: Let us present a statement that encompasses it and gathers its ends. We say: If the intended meaning is known and established in souls, you have the choice in emphasizing one of the pronouns with the other. If it is unknown and is something doubted, the priority then is to emphasize one of the pronouns with the other in indication to establish and confirm it. Among what came of that is His Almighty's saying: 'They said, O Moses, either you throw or we will be the throwers (Nahnu al-Mulqin).' For the magicians' will to throw before Moses was not known to him, and because they did not declare what was in their souls; and he spoke at length on that. I say: The benefit of what I determined has appeared, that Ma'ani and Bayan are part of grammar, and if they depart from grammatical rules, their speaker stumbles blindly.
