The proof of that is that he decided in the rule he has that if the meaning is established in the soul, you are free to emphasize one pronoun with the other. This rule is not absolute. For emphasis is repetition, and a condition of it, i.e., repetition, is that the meaning is complete without it, like: 'I hit Zayd Zayd,' 'Zayd Zayd came to me,' 'You You are the virtuous,' and 'He He is the generous.' All these forms permit deleting the emphasis because the meaning is complete without it. We have found the pronoun repeated where deleting it is not permissible, like His Almighty's saying: 'And We said, O Adam, dwell, you and your wife, in Paradise.' And His Almighty's saying: 'Go, you and your Lord, and fight.' Because imperative verbs like: Stand, Sit, Dwell, all carry the pronoun and it is not permissible to show it, because the estimation is: Stand you, and Dwell you. For this reason, grammarians judged imperative verbs to be sentences (Kalam) because they are composed of a verb and a subject.

Do you not see that they raised an objection to Sheikh Jamal al-Din ibn al-Hajib, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, in his saying: 'The word (Kalimah) is an utterance coined for a singular meaning,' regarding pronouns hidden in imperative verbs collectively, and said: They are words but the tongue did not utter them. Even Sheikh Badr al-Din Muhammad ibn Malik, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, said: 'The word is an utterance potentially or actually.' So he guarded with his saying 'potentially' against the likes of pronouns carried by imperative verbs. For this reason, some interpreted 'utterance' saying: 'Utterance is what the tongue casts or what is in its ruling' so that Ibn al-Hajib's definition remains pure. If this is established, I say: 'Anta' (You) in His Almighty's saying: 'Uskun Anta' (Dwell You) is another prominent pronoun different from the pronoun hidden in 'Uskun', and its estimation is: 'Uskun Anta Anta wa Zawjuk' (Dwell You You and your wife). Yet, it is not permissible to delete the apparent pronoun here because it is not permissible to conjoin 'your wife' to the hidden pronoun, due to the weakness of what is potential compared to what is actual. This is contrary to His Almighty's saying: 'Or that we be the throwers (Nahnu al-Mulqin).' So it is proven that the expert of Ma'ani, if he does not know grammar, does not know what he says. It is possible to answer for him and excuse him by saying: He is speaking about emphasis (Tawkid), and His Almighty's saying: 'Dwell, you and your wife' is not a case of emphasis, but was brought for another matter, which is the impermissibility of conjoining to the hidden pronoun, and this is other than emphasis. I said: In any case, it is a flawed, insufficient expression, needing a constraint to exclude the likes of this, otherwise it contradicts the rule he established, for rules need to be tight and unambiguous. Ibn al-Athir discusses Al-Mutanabbi regarding some of his poetry. He said in the eighth type regarding using the general in negation and the special in affirmation: Many poets have neglected that, among them Abu al-Tayyib where he says: 'O Badr (Moon), O Bahr (Sea), O Ghamamah (Cloud), O... Layth al-Shara (Lion), O Hamam (Death/Rain), O Rajul (Man).' If he does that, he is like one rising from a place to a higher place, and if he opposes it, he is like one descending from a place to a lower place. As for his saying: 'O Badr,' it is the name of the praised one and starting with it is priority. Then he should say after it: 'O Man, O Lion, O Cloud, O Sea, O Hamam,' because the Lion is greater than the Man, the Cloud is greater than the Lion, the Sea is greater than the Cloud, and the Hamam is greater than the Sea. I say: Ibn Abi al-Hadid discussed this and said words whose summary I mention. It is that Al-Mutanabbi intended a valid purpose because he started with the Sea, which is lower than the Cloud, because the sea here is the one that is visited (for water), and it is like the pond and the river, not the salty sea, for that is a complete exhaustion. Rivers and ponds branch from the Cloud. Then he moved and said: 'O Lion of al-Shara' and moved from it to 'Hamam' because it is higher than the Lion, for were it not for death (Hamam), the Lion would not be feared. To mention generosity first, he said 'O Sea', and to mention bravery second, he said 'O Lion', and he prioritized generosity because the need of the majority of people for generosity is greater than their need for bravery. End. This is the summary of Ibn Abi al-Hadid's speech, and by my life, it is a good interpretation, reversing Ibn al-Athir's intent against him and making the verse a case of moving from lower to higher. Most people criticized the verse as Ibn al-Athir did. I said: People have another interpretation for it, which is that he is not required to move from lower to higher in what he intended. He wanted to describe him with the praise he claimed in him before. He said: 'O Badr' is his name. Then he said 'O Sea', and if I am not truthful in what I say, then 'O Cloud', and if I am not truthful, then 'O Lion', and if I am not truthful, then 'O Hamam' because you deprive the souls of your enemies of life. And if I am not truthful, then 'O Man' who gathered these qualities I mentioned. Although this interpretation is not as strong or beautiful as what Ibn Abi al-Hadid mentioned. Ibn al-Athir claimed that Hamam is bigger and higher than the Sea and did not explain the reason for that. What I say regarding that is: Because death is an expression of the absence of life, and the sea is an expression of the existence of abundant, overwhelming water, and absence is more general than existence, so it is higher than it in this regard and prioritized over it. Of this is His Almighty's saying: 'Praise be to Allah who created the heavens and the earth, and made darkness and light.' It is said: He prioritized darkness over light because darkness is an expression of the absence of light, and absence precedes existence. Were it not for this interpretation in this noble verse, Al-Mutanabbi's saying: 'O Badr, O Sea...' the verse, would be of this category.

It is problematic for the one who decided that one only moves from the lower to the higher. With this rule they decided, those who favored Angels over Prophets held fast and said: Allah Almighty moved from the lower to the higher in His Almighty's saying: 'Never would the Messiah disdain to be a servant of Allah, nor would the angels near [to Him].' For the Wise does not move from the higher to the lower, and the eloquent does not say: 'I do not think of the Sultan nor the Vizier,' but says: 'I do not think of the Vizier nor the Sultan.' The correct view held by the scholars of the Sunnah is that Prophets are better than Angels, except those who deviated among them like: Judge Abu Bakr al-Baqillani and Abu Abdullah al-Halimi. His saying: 'And the example of its efforts in the eyes of enemies was a wondrous thing.' This is empty speech like a body without a spirit. And his saying: 'And showed them in wakefulness terror and fear, and in sleep difficult camels, leading noble horses.' The origin of this meaning belongs to Ashja' al-Sulami: 'And upon your enemy, O cousin of Muhammad... are two watchers: the light of dawn and darkness / If he wakes, you terrify him, and if he sleeps... dreams draw your swords against him.' Nothing adorned his second rhyme except his inclusion of the rhyme that came in the vision of the Mobedan on the night the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, was born, and what came regarding that from the speech of Satih. Ibn al-Athir celebrated these two rhymes and wanted to match Al-Qadi Al-Fadil in the prayer of the letter he wrote regarding the conquest of Jerusalem. From it: 'And may the rains of his favor not cease to be Anwa' (heavy rains) to the spring quarters and Anwar (lights) to the mosques, and the expeditions of his terror to the enemies be horses (Khayl) to the watchtowers and phantoms (Khayal) to the sleeping places.' You, O standing upon these papers, are a judge between these two adversaries, and in your hand is the command to distinguish between the two speeches: 'So whoever deserves elevation, elevate him... and whoever deserves lowering, lower him into his privy.' Even if my passion inclined me to the speech of Al-Fadil. To Allah belongs Ibn Sana' al-Mulk where he said: 'I saw the full moon then I saw her... What is upon me if I loved the better one?' Then he said: 'And it is the conquest of Jerusalem for which the doors of heaven opened, and the stars of darkness increased with the tales of its glory, and the right of Islam was reclaimed, and long have aspirations striven in seeking it with provision and water.' What aspirations are these, and what can they attain if they have nothing but provision and water? Did they not have a concern other than provision and water, nor a thought other than that? An aspiration whose concern is not horses, men, weapons, perseverance, night travel, riding dangers, crossing deserts, and patience over sleeplessness and types of hardships—what thing can it attain? Then he said: 'And among the best he brought is that he comforted his second Qibla with his first Qibla.' I say: The rare beauty in this is what appeared in the sermon of Judge Muhyi al-Din ibn al-Zaki, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, while on the pulpit in the first Friday held in Jerusalem: 'And this mosque of yours is the first of the two Qiblas, the second of the two Harams, and the third of the two Mosques...' Al-Imad al-Katib also used that in a letter he wrote to the Divan of the Caliphate regarding the conquest of Jerusalem as well, saying after mentioning the Rock: 'So hands shook from it the place of the foot, and the joy and message were renewed for it as they were in ancient times (Qidam); for it is the second of the two Mosques, rather the third of the two Harams.' Then he said: 'And it had emerged from the weapons in a magnificent dress of impregnability, and brought out from the great darkness (Sawad A'zam) what deceived eyes, and war is deception.' I say: Is this written about a king who suffered horrors as he suffered, endured what he endured, and sacrificed himself, his son, his family, his wealth, and his armies until he saved the likes of Jerusalem from the likes of the Franks? He wants to relate to the Caliph with this favor, magnify the matter, and describe the hardships he endured until this great conquest happened in the days of the Caliph, was added to his kingdom, and entered his grasp. It is said: He deceived them with the great darkness (Sawad A'zam - also means great multitude) and war is deception. This is not appropriate in this context. Then he said: 'And the necks of lands are not defended by the abundance of the blackness (Sawad), nor protected by high walls, but by high spears.' I say: It would have been better if he had said: 'And the necks of lands are not defended by the abundance of the blackness (multitude), but by the whiteness of opinion and abundance of correctness.'

However, this letter which Ibn al-Athir—may Allah have mercy on him—cited to oppose [Al-Qadi] Al-Fadil is among the best he created and the finest he embellished. The reason for this is that he opposed him directly, borrowing his merits of deliberation and patience; thus, it came out refined with its flowers blooming. Had he taken a separate path, and Al-Qadi Al-Fadil taken another, and they sat in one place working without a template, the front-runner in the race would have been clearly distinguished from the straggler. This is similar to when Sultan Al-Mu'izz suggested to Ibn Rashiq and Ibn Sharaf Al-Qayrawani that they compose poetry regarding the slender legs of a woman, praising them because he admired them while some rival wives criticized them. He said: 'I want this to be an argument for her against those who find fault with her.' So, each of them went aside and composed on the spot. Ibn Sharaf came up with: 'And a Bilqis-like woman adorned with hair... sparse like what a miser gives. It resembled the down on cheeks, and every cheek... that has down is beloved and beautiful. If the palace of Bilqis was glass... then from the pupils of eyes she has palaces.' Ibn Rashiq came up with: 'They criticize a Bilqis-like woman when they see upon her... what was seen by the one who erected the palace. The downy hair only increased her beauty, just as... the down on the cheeks of beardless youths increases their beauty.' Al-Mu'izz admired Ibn Sharaf's verses and criticized Ibn Rashiq's, saying: 'You have provided her opponent with an argument by saying "They criticize," for indeed some people did criticize it.' This is sound criticism. Look at how these two poets spoke with one tongue, from one vision, one meaning, and one rhyme. There is no harm in establishing part of Al-Qadi Al-Fadil's letter regarding the mentioned Conquest [of Jerusalem]. Were it not for the fear of elongation, I would have included both letters in their entirety, but they can be taken from their respective sources. Al-Qadi Al-Fadil—may Allah the Exalted have mercy on him—said: 'May Allah perpetuate the days of the Noble Diwan, and may it remain victorious over every denier, rich through success beyond the opinion of any scout, its endeavors dedicated to acquiring the absolutes of praise, its victory awake while the sword sleeps in its scabbard, arriving at the clouds of generosity while clouds do not arrive at the earth, its endeavors of merit numerous even if met with only a single thanks, the judgment of its justice executed with a determination that does not proceed to draw a sword of error or feather an arrow of guidance. May the rains of its virtue continue towards the allies as stars to the meadows and lights to the mosques, and the expeditions of its terror towards the enemies as horses to the watchtowers and phantoms to the sleeping quarters.' From it: 'To Allah belongs the satisfaction in the repetition of His thanks, and for the present blessing is a permanence of which it cannot be said "this has passed." The affairs of Islam have turned to their best destinies, the beliefs of its people have settled upon their insights, and the extended shadow of the disbeliever has retracted. Allah has been truthful to the people of His religion; when the condition was fulfilled, the conditioned result occurred. Islam was a stranger, and now it is in its homeland; victory was offered, and souls were spent as its price. The command of Allah came while the noses of polytheism were rubbed in dust, and the swords journeyed by night while lifetimes were asleep. Allah fulfilled His promise to make His religion prevail over all religion, and lights flew for it revealing that the morning, in comparison, has a cowardly brow. The Muslims reclaimed an inheritance that had absconded from them; they seized it while awake, something they did not believe they would seize even as a phantom visiting in sleep from a distance. Their feet settled on the highest ground, their flags fluttered over the farthest reach, and their lips met upon the Rock (Al-Sakhrah); and though it was a rock, their thirst was quenched by it as one is quenched by water. When the Religion arrived upon it, it recognized in it the core of its heart, and its peer, the Black Stone, congratulated it on the consummation of its protection from the disbeliever and his war. Praise be to Allah that it entered the sanctuary by removing that sewn structure, and it was purified by what dripped from the support of disbelief—and the surrounding ocean would not have been enough to purify it. The servant [Saladin] did not strive his striving except for this great boon, nor did he endure that misery except for this blessing, nor did he fight those he deemed oppressors except so the Word would be united and the Word of Allah would be the highest, and to win the jewels of the Hereafter, not the base goods of this world. He who seeks something grave risks himself; he who desires a profitable deal [with God] is a winner; and he who aspires to clear the flood plunges in.' From it, when mentioning the Caliphs: 'No doubt they inherited their secret and their inner self to their purest successor, their greatest son, their noble remnant, their lofty vanguard, and the title of the page of their virtue; may Islam never lack the black of the pen and the white of the page.' From it: 'The East is guided by its lights; nay, if a light appeared from its essence, the West would call out to hide it, for it is a light not concealed by the darkness of dusk, and a mention not hidden by the leaves of scriptures.' From it, mentioning disbelief: 'A sword whose eyelid slept, yet its wakefulness spilled the drops of slumber from eyelids; the noses of its spears were cut off, though they had long been haughty with desires and bleeding with death. The Holy Pure Land became [clean], though it had been menstruating, and the Lord is Single and One, though in their claim He was the third [of three].'

From it: 'Allah replaced the bad deed with the good deed, and transferred the house of His worship from the hands of the companions of the left hand to the companions of the right hand.' From it: 'How many crescents of swords were engaged in exchange of blows until they returned like old date stalks, and how many stars of spears exchanged piercing until they became like the plague-stricken. The day was witnessed, the angels were witnesses, the Cross was screaming, Islam was newborn, and the ribs of the disbelievers were fuel for the fire of Hell.' From it, mentioning the Count and his flight: 'He was capable on the day of victory in fighting, and on the day of defeat in trickery. So he escaped, but how? He flew out of fear that the beak of the spear and the wing of the sword would catch him. It was likewise for their equipment, and he transferred from the Angel of Death to Malik [Keeper of Hell]. After the defeat, the Servant passed over the lands and folded them by spreading over them the Abbasid banner—black in dye, white in deed—fluttering, along with the hearts of its enemies and the determinations of its allies, illuminated by its lights when humans open their eyes to it, while the fingers of its streamers pointed toward the face of victory.' From it: 'He reaps disbelief and plants faith; he brings down crosses from their mosques and raises calls to prayer (Adhan); he changes altars into pulpits and churches into mosques; he settles the people of the Quran in the seats of fighting after the people of the Cross; and it delights his eye and the eye of the people of Islam that victory was attached to him and his army like a neighbor and what is neighboring (Preposition and object), and that he triumphs over every wall whose shaking and removal was not feared until the day of blowing into the Horn.' From it: 'He faced it then fought it; he descended to it then combated it; he emerged against it then dueled it; he restrained it then finished it. He embraced it with an embrace after which he anticipated the opening (conquest), and he cracked its gathering so that they could not endure the servitude of the sword edge after the freedom of pardon.' From it: 'He brought forward the mangonels whose beams and ropes undertake the punishments of fortresses, and he strung for them bows that strike while their arrows do not leave their blades. They shook hands with the wall, so their arrow became a toothpick in the gaps of its battlements. Victory presented a vulture from the mangonel that clings to the earth yet rises high to the sky (Arcturus); it fractured the cartilage of its towers and made the sound of its dust heard, emptying the wall of patrols and the war of spectators. It enabled the miner to unveil the face of war and return the stone to its original state of dust. He advanced to the rock, chewing its mail with the fangs of his pickaxe, untying its knots with his clumsy blow that indicated the delicacy of his fingertips. He made the Noble Rock hear his yearning and plea until it almost softened at his fatal spot. Some stones disowned others, and ruin took a covenant upon it that it would not leave the ground. He opened a door in the wall that blocked doors of escape for them. He began to crumble its stone, and the disbeliever said: "Oh, I wish I were dust."' From it, regarding receiving the city: 'Islam possessed a plan with which its covenant was a dwelling of inhabitants, then disbelief served it until it became a garden of paradise. No doubt Allah the Exalted expelled them from it and brought them down, pleasing the people of Truth and angering them.' From it: 'In it is every strange type of marble whose water flows but its shimmer does not flow away. Iron was made delicate in its marbling, and art was mastered in its expansion, until the iron, which has severe might, became like gold, which has ready comfort. You see nothing but seats like meadows with shimmering white marble, and columns like trees with leafy vegetation.' From it: 'The sermon (Khutbah) was established, and the heavens almost split apart from flowing tears, not from silence, and the stars almost scattered from joy, not for stoning devils. The word of Monotheism (Tawhid) was raised to Allah while its path had been blocked; the graves of the Prophets were purified while they had been defiled by impurities; the five [prayers] were established while the Trinity had been holding them back; tongues voiced "Allah is Great" while the magic of disbelief had been knotting them; and the name of the Commander of the Faithful was announced in his most noble location from the pulpit, so he was welcomed with the welcome of one who is righteous by one who is righteous. His two banners fluttered in the east and west; had he flown from joy, he would have flown with his two wings.' From it: 'Every hardship compared to the Conquest is bearable, and the ambitions of the Franks after this are neither hopeful nor isolated. If they make a call, the Servant hopes from Allah it will not be heard, and they will not untie their hands from the collars of the lands until they are cut off. For these good tidings, there are news that cannot be personified except by tongues, nor summarized by anything other than oral communication. Therefore, he sent So-and-so explaining, and a loud announcer giving good news, presenting the report in its context, and displaying the army of joy from its vanguard to its rearguard. He is So-and-so.' He said in another letter mentioning the Rock: 'Nebuchadnezzar's luck in returning Jerusalem was sharper than the sword of Nebuchadnezzar.' Here I mention the verses of the companion Jamal al-Din ibn Matruh, may Allah have mercy on him, which are: 'The Al-Aqsa Mosque has a habit... that traveled and became a proverb current (Mathal Sa'ir) / If it becomes a settlement for disbelief... Allah sends a helper (Nasir) for it / So a Nasir [Saladin] purified it first... and a Nasir [Al-Nasir Dawud] purified it last.' Returning to the words of Al-Fadil:

From it: 'Disbelief had settled in this city, so it possessed and consumed it, locked it and secured it. Its keys were lost to Islam and it did not find them except in the time of the Commander of the Faithful, and they are the swords. No battle line was struck in its courtyard for war until rows were struck in its mosque for prayer. So he reclaimed the Rock, which is the bezel of the ring of Islam, just as Solomon of old reclaimed his ring; and the agent of Islam in reclaiming its ring was its sharp sword.' End of the speech of Al-Fadil, may Allah the Exalted have mercy on him. This is intuitive, not like the drafting of a sayer... who, when he intends to speak, falsifies it for a month. Ibn al-Athir—may Allah have mercy on him—followed the book of the conquest of Jerusalem with a chaotic appointment decree (for market inspection - Hisba), in which he elongated without a mediator in its knot, nor a witticism in its folds to link it with wonder. Rather, he exhausted the etiquettes of Hisba and enumerated them, set its commandments in his wire and arranged them, and lengthened its text when he listed them. He displayed knowledge in it, not the subtlety of work, and produced it stripped of beauties, so there is no desire in it for the skilled composer nor hope. It is more worthy of being a chapter on the etiquettes of Hisba than being counted among appointment decrees, and to be added to books written for that purpose rather than being listed in the collection of composition (Insha'). ? Regarding the occurrence of 'an' after 'lamma' and its effect on indicating a delay in time. He said in the seventeenth type regarding Repetition: He mentioned the entry of 'an' which comes after 'lamma' and claimed that if it enters the speech, it indicates that the action was not immediate, and that there was a delay and a respite. He cited the Almighty's saying: 'And when (falamma an) the bearer of good tidings came, he cast it over his face, and he returned seeing.' He argued: If one looks at the story of Joseph with his brothers from the time they threw him in the well until the bearer of good tidings came to his father, peace be upon him, one finds that there was a delay and a very long duration. Had there not been a long period and an extended term, 'an' would not have been brought after 'lamma' and before the verb. Rather, the verse would have been: 'falamma ja'a...' (So when the bearer of good tidings came...). He said: These are subtleties and symbols not found with the grammarians because it is not their concern. I say: This is a crime of a man's vanity with his own mind and opinion. Do you not see how he imagined error to be correctness, then began to boast that he found what the grammarians did not understand nor know? Did he not look at this 'Fa' (So/Then) which indicates succession; following what did it appear? Did it appear following the Almighty's saying: 'So when they took him and agreed to put him in the bottom of the well...' and the verses related to the incident of throwing him in the well, for him to make this claim? Or did it appear following the Almighty's saying: 'Go with this shirt of mine and cast it over my father's face; he will become seeing. And bring me your family, all together. And when the caravan departed, their father said: "Indeed, I find the scent of Joseph, if you did not think me senile." They said: "By Allah, indeed you are in your old error."... up to the Almighty's saying: 'And when (falamma an) the bearer of good tidings came...'? So what delay is there between these two events of 'far distance' and 'extended duration'? It was only the measure of the distance from Egypt to the land of Canaan, the residence of Jacob, peace be upon him, which is about twelve days or thereabouts. That is why the grammarians said: It ('an') is extra here. He also said in this type, citing the verse of Abu Nuwas: 'We stayed in it a day, and a day, and a third... and a day to which the day of departure was a fifth.' His meaning by that is that they stayed four days. Oh, wonder at him! He brings such a silly verse indicating obscene inarticulateness amidst those verses. I say: The matter is not as he claimed, that he meant they stayed four days. Rather, some literati have held that the stay was seven days, based on the evidence that he stayed 'a day, and a day, and a third'—these are three days. Then he said: 'and a day to which the day of departure was a fifth,' so he added the three to another four, the fifth of which was the day of departure. The person of taste does not doubt that this expression is better than saying: 'We stayed in it a week,' even if the latter is more concise in wording, but that has its place. Even if we concede that the stay was four days, he repeated it for a meaning found only in this repetition, which is that the stay in this state is a station of describing days he spent in pleasure. So he began counting them individually, not in sum, saying: 'We stayed in it a day, and a day, and a day,' like one savoring the form of each day he summons in his mind, and the types of pleasures and delights that passed for them in it. This is a common matter in good and evil, so it is said: 'He contacted me day, after day, after day, after day,' and 'He abandoned me day, after day, after day, after day.' Similar to this is the saying of Marwan al-Asghar: 'May Allah water Najd, and peace be upon Najd... and oh, how lovely is Najd despite the distance and remoteness.' He repeated it to savor its mention and burn with longing for it. And how excellent is Al-Mutanabbi where he said:

He said in this type as well, citing the saying of Abu Nuwas: 'We stayed there a day, and a day, and a third... and a day to which the day of departure was a fifth.' His meaning from that is that they stayed four days. How strange of him to bring such a silly verse indicating obscene stuttering amidst those verses. I say: The matter is not as he claimed that he intended they stayed four days. Rather, some literati have gone to say that the stay was seven days, based on the evidence that he stayed 'a day, and a day, and a third,' so these are three days. Then he said: 'and a day to which the day of departure was a fifth.' So he added to the three another four, the fifth of which was the day of departure. No person of taste doubts that this expression is better than his saying: 'We stayed there a week,' even if this is more concise in wording, but that has a position. We grant that the stay was four days, but he repeated that for a meaning found only in this repetition, which is that the stay in this state is a stay of description of days he spent in pleasure. So he began counting them individually, not collectively, saying: 'We stayed there a day, and a day, and a day,' like one relishing the form of each day he summoned in his mind, and the types of pleasures and joys that passed for them in it. This is a familiar matter in good and evil. It is said: 'He connected with me a day, in a day, in a day, in a day,' and 'He abandoned me a day, in a day, in a day, in a day.' Of this is the saying of Marwan al-Asghar: 'May Allah water Najd, and peace be upon Najd... And oh how lovely is Najd despite distance and remoteness.' He repeated it out of pleasure in mentioning it, and burning with longing for it. To Allah belongs Al-Mutanabbi where he said:

'So I swear, if you saw me at her death... and my eyelid pouring tears bucket after bucket / You would have mourned for a blade whose sheath death took... and marveled at a branch wailing over a root.' This metonymy might be beautiful from Al-Sharif Al-Radi in the chapter of sarcasm (Tahakkum) and be the ultimate in beauty. In general, the ugliness of the metonymy he mentioned is not intrinsic but due to an accidental matter. Although he cited after it the saying of Al-Farazdaq mourning his wife: 'And a sheath of blades I have been bereaved of, so I did not wail... over it, nor did I send wailing women over it.' He said: This is beautiful and novel in its chapter, and no woman who died was alluded to with a plural better than this metonymy nor more magnificent in status. It is said to him: What beauty is in this and what ugliness in that? Regarding conceptual fallacies. He said in the twentieth type regarding conceptual fallacies: Among it is what I wrote in a section of a letter upon my entry into the lands of the Romans (Anatolia), describing the cold and snow: 'Among the qualities of this cold is that it knots pearls in its background, and tears in its tip. Perhaps it transgressed to the well of the mind, so it deserved that I run with its description. The earth is gray (Shahba'), except that it is a yearling not trained. The flood channels of mountains are rivers, except that they are frozen not waded.' I say: Then he began to describe the place of beauty in his saying: 'Yearling and not trained.' What great beauty is in this to record and cite? But he is excused if a Tawriya (double entendre) occurred in his speech to propose to it. How would he be if he said like Al-Qadi Al-Fadil describing the cold: 'In a night whose wine froze, and whose ember was extinguished... to a day when the onion would wish to increase its layers (shirts), and the sun would wish to drag the fire to its disk.' Al-Jalal ibn al-Saffar versified this, saying: 'And a day of cold whose breaths... tear faces with their pinching / A day whose sun wishes from its cold... that it could drag the fire to its disk.' And from the speech of Al-Fadil in a very cold night: 'In a night water froze in its felts until its back became heavy, and the rule in simile was reversed until its wool became like mountains.' Sahib Jamal al-Din ibn Matruh said: 'Look, you will find the face of the earth white... no black mole appearing in it / The clouds were generous and covered the soil with snow... Indeed, the generous one has the white hand.' Mujir al-Din Muhammad ibn Tamim said: 'Since your world promised that you would remain... in bliss and happiness that does not end / The proof of its fulfillment was that it... began facing us with a white face.' Mujir al-Din also said regarding the cold: 'And a cold night in which blew... a breeze not faced by chests / A breeze from which the garden shivers... when it arrives, and the pond trembles.' Then he said: 'Among that is what I mentioned in describing a generous man, so I said: And I descended upon him with Muhallabi (Generous) deeds, Ahnafi (Forbearing) morals, and I met him as if I was not frightened by the sting of separation. No dignity for family and homeland so that I say I exchanged family and homeland for him. My covenant with days is that they are weaning (Fatima) from charity, but he generated beauty (Hasan) by his neighborhood.' Then he began praising that. I say: The utmost of what he mentioned is that he used the name of Fatima and Al-Hasan, may Allah be pleased with them both, as a Tawriya, and this is not great. How beautiful is what Al-Qadi Al-Fadil used of the name of Al-Hasan, saying addressing noble people (Ashraf): 'The happy one is he whose new resembles his old, the happy one. Old honor is cut off if new honor does not connect it. The branch from the deep-rooted tree, if it does not grow, is firewood. Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, his uncle was Abu Lahab. It is ugly that your deed be ugly while your grandfather is Al-Hasan. And that your beginning be a fighter so there is no fitnah, and you fight so there are fitnahs.' How beautiful is the saying of Abu al-Husayn al-Jazzar praising Saif al-Din Ali ibn Qilij in part of a poem mentioning time: 'And I am accustomed to bearing its calamities... if its bearer becomes tired or weary of worry / I say to my poverty: Welcome, for my certainty... that Ali is killing it with nobilities.' Such is Tawriya, and such is the transformation of imagination. Among what I happened to organize: 'I say to a singer who sang to us... while tears had ulcerated the lids of my eyes / O beautiful of face (Hasan), return and take... with the voice of Ali for us in Husayni (maqam).' Then he said: 'From this style is what I wrote in a section of a letter to some friends, saying: His covenant is with my pen while it adorns itself with clarity by his names, and highlights the lights of meanings from his darknesses. My hand has become from it a carrier of firewood (Hammalat al-Hatab), and my mind has become Abu Jahl after it was Abu Lahab.'

I say: Al-Qadi Al-Fadil used the likes of this often, and later writers became fond of such things, bringing in it the sea and the ocean. Ibn al-Nabih said: 'If the daughter of the bunch (wine) were not his saliva... his red cheek would not have become Abu Lahab / May the hands of my blamer regarding him perish (Tabbat), and his cheek... is a carrier of roses, not a carrier of firewood.' Ibn Sana' al-Mulk said about a person with facial hair: 'You were like a gazelle possessing softness... You became like a bull possessing a dewlap / A cheek that was Abu Lahab... returned as a carrier of firewood.' He said: 'I described you while the blamer opposed with blame... So you were Abu Dharr and he was Abu Jahl.' I said while I was in the sands of Egypt at Al-Arish: 'We came to the trellis (Arish) of sand at the time of its heat... So we said to it: May your hands perish, O Abu Lahab / And how many a tamarisk tree with no shade or fruit... Met us from it with the carrier of firewood.' Then he said in a section: 'Among the traces of his endeavors is that he possessed the lock of nobilities and their key. If asked for a virtue, he was its granter (Manna'), and if asked for a gift, he was its donor (Manah). A better trace than that is that he took the reins of correctness and softened their unruliness. If he witnessed the thick of war, he was its Victor (Mansur), and if he met the soul of a crisis, he was its Shedder (Saffah).' I say: This chapter, I mean the names of Caliphs in titles, is something people dared to enter, and every literati crossed it and acted in its outcome. It is easy to lead in Tawriya if pulled, and quick to rise if established or set up. Ibn Sana' al-Mulk said: 'The hand of happiness pledged allegiance to him, and the pledge... was repeated upon him by the Right Hand (Al-Yamin) / The Right Opinion (Al-Rashid) chose him over the world... So he is the Trustworthy (Al-Amin) and the Trusted (Al-Ma'mun).' Saif al-Din al-Mashadd ibn Qizil said: 'O people of my affection, a call from a sick one... whose complaint was hidden from visitors / By Allah, my skin is not obedient to you... No, nor by Allah is my heart the Guide (Al-Hadi).' Ibn Sana' al-Mulk said: 'By my father and mother is the one who is Sufficient (Al-Muktafi)... with his beauty, to his beauty as the Follower (Al-Muqtadi) / Lonely, unique in his beauty... Do not wonder at the loneliness of the Unique (Al-Mutafarrid).' Mujir al-Din Muhammad ibn Tamim said: 'O you who prefer my heading to Hama and my service... Its Sultan is after every Prince / I am confident in the Right (Rashid) of your opinion, obedient... to its Trustworthy (Amin), the Guide (Hadi) to the Victor (Mansur).' Then he said in a section: 'I only say that he felt (Sha'ara - pun on poetry) that stolen joy, so he established the Cutting (Qat' - poetic/prosody term) upon it, and saw life in it as Lowering (Khafd - ease/grammar term) so he removed it with Raising (Raf' - grammar term).' I say: This chapter is also among what preceded, and its wall is among what was ruined and demolished. People entered it in crowds, and their pearls in it pleased singly and in pairs. Al-Siraj al-Warraq said mourning Al-Jazzar: 'They raised (Raf') you and stood standing, lowering (Khafid) the... voices when death truncated (Jazm) the bonds from you / You became in the shrouds concealed (Mudmar) from them... while they see you as a manifestation (Mazhar) for majesty / Indeed the Sound (Sahih) became ill since you left us... By your father, the Sound Plural (Jam' Sahih) broke (Takassar).' He also said: 'Your enviers set up (Nasb) enmity, so they ended up... with Truncation (Jazm) for their tongues and Lowering (Khafd) of status / So when will I see them turned back while their heads... are Raised (Marfu'a) by the agents of spears.' Shihab al-Din al-Talla'fari said: 'And when the hill overlooked and I smelled from... the breath of the sanctuary a fragrance like the spread of perfume / Ask its Erected (Mansub) hill where is its Raised (Marfu') talk... from the tail of the east wind which is Dragged (Majrur).' This is the utmost beauty of craftsmanship, for he brought the Accusative in the Accusative, the Nominative in the Nominative, and the Genitive in the Genitive. He has two other verses in this meaning, but these are better and more complete. In general, these things, the later writers violated their sanctity and prevented the fathers from their protection, especially the names of Caliphs as preceded, titles of grammar as preceded, and names of Quranic Surahs. As Abu al-Husayn al-Jazzar said praising Fakhr al-Qudah Nasrallah ibn Basaqa: 'How many a night I spent in difficulty while I had... in the adornment of my hopes treasures of ease / I say to my poverty whenever I longed for wealth... When the Help of Allah (Nasrallah) comes, may the hand of poverty perish (Tabbat).' And as he also said when a robe was bestowed upon a black poet and not upon him, addressing Jamal al-Din ibn Ramadan: 'It is not hidden from you what the black one attained... yesterday of the Sultan's generosity and his walking / With the turban, the robe... the sleeve handkerchief, and the shawl.'

'I said when I detailed against him, I see the Ornament (Zukhruf)... recited by text above the Smoke (Dukhan).' And as Saif al-Din ibn Qizil said: 'I swear by my eyelid by the Scatterers (Dhariyat)... And by the tears of the eye by the Emissaries (Mursalat) / I am upon sincerity in your love... Until you see my soul in the Pluckers (Nazi'at).' And as another said: 'I implore the Merciful (Rahman) to gather our union... He swears this will not be until the Gathering (Hashr) / If his heart became like Iron (Hadid)... Then by the Time (Asr), the lovers are indeed in Loss (Khusr).' And names of books, as one said in verses: 'O you who ask me after them about my state... Leaving the answer is the Answer to this Question / My state if narrated is neither Summarized (Jumal) nor... Shining (Luma'), having no Completion (Takmila) / I have a burning passion that leaves the Eloquent (Fasih) stupid... So leave the Detailed (Mufassal) and take the Summary (Mujmal) / The heart is not of the Healthy (Sahih) so its Reform (Islah) is hoped... And the eye is heavy clouds.' He mentioned in these three verses ten names of literary works. As Ibn Qizil said regarding a beautiful person playing the Qanun: 'You see Ibn Sina in his hands... The least of his playing is Singing (Ghina) / His Canon (Qanun) is Pleasing (Murtada), Salvation (Najah)... All his Signals (Isharat) are Healing (Shifa).' He mentioned in the second verse, despite the shortness of its meter, four books of the Chief (Avicenna). And as Abu al-Husayn al-Jazzar said: 'O my Master (Maliki), my Intercessor (Shafi'i) is nothing... to you but my manners / Far be it from you to need in alerting... the Polished (Muhadhdhab).' And names of Sheikhs of Sciences, as Abu al-Husayn al-Jazzar said: 'Indeed, the season of winter, since it approached my body... my limbs showed its explanation / In it my bone is the Cooled (Mubarrad) as the Clothed (Kisa'i) appeared... and the Furrier (Farra') protected himself.' And as Nasir al-Din Hasan ibn al-Naqib said: 'O one whose Stations (Maqamat) in generosity are gilded... And of his honorific robes are embroidery and brocade / You gave me a body cast down having no... spirit, and having disturbance and agitation from the cold / There is no dispensing with a fur coat under the silk... Indeed, the Silk-maker (Hariri) is in need of the Furrier (Farra').' And as Mujir al-Din Muhammad ibn Tamim said: 'And a singing woman repeating her song to me... delighting me while I ignore what she says / With a melody in which Ibrahim was confused... And a meter which Al-Khalil did not know.' Sharaf al-Din al-Maqdisi, may Allah have mercy on him, organized a poem approaching fifty verses, collecting a group of books of Exegesis, Hadith, Fiqh, Grammar, Language, and others, and mentioning Sheikhs of Sciences and others. It is all ghazal. And the names of the twelve Zodiac signs and the Stations. As Ibn Qizil said: 'A full moon for whom I made the heart Tents (Akhbiyah)... So that its watcher the Howler (Awwa') does not see it / The Sun bestowed upon him the splendor of his beauty... And Gemini (Jawza') gave him the splendor of his mouth.' And as another said: 'I spent the night with the full moon of darkness as my bedfellow... And he was compliant without refusal / So I said to the enviers when... the Sun shone with rays / The Heart and the Glance (Tarf) are his two stations... And he is until now in the Arm (Dhra').' And as another said regarding a beautiful person ploughing: 'O Ploughman (Harith) from whom stations of passion are narrated... regarding his lethal glance, interpreted / He became splitting the graves of those killed by passion... In his ploughing, not neglected lines / My soul is the ransom for a full moon driving... the Bull, not desiring anything but the Ear of Corn (Sunbula).' And names of famous Arabs, as Ibn Sana' al-Mulk said: 'I, despite my preoccupation with passion... was not distracted, and my idleness was not nullified / I am the grandfather of the Prophet's Helpers (Ansar) because I am... O blue-eyed one, the servant of the Ashhal (Abd al-Ashhal).' And as Ibn Qizil said: 'I returned in him to the Jahili... love without transgression / The glance of my eye is Abd Shams... and my heart is Abd Wadd.' And as Shams al-Din Muhammad ibn al-Tilmisani said: 'I was not mad (Majnun) with passion before... a reasoning one (Aqil) was seen for my heart captive in your temples / And if Quss were a describer of a cheek of yours... a plant in it would disable him (Baqil - pun on Baqil the stupid).' And names of cities, names of sects and creeds, names of prosody meters, names of Quran reciters, names of geomancy figures, names of poets, names of Arab stations and places, and things other than that.

Were it not for fear of prolongation, and that I did not produce these papers for this purpose, I would have brought evidence for that. So that you may know, O you who stand upon this book of mine, that Ibn al-Athir, may Allah have mercy on him, did not bring much benefit, nor did the breaths of dawn or the coolness of afternoons become gentle by his speech. And that if his existence had been delayed to this age, he would have known that his saying is not a proof, and that his drop drowns in such an abyss, and that people have reached the destination while he is until now in the darkness of the night. How beautiful is the saying of Mujahid al-Khayyat satirizing Abu al-Husayn al-Jazzar: 'Abu al-Husayn, be polite... Pride in poetry is no pride / While you have not been wet by it... with a drop, while it is a sea / Even if you brought a verse... and your verse has no value / You did not bring the verse except... that there is a monopoly on it for the people.' I have written a book on Tawriya and named it 'Fadd al-Khitam 'an al-Tawriya wa al-Istikhdam' (Breaking the Seal on Double Entendre and Usage). If you want to uncover the essence of that and stand upon its beauties, then examine it; perhaps there will be a cream in it for you, or you will find in it help for what you see. Then he said in a section mentioning fever (Humma): 'For this reason, medicines in its treatment became not medicines, and the days of its slaughter (Nahr) among people became not beginning with days of perfusion (Tarwiyah - day before Arafa).' I say: In the first rhyme, there is no benefit and it is empty speech. As for the second, there is nothing in it except the Tawriya of the Day of Tarwiyah for Nahr, and there is no great matter in that. How beautiful is the saying of Al-Jazzar: 'I am of a people for whom shedding blood... is a habit, and ask about them if you desire my verification / Their courtyards shine with blood in brightness... So all their days are Days of Tashriq.' As for the verses of Al-Mutanabbi regarding fever, no one has the like of them in beauty. Among them: 'And my visitor, as if she has shyness... So she does not visit except in sleep / I offered her robes and mattresses... But she refused them and spent the night in my bones / The skin narrows for my soul and for her... So she expands it with types of sickness / When she leaves me, she washes me... As if we were secluded for a forbidden act / As if the morning drives her away, so her tears flow... in four pouring channels.' Al-Siraj al-Warraq followed his path and said: 'And my visitor, and she has no modesty... She visits in the forenoon and knocks in sleep / She has whoredom and has no abstinence... From the old sheikh nor the boy / When she knocks, I seek refuge in Allah from her... I was consoled from noble women and men / She has heat in my exterior and cold... In my heart, and languor in the bones / Her fire cooks my flesh as food... And she drinks pure wine from my blood / And the sounds of singing for her are my moaning... So she does not cease from this station (Maqam) / She lies with me despite my weakness and gray hair... While mistresses of tents tired me / When she leaves me, she washes me... Because I have reached my death (Hamam).' How beautiful is the saying of Amhadust al-Daylami: 'And a visitor visiting without a watcher... And descending upon the youth without his love / She spends the night inside his entrails... So he seeks afterwards from the greatness of his distress / And prevents him from the delicious life until... She disturbs him in his food and drink / She came to visit me without a promise... And how many a visitor is not welcome.' And the saying of Nasir al-Din Hasan ibn al-Naqib: 'I say to the turn of fever: Leave me... And let there not be a return for you as long as I live / She said: How is it possible to leave this... And does the Prince remain without a turn (music band/turn)?' Mujir al-Din Muhammad ibn Tamim was witty in his saying, when Al-Nur al-Is'irdi had a fever: 'They hid their schadenfreude from me and approached... in the guise of one with a wounded, injured heart / They said that the Light (Al-Nur) has a fever (Humma). So I said: There is no one around the Light (Fire) who is protected (Huma).' Thus are the intentions of literary people and their Tawriyas and descriptions, not as Ibn al-Athir said: 'Medicines in its treatment are not medicines.' People's sayings about the feverish beautiful person are famous, so there is no need to mention them. I had at one time written a letter to some friends complaining of fever. From that: 'He reports, nay complains, of his state for which he has no substitute, and his pains that wounded his limbs so his skin cannot bear cutting that debate (Jadal), and his fever from which a scorpion stings him and a bow shoots him, so would that his body with that were a Ram (Hamal). And the continuity of his sweat's flow regarding which it is not said with its sea: I will seek refuge from beautiful patience to a mountain. So where is their saying: I encountered the sweat of the water-skin from it, compared to one who encountered the drowning of distress from it?'

'When she leaves me, she washes me... As if we were secluded for a forbidden act.' The servant is incapable of describing the headache that happened to his head, and the cracks (Sudu') to his body, and the cutting of his suspended hopes, and his share of the interruptions (Qutu'). Then he said in a section of a letter to the Divan of the Caliphate containing the conquests of a land from the disbelievers: 'And the one traveling with it is So-and-so, and he is the narrator of the news of its victory which she corrected in discrediting (Tajrih) the men, and the high parts of its chain of transmission are taken from the paths of spears (Awali), and the nights and days are narrators for it, so what is the thought regarding the narration of days and nights.' I say: This section with which he ended the letter with which he opposed Al-Qadi Al-Fadil regarding the conquest of Jerusalem. He cited it here as well and claimed this claim in it. It reminded me here of the saying of Mujir al-Din Muhammad ibn Tamim: 'I wonder in war at a knight... the subtleties of my thought were confused about his essence / He gave testimony for me that I am the knight of war... when I wounded (Jarahtu) him in his face.' It is taken from the saying of Ibn al-Sa'ati: 'And how many a time he watered an army the cups of its death... brimming, while the tips of spears (Awali) were stirring sticks / O his sword, you attained uprightness (Adala) against the enemies... And there is no witness but that he has a discrediting (Tajrih) by you.' How sweet is the saying of Al-Qadi Al-Fadil: 'And the servant knew of the riding of our Master Al-Malik Al-Afdal in the center (Qalb). The Sultan was generous to the heart (Qalb) with his heart, and brought it out bare for his war. This position is an explicit text on the Sultanate, and it is an absolute text in which the sword was the judge and victory was the evidence (Bayyina). Islam celebrated a wedding with it, and the scattering was the dinars of the blazes of horses, and the greetings were the basils of the tips of spears. So he is, may Allah strengthen his victory, the preceding in birth and Jihad. His father begot a father, and fathers begot children. Praise be to Allah who aided Islam through him and his sword with Ali and Dhul-Fiqar, and with Omar while in his hand was the sword of Ammar.' What relates to this place are the first two rhymes, but the pen found this melody sweet and said: 'Excused is he who is filled... and drank the cups of wine.' Riddles and Fallacies in Al-Hariri's Maqamat. Then he said in the twenty-first type regarding Riddles (Ahaji): 'Likewise Al-Hariri did in his Maqamat, for he mentioned the riddles which he made according to the rule of Fatwas as metonymy and fallacy, and thought that they are riddles like his saying: Is it permissible for a fasting person to eat during the day?' Then Ibn al-Athir began to deduce that this is from the category of conceptual fallacies. I say: Although I do not know what to say, this man, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, imagines something and binds people to it, and accuses them of its evils while they neither intended nor said it. The Maqamat is a book that became famous, memorized, studied, and not effaced. These issues to which he referred, Al-Hariri, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, deposited in the thirty-second Maqamah. They are one hundred Fatwas, and he listed them arranged according to the chapters of Fiqh. He did not call that a riddle or a puzzle. Rather, he said when mentioning them: 'So a youth, eloquent of tongue, bold of heart, withstood him and said: I debated the jurists of the world, and gathered from them one hundred Fatwas. If you are of those who turn away from daughters of others, and desire provision from us, then listen and answer, to be met with what is incumbent.' He said: 'Allah is Greater, the news will become clear, and the hidden will be revealed, so declare what you are commanded.' He said: 'What do you say regarding one who performed ablution then touched the back of his sandal?' He said: 'His ablution is invalidated by his action.' Until he finished that, and he did not say riddle, puzzle, metonymy, or fallacy. As for the introduction of the book, he said: 'I encrusted it with Arab proverbs, literary subtleties, grammatical riddles, and linguistic fatwas.' He mentioned them in the introduction and in the Maqamah specific to them as Fatwas. Ibn Faris has a book he named 'Fatwas of Language' from which Al-Hariri drew; so what harm is there on Al-Hariri if he calls them Fatwas? The difference between Riddling and Description. Examples of describing ships. He said: On this style came the saying of Abu al-Tayyib regarding ships: 'And he stuffed them (the sea/ships) with runners without legs... barren of bellies, black of bodies / They come with what the horses captured, as if they are... beneath the beauties, the lying places of gazelles.' I say: He counted these as riddles, but they are not of that at all. Rather, they are from the category of descriptions, because a condition of a riddle is that the thing riddled is not mentioned explicitly in the speech. This contradicts that because Abu al-Tayyib said before them: 'Twisting ropes from braids above it... and building ships for him from crosses.' This is explicit. So they are from the category of descriptions, not riddles. Look at the saying of Al-Siraj al-Warraq riddling about a boat: 'And it is not a big thing upon us... and our purpose from it is a small thing / It became one while it is a plural (Jam' - also collection) just as... that illuminating Book came to us.' The first is obvious despite the Tawriya in it. As for the second, the Imams of language have stated that 'Fulk' (ship/ships) is a word in which the singular and plural are equal. I organized a riddle about a ship, saying: 'And a girl (Jariyah - also ship) whose treading is lawful for me... and there was nothing in that to prevent / Oh wonder, she committed no suspicion... yet I compel her to take off (Tuqli' - also set sail).' So Al-Siraj's saying and mine are from the category of riddles, because we did not explicitly mention the word boat or ship. As for Al-Mutanabbi, he explicitly mentioned ships, so he exited this category, and it is from the category of descriptions. Likewise the saying of Mujir al-Din Muhammad ibn Tamim: 'I wondered at the sea when I saw in it... those masts and they exceeded the stars / I think they were only tall because they undertook... carrying letters between the Fulk (ships) and the Falak (orbit/stars).' And his saying also employing implication: 'When we boarded the ship and the sea surged... and its crashing waves raged against us / It walked for us in an abyss with its bellies... just as snakes walk on the ground.' Ibn Qalaqis al-Iskandari is among those who excelled in describing ships in several poems. Among that is his saying mentioning the sea: 'You see the cleavers running in its swelling waves... ascending to its heights and descending / Of every black one like a mole, carried... by a cheek of it in which is shyness for the forenoon.' And his saying also from a poem: 'And I saw the signs (of the Hour) standing in it... because its waves run with mountains / Rising, so were it not for the Book of Allah, it would be true for us... that the heavens have pillars / And we are in a home that travels with its inhabitant... so listen to the tale of a resident whose house is leaving / I refuse, if I spend the night—and from it is in a depiction... of the tightness of a grave and the darkness of a tomb / No side settles for us in its lying place... as if our states are the states of worshippers.' He has things other than these, which I turned away from for fear of prolongation. How sweet is the saying of Abu al-Husayn al-Jazzar: 'I was in a raft (Kalakka) flying with a sail... while it hovers around death at times / I look at the wave around it and imagine the... Jim as a Ta out of my fear, while it is a Jim (Mawj -> Mawt) / I did not find in it a warm friend (Hamim)... except that I am bathed (Hamim) in water in it / And if it approaches the land, there becomes... for us a seat and a place of residence / The cliff prostrates whenever the wave bows... so my habit there is Taslim (submission/greeting).' And it is ugly of me to complain of land... and sea, while you are Beneficent (Barr), Merciful.' Ibn al-Sa'ati said, although there is some awkwardness in it: 'When we reached the middle of the Nile in the morning... I thought, while the heart of the day was joyful with amusement / An Ushari (type of ship) was a human whose eye was the water... and it had no eyelids except the oars.' Al-Qadi Al-Fadil, may Allah have mercy on him, mentioned ships in several places. Among them his saying: 'And the fleet arrived in fifty galleys (Ghurab - crow), flying with sails as its wings, breaking with the claws of its weapons. It did not visit a gathering but invited it to death, and realized what it incites of separation.' And his saying: 'It fills them against them with runners (Jawar) in the sea like landmarks (mountains), and cities traveling in the abyss as if they were nights taking off with days. They rise upon the assembly of Islam as hopes, and rise upon the disbelievers as dooms. Marked, extended by marked angels. And known, presenting their bows (Hayazim) like the advance of Hayzum (Gabriel's horse) under the bundle.' He said: Better and more delicate than that is the saying of some of them regarding the Anklet (Khalkhal): 'And a beaten one without a crime... beautiful of color, loved / It has the shape of the crescent upon... a beautiful figure, slender / And mostly it is seen forever... upon the combs (feet) in the market (legs/market).' I say: Thus I found it in the copy of Al-Mathal, and I stood upon it also in the book: 'Al-I'jaz fi al-Ahaji wa al-Ilgaz' by Al-Haziri in this form. It is better to say in it: 'It has the likeness of the crescent' or 'the shape of the crescent' or 'the collar of the crescent'. For 'the figure (Qadd) of the crescent' is not appropriate. But this is from his saying previously regarding the apple and the greatness of its figure. I said, riddling about the Anklet: 'What yellow one circulated upon a white one... it softened but its heart is hard / Many a leg (Saq) choked on it, and how... beautiful is this description among people.' I also said about it: 'Oh wonder at a patient, silent one, and it did not... utter a word ever at the time of beating / It stayed and did not leave a place where it settled... although it became revolving around the ankle (Ka'b).' And since a thing is mentioned by a thing, how sweet is the saying of the one riddling about a Bracelet (Dumluj): 'To women it seeks refuge... and with them it is found / Its body is silver... and its heart is rock.' Discussion by Al-Safadi of Ibn al-Athir regarding his comment on a riddle about a Bathhouse.

'It became one while it was a plural (collection), just as... that illuminating Book came to us.' As for the first, it is apparent based on the tawriya (double entendre) within it. As for the second, the Imams of language have stated that the word 'Fulk' (ship/ships) is a term used equally for singular and plural. I composed a riddle about a ship, saying: 'And a girl (Jariya) whom it is lawful for me to tread... and there was nothing in that to prevent. Oh wonder, she committed no suspicion... yet I compel her to take off (tuqli' - also means to set sail).' The saying of Al-Siraj and my saying are from the category of riddles, because we did not explicitly mention the word 'Markab' (vehicle/ship) or 'Safina'. As for Al-Mutanabbi, he explicitly mentioned 'Safin' (ships), so he exited this category, and it is from the category of descriptions. Likewise is the saying of Mujir al-Din Muhammad ibn Tamim: 'I marveled at the sea when I saw in it... those masts surpassing the celestial tracks. I think they did not grow tall except because they undertook... carrying letters between the spheres (Falak) and the ships (Fulk).' And his saying, also embedding: 'And when we rode the ships (Fulk) and the sea had surged... and its crashing waves raged against us; It walked with us in an abyss on its bellies... just as vipers walk upon the ground.' Ibn Qalaqis al-Iskandari is among those who excelled in describing ships in several poems. From that is his saying describing the sea: 'You see the prows running in its swelling waves... ascending to its heights and descending. From every black one like a beauty mark, carried by... a cheek of it (the sea) in which there is bashfulness toward the morning.' And his saying also from a poem: 'I saw signs in it standing... because its waves run with mountains (ships). Rising high, were it not for the Book of Allah, it would be true for us... that the heavens have pillars. And we are in a dwelling that travels with its inhabitant... so listen to the tale of a resident whose house is a traveler. I spend the night, if I spend it—and from it is in a pictorial form... of the narrowness of a grave and the darkness of burial. No side settles for us in its bed... as if our states are the states of worshippers.' He has other things besides this, which I omitted for fear of length. How sweet is the saying of Abu al-Husayn al-Jazzar: 'I was in a Kalakka (type of ship) flying with a sail... while it hovers over deaths at times. I look at the waves around it and imagine the... Jim as a Ta due to my fear, while it is a Jim (referring to 'Mawj' - wave vs 'Mawt' - death). I did not find in it a warm friend (Hamim)... except that I am bathed (Hamim) in water within it. And when it approached the land, there became... for us from it a seat and a resident. The cliff prostrates whenever the wave bows... so my habit there is Taslim (submission/salutation).' And: 'It is ugly for me to complain of land... and sea, while You are a Merciful Benefactor (Barr Rahim).' Ibn al-Sa'ati said, although there is some awkwardness in it: 'And when we reached the middle of the Nile's extent in the morning... I thought, while the heart of the day was joyful with play, An Ushari (boat) was a human whose eye was the water... and it had no eyelids except the oars.' Al-Qadi Al-Fadil, may Allah have mercy on him, mentioned ships in several places. Among them is his saying: 'The fleet arrived in fifty galleys (Ghurab - also means crow/raven), flying with sails as its wings, breaking with the claws of its weapons; it never visited a gathering without inviting it to doom, and realizing what separation (Bayn - also associated with the raven) incites.' And his saying: 'Girls (ships) fill it against them in the sea like mountains, and cities traveling in the abyss as if they are nights setting sail with days. They rise upon us, the assembly of Islam, as hopes, and rise upon the disbelievers as deadlines of death; marked, extended by marked angels, and distinct, their sterns advancing with the advance of Hayzum (Gabriel's horse) under the tightness.' He said: Better and more subtle than that is the saying of someone regarding an anklet (Khalkhal): 'And a hammered one without a crime... beautiful in color, beloved. It has the figure of the crescent upon... a beautiful figure, slender. And mostly it is seen forever... upon the combs (bridges of feet) in the market (legs - Suq).' I say: This is how I found it in the copy of 'Al-Mathal', and I also found it in the book 'Al-I'jaz fi al-Ahaji wa al-Ilghaz' by Al-Haziri in this form. It is better to say in it: 'It has the resemblance of the crescent' or 'the shape of the crescent' or 'the collar of the crescent.' For 'the figure (Qadd) of the crescent' is not suitable. But this is from his saying previously regarding the apple 'and the greatness of its figure (Qadd).' I composed a riddle about the anklet: 'What is a yellow one that turned upon a white one... it softened but its heart is hard. Many a leg (Saq) choked from it, and how... beautiful is this description among people.' And I also said about it: 'Oh wonder at a patient silent one, and it did not... utter a word ever at the hour of striking.

It stayed and did not leave a place it resided in... except that it became revolving around the Kaaba (the ankle bone - Ka'b).' Since one thing is mentioned by another, how sweet is the saying of the poet creating a riddle about a bracelet (Dumlij): 'It seeks refuge with women... and with them, it is found. Its body is silver... and its heart is rock (Jalamid).' Al-Safadi's Discussion with Ibn al-Athir regarding his comment on a riddle about a pigeon. He said: I found a riddle by some literati about a pigeon. Then he mentioned it and said after finishing it: 'This is among the eloquent riddles, and it cannot be said of its author that he is, in blindness, losing the cane.' I say: The second rhymed phrase is not suitable for the first in praise and eulogy. The rhyme only wanted him to say after it: 'Nor is he counted among the animals as a beast,' because it (the pigeon/author) was unique in speech and distinguished. I have never seen anyone praise someone with such praise where the context is one of approval, commendation, and praise, by saying: 'He is not, in blindness, losing the cane.' What praise is there in this when he has made him blind with a cane? He is in a worse state than the blind man who walks without a cane. For he who relies on his cane with his blindness has combined blindness of insight with blindness of sight. It appears he wanted to mention the blind poet (Al-Ma'arri or similar), but it did not work out, and he was committed to the letter 'Zay', so he found nothing but 'Al-'Ukkaz' (the cane). The end of this rhyme is the second hemistich of a verse by Abu al-Tayyib (Al-Mutanabbi), which is: 'And he thinks that he is the sighted one regarding this... while he is, in blindness, losing the cane.' From their sayings regarding the Bathhouse (Hammam). Since the bathhouse is mentioned, there is no harm in mentioning some of the words of the later scholars in this locus and citing them. Judge Muhyi al-Din Abdallah ibn Abd al-Zahir, may Allah the Exalted have mercy on him, wrote inviting to a bathhouse: 'Would you, may Allah prolong your survival a prolongation that sips from the spring of bliss, and enjoys happiness the enjoyment of flowers with the spring rain and sight with the handsome face, [join] in sharing in combining a garden and a fire, storms and lights, flowers and blossoms, wherein reserve and all shame have vanished, and there is no shame. The stars of its sky are not afflicted by setting, and the plants of its marble are not altered by withering. The elements competed to serve the state within it, a competition in which each excelled in reaching its goals. The sea sent what its body envied of its foam to kiss the hand of his sole, since its ambition fell short of kissing his hand. The dirt did not see an entry for itself in this service, so it intruded and came, not knowing that scrubbing (Tasrih - also dismissal) is for the one who comes intruding. The fire saw that it was the essence of its operation and that by the duty of serving him it does not slacken, and because it has the sanctity of guiding the guest in the night travel, and by it is the repulsion of cold and the benefit of hospitality; so it informed its opposite, the water, and it entered with hot breaths. Its cauldrons boiled, and for that reason, the whisper of the sound of its pouring entered it. The air saw that it fell short of prolonging this competition, so it held back in awe, looking but from behind a glass at that house. Then the trees saw that they had no share in this favor nor a portion in that privacy, so they sent from combs palms that excelled in what the hair-partings call for, and passed through the blackness of the coal-black sideburns just as lightning passes. That is at the hand of a keeper (Qayyim) who stands up for the rights of service, knowing how the people of bliss treat the people of grace, light of hand with trustworthiness, described with dignity among the people of that profession (Mahana), gentle in manners as if they are a reproof between Jahza and Time, and of good craftsmanship so he does not touch a hand except with kindness (Ma'ruf) nor comb except with charity (Ihsan). He is always seen with his purity while he is boastful, and is witnessed removing every harm so that if he served the full moon, he would remove the blemishes from its face. In his hand is a razor as if it were a morning abrogating darkness, or a breeze shaking the calyxes off flowers. When he takes his soap, he makes the one he serves understand, by passing it over his body, that he is a crashing sea, and that the foam of the skin-folds appears from it, which is more beautiful than waves. So come to this pleasure, and do not consider the bathhouse an invitation of the riffraff, for perhaps this one is unique among those invitations.' He also wrote in the presence of a keeper in the Sufah bathhouse:

The poor servant to Allah the Exalted, Abdallah ibn Abd al-Zahir, says that Abu al-Hajjaj Yusuf has ceased not to be a destination for the righteous, and he possesses a quality of craftsmanship by which he deserved to be called a Keeper (Qayyim). How many a body has he graced with a favor, and how many users approached him whose faces were recognized with the radiance of bliss. How often did he strip down with a righteous sheikh in seclusion, and how often did the friend of Allah say 'Good news' (Ya Bushra) because he is Joseph (Yusuf) when he lowered his bucket into the well. How many a human from the scholars and righteous has he served, and how much of their blessing has he stored for a world and an afterlife, thus obtaining from each of them two intercessors: one clothed and one naked. How many human skins thanked him, and how many legs of a righteous man rubbed [against him], so it was verified there that happiness indeed glances at the stone. He has distinguished his family and tribe by the service of the virtuous, and he is thanked for what others are criticized for: the length of the wick (Fatila - also means lint roll from scrubbing). How often did he conclude the washing of a man by giving him his exemption (Bara'a - purity/release) to use, and he exits from a hot bath; so he used it and exited, and it was for him an exemption and a freedom from the Fire. How many a hair-parting did he clarify, and how much grime did he wash away with gray hair, so that which cleaned did not leave [any dirt]. Bodies enjoy his perfuming of his bathhouse with extended shade and poured water, and the abundance of water he brings out almost makes it tube upon tube like a spear. How many clear proofs of heat regarding the increase of water by which ambiguity is removed, and how many ripples curled appearing like lines in every basin, so say: 'This is the Book of Purity, Chapter of Waters.' How many a head did his razor recite to when it brought out greenery from the succession of growth: 'If I had a tongue in every hair follicle spreading thanks, I would [still] be negligent.' I say: It is not hidden what is in this speech of Tawriya (double entendre), Istikhdam (using a word with two meanings), resolving verses, Hadith, and others; and were it not for the fear of elongation, I would have mentioned that. How beautiful is the saying of Al-Nasir Al-Hammami (the bathhouse keeper) and how subtle: 'I have a house whose kindness... pours down as rain like clouds. I accept the one with an excuse in it... and honor the neighbor who is Junub (ritually impure/distant).' And his saying also: 'And you muddied my bathhouse with your absence which... muddies every drinking place of its pleasures. So the chest of the basin was not expanded (happy) by it... nor was the heart of the water in it pleasant.' And he wrote inviting to his bathhouse: 'It is my opinion that you join a seclusion... that has a burning liver and flowing eyes. It observes stars in you from the heat of its heart... and weeps with my tears, happy and sad. Its heart became fond of you, and if you... delay, it becomes in the basins of death (Manun).' People have beautiful things in the praise and dispraise of bathhouses which is not the place to mention for fear of length. Examples of Good Riddles and Discussion on the Difference between Riddle and Allusion. He said: Among the good riddles I heard that occur in dialogues is what is told about Umar ibn Hubayra and Sharik al-Numayri. Umar was traveling on a draft horse of his, and at his side was Sharik al-Numayri. Sharik preceded him in the march, so Umar shouted at him: 'Lower (Ighdid) its bridle.' He said: 'May Allah amend the Amir, she is Maktuba (written/bound).' Umar smiled and then said to him: 'Woe to you, I did not mean this.' Sharik said to him: 'Nor did I mean it.' Umar had intended the saying of Jarir: 'So lower (Faghdid) the glance, for you are from Numayr... so you reached neither Ka'b nor Kilab.' Sharik answered him with the saying of the other: 'Do not feel safe from a Fazari you are alone with... upon your young camel, and write (bound) her with straps (Asyar).' The Difference between Riddle (Lughz) and Allusion (Ta'rid). I say: This and its likes are not riddles at all. For a riddle is to mention a thing with descriptions that others share with it, so the mind returns in that to confusion, not knowing where to direct it to which of the two possesses those descriptions, because they are true from one aspect and false from another. Its derivation is from 'Lughayza', which is a hole the jerboa digs under the earth, making it branched right and left to hide its matter from the one who seeks it; if he seeks it in one, it exits from another. Do you not see that the listener, when he hears the saying of the speaker: 'A girl (Jariya - also ship) who came from India... the journey urges her toward the destination. She has daughters not of her species... in their sharpness, they exceeded the limit. They have horns and she has a hoof... and that is among the strangest things I show. And the most amazing thing is her children... they speak to people in the cradle.'

He begins to say to himself: In the first verse, 'A girl came from India urged by marching,' there is nothing in that. When he hears the second: 'She has daughters not of her species,' he returns to confusion and thinks and says: 'How can they be of a species other than their mother?' When he hears the third: 'They have horns and she has a hoof,' his confusion increases and he says: 'Neither these nor their mother are humans.' When he hears the fourth: 'They speak to people in the cradle,' his confusion is confirmed, then he returns to thinking they are humans because of affirming the cradle and speech, and begins working his mind on an existent described by these qualities. If he is exhausted, he leans towards homonyms, and lands by the power of his thought and correctness of his intuition that it applies only to the Inkstand (Dast) of the writer and his pens (feathers). How sweet is the poet's use of marching, hoof, and speaking. Such is the riddle. The story of Tha'lab, may Allah have mercy on him, is famous with the Bedouin who stood over him and recited a riddle verse by verse. Tha'lab would say: 'This is such-and-such,' then shift in the second to something other than the first interpretation, until when the Bedouin finished his recitation, Tha'lab said: 'This is a pen.' If this is established in the riddle, then what Ibn al-Athir cited is not riddles, but rather from the category of Allusion (Ta'rid) and Signal (Ishara), as if the speaker with such implies to the addressee what was said and points him to an event that occurred. I have not seen anyone count such as a riddle other than Ibn al-Athir, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, although he said in Al-Mathal regarding Metonymy and Allusion: 'It was named Ta'rid (Allusion) because the meaning in it is understood from the side (Ard) of the utterance, meaning from its side; and the Ard of everything is its side.' I say: Likewise the incident of Umar and Sharik; each of them understood his companion's intent from the side of his speech. For 'lowering' is a side of the poet's saying: 'So lower the gaze...' the verse. And likewise 'writing' is a side of his saying: 'And write it with straps.' So it is determined that Allusion is different from Riddle. This Sharik was a man of sharp answers. It is said: The people of Kufa, if one of them wished for something, would say: 'I wish I had the Fiqh of Abu Hanifa, the memorization of Sufyan, the piety of Mis'ar ibn Kidam, and the answer of Sharik.' Similar to the story of Umar and Sharik is what the author of Al-Aghani mentioned. He said: Mu'awiya displayed his horses to Abd al-Rahman ibn al-Hakam. A horse passed by him, so he said: 'How do you see it?' He said: 'This is a swimmer (Sabih).' Then another was displayed to him. He said: 'And this is possessor of repeated run (Dhu 'Ulala).' Then another passed by him, so he said: 'And this is hoarse, neighing (Ajash Hazim).' Mu'awiya said to him: 'Are you using allusion against me?! I knew what you intended.
