You only alluded to the saying of Al-Najashi: And a swimmer, possessor of repeated run saved Ibn Harb... Hoarse, neighing, while the spears were near. Get out, for you will not dwell with me in a city.' Look at the speech of Mu'awiya, may Allah be pleased with him, how he explicitly used the word Allusion in two places. Literary scholars have cited a group of this category in their books. As for Abu Abdullah Muhammad ibn al-Sayyid al-Batalyusi, he cited this incident of Sharik and Umar ibn Hubayra in the commentary on Adab al-Katib, then said after finishing it: 'Ibn Hubayra alluded to him with the saying of Jarir, and Sharik alluded to him with the saying of Salim ibn Dara.' He cited examples of this incident, and in all of them he says: 'Alluded.' This is explicit from such a man, and he is an Imam in what he says and his saying is a proof. How beautiful is the saying of the one who said, and how delicate: 'Pour me a wine like the thinness of my religion... or like my mind, and I do not say like my state / Fearful of people imagining that I... said this as an allusion (Ma'rad) to begging.' Among allusion is the saying of Al-Siraj al-Warraq alluding to a request for soap: 'I sent the letter to you and my walking was little... on my head to your door with the letter / And my excuse to you for the delay is that I... the inkstand spilled on my clothes.' I copied from the handwriting of Al-Siraj al-Warraq, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, what reads: 'Abu al-Husayn the Grammarian used to sit at a drink-seller's. One day he came and found a rose-water bottle (Qumqum) in his place. The seller said to him: O our master, we will remove the bottle and you sit. He said to him: How, when you commanded me to stand twice by your saying: Qumqum (Stand Stand)?! It happened that someone gifted me a bottle, so I recited to him: If that one said: Stand Stand (Qum Qum), driving away... his sitter with a signal in the bottle (Qumqum) / Then I am the one whose luck made time sit... so it brought that to him and called: Stand Stand.' Principles and Openings. He said in the twenty-second type regarding Principles and Openings:

'Among the skill in this chapter is to make the prayer at the beginning of Sultani and fraternal correspondences and others imply the meaning upon which that letter is built. This is something I was unique in inventing, and you see it often in what I composed.' Then he said: 'Among that is what I mentioned in congratulating on a newborn, which is: May Allah renew the joys of the So-and-so Assembly, and send the morning drink of its happiness with its evening drink, and make him enjoy his scion (Salil) who is heralded by his rising (Turuq), and preserve him until he seeks light by his opinion and shoots from me over him (referring to arrow), and gladden the virgins of high qualities with him until he perfumes their sides with his perfume (Khuluq), and make him like a crop that brought forth its shoot, then strengthened it, so it became thick and stood upon its stem (Suq).' I say: This is after he criticized Al-Sabi and a group of poets regarding openings, and claimed this claim, then came with such an opening in congratulating on a newborn. There is nothing in the first rhyme indicating that the congratulation is for a newborn, circumcision, wedding, conquest, Eid, recovery from illness, or other types of joys; it indicated absolute congratulation. As for his saying: 'and gladden the virgins of high qualities with him until he perfumes their sides with his perfume,' I do not know what rhetoric is in this. I wrote in congratulating on a newborn: 'And he adorned the horizon of happiness with his star which became rising, and made him reach in his youth the highest prides until he is, before puberty, reaching the goals of high qualities, and occupied sovereignty with him, for its heart was empty except of this house.' I also wrote: 'And He preserved for the forest of kingdoms its cub, and made him a vanguard of glad tidings for what is after him just as he came as a rearguard of good for what was before him, and qualified him to be an Imam in front of the ranks of war, just as He made his face a collector for beauty and his hand a Qibla for the kiss.' I also wrote: 'And He cooled his eye with this joy (Qurrah), and made him reach the ends of his hopes in him of fortunes, for they are interpreted in this margin (Turrah), and made the afternoon the saffron of this perfume (Khuluq) and the twilight the carnelian/aqiqa sacrifice of this pearl (Durrah).' I wrote a reply to a letter that arrived accompanied by details of embroidered cloth. I said: 'The hand kisses the extended one (Basita), may the sentences of its generosity not cease to be thanked in details (Tafasil), and the masterpieces of its embroidered kindness perform for its friend what he wills of niches and images (Tamathil), and the engravings of its gifts shoot the souls of enemies with destruction from their flocks of birds (Ababil).' Regarding congratulating on a child. Among what came in the speech of Al-Qadi Al-Fadil, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him: 'And this blessed child is the one completing twelve children, nay twelve burning stars. Allah has increased him in his stars over the stars of Joseph by a star. The Master saw them while awake and he saw that in a dream. He saw them prostrating to him and we saw creation prostrating to them. He is capable of increasing the boundaries of the Master until he sees them as a father and grandfathers.' From his speech also: 'It is announced that Allah, and to Him belongs praise, granted Al-Malik Al-Aziz, may his victory be glorified, a blessed, high, male, sound, pure, pious child, from offspring some of whom is from others, and from a house whose kings almost became angels in heaven and whose slaves became kings on earth, at the beginning of the crescent of Jumada. So for this night are two blazes and two crescents, heralding heavy rains, truthful.' 'The servant issued this service heralding that Allah Almighty does not leave our Master at any time without an increase of children He grants, or an increase of lands he conquers. So he is every day given glad tidings of what is facilitated for him. The orbit runs with what we hope for him and is fixed for him. Its stars rise upon him star by star, and its clouds pour upon him shower by shower. It has been narrated in the tradition that the child is the basil of Paradise; so noble houses based on this are gardens, and righteous children based on this are basils. May our garden not be effaced, nor our basil wither, and may the grandfather of the sons of our Master, who is their grandfather and their father and our Sultan, be high.' Ibn al-Athir claimed that he was the one unique in the appropriateness of openings, while this is what most people have always observed. Ibn Khalaf stated that in 'Al-Manthur al-Baha'i', saying: 'Among that is the opening of a letter to the Divan of the Caliphate,' and he listed the introduction of the letter, and at its end: 'And the letter and its gift might be expressed as the cloud and its downpour. If it issued from a hand like the hand of the Noble Divan, the simile has fallen in the place of correctness, and the saying of the sayer became true then, that the sea is the element of the cloud.' I say: This is not verification at all. Whoever claims that the cloud comes from the sea has no knowledge of the reality of that. How can it be when the sea is salty and bitter, and the drops sent down from clouds are sweet and fresh? It was interpreted in His Almighty's saying: 'And in the heaven is your provision and what you are promised' that it is the clouds that rain. If it were as he claimed, He would have said: 'And in the sea is your provision.' Allah Almighty said: 'Allah is the one who sends the winds, so they stir up clouds,' making the cause of the cloud's origin the sending of winds, and He did not mention the sea. How beautiful is the saying of Ibn Zaydun: 'To the intercessor belongs praise and thanks in the downpour... of rain, to the winds not to the clouds'

[This is] a reference to the meaning of the noble Verse. Even if a transmission trusted for its truthfulness came regarding that, it is returned via interpretation to this. Abu al-Ala al-Ma'arri said: 'And the bounty of the clouds may be begged for, while... it is from the sea, as people claim, that we beg.' He guarded himself by saying: 'as people claim.' Meaning: in the apparent. Even if the matter in the hidden is contrary to that. How beautiful is the saying of Al-Husayn ibn Mutayr describing rain: 'If its water were from the depths of the coasts... no water would remain in the depths of the coasts.' Perhaps some ignorant people might dispute and say: 'Clouds are from the sea, but the winds shorten (condense) it so it becomes sweet.' Similar to this is the saying of Al-Tihami: 'Like the sea, the clouds rain it, and they have... no merit over it because they are from its water.' What is appropriate for this place is nothing other than pointing out that rain is not from the [salt] sea [directly], and that the sea is not the element of clouds. Other than that can be taken from the books of this art in the Natural Sciences (Tabi'iyyat). How sweet is the saying of Al-Qadi Al-Fadil, may Allah the Exalted have mercy on him: 'His letter arrived and the spring and its time had passed, and its roses had returned and dismantled its watering place. So its lines substituted and excelled in substitution, and people knew the kinship between him and the spring, nay the brotherhood, for their mother is the cloud.' He said: Among the letters referred to is the opening of a letter I wrote to some brothers, and I sent it to him from Mosul. Then he mentioned the letter. When he finished it, he exclaimed 'Bakh Bakh' (Bravo) to himself and praised it, and cited other letters regarding the praise of incoming correspondence. Among them is some beauty of beneficence; but if you compared them to the speech of Al-Fadil, you would say: 'A youth, but not like Malik; and a pasture, but not like the Sa'dan.' From the Beauties is opening the Letter with a Verse or Hadith or a Line of Poetry. He said: Among the beauties of this art is that the letter is opened with a verse from the signs of the Quran, or a report from the Prophetic reports, or a line of poetry, then the letter is built upon it. From that is what I wrote in the beginning of a letter containing the good news of a conquest, which is: 'And whoever seeks the glorious conquest, then... its keys are the white, light, sharp swords.' We have taken the saying of this wise poet, and made the sword a means to producing sterile (unprecedented) kingship. I say: Among the beauties I found of this type is a letter written by Judge Muhyi al-Din ibn Abd al-Zahir, may Allah the Exalted have mercy on him, in reply to Amir Shams al-Din Aqsunqur, regarding a letter that arrived from him about the conquest of the lands of Nubia. He opened it after the Basmala with the Almighty's saying: 'And We made the night and the day two signs, then We erased the sign of the night and made the sign of the day visible.' 'May Allah perpetuate the grace of the Council (Al-Majlis), and may his determinations remain feared, and his spoils brought and driven, and his power and these steps of his restrain misfortunes (Nuwab) and the Nubians (Nuba). May his tread upon the disbelievers remain severe, and his hopes for destroying the enemies remain extended like his spears, and may the state never lack the white blades of his swords by which "you see those who lied against Allah, their faces blackened."' This correspondence was issued to the Council praising his determinations which complied with every right command, and finished off every stubborn tyrant, and judged with the justice of the sword regarding every bad servant—'And your Lord is not unjust to the servants.' Where it thanked the short-haired horses and praised the camels. The day of victory resembled its yesterday due to the substitution of weak letters (grammar metaphor), so the raid on the church of Sawsan became like the raid of Sis. And we inform him that we knew the bounty of Allah in purifying the lands from their filth, removing the stubbornness, cauterizing the material of their majority—the disbeliever—when he had almost plotted and plotted, and hastening the Festival of Sacrifice (Eid al-Nahr) by sacrificing every ram of war that kneels in blackness, looks in blackness, and walks in blackness. We have verified the victory that healed souls and removed misery, and erased the sign of the night with the best of suns, and destroyed Dongola for the crime of Saws (weevils/decay), and how can something not be destroyed when there is Saws in it.

'So praise be to Allah that the resolves of the Seat greeted them in the morning with woe, and that He inserted the day of the sword from them into the night, and that He turned the war of their spears back to their throats, and made their destruction in their planning, and distinguished the white line of the sword from the black thread of the dawn of their immorality. He informed the present mind of the Seat about the unseen matters of victory, and made the believing Solomon of the time inherit the kingdom of the disbelieving David. He coupled victory with the most rising resolve of the Seat, and destroyed the black enemy with the auspicious white bird of victory—and how not, when Aqsunqur is the White Bird (Falcon). He cooled every eye for the people of Upper Egypt, and gathered their unity so they do not see after it the Crow of Separation (Ghurab Bayn) from their enemy. He granted victory to the owners of swords over the owners of spears (Harab), and facilitated the hunting of their king at the hand of the Seat—and how can hunting the Crow be difficult for the Falcon (Sunqur)? Thanks be to Allah for humiliating their king who softened and weakened, and He humiliated him with His might which the evil of each of them declared in fighting him, so he ended up naked. And perishing them with tongues whose stabbing became like the mouth of the waterskin when the waterskin is full. And crushing their napes with the sword which Allah made the non-Arab bird speak with its omen, saying: Daqq Qafa al-Sudan (Crush the nape of the blacks). May Allah preserve the Jihad of the Seat which straightened this bent accident. Islam did not lack in this affair a sword that stood as a preacher (Khatib)—and how not, when He dressed it in black (Abbasi color/ink) from them. And thanked him for his resolve with which the frowning face of time rejoiced, and the lands of the North realized the welfare of the lands of the South through it. The arrows of spoils became aimed in every direction through it, and the backs of conquests are ridden, so at times the sword rides every Sis and at times every Adham (black horse/fetter). And praised his bravery against whose shock the great multitude (Sawad A'zam) did not stand. To Allah is the favor that He made the quarters of the enemy harvested by the resolves of the Seat as if they had not flourished yesterday, and established the duties of Jihad with his sharpened swords and his five fingertips. He coupled his firmness with delivering the stab to the throats of enemies, and the time of sacrifice (Nahr) is the measure of a spear from the rising of the sun. We hope from the generosity of Allah to catch the sought David and return him to the sword with the defect of his flight; and the bad slave, if he flees, is returned inevitably with the defect of flight. Allah thanks the details of the Seat's letters and their summaries, the last of his raids and the first, the combat of his sharp swords and their lodging. And may He make him, when the day of his sword withdraws from the night of this enemy, return safe to his resting place, and the sun runs to a resting place for it.' I recorded this letter in its entirety because of the delightful witticisms and strange Tawriyas in it. Judge Muhyi al-Din, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, has two verses on this incident, and it is said they belong to Ibn al-Naqib. They are: 'O day of Dongola and the killing of its slaves... in every side and every place / From every Nubian saying to his mother... Wail (Nuhi), for they have crushed the nape of the blacks (Daqqu Qafa al-Sudan).' On Transition (Takhallus) and Improvisation (Iqtidab). He said in the twenty-third type regarding Transition and Improvisation, and cited the saying of Abu Tammam from a set of verses: 'No, by the One who knows that distance is... a term (Ajal) and that Abu al-Husayn is generous.' Then he said: This is an exit from Ghazal to praise. I say: What is famous in this verse is that Abu Tammam said it: 'No, by the One who knows that distance is... patience (Sabr)...' I have not seen anyone cite it like that (Ajal), nor have I found it in a Diwan despite the many copies except as I mentioned (Sabr). As for the masters of rhetoric, they mentioned the verse and counted it among the defects, because there is no relevance between patience and generosity. If it were said: 'Time is miserly and Abu al-Husayn is generous,' or he says 'Distance is patience and connection is honey,' it would be appropriate. No one mentioned it to my knowledge except counting it as a defect, and this one counted it among the beauties and changed its wording. Justice is other than this; would that he corrected it when he changed it. There is no harm in citing a portion of what came for poets in this genre. Among that is the saying of Al-Ma'arri Abu al-Ala mentioning she-camels: 'They asked, so I said our destination is Sa'id... So the name of the Emir was a good omen for them.' And the saying of Muslim ibn al-Walid: 'My companions say, while they strove in haste... and horses pulled at the bridles with the riders / Is it the rising place of the sun you intend to take us to? ... I said: No, but the rising place of generosity.' Abu Tammam took it, a taking and a slicing, saying: 'Is it the rising place of the sun you intend to take us to? ... I said: No, but the rising place of bounty.' Al-Ghazzi also took it, and molded it confusedly when he said: 'She says when we urged them and she remained... whispering to us with tongues of fatigue / Is it to the horizon of the crescent my riders travel? ... We said: No, but to the horizon of giving.' And the saying of Ali ibn al-Jahm: 'And a night whose eye was kohl-ed with ink... threw the veil of darkness into every trench.'

'Its waves of darkness almost drown me... Were it not for my borrowing light from the face of Dawud.' And the saying of the leader Abu Abdullah al-Sanbasi praising Sayf al-Dawla Sadaqa ibn Mansur: 'And a wet narcissus whose eyes resemble... pupils of gold on eyelids of camphor / As if its scent in every morning... is musk diffusing or the mention of Ibn Mansur.' And the saying of Ibn Sana' al-Mulk: 'The yearning lover does not turn back from passion... Or Al-Malik Al-Aziz turns back from generosity.' And his saying also: 'So the passion is for me alone without creation... And the kingdom belongs to Allah and to Al-Zahir.' And the saying of Ibn al-Sa'ati: 'My passion, even if I am the humble one by his whites (swords)... Al-Aziz found it with every brown flexible spear.' And his saying also: 'How often we stood in it with the rain like two likes... we were weeping eyelids and a cloud / The blades of lightning thickened it with wounds... gushing, flowing upon it as heaps / As if the cloud is dust of war in which Al-Malik Al-Mu'izz... has drawn a sword.' And better than all this is the saying of Sheikh Sharaf al-Din Abdul Aziz, Sheikh of the Sheikhs in Hama, from a ghazal poem praising the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: 'Whoever saw that fasting sash (belt)... prayed upon Muhammad.' And the saying of Abu al-Husayn al-Jazzar praising Jamal al-Din Musa bin Yaghmur: 'I dared to kiss the anemone on her cheek... and sip saliva I am still drunk from / And I do not fear the magic of her glances... because through Musa (Moses) I have become safe from magic.' And his saying also praising Fakhr al-Qudah Nasrallah bin Basaqa: 'How many a night I spent in difficulty while I had... in the adornment of my hopes treasures of ease / I say to my heart whenever I longed for wealth... When the Help of Allah (Nasrallah) comes, may the hand of poverty perish (Tabbat).' Regarding the Transition (Mukhallis), how sweet is the saying of Al-Siraj al-Warraq: 'If my chest is light for rhymes and organizing them... Then in grace and the shade of generosity, I am restricted / And how many a beginning (Matla') I composed for a poem... Jesus says to me: Or perhaps there is a way out (Mukhallis) for you.' And it was witty of one who dispraised the transition in one verse where he said: 'While locks of hair of the one he loves were in his palm... until the beard of the praised one got stuck.' Transition in the Holy Quran. He said: And Abu al-Ala Muhammad bin Ghanim, known as Al-Ghanimi, said: The Book of Allah is free from Takhallus (poetic transition). It is only the exit from one speech to another speech via a subtlety that harmonizes the two speeches, the one exited from and the one entered into. Regarding examples of that which Ibn al-Athir cited from the Holy Quran. Then Ibn al-Athir said: And in the Quran are many places. Among them: And he began citing what he cited. Like His Almighty's saying: 'And recite to them the news of Abraham, when he said to his father and his people: What do you worship?...' to the end of the story, and other than that. I say: What Ibn al-Athir mentioned does not go beyond what Al-Ghanimi said; for the Quran is all connected to one another, such as exiting from preaching and reminding to warning, or to glad tidings, or to a command, or prohibition, or promise, or threat, except for what its connection is hidden in appearance. Imam Fakhr al-Din observed this in his exegesis and spoke about the relationship of the verse to what follows it. Ibn al-Athir did not understand Al-Ghanimi's speech nor know his intent, which is that he meant the Takhallus that poets agreed upon, which is for the poet to transition within a single verse from ghazal or blame or description to praise. Such a thing I do not know to have occurred in a single verse (of Quran). As for the connection of a verse to what precedes it, only a little deviates from this, and that is in appearance; otherwise, when a person contemplates it and reflects on it with true reflection, he will not find it cut off except in what is known to be improvisation (Iqtidab). Models of Transition in Ibn al-Athir's composition. He said: Something of transitions came to me in prose composition in many things. Among that is what I mentioned in a letter to some brothers describing spring, then I exited from that to mentioning longings. So I said: 'Just as these descriptions are beautiful in their affair, so too is my longing beautiful in its affair, except that its meter (sea) is a summer season and this is a spring season.'

'Its waves of darkness almost drown me... were it not for my borrowing light from the face of Dawud.' And the saying of the leader Abu Abdullah al-Sanbasi praising Sayf al-Dawla Sadaqa ibn Mansur: 'And a wet narcissus whose eyes resemble... pupils of gold on eyelids of camphor / As if its scent in every morning... is musk diffusing or the mention of Ibn Mansur.' And the saying of Ibn Sana' al-Mulk: 'The yearning lover does not turn back from passion... Or Al-Malik Al-Aziz turns back from generosity.' And his saying also: 'So the passion is for me alone without creation... And the kingdom belongs to Allah and to Al-Zahir.' And the saying of Ibn al-Sa'ati: 'My passion, even if I am the humble one by his whites (swords)... Al-Aziz found it with every brown flexible spear.' And his saying also: 'How often we stood in it with the rain like two likes... we were weeping eyelids and a cloud / The blades of lightning thickened it with wounds... gushing, flowing upon it as heaps / As if the cloud is dust of war in which Al-Malik Al-Mu'izz... has drawn a sword.' And better than all this is the saying of Sheikh Sharaf al-Din Abdul Aziz, Sheikh of the Sheikhs in Hama, from a ghazal poem praising the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: 'Whoever saw that fasting sash (belt)... prayed upon Muhammad.' And the saying of Abu al-Husayn al-Jazzar praising Jamal al-Din Musa bin Yaghmur: 'I dared to kiss the anemone on her cheek... and sip saliva I am still drunk from / And I do not fear the magic of her glances... because through Musa (Moses) I have become safe from magic.' And his saying also praising Fakhr al-Qudah Nasrallah bin Basaqa: 'How many a night I spent in difficulty while I had... in the adornment of my hopes treasures of ease / I say to my heart whenever I longed for wealth... When the Help of Allah (Nasrallah) comes, may the hand of poverty perish (Tabbat).' Regarding the Transition (Mukhallis), how sweet is the saying of Al-Siraj al-Warraq: 'If my chest is light for rhymes and organizing them... Then in grace and the shade of generosity, I am restricted / And how many a beginning (Matla') I composed for a poem... Jesus says to me: Or perhaps there is a way out (Mukhallis) for you.' And it was witty of one who dispraised the transition in one verse where he said: 'While locks of hair of the one he loves were in his palm... until the beard of the praised one got stuck.' Transition in the Holy Quran. He said: And Abu al-Ala Muhammad bin Ghanim, known as Al-Ghanimi, said: The Book of Allah is free from Takhallus (poetic transition). It is only the exit from one speech to another speech via a subtlety that harmonizes the two speeches, the one exited from and the one entered into. Regarding examples of that which Ibn al-Athir cited from the Holy Quran. Then Ibn al-Athir said: And in the Quran are many places. Among them: And he began citing what he cited. Like His Almighty's saying: 'And recite to them the news of Abraham, when he said to his father and his people: What do you worship?...' to the end of the story, and other than that. I say: What Ibn al-Athir mentioned does not go beyond what Al-Ghanimi said; for the Quran is all connected to one another, such as exiting from preaching and reminding to warning, or to glad tidings, or to a command, or prohibition, or promise, or threat, except for what its connection is hidden in appearance. Imam Fakhr al-Din observed this in his exegesis and spoke about the relationship of the verse to what follows it. Ibn al-Athir did not understand Al-Ghanimi's speech nor know his intent, which is that he meant the Takhallus that poets agreed upon, which is for the poet to transition within a single verse from ghazal or blame or description to praise. Such a thing I do not know to have occurred in a single verse (of Quran). As for the connection of a verse to what precedes it, only a little deviates from this, and that is in appearance; otherwise, when a person contemplates it and reflects on it with true reflection, he will not find it cut off except in what is known to be improvisation (Iqtidab). Models of Transition in Ibn al-Athir's composition. He said: Something of transitions came to me in prose composition in many things. Among that is what I mentioned in a letter to some brothers describing spring, then I exited from that to mentioning longings. So I said: 'Just as these descriptions are beautiful in their affair, so too is my longing beautiful in its affair, except that its meter (sea) is a summer season and this is a spring season.'

I say: This man has cited examples of poets' transitions, like Abu Tammam, Abu al-Tayyib, Al-Buhturi, and others, yet he did not notice the transition and its beauty. Can such a thing be counted among transitions? If he had said: 'And an anemone tore its sleeves, raised its flags, filled its cup with wine, revealed its red cheek with a black mole in it, and kindled its fire resembling the embers of my longings and its intensity,' people would have counted this as a transition. Then he mentioned another section on cold, and claimed he transitioned to longing, and it is of this ratio. Then he mentioned another section on a gift, and transitioned from it to intercession, and it is of this type. Then he mentioned a section on mentioning affection, and transitioned to asking for fresh dates, and it is of this category. Proportion between meanings and discussion of examples of that. He said in the twenty-fourth type regarding proportion between meanings, after citing the saying of the poet: 'Behold, O son of those who perished and died... By Allah, they did not die for you to remain / And you possess—so know—a station in it... When you have completed terms (Ajala - plural) and provision (Rizqa - singular).' And he denied the lack of proportion between the singular 'provision' and the plural 'terms', and considered it ugly: 'I used to see this type as obligatory in usage, and that it is not good to deviate from it, until I came across in the Quran what contradicts it. Like His Almighty's saying: 'Do they not see what Allah has created of a thing, its shadows return from the right (Yamin - singular) and the lefts (Shama'il - plural).' And he cited His Almighty's saying: 'Those are the ones upon whose hearts, hearing (singular), and sights (plural) Allah has set a seal.' And His Almighty's saying: 'Until when they come to it, their hearing, their sights, and their skins testify against them.' I say: There is no doubt regarding the poet's saying: 'terms and provision', that it is defective and counted as a lack of proportion between meanings, and scholars of rhetoric have mentioned it and stated it. If he had said: 'a term and provisions' it would have been lesser, for the term (lifespan) is one, and provision is multiple. Correct taste refuses such a thing. As for his citing these verses, the plural did not come with the singular except for a wisdom Ibn al-Athir did not view. That wisdom is greater and grander than observing proportion. It casts to the side of the left so it is one, but when the sun declines and returns to the side of the west, the shadow reverses and takes from the north, then becomes bit by bit, and its increases multiply and the erectness is ordained. Likewise for facing the Qibla and the honor of its direction. Leave this aside, for the word 'Shama'il' (lefts) is sweeter in plural than singular and more delightful, and it is the habit of Arabs to observe the lightness of words and their sweetness despite the lack of proportion in meanings. And you have decided that there are words that are heavy when singular and light when plural. As for 'Hearing' in the two noble verses, it was singular because it is a verbal noun (Masdar), and the verbal noun applies to the few and the many. If it falls among plurals, it takes their ruling, and if it falls among singulars, it is in their ruling. In general, pluralizing verbal nouns is awkward (Iyy), because the meaning of multitude is present in them, or because it implies the deletion of a possessive noun (Mudaf) which is not good in others, as if He Almighty said: 'And upon the margins of their hearing.' And the like does not hold true for sights and hearts. As for sights, because they are not sealed but covered. As for hearts, because they are not contained within what has margins upon which the seal falls; rather, the seal is upon the hearts themselves, not their margins. Of this is His Almighty's saying: 'And He made darkness (plural) and light (singular),' because darkness comes from thick bodies, and light from fire. So likewise the Right and the Lefts. Discussing Ibn al-Athir regarding Economy, Negligence, and Excess. He said in the twenty-fifth type regarding Economy, Negligence, and Excess, when mentioning Negligence: Know that praise has words specific to it, and blame has words specific to it. A group has gone deep into this until they said: It is of manners not to address Kings and those close to them with the 'Kaf' of address (singular 'You'). This is a cold error, for Allah, who is the King of Kings, was addressed with the 'Kaf' in the beginning of His Noble Book, where it was said: 'It is You (Iyyaka) we worship and You (Iyyaka) we ask for help.' And similar examples appeared in limited places in the Quran. I say: His citing this is not something that refutes the saying of those who went to say that manners in addressing Kings and those close to them should not be with the 'Kaf', because this is the Opening of the Book (Al-Fatiha) and is recited in every Rak'ah, and the Noble Quran was only revealed to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and among its benefits is declaring Allah Almighty free from partner, child, and wife. If it were said: 'It is You (plural) we worship and You (plural) we ask for help,' it would imply to the polytheists and Christians what they say of multiple gods, and would be a doubt for those claiming that.

A letter arrived from the island of Cyprus via William the Frankish merchant in the year seven hundred and twenty approximately, and I stood upon it in the city of Safed. I found its author arguing for the validity of the Christians' doctrine in saying the Trinity, using transmitted things from the Great Quran. Like His Almighty's saying: 'He said, My Lord, return me (Irji'un - plural imperative)' and 'And sufficient are We as reckoners.' And with such verses, and with other things that are laughable to use as evidence. Then he began to argue for the Trinity with His Almighty's saying: 'They said, We worship your God and the God of your fathers, Abraham and Ishmael and Isaac,' mentioning three, and this is something laughable. Although some of the Rafidah (Shia) have an argument for the validity of marrying nine (women) from this type. It is His Almighty's saying: 'Marry what pleases you of women, two and three and four.' He said: This total sum is nine, and the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, died leaving nine wives. As for this Cypriot letter; Sheikh Taqi al-Din ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, answered it in two volumes, and engaged with it for a while and was fond of it. If you say: With the likes of His Almighty's saying: 'My Lord, return me (plural)' and 'Sufficient are We as reckoners', it becomes problematic for you regarding what you established in the Fatiha. I say: It is established for us in the Quran from other than this, and proofs were established for Oneness by the likes of His Almighty's saying: 'If there were therein gods besides Allah, they would have both been ruined.' When such comes, we know that the intended meaning is magnification. People only took addressing the great with the plural wording from the Great Quran. The reason the magnified one himself says: 'We did' and 'We commanded'... and the like, is because only one who is obeyed and magnified among his people says this, and the obeyed one is only he who has followers and servants who speak by his saying and return to what he says. Like the owner of a school of thought says: 'Our opinion' and 'Our school', meaning I and those who say this saying. For this reason, the jurists and debaters, one of them says: 'We do not concede,' while he is one and no other, and the meaning is 'I prevent this, I and whoever agrees with my saying.' Since the speaker, when he was great, said: 'We did,' his address was carried upon that, so it was said to him: 'You (plural) did,' so that it would be a correspondence to what he says. As for this age, people have rested from addressing Kings in their correspondences and other than their correspondences with the 'Kaf' and with the plural pronoun. For it is only said: 'The Noble Decrees', 'The High Opinions', 'The Noble Charities', and 'The Noble Doors', except what is too high in honor to be described as such, like: The Stable, the Camel-rest, and the Kitchens and the like, for they are described as 'The Happy' (Al-Sa'ida). And if the speaker is before the Sultan, he says: 'The Head of our Master the Sultan, may Allah perpetuate his kingdom,' and everything he mentions, he adds to this sentence. The preference between the namings 'Irsad' (Preparation) and 'Tawshih' (Sashing). He said in the twenty-eighth type regarding Irsad: I saw Abu Hilal al-Askari naming this type: 'Al-Tawshih'. It is not so, rather naming it 'Al-Irsad' is more appropriate. I say: This 'Irsad' which he went to saying is more fitting than 'Tawshih' for the meaning he decided, its example is the saying of Al-Buhturi: 'She made lawful my blood on the day of separation and forbade... without cause, on the day of meeting, my speech / And the one she made lawful was not lawful (to kill)... And the one she forbade was not forbidden (Harim).' It is that the poet brings a half-verse from which the second half is understood, or a beginning from which the end is understood, or from the part the whole is understood. It is proof of mastery and quality of nature. The face of appropriateness between this meaning and 'Tawshih' is to place the beginning of the speech and its end in the position of the shoulder and the flank, and place the indication of what is in its beginning to its end in the position of the sash (Wishah) roaming over them. This is a meaning fitting for this name, and the word itself is sweeter to the ear than 'Irsad'. He said: A group has followed in prose speech and poetry paths outside the subject of the science of Bayan (Rhetoric), and they are far from it, because they are in a valley and the science of Bayan is in a valley. Among those who did that is Al-Hariri, the author of the Maqamat, for he mentioned that letter which is one dotted word and one undotted word, and the letter where one letter of its words is dotted and the other undotted. And others organized poetry where the end of each verse is the beginning of the verse that follows it. All of this, even if it involves hardship of craft, is outside the door of eloquence and rhetoric. I say: Al-Hariri, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, did not bring what he brought of these types claiming that this is eloquence and rhetoric. Rather, he brought that to exhaust the types of literature (Adab), and show the literati what is required for them to know. All of that is proof of ability and mastery. If Al-Hariri had done that in all the Maqamat, it would not have been good.

Such things like the riddle, the puzzle, the catch-questions, bringing a dotted word followed by an undotted one, and a dotted letter followed by an undotted one, or the beginning of a verse being such and its end such... all of that is suitable for Maqamat. As for correspondence and sermons, it is disliked and found heavy. Because correspondence is not intended for showing jurisprudence in literature, but is rather for congratulation, condolence, thanks, praise, description, seeking sympathy, blame, longing, or other than that. Such things do not befit affectation. However, even if these types are in the Maqamat, they should be like small flashes, for if they increase, they become ugly. Do you not see that Al-Imad al-Katib, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, when he made his speech laden with Jinass (paronomasia) such that hardly a word is free from it, it became heavy on ears and hearts, and did not have the lightness of Al-Qadi Al-Fadil's speech on hearts. A poet might be excellent, so he brings a type of affectation without the trace of burden upon it. Like the saying of Ibn Hamdis: 'With side-locks like Zirfan (chain-links), his glance attacks playfully... the creation, joyful if I complain of passion, laughing / Do not expose yourself to a rose upon his cheek... for his eye only set it as a trap.' The first gathers all the dotted letters without the burden showing on it. Likewise the saying of the sayer: 'Clever (Labiq), a slender one approached (Aqbala) in it... Every (Kull) thing I own, if he sings, give it (Habhu).' For every two words of this, their meaning does not change by reversal (palindrome) except the rhyme, for it is known in itself. And there is no trace of burden on it. Similar to it also: 'A green land in which is... a slender one pouring a cup.' Also the saying of the sayer: 'The God showed us... a crescent that illuminated.' Also the saying of the sayer: 'You kill, you sin... you tyrannize, you regret.' If reversed and misspelled (dots changed), it becomes: 'Melter of my soul, when do we meet.' Similar to it is the saying of the sayer: 'The qualities of my killer fluttered... so for that my soul does not rest / The beloved returned his answer... so it is as if it is pearls in wording.' The beginning of every verse is the reverse of the last word of it. And there is no burden on it. As for Ibn al-Athir, it seems he thinks that literature (Adab) is only correspondence, and he did not know that it is a part of it, even if a large part and a majestic type. The least heavy of these affectations is what is entirely undotted (Muhmal), nay, it is not counted as heavy at all, but is light and sweet to the ear and heart. Like the saying of Al-Hariri: 'Prepare for your enviers the sharpest weapon... And lead the hopeful to the watering place of generosity.' The poem is entirely of utmost beauty. I found for Al-Qadi Al-Fadil, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, a sermon he composed for the entry of the New Year, and it is long, all of it stripped of dotting, and it is of utmost beauty. Were it not for fear of length, I would have recorded it. I found Al-Warraq al-Haziri had taken pains in things of these types. Among them are two verses every word of which has a Hamza. They are: 'By my father is a soft one who melted my heart... when he distanced himself and showed turning away (I'rad) / A gazelle (Rasha') accustomed to harshness, so if he approaches... he shows to those hoping for him contraction (Inqibad).' Regarding 'Inqibad' there is a view; the saying of Abu al-Tayyib almost: 'I aim (Ummi) for Abu al-Fadl the Beneficent (Al-Mubirr), my oath... I will indeed aim for the greatest sea in essence.' This is from this necessity, and in it with the repetition of Hamza is the repetition of Shaddas. Among that is a piece which, if read, the lips do not move (Labials omitted). It is: 'Here I am, bare of skin (patience)... He who slept kept me awake / Ah for an eye that looked... at a gazelle possessing softness / You showed me, O my viewer... the hunting of the gazelle by the lion / Indeed, wasting away due to his abandonment... O my blamer, destroyed the body / My entrails were stuffed when he distanced... the fire of Ghada wood when he fled / O treacherous one who left me... upon the blaze of a fire burning / Will you not treat kindly a thin one... who does not complain to anyone.' Among that is a piece, the first halves are dotted, and the seconds are undotted. From it: 'In me is passion (Shaghaf) that ignited (Shabba) between my sides... Its medicine is affection and connection / He broadcasts my grief, hidden in anger... A haw-eyed one whose promise is impossible / Adorned with two things: coquetry of an eyelid... and salt of coyness that has perfection.' He said: On this style came the saying of some of them: 'And a youth from Mazin... who surpassed the people of Basra / His mother is Definite (Ma'rifa)... and his father is Indefinite (Nakira).' Is there any doubt in the beauty of this meaning and its delicacy?

Do you not see that Al-Imad al-Katib, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, when he made his speech laden with Jinass (paronomasia) such that hardly a word is free from it, it became heavy on ears and hearts, and did not have the lightness of Al-Qadi Al-Fadil's speech on hearts. A poet might be excellent, so he brings a type of affectation without the trace of burden upon it. Like the saying of Ibn Hamdis: 'With side-locks like Zirfan (chain-links), his glance attacks playfully... the creation, joyful if I complain of passion, laughing / Do not expose yourself to a rose upon his cheek... for his eye only set it as a trap.' The first gathers all the dotted letters without the burden showing on it. Likewise the saying of the sayer: 'Clever (Labiq), a slender one approached (Aqbala) in it... Every (Kull) thing I own, if he sings, give it (Habhu).' For every two words of this, their meaning does not change by reversal (palindrome) except the rhyme, for it is known in itself. And there is no trace of burden on it. Similar to it also: 'A green land in which is... a slender one pouring a cup.' Also the saying of the sayer: 'The God showed us... a crescent that illuminated.' Also the saying of the sayer: 'You kill, you sin... you tyrannize, you regret.' If reversed and misspelled (dots changed), it becomes: 'Melter of my soul, when do we meet.' Similar to it is the saying of the sayer: 'The qualities of my killer fluttered... so for that my soul does not rest / The beloved returned his answer... so it is as if it is pearls in wording.' The beginning of every verse is the reverse of the last word of it. And there is no burden on it. As for Ibn al-Athir, it seems he thinks that literature (Adab) is only correspondence, and he did not know that it is a part of it, even if a large part and a majestic type. The least heavy of these affectations is what is entirely undotted (Muhmal), nay, it is not counted as heavy at all, but is light and sweet to the ear and heart. Like the saying of Al-Hariri: 'Prepare for your enviers the sharpest weapon... And lead the hopeful to the watering place of generosity.' The poem is entirely of utmost beauty. I found for Al-Qadi Al-Fadil, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, a sermon he composed for the entry of the New Year, and it is long, all of it stripped of dotting, and it is of utmost beauty. Were it not for fear of length, I would have recorded it. I found Al-Warraq al-Haziri had taken pains in things of these types. Among them are two verses every word of which has a Hamza. They are: 'By my father is a soft one who melted my heart... when he distanced himself and showed turning away (I'rad) / A gazelle (Rasha') accustomed to harshness, so if he approaches... he shows to those hoping for him contraction (Inqibad).' Regarding 'Inqibad' there is a view; the saying of Abu al-Tayyib almost: 'I aim (Ummi) for Abu al-Fadl the Beneficent (Al-Mubirr), my oath... I will indeed aim for the greatest sea in essence.' This is from this necessity, and in it with the repetition of Hamza is the repetition of Shaddas. Among that is a piece which, if read, the lips do not move (Labials omitted). It is: 'Here I am, bare of skin (patience)... He who slept kept me awake / Ah for an eye that looked... at a gazelle possessing softness / You showed me, O my viewer... the hunting of the gazelle by the lion / Indeed, wasting away due to his abandonment... O my blamer, destroyed the body / My entrails were stuffed when he distanced... the fire of Ghada wood when he fled / O treacherous one who left me... upon the blaze of a fire burning / Will you not treat kindly a thin one... who does not complain to anyone.' Among that is a piece, the first halves are dotted, and the seconds are undotted. From it: 'In me is passion (Shaghaf) that ignited (Shabba) between my sides... Its medicine is affection and connection / He broadcasts my grief, hidden in anger... A haw-eyed one whose promise is impossible / Adorned with two things: coquetry of an eyelid... and salt of coyness that has perfection.' He said: On this style came the saying of some of them: 'And a youth from Mazin... who surpassed the people of Basra / His mother is Definite (Ma'rifa)... and his father is Indefinite (Nakira).' Is there any doubt in the beauty of this meaning and its delicacy?

I say: How deserving these two verses are of doubt, and how worthy their composer is of a slap! What beauty is in them and what delicacy, with these heavy words in his use of 'Basra' with a vowel on the Sad (Basara), and what is in them of meter defect (Zihaf) even if permissible. Is there anything in them other than mentioning Definite and Indefinite? What great matter is in that! If the writers of this age wanted to use the chapters of grammar and titles of syntax from the beginning of the art to its end in whatever meaning they wanted, they would do so. As for prose, I found for Judge Muhyi al-Din ibn Abd al-Zahir, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, a note he wrote as intercession via a person to a great man. It is: 'May the banner (Alam - also Flag) of his knowledge remain Raised (Marfu') forever, and the structure (Bina') of his glory Erected (Mansub) by the Lowering (Khafd) of the enemies. May the letters of his pens remain Jussive (Jazima) to the verbs of doubt, and the delegations of fortunes Transitive (Muta'addiya) away from his enemies and Intransitive/Binding (Lazima) to his allies. It is conveyed that So-and-so attended and mentioned that his name is Apocopated (Murakham) without Calling (Nida'), and Truncated (Juzima) while Truncation (Jazm) does not enter upon Nouns (Asma'). He was Excepted (Istuthniya) without a cause by Lowering (Khafd), and Lowering is not among the tools of Exception. He claimed that the Operator (Amil) that entered upon him prevented him from Conjugation (Tasarrun) and bound him with the binding of Indeclinability (Bina'). He entered with him into the Condition (Shart) and singled him out in the Penalty (Jaza'). The Influencer (Mu'aththir) - may Allah support him - Erected (Nasaba) his place upon Praise (Madh) not upon Incitement (Ighra'), and Raised (Rafa') his name, stripped of Operators (Awamil), upon Inception (Ibtida'). In him is of Distinction (Tamyiz) and Adverbial status (Zarf) what necessitates Conjunction (Atf) for him, and of Justice (Adl) and Knowledge (Ma'rifa) what prevents him from Morphological Change (Sarf). May the door of our Master remain for the Returner (A'id) and the Connection (Sila), and the state of his status widespread, not Transitive (Muntaqila).' Look at the craft of this writer in this letter, how delicately he brought this grammatical terminology in the meaning of intercession, prayer, and praise for the one he interceded to, from the beginning of his speech to its end. As for poetry, poets have played with it often, and it is famous. How sweet is the saying of Al-Baha Zuhayr: 'Your Zayd did not fulfill his wish (Watar) from your connection... Nor did he spend his night or dawn in your abandonment / You left my news (Khabari) in abandonment a Subject (Mubtada)... And every Definite (Ma'rifa) of mine became in passion Indefinite (Nakira).' In the two verses cited by Ibn al-Athir, there is nothing but the metonymy regarding the mentioned person that he is a child of adultery whose father is unknown. How beautiful is the saying of Ibn Unayn satirizing Ibn Sayyida: 'Say to Ibn Sayyida, even if he has... servants indicating abundance and horses / You are nothing but like the mule, for her mother... is Known (Ma'luma - Mare) and she has an Unknown (Majhul - Donkey) father.' Regarding Poetic Thefts. He said in the thirtieth type, regarding Poetic Thefts, after citing the verse of Ibn al-Khayyat: 'I am jealous if I sense a groan in the tribe... fearing for him that it might be for his love.' And the verse of 'Umara: 'Does the House (Kaaba) know that after leaving it... I did not travel from a sanctuary (Haram) except to a sanctuary.' That these two are stolen from the saying of Al-Mutanabbi: 'If I said to the lovesick sick one: May I be his ransom... because of what he suffers, it would tempt him with his ransom.' And from the saying of Abu Tammam praising some Caliphs when he performed Hajj: 'O one who saw a sanctuary striving to a sanctuary... Blessed is a toucher (of the Black Stone) coming and embracing.' He began criticizing the people of Syria and Egypt for the fact that the likes of this was hidden from them, and increased in wonder. I say: The reason for the concealment of the theft in these two verses and others is that the original is often weak, unused, not circulating on tongues in correspondences, dialogues, and proverbs. So some poet comes to that obscure meaning, highlights it in a beautiful image, and casts it in a mold more graceful and delicate than the first. So it becomes sweet and pleasant, people circulate it, and the first returns to being forgotten as if it never was. Just as when the star appears, then the full moon appears after it, the sight does not busy itself with the star and leave the full moon. How beautiful is the saying of Abu Tammam: 'Is the sun at your place boasting of its beauties... while you are busy in the entrails with the moon?' No attention is paid in the second except to its beauty without searching for its origin, and whether it is stolen or invented. Moreover, the literati, no matter how great his transmission and knowledge, cannot extract every meaning he passes by without deliberation and tracking of that. Especially in what became sweet and palatable, and appeared in an image other than its first image. There is no doubt that the saying of Ibn al-Khayyat is sweeter than the saying of Al-Mutanabbi, and for this reason it became famous. Likewise, the saying of 'Umara is better and thinner than the saying of Abu Tammam, and for this reason it became palatable and famous, and was used as a proverb despite his later time and the earlier time of Abu Tammam. Especially the second hemistich of 'Umara's verse, for it spread and diffused, and filled mouths and ears. If a thing is mentioned by a thing, how sweet is the saying of Abd al-Hakam ibn al-Khatib al-Iraqi regarding a man who deserved death, so the executioner shot him with an arrow which hit his liver and killed him instantly:

'It brought out its son from the liver (Kabid - also handle) of the bow, so it began... to moan, and the mother may be affectionate to the child / And it did not know that when it threw him... he did not travel from a liver except to a liver.' As for jealousy, among the most eloquent of what came in that is the saying of Ibn Qalaqis in verses: 'And my tribulation is from a secluded woman... before whom are a wall and fences / And lions whose power is feared by... everything possessed by Khaffan (lion's den) / And a watcher who, if he glances at her... bends while he is jealous.' And the saying of Ali ibn Abdullah al-Ja'fari: 'Perhaps your turning away from me pleased me... in my seeking you and your refusal of me / Fearing that I be a key for another... and when I am alone, you are the wish.' Hafsa al-Maghribiyya exaggerated in her saying: 'I am jealous for you from others and from myself... and from you and from your place and time / Even if I hid you in my eyelids... until the Day of Resurrection, it would not suffice me.' Jamal al-Din ibn Matruh took some of this and said: 'So if he persists in my destruction... I say: My torturer, by Allah increase me / And do not grant me your connection, for I... am jealous for you from myself, so how about from me (others)?' From it is the saying of Sa'd al-Din Muhammad ibn Arabi: 'O one for whom I am jealous from myself in passion... So I turn away from him while my heart is yearning / Protect the beauty of your face from my glances, for I have... a heart that sees, and for my eye is lowering (gaze).' How beautiful is the saying of Shihab al-Din ibn al-Khaymi: 'And a blamer who made me doubt his advice... whenever I increased in passion, he increased in persistence / My blamer is never but a lover... who covered jealousy with blame and darkened.' I organized (verse) regarding the meaning of Ibn al-Khaymi's saying: 'My blamer became cunning in love and his... intentions were not hidden from a lover like me / He loved my beloved then became jealous, so he feared that... I would open the subject of him, so he raced with blame.' However, Al-Mutanabbi, in the origin, took the meaning from Al-Abbas ibn al-Ahnaf where he says: 'I did not meet one with sorrow revealing his love... except I thought you were that beloved / Out of caution for you, even though I am confident in you... that other than me will not attain a share of you.' Among jealousy is the saying of Abu Tammam al-Ta'i: 'I am jealous for you from my kiss... even if you gave me my hope / And I fear to see your cheeks... set up as sites for kisses.' Among jealousy is the saying of the sayer: 'Passion became pure for you and my love selected you... until I am jealous for you from your two angels / And I see you strutting in your beauties which... are my ordeal, so I am jealous for you from you / If I could, I would wound your pronunciation out of jealousy... because I see it kissing your lips.' How delicate is the saying of Abdul Muhsin al-Suri, for he reversed the intent when he said: 'I became attached to him drunk from the wine of youth... in him is negligence of my anguish and flame / Every slender one shares with me in his love... sharing with me a portion of my soul / So do not bind me with jealousy I have not accustomed to... for my beloved is whoever loves my beloved.' Economy in Wording. He said: Bashar ibn Burd said: 'Whoever watches people does not win his need... and the bold one, fond (of it), wins the good things.' Salm al-Khasir took it, and he was his student, so he said: 'Whoever watches people dies of grief... and the daring one wins the pleasure.' There are two words difference in composition between the two verses... I say: Salm al-Khasir was not fair, and it is not said in this: there are two words difference in composition, since a 'word' (lafza) applies to two letters, like: Min, An, Ma... and others. Rather, even to one letter like the Ba of genitive and Lam. The better way in this is to say: Between them are nine letters. For the first is forty-four letters, and the second is thirty-five letters. Likewise the saying of Abu al-Atahiya: 'And I am indeed excused for the excess of loving her... because she has a face that indicates my excuse.' Abu Tammam took it and said: 'She has a face, if you see... it, it whispers to you my excuse.' The first is forty-four letters, and the second is twenty-six letters, so between them are eighteen letters. Salm al-Khasir is among those who have the ability to abbreviate. Do you not see his saying: 'They approached in the height of the forenoon... covering the face of the sun with the sun.' And the saying of the other: 'And when the gazelle (sun) appeared in the sky... and the day began to depart for its time / She showed to the eye of the sun an eye like it... meeting the sky with the like of what it welcomes.' And likewise his saying also:

'She watered me passion with her eyes and I watered her... so the creeping of wine crept in every joint.' And the saying of Ubaydullah, one of the Hamasah poets: 'You split the heart then sprinkled your love... in it, so it closed up and the cracks healed / It penetrated where no drink reached... nor sadness, and no joy reached.' He said: On this came the saying of Ibn al-Rumi: 'As if I seek nearness to you with the son of a bow (arrow)... when pulling brings it near the chest, it distances it.' Some poets of the Levant took it, namely Ibn Qasim al-Hamawi, and said: 'So he is like the arrow, the more you increase him... in nearness by pulling, the more he increases in distance.' I say: Al-Arjani also took it and said: 'So do not deny the right of the yearning one, for we... for us and for you the stars of the night testify / I see us as arrows in passion and see you... as bows, so you do not come near except to distance.' And he repeated it saying: 'The figure bent in farewell and brought me near... as an arrow, then distanced me from where it brought me near.' And he repeated it also saying: 'Like the arrow, its shooter brings it near... and for the sake of distance is that nearness.' And he said: 'The day of departure did not embrace me out of passion... rather it was bringing me near to distance me.' And he said: 'And the intimate friend embraced me for separation... so my cheeks and his cheeks wrapped / As if he aimed at a goal... taking the arrow with his right hand / Until when he brought it near his chest... he distanced it the hour he brought it near.' Kushajim took it before Al-Arjani and said: 'I see your connection does not clear up for the one hoping for it... and abandonment follows it running on the trail / Like the bow, the nearest of its two arrows to which you bent... upon, is the furthest of them from the pull of the string.' Ibn Babak generated another meaning from this, saying: 'I became in his polo stick a ball... its nearness to the striker distances it.' How beautiful is the saying of Ibn al-Mughallis riddling about it: 'He wanted its nearness, until when... it came near him with toil—what toil—he hated it / Then he followed it with a strike... and exchanged its nearness to him with distance.' Between Prose and Poetry. He said regarding preferring prose over poetry at the end of the book: 'If a poet wants to explain multiple matters, having different meanings in his poetry, and needs to prolong by composing two hundred or three hundred verses or more than that, he does not do well in all of it nor in much of it; rather, he does well in a small part, and much of it is bad and unsatisfactory. The writer (prose) is not afflicted by that; rather, he prolongs in a single letter a vast prolongation reaching ten layers of paper or more, containing three hundred lines or four hundred or five hundred. And he is excellent in all of that. There is no dispute in this, because we have seen it and said it. Based on this, I found the Persians superior to the Arabs in this point referred to. For their poet mentions a book composed from its beginning to its end in poetry, which is an explanation of stories and conditions, yet it is in the utmost eloquence and rhetoric in the language of the people, as Firdawsi did in composing the book known as Shahnameh, which is sixty thousand verses of poetry, comprising the history of the Persians. It is the Quran of the people. Their eloquent ones have agreed that there is nothing in their language more eloquent than it. This is not found in the Arabic language despite its vastness and the branching of its arts and purposes, and despite the fact that the language of the Arabs compared to it is like a drop in a sea.' I say: Ibn al-Athir, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, ended his book with this point in which he leaned towards Shu'ubiyyah (anti-Arab sentiment). Ma'mar ibn al-Muthanna, Sahl ibn Harun, and Ibn Gharsiya in his epistle did not say the like of this. Among the people of the Arabic tongue, there have been found those who organized much as well. If he counts Firdawsi, I count for him a group like that. Among them are those who versified the history of Al-Masudi in a versification of utmost beauty. And among them are those who versified the book Kalila wa Dimna in ten thousand verses; Aban al-Lahiqi also versified it. The Sheikh, Imam, Hafiz Shams al-Din Abu Abdullah Muhammad al-Dhahabi informed me that Makki ibn Abi Muhammad ibn Muhammad ibn Abihi al-Dimashqi, known as Ibn al-Dajjajiyya, versified the book Al-Muhadhdhab in a poem on the rhyme of Ra, calling it 'Al-Badi'a fi Ahkam al-Shari'a'. End. I say: Al-Muhadhdhab is in four volumes.

'She watered me passion with her eyes and I watered her... so the creeping of wine crept in every joint.' And the saying of Ubaydullah, one of the Hamasah poets: 'You split the heart then sprinkled your love... in it, so it closed up and the cracks healed / It penetrated where no drink reached... nor sadness, and no joy reached.' He said: On this came the saying of Ibn al-Rumi: 'As if I seek nearness to you with the son of a bow (arrow)... when pulling brings it near the chest, it distances it.' Some poets of the Levant took it, namely Ibn Qasim al-Hamawi, and said: 'So he is like the arrow, the more you increase him... in nearness by pulling, the more he increases in distance.' I say: Al-Arjani also took it and said: 'So do not deny the right of the yearning one, for we... for us and for you the stars of the night testify / I see us as arrows in passion and see you... as bows, so you do not come near except to distance.' And he repeated it saying: 'The figure bent in farewell and brought me near... as an arrow, then distanced me from where it brought me near.' And he repeated it also saying: 'Like the arrow, its shooter brings it near... and for the sake of distance is that nearness.' And he said: 'The day of departure did not embrace me out of passion... rather it was bringing me near to distance me.' And he said: 'And the intimate friend embraced me for separation... so my cheeks and his cheeks wrapped / As if he aimed at a goal... taking the arrow with his right hand / Until when he brought it near his chest... he distanced it the hour he brought it near.' Kushajim took it before Al-Arjani and said: 'I see your connection does not clear up for the one hoping for it... and abandonment follows it running on the trail / Like the bow, the nearest of its two arrows to which you bent... upon, is the furthest of them from the pull of the string.' Ibn Babak generated another meaning from this, saying: 'I became in his polo stick a ball... its nearness to the striker distances it.' How beautiful is the saying of Ibn al-Mughallis riddling about it: 'He wanted its nearness, until when... it came near him with toil—what toil—he hated it / Then he followed it with a strike... and exchanged its nearness to him with distance.' Between Prose and Poetry. He said regarding preferring prose over poetry at the end of the book: 'If a poet wants to explain multiple matters, having different meanings in his poetry, and needs to prolong by composing two hundred or three hundred verses or more than that, he does not do well in all of it nor in much of it; rather, he does well in a small part, and much of it is bad and unsatisfactory. The writer (prose) is not afflicted by that; rather, he prolongs in a single letter a vast prolongation reaching ten layers of paper or more, containing three hundred lines or four hundred or five hundred. And he is excellent in all of that. There is no dispute in this, because we have seen it and said it. Based on this, I found the Persians superior to the Arabs in this point referred to. For their poet mentions a book composed from its beginning to its end in poetry, which is an explanation of stories and conditions, yet it is in the utmost eloquence and rhetoric in the language of the people, as Firdawsi did in composing the book known as Shahnameh, which is sixty thousand verses of poetry, comprising the history of the Persians. It is the Quran of the people. Their eloquent ones have agreed that there is nothing in their language more eloquent than it. This is not found in the Arabic language despite its vastness and the branching of its arts and purposes, and despite the fact that the language of the Arabs compared to it is like a drop in a sea.' I say: Ibn al-Athir, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, ended his book with this point in which he leaned towards Shu'ubiyyah (anti-Arab sentiment). Ma'mar ibn al-Muthanna, Sahl ibn Harun, and Ibn Gharsiya in his epistle did not say the like of this. Among the people of the Arabic tongue, there have been found those who organized much as well. If he counts Firdawsi, I count for him a group like that. Among them are those who versified the history of Al-Masudi in a versification of utmost beauty. And among them are those who versified the book Kalila wa Dimna in ten thousand verses; Aban al-Lahiqi also versified it. Some Maghrebis praised our Master the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, in a poem numbering eighteen thousand verses. Ibn al-Habbariya has the book 'Al-Sadih wa al-Baghim' in two thousand verses; each verse is a lofty palace, and its witticisms have no increase in beauty upon them. It comprises tales, anecdotes, proverbs, and wisdoms, all in the utmost eloquence and rhetoric, having no 'if' or 'would that' (flaws). As for those who versified a thousand or less, they are very many, uncountable. As for Al-Shatibiyya and what it contains of knowing the seven readings and their differences, and those symbols whose exterior is ghazal and interior is knowledge, it is a book that became famous and appeared, and its magic snatched minds and dazzled, until the sayer said about it: 'Al-Ru'ayni unveiled to us in the forenoon... his virgin bride, and oh what he unveiled / If another innovator sought her... her rhymes would say to him, all of them: No.' As for the Rajaz poems of grammar, prosody, and Fiqh, like the one who versified Al-Wajiz and the system of the Hanafis, and other than that of medicine and other sciences, they are very many, to the extent that description cannot encompass. We have not heard of any Persian who busied himself with Arabic except that he preferred the Arabic language. The proof of this claim is that Abu Ali al-Farisi, Bundar, Abu Hatim, Al-Zamakhshari, and others of these, when they busied themselves with Arabic and tasted its sweetness, they fell in love with it and became fond of its beauties. They spent nights and days acquiring it, and spent the duration of life in composing and recording it, and tracking its beauties, the rules of its analogies, and the wonders of its arts. It is impossible that these people strove this striving in Arabic and spent the duration of life while it is something that does not succeed in anything, being inferior to another. It would have been more appropriate for them and for every rational person to busy themselves with the best, most eloquent, most rhetorical, and most wise. If these people knew that the Persian language had the superlative (Af'al al-Tafdil), they would not have stopped at Arabic except long enough to know it, then turned back to their language. Among the genius words of Al-Zamakhshari: 'Your differentiating between Rutab (fresh dates) and Ajam (seeds) is a difference between Arabs and Ajam (Non-Arabs).' And among them: 'The Arabs are a hard Nab' tree of dictionaries (Ma'ajim), and the Gharb (willow/West) is a likeness for the A'ajim (Non-Arabs).' Look at Al-Zamakhshari how he made the Arabs Rutab (fresh/good) and the Ajam (Persians) Ajam (seeds/hard/speechless). Ajam with the movement of Jim is the date pit. And how he made the Arabs like the Nab' tree, which is hard and from which bows are made, and made the Ajam like the Gharb tree, which is weak. Al-Mutanabbi said: 'Let not the nights attain you, for their hands... if they strike, break the Nab' with the Gharb.' If you say: The scholars of Arabic among the Persians were not knowledgeable in the Persian language as they should be, I say: Is it not that they knew Persian, then they became skilled in Arabic and exaggerated in mastering it? Whoever reaches in a language of languages what Abu Ali and Al-Zamakhshari and others reached in knowing the major and minor derivation, structures, and morphology, in the noun, past verb, present verb, imperative, active participle, and passive participle, and possessed that faculty, had the qualification to look into every language whose tongue he knew, and to extract its rules and follow its principles, thus falling upon the wonders of its wisdom and beauties of its rules, due to the entanglement of sciences with each other, and the gathering of their union in the goal that necessitated their establishment. Only a wise man establishes language. Do you not see that some grammarians arranged the Turkish language according to grammatical rules, and distinguished the noun from the verb, the past from the present from the imperative, the pronoun of the speaker from the addressee from the absent, the plural from the singular, the sign of the plural, and the possessive from the possessed, and so on? This is a matter not hidden. As for his saying: The book Shahnameh is sixty thousand verses, all in the utmost beauty of eloquence and rhetoric, and there is nothing in it to be criticized; this claim is not heard stripped of the proof that supports it. Who can bring sixty thousand words, or six thousand words, that are in the utmost eloquence in wording and rhetoric in meaning such that they cannot be criticized in any way?! This is not in human power in any language. We grant that it is not criticized in that language, but from where do you get that the good poetry of the Persians is in the class of the quality of Arab poetry? As you say: The moon is more luminous than the stars, and the sun is more luminous than the stars. The sun and the moon shared in the virtue over the stars, but in themselves they are not equal, for example. 'And each has his virtue, but the white-footed (horses)... on the day of differentiation are below the blazes (Ghurar).'

Is the good of the Persians like the good of the Arabs? Like the description of Imru' al-Qais regarding horses, Al-Nabigha in apologies, Zuhayr in praises, and Al-A'sha in wine? Or like the good of Jarir, Al-Farazdaq, Al-Akhtal, Bashar ibn Burd, Muslim ibn al-Walid, Abu Nuwas, Dik al-Jinn, Al-Husayn ibn al-Dahhak, Al-Mutanabbi, Abu Tammam, Al-Buhturi, Ibn al-Rumi, Ibn al-Mu'taz, Abu Firas, and others up to this age, and the poets in between whose oceans drown the drops of the Persians, such that he says: All of that is good and not criticized. Are they equal, for example, in quality as such: 'Do you not see that the sword decreases in value... if you say that the sword is sharper than the stick?' The good in poetry is only rare because the eloquent ones and scholars of literature selected the high good which is the summit in eloquence and rhetoric, and made it a model and example to follow, according to what they decided by the power of their thought and correctness of their criticism. So that good was in the highest class. No doubt the fallen (low quality) of poetry is more than the high according to the Imams of rhetoric; otherwise, in reality, what the masters of rhetoric count as fallen poetry is good according to others, not defective, except what is fallen to the extreme. This point is the cause of the scarcity of good poetry. From where is there in the poetry of Persians what is in the poetry of Arabs of Majaz (metaphor), Isti'ara (metaphor), Kinaya (metonymy), Tashbih (simile), Tawriya (double entendre), Istikhdam (usage), and Jinas (paronomasia), with the difference of every type of these types and the branching of its sections? To other types of Badi' (rhetorical embellishments) which approach one hundred types. Far from it! Between them is the form of the superlative (Af'al - i.e., great difference). Al-Husri mentioned in 'Zahr al-Adab' that a Bedouin said to a poet from the Persians: 'Poetry belongs to the Arabs, and whoever among you speaks poetry, then a man of us leaped upon his mother.' End. Ibn Khalaf was fair in his saying: 'The Arabs have a Tent (Bayt - also verse) and a Diwan (Collection/Council), and the Persians have a Palace and an Iwan.' As for his claim that the poet does not do well in the majority (of long works), the excuse for that is apparent. Because he is in two severe straits to the extreme. They are: Meter (Wazn), and the necessity of a single Rhyme (Rawi). The prose writer is not compelled to either of them; rather, he is left to himself. If he wishes, he brings two rhymed phrases on one letter, and if he wishes on more. If he wishes, he brings the rhyme on twenty words, or less down to two words. If the writer brought a long letter on one letter in his rhyme, and a specific number of rhyme words, his condition would be the condition of the poet; rather, his speech would be uglier and heavier on ears and hearts, because poetry is promoted by meter, unlike prose. Therefore, this is not fit to be a virtue of prose over poetry. 'And how, when poetry still has water (luster)... over which the basil of hearts flutters.' Let this be the end of what I wanted to say regarding 'Al-Mathal Al-Sa'ir'. I have forgiven him in much where his slip is apparent. Although I do not deny the excellence he has in it, and the witticisms that are a pupil for the eye of this art. For he did not spare effort in the instruction he gave, nor fall short in the education he provided. He alerted to the notches of this art, and pointed to hunting what strayed from it and what appeared. If a writer or poet happens to review 'Al-Mathal Al-Sa'ir', 'Al-Falak al-Da'ir', and these papers, there is no doubt that this will benefit him with abundant benefits, alert him to sources of error so he avoids them, and awaken him to sites of beauty so he seeks them. 'And I have gifted it to you, and it is to me... over the days, among the purest gifts.' Praise be to Allah first and last, and blessings upon our Master Muhammad and his family and companions, the good and pure, and peace.
